PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Douglas McClelland) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that: Upon evidence from within Australia and overseas, the introduction of Plant Variety Rights legislation would not be in Australia's best interests because:
1. Plant genetic resources should remain a public resource;
2. Australia's public plant breeding programmes could be undermined;
3. Such legislation may lead to a reduction in the genetic diversity of commercial varieties;
4. There is reason to fear that choices of seed and other plant propagation materials may be restricted due to the controls placed on their use;
5. Plant Varietal Rights legislation could lead to higher costs for the grower, the consumer, the plant-breeder and the tax-payer;
6. Plant Variety Rights will lead to a further increase in foreign control of Australia's plant genetic resources;
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that Parliament ensure that it recognises the widespread public opposition to PVR and promote alternative means of royalty collection for plant breeders.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the Australian Bill of Rights is a harmful, dangerous, divisive and unnecessary proposal, the provisions of which are dictatorial, harmful and against the true interest of the people of Australia.
Your petitioners pray: That the Senate reject the Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pornography
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we the undersigned, having great concern because of the spread of moral pollution in our nation call upon the Government to introduce immediate legislation:

1. To provide strict controls over importation, production, sale, hire or mailing of video-cassettes with the open sale of only G, PG, and M rated video-cassettes; and the total prohibition of the sale of R rated video-cassettes so that R rated films can only be viewed in an adult theatre by persons over 18 years. We totally reject the concept of ``X'' rated video-cassettes which would allow the legal sale of hard-core pornographic films for screening in the homes of our nation, which endanger our children.

2. To dramatically improve the Federal Attorney-General's Guidelines for Classification of Video tapes/discs which restrict the importation, production, sale or hire, screening in private homes and mailing by Australia Post so as to include the total prohibition of any pornographic, obscene or blasphemous video cassette, or film containing child pornography, bestiality, sodomy, group sex, violent sex acts with women, such as rape and pack rape, sadism and torture, etc.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will protect our society, especially women and children from moral pollution and its harmful effects.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned members of the Shop Distributive and Allied Employee's Association and Australian citizens respectfully showeth that:

1. The Sex Discrimination Act, passed by Parliament in 1984, will automatically make unenforceable from 1st August, 1986 the weight lifting limits applicable to women employees and contained in State laws, regulations and awards.
2. These weight lifting limits have applied throughout Australia for many years and have acted to prevent many injuries at the workplace, thereby avoiding much suffering and loss of working time.
3. The removal of this protective legislation will increase the rate of injury among women employees and lead to greater Workers' Compensation costs for employers.
4. The weight lifting limits do not in any way hamper the achievement of equality and equal opportunity in employment for women employees in the workforce.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Parliament will amend the Sex Discrimination Act to enable the weight lifting limits for women employees to continue.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia, respectfully showeth:

That the proposed Australian Bill of Rights Bill 1985 will endanger the Federal system in Australia, the State and Federal criminal justice systems, the State and Federal Police Force, the State and Federal education systems, the independence of the churches and religious associations, marriage and the family, children, the unborn, the handicapped, the aged and the infirm, employer and employee relationships and Australian society generally.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:
That your Honourable House defer debate on the Bill for twelve months and circulate the Bill for twelve months for the widest possible debate, scrutiny and discussion.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
Graduated family allowances are of important assistance to families with more than one child.
All family allowances, whether for one, two, three, or more children, have not kept pace with inflation.
There are suggestions that all family allowances should be paid at the one flat rate. This would severely disadvantage families with more than one child.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should reject any suggestion that family allowances be paid at a flat rate and instead should ask the Federal Government to increase the value of existing payments.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Reid (from 258 citizens) and Walsh (from 300 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Pine Gap Defence Space Research Facility
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
1. The Agreement between the United States of America and Australia concerning the Joint Defence Space Research Facility at Pine Gap terminates on 19 October 1986.
2. In the event of war between the United States and the Soviet Union, access by the United States to Pine Gap's facilities makes it a probable nuclear target.
3. Access by all nations to Pine Gap's capacity to monitor and verify compliance with existing and future nuclear limitations treaties could contribute to world peace and security.
4. The people of Australia are entitled to be consulted, through their representatives in Parliament, on any extension or modification of the Agreement affecting their lives, security and welfare.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should decide that-
1. The Agreement between the United States and Australia concerning the Joint Defence Space Research Facility at Pine Gap not be extended beyond October 1986.

2. Public discussion and inquiry be instituted into the feasibility of negotiating a new agreement with the United Nations during the International Year of Peace offering the verification facilities of the Pine Gap base to all nations.
3. Any agreement concerning the future use of Pine Gap be referred to Parliament for ratification.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: South African Students: Scholarships
PETITION.PARA: To the Parliament of Australia.
This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

the abhorrent, racist system of Apartheid prevents non-white children and youth in South Africa and Namibia from equal participation in education (official statistics given in the South African Parliament for 1980-81 showed the annual expenditure on education to be 1,000 rand per capita for whites as against less than 200 rand per capita for blacks);

education inside South Africa and Namibia is so imbued with the ideology of apartheid that non-white students have rebelled against the `Bantu' Education system, leading to many students being imprisoned, beaten and harassed by police; many children and youths have fled apartheid South Africa and Namibia to refugee camps run by the African National Congress of South Africa (ANC) and the South West African People's Organisation (SWAPO) of Namibia. In these refugee camps international aid provides primary and secondary education, but tertiary education in such circumstances is impractical;
the Australian Parliament has a bipartisan policy of opposition to Apartheid;
the provision of scholarships for tertiary study in Australia for students from these refugee camps is one of the most positive steps Australia can take towards a non-racist future for South Africa;
community contributions to the Jim Gale Memorial African Scholarship Fund have reached over $13,000 in eight months, demonstrating the strong concern among Australians about this issue.
Your petitioners therefore pray and urge the Parliament of Australia to
provide one hundred scholarships annually for South African students to be selected from ANC refugee camps, to enable them to undertake tertiary studies in Australia
provide one hundred scholarships annually for Namibian students to be selected from SWAPO refugee camps, to enable them to undertake tertiary studies in Australia
join with the Jim Gale Memorial African Scholarship Fund to provide at least one scholarship each year in memory of Jim Gale
waive any visa charges which might otherwise attach to these students as overseas students.
Your humble petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Postal Charges
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

We, the undersigned, are concerned that the proposed increases in postal charges will impose a crippling burden on private individuals (particularly pensioners and unemployed), on small businesses, and on voluntary and/or charitable organisations which are compelled to circulate newspapers, bulletins and also appeals for financial support.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, will call upon the Government to use its good offices to prevent any postal increase in the coming financial year and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Skrijel Family
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament.
The petition of the undersigned shows:

Your petitioners as in duty bound will humbly pray, that a public inquiry be conducted in my allegations of prosecutions, harassment, and destruction of my property because of my refusal to become part of a heroin ring. And that the rights of Mehmed Skrijel and family be recognised in Victoria and South Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Pornography
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate of the Parliament of Australia assembled.

We, the undersigned, plead that Parliament will re-voke the blasphemy, indecency, and obscenity proscription into the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations, by adding those proscriptions to the present Section 4a, sub-regulations 1a (b) (i), for the following reasons:
because these is a flood of obscene publications into the country,
because such publications depict the abnormal as normal
because such publications degrade men and women
because such publications create new, offensive demands on women, with which they do not willingly comply (Eyeenck and Nias)
because this causes marriage breakdown
because children easily obtain such publications
because children copy what they see

because the child found in possession of such publications is at risk, facing rejection, and carrying the burden of having altered the relationships in his home for the worse, between parents, and between parent and child
because such a child faces, alone, the loss of trust
because I am a reasonable adult person and I am offended by the obscene books which you have legislated into this community.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will give this matter your earnest attention.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Smoking and Tobacco Products Advertisements Prohibition Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully shows:

That we strongly support ``The A.C.T. Smoking and Tobacco Products Advertisements Prohibition Bill'' introduced by Senator Evans, because it represents the first positive national step towards the eventual elimination of wide-spread serious ill health caused by smoking tobacco.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Embryo Experimentation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows:
That human embryos deserve legal protection to enable the development of their full human potential.
Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:
Pass Senator Harradine's Bill to prohibit experiments involving the use of human embryos created by in vitro fertilization.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to establish an authority to undertake reinsurance business, and for purposes connected therewith.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FINANCE AND GOVERNMENT OPERATIONS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That, if the Senate be not sitting when the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations has completed any of its Reports, the Committee may send the Reports to the President, or, if the President is unable to act, to the Deputy-President, and, in that event-
(a) the Reports shall be deemed to have been presented to the Senate.
(b) the publication of the Reports is authorised by this Resolution;
(c) the President or the Deputy-President, as the case may be, may give directions for the printing and circulation of the Reports; and
(d) the President or the Deputy-President, as the case may be, shall lay the Reports upon the table at the next sitting of the Senate.
(2) That the foregoing provisions of this Resolution, insofar as they are inconsistent with the Standing Orders, have effect notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing Orders.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON INDUSTRY AND TRADE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following matter be referred to the Standing Committee on Industry and Trade: Certain aspects of Australia's Manufacturing Industry Revitalisation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris Sen J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) notes with regret the decision of the Premier of New South Wales, Mr Neville Wran QC, M.P., to resign from that office;
(b) records its admiration for Mr Wran as the greatest Premier in our nation's history; and-
Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, it is all right for the people on the other side to interject--
—Order! Will the honourable senator give his notice of motion.
—Thank you very much, Mr President. My notice continues:

SPEECH.PARA: (c) congratulates Mr Wran for the respect he has earned nationally for his many achievements for the people of NSW, particularly:

(i) the reform of the NSW electoral system by providing for the democratic election of the Legislative Council by the people of the State, the elimination of unequal quotas for Lower House seats and the introduction of the 4-year term;
(ii) the attack made on the political corruption of the Askin era by the introduction of public funding for election campaigns;
(iii) the development of tighter and more efficient financial controls for the Public Service which gave NSW citizens more value for their tax dollar,
(iv) the establishment of NSW as the pioneer State in developing strong and sensitive policies on the environment, our heritage, Aboriginal land rights and the arts,
(v) the strenuous and successful efforts to establish new industries and provide jobs,
(vi) setting a model for consultation by encouraging tripartite negotiations on all issues involving government, trade unions and employers,
(vii) boosting the State and national economy by undertaking the largest capital works program of any government in our nation's history; and
(viii) transforming the NSW public transport system from the worst in Australia to the best.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to standing order 448, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the Senate proceeding with the Notice of Motion given by Senator Morris forthwith.
Senator Morris has invited the Senate to debate a motion expressing the Senate's disappointment and regret at the retirement--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I said quite clearly in my notice of motion `on the next day of sitting'. I suggest that Senator Puplick should be ruled out of order.
—Order! There is no point of order. Senator Puplick has moved for the suspension of Standing Orders.

—The Senate is invited by Senator Morris's notice of motion to express some degree of regret or disappointment at the retirement of Neville Wran from the position of Premier of New South Wales. If anything, the Senate should have before it a motion noting the retirement of the Premier of New South Wales as being the best thing that could possibly happen for the restoration of decency and democracy in that State.

—On a point of order, Mr President: Senator Puplick knows as well as anyone else that under the Standing Orders he should confine his remarks to why we should suspend Standing Orders, and not debate the substantive issue. I suggest that you ask him to do so.
—I suggest that Senator Puplick confine his remarks to the reasons why Standing Orders should be suspended.

—Mr President, it is important to suspend Standing Orders because the issue Senator Morris has raised-the issue of decency, probity and honesty in public life-is a matter which ought to be brought before the Senate for debate at the earliest possible opportunity. In terms of probity, decency and honesty in public life, nobody has traduced those virtues and those values more thoroughly than the Premier of New South Wales. It ought to be, therefore, in the competence of the Senate to debate that matter.

—Mr President, on a point of order: I draw your attention to another standing order which prevents people such as Senator Puplick from making remarks of that type about the Premier of a State. I remind you that Mr Wran has not yet resigned. He resigns on 4 July.
—I have listened to Senator Puplick's remarks. As yet he has not offended that standing order, but I draw his attention to it and remind him of the remarks of Senator Grimes.
—There is also a substantive motion before the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Senate will come to order. We are not in a bear pit; I ask honourable senators to remember that this is the Senate of Australia.
—The reason for the suspension of Standing Orders--
—Tell us about your duty free shops.
—I can appreciate Senator Morris's enormous discomfiture if he thinks that--
—Order! I ask Senator Puplick--
—Mr President, I raise a point of order.
—Senator Morris, will you please resume your seat?
—Mr President, I am raising a point of order.

—I ask Senator Morris to resume his seat. I remind Senator Puplick that he is speaking to his motion for the suspension of Standing Orders and I ask him to confine his remarks to that matter. Senator Morris, do you wish to take a point of order?
—Mr President, you have now fixed the situation.

—As I was saying, the suspension of Standing Orders will allow the Senate to debate a matter of considerable importance. It is important to the people of New South Wales that the truth be put on the record because the truth can be put on the record in this place whereas it cannot be put on the record in the Parliament of New South Wales where the jack-boot activities of certain politicians in the Australian Labor Party Government in that State have consistently prevented the truth about the corruption of the Wran Government from being put on the public record. If we suspend Standing Orders--
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Senator Puplick is now debating the issue.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—As I was saying, important matters arise from the motion which Senator Morris has put forward. It is only by suspending Standing Orders in order to bring on the debate in the chamber forthwith that we allow honourable senators to debate the very substantive issues which are raised in the motion. There is nothing more important than integrity and honesty in public life and nothing which will more allow the Senate to debate and expose the corruption both of members of the Australian Labor Party and their Government in New South Wales and which will allow the complete exposure of the corruption not only of the democratic and parliamentary system in New South Wales but also of the police force in New South Wales aided, abetted and encouraged by the Labor Government in that State-the attacks upon the judiciary and the magistracy in New South Wales--
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Should not the question be put without debate?
—Order! There is no point of order.

—Fortunately the Rafferty's rules of the liquor and allied trades union do not apply in this place at the moment. We will have the opportunity, on the basis of this substantive motion, to deal with a whole series of issues which ought to be brought before the Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia. We have been presented with Senator Morris's motion, which I take in good faith was an attempt to bring before the Senate the opportunity of discussing the State of New South Wales and the record of the Premier of New South Wales. I am inviting Senator Morris, if he is a great believer in discussing these virtues, to rise in this place today and debate them. We on this side of the chamber are perfectly prepared to debate them and want to give Senator Morris the opportunity right here and now to bring on his motion for debate. I have no doubt that he has his speech ready, that he has his eulogy ready, and that he has his next preselection speech; and I want him to be able to give his speech.
—Order! I ask Senator Puplick to confine his remarks to the motion for the suspension of Standing Orders. Otherwise I will ask him to resume his seat.

—It is only by the suspension of Standing Orders that this motion can be brought forward. Because of the very significant issues which are raised in the motion, I believe that Standing Orders ought to be suspended. It is only by the use of this device that the significant issues which are encompassed in Senator Morris's proposed notice of motion can be debated in the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said and as you, Mr President, and honourable senators would be aware, there is a great deal to be said about New South Wales, about the Premier of New South Wales and about his 10-year record. It is only by the suspension of Standing Orders that we can have the advantage of bringing that debate before the Senate today. That debate will be a useful debate. It will allow us to discuss a number of issues, and only by the suspension of Standing Orders can we really discuss the attacks upon the integrity of a man like Clarrie Briese. It is only by the suspension of Standing Orders that we can discuss issues such as the promotion of Bill Allen. It is only by the suspension of Standing Orders that we can raise the whole issue of the way in which the Premier of New South Wales has treated the Parliament of New South Wales-the sort of legislation that has been passed, the sort of taking away of the rights of individual citizens and the seizure of private property in New South Wales.

It is only by the suspension of Standing Orders that one can get to the issue of ministerial propriety, whether it happens to be in relation to former Ministers for Corrective Services or any number of royal commissions which have occurred in New South Wales. It is only by the suspension of Standing Orders that we can get to the way in which the whole Botany Municipal Council has had its pervasive influence on New South Wales. It is only by the suspension of Standing Orders that one can look at the rort of the electoral system in New South Wales, which was raised in Senator Morris's notice of motion. It is only by the suspension of Standing Orders that we can have before the chamber for debate the whole question of whether the administration of New South Wales has been honest and efficient. It is only by the suspension of Standing Orders that we can look at the destruction of the New South Wales economy over the course of the last 10 years and the sell-out to various industrial interests in that State. It is only by the suspension of Standing Orders that we can deal with the way in which the State Government has ridden roughshod over the rights of the citizens of Sydney in terms of development, the monorail and all of those other things the citizens happen to be interested in.

It is only by the suspension of Standing Orders that we will be able to get before the Parliament the way in which the Premier's resignation has been brought forward at this particular stage for the purposes of guaranteeing certain people a succession in the leadership of the Labor Party, and to expose the way in which the whole manipulation of the Labor Party machine in New South Wales is now being seen for the first time. It is only by the suspension of Standing Orders that we can talk about the Enmore case, about Tom Domican, about the relationships of these people with the Premier of New South Wales--

TALK.START.PARA: —The Baldwin bashing.

—And we can talk about the Baldwin affair. It is only by the suspension of Standing Orders in order to debate the substantive motion which Senator Morris wants to put forward that we can deal with the whole 10 years of corruption, crime, mismanagement of the economy, the rorting of the Parliament and the perversion of the electoral system which has gone on throughout the whole of New South Wales. It is only by the suspension of Standing Orders that we can allow Senator Morris to come forward to try to justify the unjustifiable-the record of the Wran Government over the course of the last 10 years, which has brought an absolute public scandal upon New South Wales in terms of the way in which the Labor Party, the Government and the whole of the administration of the State has been brought into disrepute, the judiciary traduced, the magistracy threatened, the police force corrupted, the economy ruined, the unions put on top of the citizens of New South Wales, planning and environment decisions cast to nought, brown paper bags being passed backwards and forwards to ensure development applications and the Botany Council scandal. It is only by the suspension of Standing Orders that all of these things, which are of enormous significance to the citizens of New South Wales, can be brought forward and debated in this place today.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Colston

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. Standing order 448 reads:

INTERJECT.PARA: In cases of urgent necessity, any Standing or Sessional Order or Orders of the Senate may be suspended on Motion without Notice.
Mr President, I put to you that what should be being debated is whether there is an urgent necessity rather than debating the substantive issue at this stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is no debate on the substantive issue. I have pointed out to Senator Puplick that he has to confine his remarks to reasons why the Standing Orders should be suspended. That is the purport of his remarks to date, and there is no point of order.

—It is only by the suspension of Standing Orders that the Parliament will have the opportunity to discuss such matters as the administration of the State of New South Wales. It is only by the suspension of Standing Orders that we will be able to look at Morgan Ryan, at Murray Farquhar, at Rex Jackson, at Bill Allen, at Donald Mackay, at the Age tapes, at the Trimbole question, at the whole Kevin Humphreys question. It is only by the suspension of Standing Orders that we will be able to find out why it is that when the son of a murdered man goes to the Premier of New South Wales to ask for an investigation into the murder of his father, the Premier of New South Wales abuses him, calls him a thick-headed South African and transduces the memory of his father because the Premier is not prepared to have that sort of investigation. It is only by the suspension of Standing Orders that we will be able to look at exactly who is whose little mate in the State of New South Wales. Given the level of corruption in New South Wales at the moment, I believe that we ought to suspend Standing Orders and deal with this matter forthwith.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate will be surprised to know that the Government opposes the motion. Senator Puplick obviously thinks, by the schoolboy look on his face, that he has done something new in this place. He has done something which has been done so often before. He has demonstrated his thespian skills and his capacity as a schoolboy debater. But, as he often does, he has overdone it a little. In normal times I, of all people in this place, would enjoy such a debate because not only would we discuss the matters raised by Senator Puplick, but also we would discuss the matters raised in a little book called The Prince and the Premier. We would discuss the associations of members of this Senate now with that Premier, and would discuss the stories of what happened then. I do not think that this is the time to do that, but I would be happy to do it at some time.

SPEECH.PARA: I am also interested in Senator Puplick's concern that of all the notices of motion that have been brought up in this place-the many notices of motion by Senator Michael Baume about the state of economy, about the state of the world-Senator Puplick has never thought it necessary to bring on those motions. It is only at this time that he has put on this little turn. We have all been impressed, but we are not impressed enough to vote with him on the suspension of Standing Orders.

TALK.START.PARA: —Too scared.
—The day I am too scared to debate with you, ma'am, is the day I will give it away. For that reason we will not be supporting the motion to suspend Standing Orders.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The motion moved by Senator Puplick will have the Opposition's support and I shall explain why. I might have hoped that Neville Wran would be politically interred without reference being made to him in this place, because any reference to Neville Wran would be certain to require from this side expressions which are totally contrary to those which have been put forward by Senator Morris. The reason that there is some urgency in disposing of this matter from the Notice Paper, where it has just been put by Senator Morris, is that if one looks at the first three paragraphs of the motion, one finds three things that would be utterly repugnant to senators on this side of the House, and I believe to Senator Chipp. We find that the Senate:

SPEECH.PARA: Notes with regret the decision of the Premier of New South Wales, Mr Neville Wran, to resign from that office.
I can only say, as I said publicly, that that was one of the best bits of news for Australia I have heard for some time. Paragraph (b) of the motion reads:
records its admiration for Mr Wran as the greatest Premier in our nation's history-

I will say a little bit more about that in a moment. Worst of all, the motion congratulates Neville Wran for the respect he has earned nationally. I cannot think of anything which is further from the truth and which this Senate would less want to see on its Notice Paper as a possible expression of the opinion of the Senate. My reason for saying that and why I think there is some urgency in this matter is that the departure of Neville Wran has, as usual, led to the sorts of expressions which Senator Withers is so fond of describing--

TALK.START.PARA: —Vote early and vote often.

—No, that is not it. He has forgotten his own expression. The sort of unctuous remarks about Mr Wran which are repeated in this motion are far from the truth. For example, it is said of him that he showed grace under pressure, when in fact we all have recollections of the Premier of New South Wales and his response to anyone who opposed him, which was to use the expression `apply the blowtorch to the belly'.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition is now tending to debate the substantive motion. I ask him to return to the reason for the suspension of the Standing Orders.

—Of course I must address the question of the suspension of Standing Orders. The point is that unless we suspend Standing Orders this ridiculous expression of opinion which has been put forward by Senator Morris will presumably sit here on the Notice Paper for months as a possible expression of opinion of this Senate. I want to make it clear that on this side of the House we would regard those expressions of opinion as totally contrary to the truth. Neville Wran's treatment of people such as Temby and Briese is a simple illustration of why we have such contempt for the Premier. I believe that we should put this motion and dispose of it very quickly. By disposing of Senator Morris's motion we should express our absolute disregard for the Premier of New South Wales and for the dreadful way in which he has debased politics in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I oppose the suspension of Standing Orders for two reasons. The first is that there will be an opportunity to debate the substantive motion at some later time, and I think that this question, as it relies on standing order 448, does not have the necessary quality or urgency. It can be dealt with at a later stage without denying to any honourable senator the opportunity of having a say on this matter. Also, this matter is not in the nature of a piece of legislation which must be debated today. It is not as if we will not be able to have another bite at it some other time. My second reason for opposing the suspension of Standing Orders is that I believe that we in this Senate, this States House, owe to the people of New South Wales a chance to look forward rather than backward. We owe them the chance to look forward to a firm, fresh and fearless administration under the leadership of a new Premier, Barrie Unsworth.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Puplick's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-

(a) notes the Prime Minister's (Mr Hawke's) warning in his Address to the Nation on 11 June 1986 that Australia's economic crisis means we have to accept reduced standards of living and increased standards of effort, that the Federal Government will make the decisions necessary to meet this challenge and that it will not shirk from these hard decisions;

(b) requests Mr Hawke to stop just talking and actually do something to fix up the serious problems that his misdirected economic policies, particularly his big government spending, record high interest rates and the worst relative inflation rate for 25 years, have got us into;

TALK.START.PARA: —I have postponed Notice of Motion No. 1 because the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances is awaiting a reply from the Minister for Territories (Mr Scholes) concerning the Motor Traffic Ordinance on the question of whether its provisions take away rights retrospectively. I will withdraw Notice of Motion No. 2 tomorrow. The Committee this morning considered a letter from the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) which assured it that the determination concerning Defence Force uniform allowances did not discriminate against any member on the grounds of sex. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the letters for the information of honourable senators.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The letters read as follows-
16 April 1986
The Hon. Kim Beazley, M.P.
Minister for Defence
Parliament House
CANBERRA A.C.T. 2600
Dear Minister,

At its meeting on 10 April 1986, the Committee considered Defence Determination no. 14 of 1986, being Determination 0602, Outfit Allowance, tabled in the Senate on 9 April 1986. The Committee also considered the letter of 19 march 1986 signed on your behalf by The Hon. John Brown, the Minister Assisting, concerning the need for retrospectivity in this Determination.

The accompanying Explanatory Statement indicated that the Determination provides for the payment of allowances to male and female officers and sailors of the Permanent Naval Forces ``for the initial purchase of a uniform, the purchase of additional uniform items or to have necessary alterations made to the uniform''.

The Committee accepted as reasonable explanations given by the Minister Assisting regarding the need for certain paragraphs of the Determination to be made retrospective to 15 July 1985. However, the Committee has a further concern about the differing rates of outfit allowance that are paid under the Determination to officers of equal rank and position depending on whether the officers are males or females.

Obviously the uniforms of male and female officers, while presumably being of equal quality and propriety, will nevertheless differ in aspects which can affect their price. Where the supply of complete uniforms and additions, etc., is the responsibility of the employer these discrepancies in respective costs of items may not give rise even to the appearance of disparate treatment on the grounds of gender. On the other hand the payment of differing levels of allowance for the private purchase of necessary items, may in practice result in discriminatory treatment. Certain male or female officers of a particular rank or position may thus enjoy a monetary advantage over their fellow officers of a different gender as a consequence of that gender difference.

The Committee recognises that you have no intention whatsoever to treat officers in an unfairly discriminatory way in this matter. Indeed the Committee noted that in the letter from the Minister Assisting, he explained that the quantum of outfit allowance is reviewed annually based on an annually revised Naval Clothing Price List. The Committee noted the Minister's comment that the task of assessing the relevant clothing price changes is a particularly detailed one involving consideration of price movements and changes in scales of entitlement.

Nevertheless, the fact remains that, assuming equal quality and propriety in the uniforms worn by Naval Officers of both sexes, the payment of different monetary allowances for individuals who are otherwise treated equally, may be a matter of concern to the Committee under its Principles. There appear to be some quite significant differences in the levels of allowances to be paid to male and female officers who appear to be of equal rank and position.
It may be that, notwithstanding similar rank, male and female officers perform widely different duties which tend to necessitate the acquisition of more expensive uniforms by male officers.
The Committee would be grateful to have your comments and advice on all of these questions.
Yours sincerely,
BARNEY COONEY
Chairman
Senator Barney Cooney
Chairman
Senate Standing Committee
on Regulations and Ordinances
CANBERRA, A.C.T. 2600
Dear Senator Cooney

I refer to your letter of April 1986 regarding Defence Determination No. 14 of 1986 in which you expressed concern about the differing rates of Outfit Allowance that are paid to RAN officers of equal rank and position depending on whether the officers are males or females.

In general, the differences in the amounts of the allowance paid to male and female officers of the RAN reflect the obvious gender difference which is the main reason for uniforms of different value being required, but also reflect to some extent the different range of duties imposed upon members of each group. No monetary advantage ensues because the amount paid is fully expended on the range of uniform items or alterations considered necessary for each group to maintain a uniform of the required scale.

The scales of uniform for the various categories and ranks of the RAN are compiled in the knowledge of the requirements of the duties to be carried out by the member, with due consideration having been given to rank, gender and branch category. Amounts of the allowance are then based on the appropriate scale of uniform and the cost of individual items.

The difference in the amounts of allowance paid to members on entry, which favours female members, takes into account those members being provided with such items as a handbag and gloves, which are not provided to male members, and the more expensive female foot-wear. The difference in the amounts of allowance on promotion, which favours the male members, takes into account the cost of upgrading gold lace rank insignia on a mess jacket, which is not worn by female members. The larger difference on promotion to Commander is due to the provision of two new caps with gold oak leaves on the peak to male officers; the female Commander has no requirement to change hats. Moreover, all female officers, other than University Undergraduates and female other ranks on promotion, are issued gratuitously with all or most items of uniform on appointment and promotion, and this explains some of the more significant differences in Schedule 2 of the determination.
I trust that these comments on the questions of apparent discrimination which you raised will prove helpful.
Yours sincerely
Kim G. Beazley
