TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The purpose of this statement is to provide, through the Parliament, the opportunity for those involved in the community and in the Parliament to look at the Government's intention with regard to new disability legislation between now and the Budget session. With that in mind, I seek leave to incorporate the statement in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

The purpose of this statement is to inform the Senate of the Government's plans for introducing new Disability Services legislation which will replace the present Handicapped Persons Assistance Act 1974, and contain legislative provision for the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Program and the Program of Aids for Disabled People.

Among the first initiatives of this Government were decisions to fund the Australian chapter of Disabled Peoples' International and to establish the Disability Advisory Council of Australia to provide direct advice to the Government from people with disabilities themselves.

These two initiatives in 1983 resulted in increased exposure and discussion of the issue facing people with disabilities. It became clear that there was a need for fundamental change in the way the community provides for the needs of people with disabilities and that a truly comprehensive review of all Commonwealth policies and programs was required.

Accordingly, in late 1983 we set up the Handicapped Programs Review to examine all Commonwealth programs and services directed at assisting people with disabilities. This Review was the first of its kind in Australia, being based both on submissions and on extensive community consultation, especially with people with disabilities. During the course of the Review over 65 towns and cities across Australia were visited and more than 5,000 people were involved in meetings, seminars and personal interviews.

Pending publication of the Review Report, the Prime Minister announced in December 1984 the establishment of the Office of Disability whose responsibilities include providing advice to the Government on the quality and effectiveness of services at a national level. One of its roles is to carry forward initiatives contained in the report of the Handicapped Programs Review entitled ``New Directions'' which I tabled on 30 May 1985.

The Report found broad community support for the Commonwealth's policies of meeting needs through mainstream community programs as far as possible, and of ensuring that the least restrictive alternative principle is followed where specific services are required for people with disabilities. It concluded that substantial improvements were required in the accountability of subsidised organisations for service content and quality, and that major changes were needed in the programs themselves. A restructuring of services, funding and other resources was also required.

The Review believed that these changes could be effected only through new legislation to replace the Handicapped Persons Assistance Act, based on the principle that positive consumer outcomes should be the rationale for program development, delivery and review.

The Government at the time endorsed the thrust of the report and I foreshadowed new legislation under the Community Services portfolio to provide for the range of Commonwealth support programs for people with disabilities to replace the Handicapped Persons Assistance Act. The Government will be introducing such new legislation in the Budget Session.

One of the major thrusts of the new legislation will be to establish a clear linkage between a commitment and action by organisations in achieving desirable outcomes for individual people with disabilities and organisations' receipt of financial assistance from the Commonwealth.

For some time, and within the constraints of the present legislation, my Department has been working closely with organisations conducting subsidised services to encourage them to provide programs on the ``least restrictive alternative'' model and more recently to adopt the principles underlying the New Directions report.

The substantive work of re-shaping existing methods of service delivery is, however, still largely ahead of us and, with this in mind, the Government has adopted a two-fold strategy to achieve a complete re-structuring of services for people with disabilities subsidised under current legislation.

The first component in our strategy is a program of demonstration projects to illustrate to service providers and to people with disabilities who are the consumers of those services, the types of services and the principles and operating practices underlying them which the Government wishes to promote in the context of ``New Directions''.

This demonstration program commenced this year and will run for two years, costing some $20 million in total. Examples in two key areas will make it clear how different, even radical, some of these new types of services may be when seen against the traditional service pattern.

In the area of vocational services, where the principal choice for disabled people in the past has generally been limited to sheltered employment, services to be developed include long-term supported employment models such as:
work enclaves in open industry where small groups of disabled workers are given special training, supervision, and adjusted work targets;
work crews where a group of disabled people are an integral part of an independent commercial business; and
individual work-stations where a disabled person works alongside non-disabled workers, but support is provided through extra training and supervision on site.

There will also be competitive employment and placement programs which will train disabled people in work skills and work-related behaviours and locate individual jobs for the program graduates in open employment. Examples of this might be where a cafeteria teaches food service tasks and finds people jobs in regular restaurants. In these instances, any subsidy provided would be for the training and personal support components only, not towards the commercial activity as such.

From these examples, it is clear how we are opening up vocational opportunities which will greatly enhance the dignity and better match the aspirations of people with disabilities, compared with the limiting, isolating, and often stigmatising options traditionally available.

The other key area where I would like to give examples of new types of services is that of supported residential accommodation for people with disabilities. We are all familiar to varying degrees with the traditional residential institutions where dozens, but at times even hundreds, of people with disabilities are accommodated in the one large complex.
More community integrated models of residential support have already begun to be introduced, but the demonstration program will broaden the range of options available by including approaches such as:
co-tenancy arrangements where a non-disabled person offers support to a disabled flat-mate in return for concessional costs of living;

tenant support programs where disabled people occupying a number of flats in a single development are given support from staff living staff living in a separate flat both at set time periods (such as meal preparation) and on-call if necessary;
group homes in ordinary community settings with live-in or on-call staffing appropriate to the needs of a small group of multiply-disabled adults;

model or demonstration de-institutionalising projects which support an existing organisation in the transition from a large institutional facility to a more appropriate range of housing options in the community for its existing residents; and
respite programs.

All told, under the demonstration program, we have so far funded 68 projects, comprising-14 long-term supported employment projects; 13 competitive employment projects; 14 projects exploring options in residential living; and 27 projects providing advocacy and information services and individual personal development planning for people with disabilities. I regard these as significant achievements.

The second component of the Government's strategy for restructuring of the system is the introduction of the new legislation. Our original intention was to introduce the new legislation in this present Autumn session but this will not now be achievable because of pressures on Parliamentary Counsel. As I said earlier, the Bill will be introduced in the Budget session 1986.

However, I am able to indicate now the scope of the new Bill. It will draw together existing programs for people with disabilities within the Community Services portfolio and provide a new coherent framework for these programs to facilitate the pursuit of the Government's objectives for people with disabilities.
The new Bill will contain an explicit statement of its goals and objectives. These may be summarised as:

to achieve for people with disabilities positive outcomes such as long-term increases in independence, participation in paid employment, integration into the community, and the promotion of a positive image;
to provide financial assistance to eligible organisations conducting approved services directed at achieving such outcomes in an integrated fashion;
to enable service performance in achieving the desired outcomes to be taken into account in making funding decisions; and
to encourage innovation in service development and delivery.

There will also be specific objectives relating to the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Program and the Program of Aids for Disabled People both of which will be incorporated into the Bill. I will refer to these programs again later.

First and foremost, the Bill will provide for the funding of a range of services many of which are outside the provisions of the Handicapped Persons Assistance Act, which will be repealed. Some of these categories will be:
Accommodation Support;
Selected Respite Services;
Supported Employment;
Competitive Employment Training and Placement;
Independent Living Training;
Advocacy and Information;
Recreation;
Individual Assessment and Program Planning; and
Services for Persons with a Print Disability.

The Government recognises that non-government bodies play an essential role in providing services for people with disabilities and will retain the concept of assisting eligible organisations as service providers.
The Bill will include a clear definition of the eligible target group to be assisted by organisations receiving financial support. The proposal is that the target group be comprised of people who:
have an intellectual impairment or a sensory or physical impairment, being a sensory or physical impairment which has become manifest before the person has reached the age of 50 years;
are likely to have that impairment indefinitely; and
as a result of that impairment have a long term incapacity for independent living and have a substantive functional limitation in relation to communication, learning or mobility.
There will be a discretion to include in the target group categories not specifically mentioned in the Bill, if this promotes the purposes of the legislation.

The range of services provided by the Commonwealth and the States in the disability area varies from State to State and the situation is complex. I intend that the new Bill will provide a mechanism whereby inter-governmental and agency co-operation can be enhanced. Local government will continue to qualify for the funding of approved services under the new legislation. The new legislation will also encourage partnership arrangements with State Governments.

One of the biggest problems with the current Act is that there is no recognition of the different funding requirements of different service types. There needs to be flexibility to recognise the widely differing needs of people assisted under the program and the differing needs of individual service types. Rather than a set funding formula, I propose that the Bill provide for funding formulae to be set out in regulations. These funding formulae will change the ad hoc arrangements which exist at present and will reflect the desired outcomes anticipated for individuals.

To assist in developing detailed funding formulae, my Department is sponsoring a consultancy to identify the actual costs of conducting the various types of services, and to make recommendations on the formulae to be adopted. This task will obviously require a great deal of careful analysis and take some time to complete.
When developed and approved by Parliament, these funding formulae will be applied to services which meet the objectives of the new legislation.
In the meantime, in order to provide for funding continuity, transitional funding arrangements will apply to currently funded organisations.

As I mentioned earlier, the new Bill will also provide a new legislative basis for rehabilitation services administered within the community services portfolio thus removing them from Part VIII of the Social Security Act. This will involve transfer of the enabling provisions from that Act to the new Disability Services Act, with some minor modifications. This will facilitate a common philosophical base for the Government's assistance to people with disabilities.

The Department's rehabilitation program is currently over half way through a Three Year Forward Plan which emphasises the development of community based services in preference to those provided in institutional settings, and concentrates on social and vocational rehabilitation for working aged people and on improving access to rehabilitation programs by women, Aboriginals and people with non-English speaking backgrounds.

It is proposed that our rehabilitation services, providing as they do, a direct service to people with disabilities, should work closely with those areas of my portfolio which fund organisations providing services to disabled people. This will ensure the provision of a co-ordinated range of services.

The Bill will also provide for the Commonwealth's Program of Aids for Disabled People, currently based in various provisions of the national Health Act. At this point the Government is proposing no major changes to this program but the opportunity will be taken to improve its operation through minor legislative modifications.

At this stage, I anticipate that the new legislation will become operative as from 1 April 1987. For operational reasons The Handicapped Persons Assistance Act and those sections of the Social Security Act relating to the provision of the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Program will not be repealed until 30 June 1987. In addition discussions are taking place with the Department of Health regarding the authority for the operation of the PADP scheme. Regulations will then be introduced under the new Act to provide initially for interim funding for organisations who commit themselves by way of formal contracts to the objectives of the new program. This interim funding will be similar to that currently provided under the Handicapped Persons Assistance Act.

Departmental officers will be contacting each organisation through to April 1987 to discuss the objectives of the new legislation as this relates to the specific service types, and to invite organisations to enter into contracts which will be consistent with the new legislation.

There may be a small number of existing services which will not qualify for funding at all under the new legislation. I envisage that carry-on funding at existing levels will be available for these services until such time as other arrangements can be made for them.
A requirement under the new legislation will be that a review of all services, to assess their achievement of the objectives embodied in the legislation, be undertaken at least every five years.

The Department of Community Services will be conducting a series of short intensive workshops to explain in more detail the operational significance of the new legislation and its underlying aims and objectives. The present intention is for these to commence towards the end of 1986.

At the same time as the introduction of the new Disability Services Bill the Government will launch a Statement of Principles and Objectives in relation to people with disabilities to be followed in the administration of the legislation and specifically to be applied to individual services. We will also work towards the implementation of the Principles and Objectives by all those involved in service delivery to people with disabilities. A draft of the Statement of Principles and Objectives is attached.

The Principles recognise that people with disabilities are individuals who have an inherent right to respect for their human worth and dignity, and, irrespective of the origin, nature, type and degree of disability have the same fundamental rights as do other members of society. This applies to the realisation of individual potential; to involvement in decision-making in matters affecting their lives; to the pursuit of grievances and rights; and to services which offer the least restrictive alternative in the achievement of these ends.

The Objectives relate more directly to service delivery and cover aspects such as a focus on consumer benefits, integration of services into the regular service structure where possible, and a community-based focus for specialist services where these are required.

Adoption of the Principles and Objectives will have some very practical consequences for service delivery. They will demand new standards of accountability by service providers to their disabled clients. They will require a new emphasis on the rights of privacy and confidentiality. They will herald a drawing to a close of an era in which regrettably it has been possible for single organisations, in some cases without any accountability, to control the entire life of a person with a disability.

The Handicapped Programs Review contained a large number of recommendations. As a means of pursuing both those covered by the new legislation and other matters, I am writing to my Commonwealth ministerial colleagues seeking their assistance in those areas which are pertinent to their respective portfolio responsibilities. For similar purposes I have also written to State Ministers, especially to open up the wider issues of co-ordination between State and Commonwealth initiatives which will promote a better future for people with disabilities.

The Handicapped Programs Review has demonstrated the crucial importance of consultation with the community about the needs and aspirations of people with disabilities, but most of all with disabled people themselves. Such consultation will continue to be a cornerstone of the Government's policy in this area.

I have outlined in this Statement the intention of the Government in the area of disability services. However, before I introduce the necessary Bill into Parliament, I and my departmental officers will be seeking discussions with relevant groups on the proposals I have outlined. I also expect those discussions to assist in the development of specific guidelines which will apply to the varying service types. I hope to be in a position to table those guidelines when I introduce the new legislation in the Budget Session.
ATTACHMENT
DRAFT STATEMENT OF PRINCIPLES AND OBJECTIVES
Principles
1. People with disabilities are individuals who have the inherent right to respect for their human worth and dignity.
2. People with disabilities, whatever the origin, nature, type and degree of disability, have the same fundamental rights as all members of Australian society.
3. Every person with a disability has the same rights as other members of Australian society to realise their individual capacity for physical, social, emotional and intellectual development.
4. People with disabilities have the same right as other members of Australian society to services which will support their attaining an acceptable quality of life.
5. People with disabilities have the same right as other members of Australian society to participate in the decisions which affect their lives.
6. People with disabilities have the same right as other members of Australian society to the least restrictive alternative in the services they receive.
7. People with disabilities have the same right of grievance as other members of Australian society in relation to the services which they receive.

In response to these principles, the Commonwealth Government will adopt the following objectives in its provision of services to people with disabilities and promote their adoption by non-government organisations, Local Government and State Governments providing assistance to people with disabilities. (A service is defined as direct assistance predominantly of a non-monetary nature provided through the Government or voluntary organisations. A program is any specific assistance of a direct service or of a monetary nature funded by the Government.)
Objectives
1. That the focus of service delivery to people with disabilities should be the achievement of positive outcomes.

2. That services for people with disabilities should ensure that the conditions of the every-day life of people with disabilities are the same as, or as close as possible to, norms and patterns which are valued in the general community.
3. That services for people with disabilities should be provided as part of local co-ordinated service systems and integrated with generic services wherever possible.
4. That people with disabilities should receive services which are tailored to their individual needs and goals.
5. That programs and services should promote a competent and positive image of people with disabilities.
6. That programs and services should promote the participation of people with disabilities in the life of the local community through maximum physical and social integration.
7. That no single organisation providing services should exercise control over all or most aspects of the life of an individual with disabilities.
8. That services providing assistance to people with disabilities, be they specific or generic, should be accountable to consumers and their representatives, funding bodies and the public at large.

9. That programs and services should provide opportunities for people with disabilities to reach goals and enjoy lifestyles which are valued by the community at large and are appropriate to the chronological age.
10. That disabled people should have access to advocacy support where necessary to ensure adequate participation in decision-making about the services they receive.
11. That services should provide appropriate avenues for people with disabilities to air and resolve grievances about the services they receive.

12. That disabled people should be provided with avenues for participating in the planning and operation of individual services and opportunities for consultation relating to major policy development and program changes.
13. That services for people with disabilities should respect an individual's rights of privacy and con- fidentiality.
Note: Individuals with disabilities should be read to include advocates and families of children with disabilities where appropriate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —In 1979 the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare published a report entitled `Through a Glass Darkly'. Four of the senators who were on that Committee are still in the Senate.
—Who thought of that title? It is a beauty.
—I thought of that title, actually. I thank Senator Chipp because it was a report about an evaluation of health and welfare services, and it is a good title.
—But where did you get it from? Quote your sources.

—My biblical colleague is asking me a question that I cannot answer. The thrust of that report was, in social policy in Australia, to measure need; we sought to work to statement of goals and we laid down objectives in outcome terms which we wanted to achieve. I think Senator Grimes, who was a member of the Committee, will recall those recommendations. The then Professor Gordon Reid, now His Excellency the Governor of Western Australia, wrote to us and said that he thought the report would have a significant effect upon welfare policy in this country. It is against that background that I want to say to the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) that the statement which I have read and which he has just incorporated in Hansard is an admirable document and one with which the Opposition would want to be associated. That may be unusual in this place where conflict is the norm, but I think the statement sets down some very important matters with which I agree and which I want to identify just briefly. Later I want to indicate a couple of concerns that I have with the statement but they are of a less important nature.

SPEECH.PARA: First, at page 11 of the statement is a very important value paragraph. It is so important that I just want to read it to the Senate. It is the view of the Government, and one which the Opposition shares. It read as follows:
The Principles-
that is, the principles behind the Government's approach to its legislation-

recognise that people with disabilities are individuals who have an inherent right to respect for their human worth and dignity, and, irrespective of the origin, nature, type and degree of disability have the same fundamental rights as do other members of society. This applies to the realisation of individual potential; to involvement in decision-making in matters affecting their lives; to the pursuit of grievances and rights; and to services which offer the least restrictive alternative in the achievement of these ends.

In terms of a statement of values, that is an admirable statement, and one with which we would wish to be associated. In the same way, the Minister's statement contains at page 6 a statement of goals and objectives which seek to implement those values that I have just read out. If the new legislations, which we have yet to see, is based upon those values and those objectives, there will be much merit in it. The Minister advises that the Government will seek to assist people through mainstream programs, through the least restrictive programs possible. It will seek to make programs more accountable for the outcomes they achieve-not just for what they do but for what they achieve-and it wants some changes in content. The Opposition wishes to associate itself with those goals and those statements.

We would also like to congratulate the Government on the demonstration project approach which will help those people with disability to know what is possible for them and will help people seeking to assist those with disability to know in which directions they might move with profit. By knowing what is possible by way of services, by knowing what is possible by way of residential options, we believe that people with disability may be able to achieve the kind of better outcome that the Government is seeking. Having made clear the support that I have, and that I am sure the Opposition has, for this document, I would like to outline a couple of concerns which my reading did reveal. First, some existing services, some services presently funded, may well lose their funding. This is made quite explicit in the document. My concern is not so much for the services but that in the process some people with disability may end up being losers by the discontinuation of funding.

Secondly, there is no real guarantee in what the Minister has said in one of the smaller sections about the program of aid for disabled persons, that the range of aids or the availability of aids will be increased to cover some of the gaps and shortfalls presently existing. Thirdly, there are some very difficult transition questions between the present method of planning and delivering services and the proposed method which still remains to be fleshed out. If this is not done with care and sensitivity, again people with disability might be the losers. It is our firm belief that a vacuum in the provision of services, either during the transition stages or later, is simply not acceptable.

We are reminded of some of the concerns that have been expressed to us in relation to the provision of rehabilitation services. We have moved from large institutional rehabilitation centres to a number of community based rehabilitation centres. But the feedback that we have been receiving from people seeking services for themselves is that during the changeover they seem to be falling through the holes. They seem to be unable to find the rehabilitation services that they need now. One of the problems we foresee is that during the transition period and afterwards there may be some new vacuums created. We ask the Government in changing over please to ensure that it does not throw out the baby with the bath water. That is all too easy to do.

The Government wishes to say that it does not favour large residential institutions or large training institutions. That may be so; but large institutions are better than no institutions. We have to understand that what we have at present may well be sub-optimal but it is better than a vacuum and no provision at all. A ghetto for people with disabilities is really not good enough; but it is better than nothing. One of the problems we have is that some people who at least have access to some services are worried that they may have access to none.

The main worry that I have relates to the inputs I am getting from people who have devoted their lives to the assistance of those with disabilities. Many people are worried that their life commitment to those with disabilities is in some way being devalued. The Minister shakes his head. I hope that he is right but I point out to him-I hope I do it constructively-that the statement that he has put down contains nothing that indicates the value that he places upon the commitment, the effort and the work of an army of people over many years, even if it is effort that he now thinks has been misdirected in some way.

An army of people have dedicated their lives, often to the support of their own relatives. They have struggled; they have faced the anguish of there being no services available; they have created services where none existed; they have filled voids. Maybe they have done so in a way which is now regarded as less than optimal; maybe we are changing direction. But what they want to hear is that what they have done over a number of years is not about to be denigrated or dismissed and that the work they have done is not about to be decried. I hope that when the Minister brings forward his legislation, with all the admirable goals and features which I have endorsed and with which I have associated the Opposition, he will also make a special point of indicating to those who may have to change direction that the work they have done has filled a vacuum, has provided services ices where none existed, and that what they have done has been appreciated. I think that that is the least we owe them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not delay the Senate. I simply welcome the fact that the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) has brought in a statement on this matter and place on record my acknowledgment of the long-standing interest of the Minister in this area, both in his capacity as a former Minister for Social Security and as the present Minister for Community Services. I, too, am conscious-I am sure we are all conscious-of the problems that are posed on a very regular basis about current funding arrangements. Page 8 of the text of the Minister's statement reads:

SPEECH.PARA: One of the biggest problems with the current Act is that there is no recognition of the different funding requirements of different service types. There needs to be flexibility to recognise the widely differing needs of people assisted under the program and the differing needs of individual service types. Rather than a set funding formula, I propose that the Bill provide for funding formulae to be set out in regulations.

That is a new initiative. It will be interesting to see whether it is successful. It will certainly enable greater attention, I believe, to be placed in the Senate on those particular questions, because if they are set out in regulations, quite obviously they will come before us as subordinate legislation and there will be opportunities for debate. I am pleased to see that the Minister and the Government have placed this question, which is a very important question, at the forefront of the attention of the Parliament.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: STATES GRANTS (EDUCATION ASSISTANCE-PARTICIPATION AND EQUITY) AMENDMENT BILL 1986STATES GRANTS (SCHOOLS ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1986STATES GRANTS (TERTIARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 11 June, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last evening we were debating these three Bills cognately in the Senate. The three Bills provide an extra $144m to our schools, higher education and technical and further education institutions. They take the form of regular supplementation Bills that come before the Senate each year. It gives us the opportunity to recognise and to put into perspective the financial resources that the Commonwealth is providing for all levels of education in Australia. This $144m takes the Commonwealth provision for education finance for the very first time to an amount in excess of $5 billion. This represents 7.2 per cent of all Commonwealth outlays. I was protesting last night, when I had more time to express this point, that in recent years we have achieved a plateau on which we seem-I realistically assess-locked in. I myself have been seeking a real increase in the education commitment from the Commonwealth. However, year by year, whether in regard to the former Government or this Government, we seem in Australia to be locked into the same amount of financial resources for education. What therefore has been happening, particularly in the last three years under this Government, is that that $5 billion worth of educational resource from the Commonwealth has been confined, restricted, locked into set boxes, administered by a rigid bureaucracy. All that is open and flexible in the system is who is able to get into it.

SPEECH.PARA: There is not the flexibility in the education system to allow for growth or change, for openly meeting all the needs of Australians in the way the Opposition would wish. The plateau of $5,000m in the provision of Commonwealth money for education has led in the last three years to this inflexible system. We in the Opposition still want in the coming weeks to announce a well thought through series of policy options to find a way out of the boxes in which education seems so circumscribed.

When these matters come before the Senate in the future, when the Opposition returns to government, I look forward to the prospect not only of our providing to education the same real amount of public money-certainly not less; certainly the same financial commitment in real terms-but also of providing it in such a way that our universities, colleges of advanced education and schools do not feel locked in and unable to meet the needs of the people they serve because they are circumscribed by all the regulations, by the need to gain the assent of the bureaucracy for any new development. At all levels of education in Australia we want to see the ability for local decisions that more truly serve the people. The Opposition is committed to maintaining this level of financial resource but with policies that will allow institutions to be flexible enough to meet the needs of their people with a maximising of choice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the States Grants (Education Assistance-Participation and Equity) Amendment Bill 1986, the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill 1986 and the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill 1986. I wish initially to address my remarks to the tertiary sector. The decade beginning with the last Hayden Budget in 1975 has been one of savage and counter-productive cuts to higher education funding in this country. Anyone who may be under the illusion that under the Hawke Government this funding has been restored need only compare funding now with that of a decade ago or compare the recommendations of the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission with the Government's appropriations. For instance, the Commission recommended a funding increase of $355m for the 1985-87 triennium. The Government appropriated $65m. In inimitable style, the Government used this disparity as evidence of the Commission's irresponsibility. The most significant cuts in the period from 1975 to 1986 have been in an area to which I have referred constantly in debates on education-the capital works program. The CTEC report for 1985 in chapter 9.12 stated in regard to academic buildings:

SPEECH.PARA: The problems most commonly identified by universities in relation to their building programs remain those identified on previous occasions. They include:
the need to comply with revised fire and safety regulations;
the dispersion of related activities both on and off campus;
the continued use of old and temporary buildings, including many World War II huts, originally intended to provide only short-term relief for accommodation problems; and
the existence of obsolete buildings which are absorbing an unacceptably high level of maintenance funds.

The problem is not new. We know what the difficulties are. We know that those difficulties are increasing. The grants in schedules 18, 19 and 20 of the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill are specified for building projects. As CTEC pointed out, the capital works program funding assumes that university buildings have a life of 200 years. This surely is carrying the bicentennial fervour a little too far. The most significant casualties, however, have been research funds. One-third of equipment in higher education is obsolete or useless. The replacement time frame is 15 years, which is absolutely absurd when compared with the rate of technological change. If one wishes to debate that point one has only to look at the Government's taxation laws, which allow computers, for example, to be written off over a three-year period. It is assumed for some reason that those areas which are teaching future generations and assisting in technological advancement can make do with replacements every 15 years.

Post-graduate research scholarships have fallen from a parity with tutor salaries to approximately one-third of that parity. The Australian research grants scheme involves a continuing dilemma of slicing too small a cake by either giving adequate grants to a fraction of the research applicants who deserve assistance or giving totally inadequate grants to a much larger proportion of applicants. A survey in 1985 of ARGS grants highlighted that only 26 per cent of new project applications received funds. This figure is at an all time low since the beginning of the ARGS. Although 331 new projects were funded, 146 had to be abandoned to make this possible. The average grant is less than 40 per cent of the equivalent grant in 1966. Seven hundred and thirty-two projects that were considered worthy of support simply could not be funded. The ARGS estimates that more than double that year's allocation will be needed to cover adequately the following year's top-ranking projects.

The Australian Labor Party in its platform before the 1983 election promised that, if elected, it would increase funds to the ARGS each year at a rate of 10 per cent above inflation. This promise has not been honoured. In 1984 the ARGS received a 3.5 per cent increase above inflation. In 1985 there was no increase and in 1986 it was 7 per cent above inflation. The latest Economic Planning Advisory Council research paper advises the Government to freeze research funding to tertiary institutions and the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation to encourage research funding from the business sector. I am not sure who writes such absolutely absurd statements. The reason for the statement is that the business sector is assumed then to receive a 150 per cent tax deduction. The reasoning behind the recommendation presumably is the contemporary dogma that research must be economically relevant rather than being just pure or fundamental research. As with most EPAC recommendations, it is based on the authority of the organisation and certainly not on any evidence that it has been able to produce.

I will refer now to a rather fascinating program by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation called Occam's Razor and to the recent program by Dr Ian Lowe. He pointed out a variety of items which I think are fascinating. He points out that what is worrying is the approach being taken by the Australian Science and Technology Council, ASTEC, which seems to have the unenviable capacity to ignore evidence which is incompatible with its own views. That body's research funds--

TALK.START.PARA: —What was the relevance of Occam?

—Entia non sunt multiplicanda praeter necessitatem-do not multiply entities without necessity. It is the basis of a scientific method. If Senator Teague wanted to relate it to the argument, he should have listened. I referred to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation program. ASTEC has a tendency to ignore evidence which is incompatible with its collective values. That body's recent report on research funding sets a new standard in this area. With an innovative leap into what appears to be a new discipline of psycho-physics, ASTEC recommends:

SPEECH.PARA: Research of the highest quality requires research groups of sufficient size to have critical mass.
It was stated on Occam's Razor:

A critical mass is the minimum quantity of fissionable material necessary for a chain reaction to take place, and ASTEC define this in research terms as being a group "as large as a normal department".

In this case there is absolutely no evidence whatsoever that large aggregations of researchers in Australia are disproportionately productive. Such qualitative indicators which are available, for example, publications per researcher or citations of these publications, research grants awarded and so on, clearly give the opposite picture. It is a vital question because in these days of funding restraints on everything except the obvious, desperate, and all out need to get the new Parliament House up and running by 1988, there is a limited amount of money available to support research in this country. The centres of research concentration are being funded at the expense of allocation to the higher education sector in general. The same is likely to be true of any further reallocation towards large teams or new centres.

The significance of this proposal from ASTEC becomes clear from a consideration of the role of university research. This research has two types of output. It produces new knowledge by way of research results and it produces skilled people who have been educated in research methods and techniques, or who have been exposed to the latest knowledge in a particular subject area. This skill base is currently at risk because of the funding constraints. As the Federation of Australian University Staff Associations (FAUSA) has pointed out, one third of the equipment in higher education is obsolete. Library funds are constrained so severely that the cancellation of journal subscriptions is returning Australia to the intellectual dark age in which we simply do not know what is happening in the rest of the world. I remind the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) that 98 per cent of research we are able to use operates and is developed outside this country. That is the usefulness of research, that is the usefulness of journals. As anybody who has been associated with tertiary institutions knows, the cutbacks in libraries are in the area of journals because that is the most expensive area being carried.

Excessive years of marginal fundings have eroded the time and other resources available for research. I have mentioned many examples in other speeches I have made in this place of researchers who have international reputation operating on research funding of $300, $400 or $500, something which people in overseas countries just cannot understand. Of course they, quite rightly, are attempting to poach those people from our higher education institutions with offers of reasonable research funding. We all know of people in these areas who are buying their research equipment out of their own pockets, who are refusing to accept any more research students because they simply cannot afford to buy the equipment necessary for the research. If funds are frozen at the current level or are reduced still further to allow teams of critical mass to be assembled, as ASTEC wants, we are expected to believe that the private sector, for some reason, will rush in with wallets agape to press resources upon the researchers of this country. One might ask why it has not been doing that to date, not only with regard to our publicly funded institutions but also with regard to the research within their own institutions, even if it were research which would be short term only and only that which can be shown to produce a dollar.

We are being offered simple answers to incredibly complex questions. We are being asked to trust in the inevitable economic recovery, or to starve the research community so that we can lavish resources on a few megastars. As has been pointed out, to every complex question there is a simple answer, and it is always wrong; but not only that, it is likely to do an enormous amount of harm. A reference to simple answers to complex questions should not pass without a mention of the Opposition's draft policy, or whatever it is that has been floating around, which looks at the so-called deregulation of education. The shadow Minister for Education, Mr Shack, announced some time ago-with a boldness which must stem from some kind of messianic ignorance-that the solution to the problems of our schooling system lies in exposing the system to market forces. We are going to call on Adam Smith to come to our aid, and will look again at vouchers, God help us. I never thought I would have to get out that file again. In fact, I did drag out my rather yellowing file on vouchers, which goes back to the early 1970s. I never thought that in 1986 we would have a rerun of that exercise. I found in my file that Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle involved herself in that issue, and I understand that it was Liberal Party of Australia policy during various election campaigns. Of course when the Liberals got into government they realised the absurdity of the proposition.

I do not want to take up too much time in this area, but basically I suggest to the Opposition that if it wants to have a look at that matter it should read the literature on it. It sounded like a good idea at the time but, when one works out the implications of that operation, undoubtedly rural education will suffer enormously-it has to; there is no other way out when we move into those areas-and more importantly there will be a congregation into selected areas, and those people who are currently disadvantaged even within the operation of the existing education system will be disadvantaged still further. Those people who are advantaged by the current system will be advantaged still further by the introduction of vouchers. I do not believe it is a serious proposition and I hope it will go away as quickly as it arose.

I want to make one final point on the research area, the area in these Bills on which I chose to concentrate. The Australian Democrats have consistently urged-I am pleased to see that Senator Button's Department, the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce, has now made such a recommendation-for the establishment of a national research council. In the last two elections I have urged on behalf of the Australian Democrats the establishment of an Australian research foundation that would receive funds from government on a triennial basis. It would be empowered also to receive funds from industry, either on a tied basis or as free grants. The reason I suggested such a single operation is that it would take over the roles of ARGS and the National Health and Medical Research Council, and also of course the abolished area of the Education Research and Development Committee, for which no additional funds have been allocated. More importantly, we need in Australia to look at current research and problems that have arisen in overseas universities and tertiary institutions, including the ethical and professional problems of tied grants. We need to establish some means of getting arms length arrangements between the actual researchers and the funders. We also believe that each institution should be able to have at least one centre of research concentration and if any institution is not of sufficient standard to achieve this, it should be funded to run a development program of staff, plant and equipment to enable it to research to world standards in a particular area in minimum time. As well, part of that centre's establishment fund should go to student accommodation. We also believe that there needs to be a total restructuring of post graduate entrance so that all those who are capable of undertaking such studies and are certified as being eligible have the opportunity to do so.

While this will cost money, I would suggest that, even from reading the document attached to the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) last night and other statements that have been made by various Ministers in this area, we have to acknowledge that the dollar spent on education is the best dollar invested by this country. Umpteen papers, symposia, documents and even books have looked at the link between money spent on education within any economic system and the performance of that economic system over time. The dollar spent on education has always out-performed the dollar spent on roads, mining or any other activity. We acknowledge that it does not bring short term gains but it does bring medium and long term gains to the community. We know it is a cost, but we must look at it in a far more realistic way; that is, look at that dollar not as a cost to the community but as the most worthwhile investment that any country can make, an investment in its own citizens. The fact that we still pay people more for unemployment than we do for study illustrates the values of our society. Until we hold education to be of economic value, until we hold the development of our own people to be that critical to the future of our community, any Education Minister, no matter what government that Education Minister is in, will be fighting an uphill battle in Cabinet to secure any reasonable funds for our education system. It really does not matter what party is in power; the total community must value our education system that greatly. Without that I do not believe this country has a future, no matter how much we go on manipulating the other variables in the economy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for their contributions, and commend the Bills to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time, and passed through their remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: AFFIRMATIVE ACTION (EQUAL OPPORTUNITY FOR WOMEN) BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 17 April, on motion by Senator Gietzelt:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I table the revised explanatory memorandum for the Affirmative Action (Equal Opportunity for Women) Bill 1986.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate may rise this week. The Affirmative Action (Equal Opportunity for Women) Bill 1986 is a major piece of legislation. Nineteen speakers from the Opposition are listed to speak in the second reading debate together with speakers from the Government and the Australian Democrats. It is a major debate and there is no possibility of its being completed this week. It is only fair to advise the Senate that the Opposition has, I think, 40 amendments which may be considered in six, seven or eight groups.
—Nineteen of them are consequential.

—Nineteen of them are consequential and, I think, the Australian Democrats wish to move a series of amendments. There is really no way that I can see this Bill in good order being completed this week and we should put that on the record.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition supports the passage of the Affirmative Action (Equal Opportunity for Women) Bill. We seek to assist the achievement of the goal of equal opportunity for all. We recognise that in the area of employment, as in so many areas, there has not been equality and women have not been given a fair go. We support equal employment opportunity because it is a fundamentally liberal goal to seek to empower people in their lives. We support it because it is right. We support it because it is fair and because it is a goal that will increase the talent and ability available in the service of the community. The Leader of the Opposition, John Howard, underscored the importance we attach to this Bill when he made the main speech on behalf of the Opposition supporting it in another place.

However, we support the Bill with some reservations and I will put down now what those reservations are. The Affirmative Action (Equal Opportunity for Women) Bill will impose upon employers one more burden, it will impose one more layer of regulations, it will impose more government bureaucracy and it will impose more expense. It is important, when considering the benefits to flow from this legislation, to identify the costs as well especially when those persons who will bear the costs are different in many cases from those persons who will enjoy the benefits. To do that is not to decry or to belittle the benefits-I will set out in my speech why we support that achievement-rather it is to present a more complete, a more honest picture for the benefit of those seeking to understand and to appreciate the legislation. We make clear in a second reading amendment some of the costs that this legislation will impose. I move:
At the end of the motion, add:
`, but in fully endorsing the principle of equal opportunity in employment and career advancement through merit, the Senate believes that
(a) voluntary co-operation rather than additional Government regulation is the preferred method of achieving equal opportunity in employment; and
(b) this Bill-
(i) should build on the goodwill and expertise developed with private employers during the voluntary pilot program,
(ii) will add to the cost burdens of business, thereby reducing overall employment opportunities and increasing prices to consumers,
(iii) will increase the level of business regulation,
(iv) will establish yet another bureaucracy at a cost to the taxpayer, and
(v) will further extend the interference of trade unions in the activities of private employers'.
I hope that the Senate will see fit to adopt these amendments.

Let me return to the Bill and to our decision that we wish to see it succeed. On behalf of the Opposition I will identify some of the obstacles, some of the prejudices, some of the discriminatory practices and some of the barriers which have made women's progress so slow in the achievement of work place equality of opportunity. Consider a running track with two lanes in it. One lane is for men and one lane is for women-the running track of life. In Australia the women's lane now has, and has always had, legal and institutional hurdles in it. The men's lane has no legal or institutional hurdles related to sex. Members of the Liberal and National parties want to remove altogether those hurdles from the track, because those hurdles make the way of women more difficult. We may have some good hurdlers in society but if there are running tracks there is no reason for them to have to become good hurdlers to succeed. To remove the hurdles is equal employment opportunity and it is the way of EEO. Some people seem to want to move the hurdle for the women's track across to the men's track and some people call this hard affirmative action. They regard it as a form of catch-up. It involves reverse discrimination, some kind of pay-back. That is the way of the virulent forms of affirmative action, the kind that has been discredited in some of its forms in the United States of America for example. We are deeply, sincerely and publicly committed to equal employment opportunity, to tearing down work place barriers against women. We are equally against virulent affirmative action where this means erecting barriers against men. One does not correct past injustice against one gender by replacing it with future injustice against the other.

We know equal employment opportunity affirmative action by two tests. The first test is the merit principle as the critical determinant of employment; and the second test is whether quotas are to be achieved irrespective of merit. The answer to those two questions will tell us whether it is EEO or affirmative action. On those two tests this Bill is not a Bill about affirmative action; it is about equal employment opportunity which we support. I remember Senator Haines described it when it first came out as the affirmative non-action Bill. It is an equal employment opportunity Bill because no quotas are imposed and because employment matters will be subject to the overriding entrenchment of the merit principle in clause 3 sub-clause (4) of the Bill which reads as follows:
Nothing in this Act shall be taken to require a relevant employer to take any action incompatible with the principle that employment matters should be dealt with on the basis of merit.

Indeed, had this legislation set aside the merit principle and sought preferential employment treatment for women the Liberal and National parties would have opposed it. However, it does not set aside these matters; it does not seek preferential employment treatment. It seeks to remove barriers and so we support it.

Every attempt to empower women to participate in society has been opposed and every advance for women has been won with difficulty. While we are considering employment matters today, employment discrimination in this Bill, it has to be in the context of equal discrimination which has occurred in the related areas of education and of access to political power because they are all related. Those are activities which help to determine success in employment.

For a start let us consider some milestones of progress and let us use just South Australia as a convenient example since I have a record of some of the dates when some progress has been achieved there. These milestones reveal just some of the discrimination which has made it impossible for women for so long to compete as equal members of society. Women had been little more than chattels through most of the nineteenth century. In 1884 the South Australian Married Womens Property Act gave to women some right to own property and even to continue to own their own property after marriage. In 1911 women were allowed to practise law. In 1921 women were allowed to become public notaries and justices of the peace. When moves were made at the Federal level to introduce a Federal maternity allowance in 1912 it was opposed and it was criticised by some as `placing a premium on vice' and as `promoting an increase in illegitimacy'. Not until 1940 did women gain equal parental guardianship rights, again in South Australia. In the same State, women gained the right only in 1948 to have their own individual nationality, not necessarily the same nationality as their husbands.

Not until 1965 did women gain the right to serve on juries though, of course, they had been required to appear as defendants before male juries for centuries. Not until 1965 were women allowed to sit on juries as part of their rights as citizens. They were still barred from serving in the Public Service if they married and they were not permitted to buy drinks in the front bars of hotels. They are some of the general kinds of barriers that existed.

I turn to education. Education provides a capacity for women to participate in society. What is the story there? Denied much education at all, women's attempts during the last part of the nineteenth century and through the twentieth century to enrol, graduate and use education as a stepping stone to equal participation in society were all opposed. They have all been opposed during the last 100 years. Eminent doctors of the nineteenth century even went so far as to argue publicly that education for women could only be at the expense of the proper development and function of their reproductive organs. I must say that it is humorous to read some of those eminent medical opinions a century later. It was 1880 before women were permitted to graduate from Adelaide University. What earthly reason could there have been not to allow women to graduate from university? It was later than that in all the other Australian universities. Women were permitted to study medicine only from 1885, but the medical graduates, certainly in my city of Sydney, though they might have had a degree, were not made resident medical officers, which was essential for full registration as a medical practitioner and essential for them to be able to participate in society, until 20 more years had elapsed.

Australia was echoing, as least in part, British resistance to the education of women. The British had no doubt that they were resisting the education of women. Oxford and Cambridge universities resisted completely the equal recognition of women students for decades. Elizabeth Windshuttle recorded that most opposition to women gaining full educational opportunity was based on the belief that they would lose their femininity if educated, and reject the role of wife and mother. So it was argued that the education of women would lead to a breakdown of the family, and so of society as a whole. Every advance for women has been opposed with exactly that argument, no matter what the advance has been. It has been argued that it will lead to a breakdown of the family and of society as a whole. This has been an objection based really on the desire to maintain an unequal society.
Indeed, Dean John William Burgon, in a sermon at the University of Oxford in 1884, argued that allowing women to study mathematics and natural science was:
. . . a proposed reversal of the law of nature which is also the law of God concerning woman . . . so far, at least, as women's education is concerned.
He ended his sermon with the following sentiment:
Inferior to us God made you, and inferior to the end of time you will remain.

Cambridge University admitted women to full honour degrees with complete equality with men only in 1948. We all know of inequalities in school offerings and in the different expectations and ideology of schooling for girls. Today women students represent 45 per cent of total higher education enrolments, but they are still grossly underrepresented in some faculties. Today, while women represent 45 per cent of the most junior grades of academic staff, they represent less than 3 per cent of all the professors in this country and less than 5 per cent of those at associate professor level. Even today educational inequality is clearly one of the hurdles on the running track of life in the way of women.

Even today the story of the winning of electoral equality for women has been equally slow and equally opposed. Women were given the vote in South Australia in 1894 and federally in 1902, but the Bill granting women the franchise was bitterly opposed by some. For example, part of the contribution of Senator Simon Fraser in this Senate in 1902 was as follows:

Woman naturally and properly clings to man. Naturally and properly, by an instinct born in her, she seeks the advice of man, and looks up to him for advice and guidance . . . I say that woman should not enter into the arena of politics, the turmoil of it, and the chicanery of it. I say that if she enters into the arena of politics herself: if she is a unit, as has been contended here; if she uses her own judgement and discretion in politics, she throws all the advantages which have been extended to her from time immemorial. I say the one thing involves the other, and were I a young woman, I would infinitely prefer the position of looking up to a man as my director, my guide and adviser, to that of having the privilege, the sham privilege, of entering into politics and fighting and elbowing my own way in spite of man.
I end that quote by Senator Simon Fraser by saying that I should observe that his grandson, Mr Malcolm Fraser, was of a very different view and much more enlightened.

In 1914 South Australian women were permitted to become municipal councillors. It was 1943, however, before a woman was elected to the Federal Parliament. I remind honourable senators that women were given the vote in 1902. The gap between the right of women to stand for election and the successful election of a woman, more often than not a Liberal, was often considerable. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a brief table for the Commonwealth and for each State Parliament with the appropriate dates of the granting of the right of women to sit and the date of election of the first woman member of each Parliament.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I digress for one moment to say something about my own family. My grandfather, and the grandfather of my cousin, Senator Michael Baume, was Frederick Ehrenfried Baume, King's Counsel and member of parliament, the Liberal member for Auckland City and then for Auckland East in the Parliament of New Zealand. He died in 1910, while a member of that Parliament. In 1919, the first occasion on which women were permitted to offer themselves for election in New Zealand, his widow, our grandmother, Rosetta Ida Baume, an early woman university graduate and feminist, was a candidate for the Auckland seat of Parnell, in the first group of women candidates ever to stand in that country. She was unsuccessful. I seek leave, perhaps sentimentally, to incorporate in Hansard the final figures for the seat of Parnell in that election.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honour- able senators. In 1921 Australia's first woman parliamentarian, Edith Cowan, was elected in Western Australia. When she was elected, what was said about her? During her first campaign she was accused of being a disgrace to women, of heartlessly neglecting her husband and children. The fact is that at that stage her youngest child was 30 years old and her husband was out campaigning for her. So much for the attitude and the rhetoric of what people were saying.
—It has not changed much.

—The honourable senator says that it has not changed. Let us consider some details of the discrimination that has occurred in the area of employment of women. Employment practices were based on certain values and attitudes critical of the capacity of women and prejudicial to the hopes of women seeking paid employment. Discrimination in public employment has been institutionalised. Mr McLachan, giving evidence to the Royal Commission on Public Service Administration in 1920, said that women were innately incapable of work requiring responsibility and ambition, and were peculiarly suitable for carrying out routine work. The Royal Commission, which reported in 1921, argued that women were less able than men-this is the Royal Commission's view, not mine-had fewer financial responsibilities, and therefore should be paid less. They were weaker and more likely to be absent from work and less able to cope with responsibility.

SPEECH.PARA: Not surprisingly, that was the way in which our Commonwealth Public Service evolved. Only in 1949 were women from outside the Service allowed to sit for the examination for the Third Division of the Commonwealth Public Service, the clerical division. The only women members of the Third Division at that time were those who had transferred from the State services at the time of Federation 49 years earlier. It was only in 1966 that the Commonwealth Public Service finally removed the marriage bar which prevented employment of married women as permanent officers and which had required them to resign from the permanent service on marriage.

This marriage bar had the effect, incidentally, of depriving women who married of their superannuation rights. In 1968-recent history now-the marriage bar was removed in New South Wales. Women continued to receive discriminatory and disadvantageous treatment in Public Service superannuation. Yet only as recently as 1972 were women permitted to sit for examination for entry to the administrative division of the Victorian Public Service. Only in 1973, just over a decade ago, when Australia signed an International Labour Organisation Convention against discrimination in employment were all Commonwealth Public Service positions opened to women in principle. It was in that year that Marie Coleman, appointed from outside the Service, became the first woman to serve in the First Division of the Commonwealth Public Service. In that same year, too, the Victorian Public Service finally ended its bar to the employment of married women. Only in 1977 did Victoria remove all discriminatory provisions from its Public Service-less that 10 years ago-and as recently as 1978 Mayor Rex Pilbeam dismissed an employee from the Rockhampton City Council when she married. The Sex Discrimination (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1986, a Bill currently before the Senate, seeks to remove a marriage bar as it relates to employees of the Reserve Bank of Australia. It is still there on the books, even if it has not been followed in practice.

On the subject of discrimination in pay the story has been equally grim. The first determination of a female basic wage in 1949 entrenched an inferior wage position for women on the basis of their sex. Equal pay was opposed by the union movement and by the Government, and the wage case determined a lesser wage for women. It was not until 1974 that an Act was passed giving equal pay for equal work, Mr Justice Moore arguing then that the Government should find some other way to compensate families where the man was the sole breadwinner.

Women were generally denied superannuation available to men. The marriage bar led to the loss of superannuation rights. Most women did not have the level of pay or seniority to win private sector superannuation. In 1979, in the higher paid groups getting access to superannuation, men outnumbered women by 10 to one and in the lowest paid groups where superannuation was not available women outnumbered men by three to one. Women filled 78 per cent of all part-time positions. Even now-and this Bill addresses these problems-available contemporary figures still show how women are missing from the ranks of senior employment and are concentrated in the lowest ranking jobs.

The Four Corners program on 17 February this year reported that women constitute half of the Fourth, or lowest, Division of the Commonwealth Public Service, they constitute one-quarter of the Third Division, but only 5 per cent of the Senior Executive Service are women. In Australia's top 10 companies, of 12,400 executives and managers, 757 are women-just 6 per cent-half of them in one company, Ansett Transport Industries. Caltex Oil (Aust.) Pty Ltd had no female executives or managers, BP Aust. Ltd had seven, Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd had 25 out of 2,000 executives, and Westpac Banking Corporation had 45 women out of 3,425 executives. Will anyone argue that these figures derive solely from lesser merit?

TALK.START.PARA: —Some of your side will.

—Well, I do not. We are supporting the principle of this legislation for the following reasons. Systemic work place discrimination is a problem for Australian women. It has been so since Federation, and before. We support equal opportunity. This Bill endorses that value. We understand that a revolution has occurred in terms of work place aspirations and rights and is continuing among women. We understand that work force participation of women is up by two-thirds in the last 20 years. We understand that two-thirds of women in paid employment are married; that more than half of married women in paid employment work full time; that almost half of married women with children are in paid employment; that more than half of non-working women plan to take paid employment in the future; that half the women in paid employment regard their job as a career; and that only 28 per cent of Australia's women are now traditional; that is, staying home with their families and not taking paid employment ever. That is a valued, valid, important role, but these days it is a valued minority role. Women have the same inherent ability as men, but occupy lower paid jobs and they have less access to power and authority than do men. With long and healthy lives, more women want to have part of their lives as full time careers at home and part of their lives getting a fair go in the work force.

SPEECH.PARA: We recognise that this Bill imposes extra costs, but we know already that many companies are adopting equal employment opportunity. We know that 80 per cent of Australians are employed under laws in four States that outlaw work place discrimination. We know that New South Wales and Western Australia already have more onerous affirmative action laws than this Act might provide. Most importantly, the needs of Australian women for a fair go outweigh even the powerful arguments of business against this Bill. We are not discussing whether or not women will work in the home or in paid employment. That is a decision that each woman will make for herself. We are discussing whether those who do choose paid employment will find equal employment opportunity and a fair go.

While we value women's choice to stay at home and while our policies will give support to single income families, we share the values and aspirations, we share the feeling of urgency of many women to cast off the shackles which have held them back. We wish to identify with moves to enable Australia to have greater access to the talents of more of its working citizens in the work place-and in more senior positions if that is where they deserve to be on merit. We are not ignorant of the existence of work place discrimination, we do not acquiesce in it and we do not support it. Therefore, we are convinced that it is right and necessary to support this Bill. We cannot afford to exclude from the work force the energy and talent of women. We can only imagine our losses as a society if potential Marie Curies were not encouraged while Pierre Curies were.

The Opposition has a series of amendments which it will move at the Committee stage. These are designed to improve the legislation and to try to endorse some of the values that I have set out in my speech on the second reading. Some of the amendments have already had the support of the Government in the other place and I thank it for the amendment that it has already picked up. I will discuss these amendments in detail at the appropriate time. It only remains to reiterate our support for equal work place opportunity for all Australians and to express our hope that this legislation will actually advance that cause. We hope that it will and I wish the legislation well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I begin my comments on the Affirmative Action (Equal Opportunity for Women) Bill 1986 by commending the Government for keeping one of the few commitments that it has made to the electorate in the past few years; that is, its commitment to introduce the sort of legislation that will give women a very real choice and remove some of the impediments that have been thrown up before them in past years. I make it quite clear that this legislation does not force women to do anything. The issue at the heart of this matter is one of choice. If women-or men, for that matter-choose to stay at home they should have that right and they should be in a position to make that choice. That is what we are talking about: People being in a position to make that choice. If women and men choose to work in the paid work force, choose to follow a career, and if they have the educational qualifications, the talents and the ambitions to achieve their goals, they should also have the right to choose to go in that direction without artificial impediments being put in their way.

SPEECH.PARA: Despite all the rhetoric to the contrary that we hear sometimes in the community, impediments-not unwillingness or lesser ability-have prevented women from achieving their goals. Anyone who does not believe this needs only to turn to a publication such as Dale Spender's splendid book entitled Women of Ideas and What Men Have Done To Them to work out just what impediments-artificial, political, educational and others-have been thrown up before women to prevent them from having choice and, more importantly, to prevent them from competing with men. That has been the source of the problem. Those sorts of impediments have led to some of the things that Senator Peter Baume has mentioned. The fact that, for example, 591/2 per cent of female employees are currently concentrated in three major occupational groups-clerical, sales and services; and the fact that while just over 19 per cent of females were in professional and technical occupations, 371/2 per cent of those were teachers and another 30 per cent nurses. The latter, of course, is hardly a highly paid position and in most States of Australia it has only been within the past 10 years that the teaching profession has allowed women to be paid the same as their male colleagues.

These impediments have caused the disproportionate employment of women in part-time jobs, meaning that women's relative share of available employment is limited and their share of available money is significantly cut back, which makes them less able than their male colleagues to compete economically. In sales and service occupations, for example, something like 41 per cent of women employees are part-time employees. This does them no economic service, it does them no professional service; in fact, it does them no real service at all, unless of course they choose to work part time. That is another matter entirely and at this point I would add that there are increasing numbers of men in the community who would also like to choose to work part time, provided that choice allowed for permanent part-time work with all the pro rata benefits that are so necessary.

It is not just in those occupational areas that women have been disadvantaged in the past or in which they are still disadvantaged. An excellent study done in 1984 by Dr Leonie Still shows that, even in executive positions, women are significantly disadvantaged.
