The whole socio cultural environment in this country-it is only a reflection, to a large extent, of what happens overseas-seems to suggest that unrestricted opportunities are available for the career seeking woman. They are not. We hear a lot about women who make it to the top, whether as tokens or because they are genuinely as good as any of their male competitors. What we do not hear is the difficulty that those women have faced on the way up and the limited numbers who actually make it. For example, American studies indicate that there is a barrier at 15 per cent, that once that magic figure is reached the ranks of men in the corporations concerned tend to close and no more women-irrespective of their merits, talents or capabilities-advance very far.

Dr Still's study shows that women executives in Australia hold a very marginal position in organisational life and that they have not begun to reach their full potential. That, of course, advantages neither the women concerned nor the organisations which employ them. Apart from that fact. the women in the survey were concentrated mainly in the lower levels of management. Women received less remuneration than men at all supervisory and management levels, with the difference in salary levels between genders becoming greater in the upper levels of management. This is despite the fact that her study also showed that the women managers were generally better qualified educationally than their male colleagues.

Furthermore, women managers tended to be concentrated more in the narrower areas-the softer option areas, if you like, of personnel, advertising, retail sales and buying. The male managers were concentrated in production and technical areas, research and development, exploration, banking and general administration-the status managerial positions, if you like. Furthermore, training opportunities for women managers, according to Dr Still's study, were not offered in the same proportion as they were offered to male managers and, more particularly, relatively few young women were employed in management cadet or graduate training programs by those companies which offered such programs. We all know how important it is to be noticed while one is still a fairly low-level employee, to be picked up by management, encouraged and given the sort of confidence that is necessary for both male and female employees to advance up the corporate ladder.

Finally, Dr Still found that there were differences in promotional opportunities for men and women managers, with male managers being recruited from many sources, including the external environment, whereas women were much more likely to be promoted from within their own organisations. In other words, the companies wanted to keep an eye on them to make sure they proved themselves. They were not prepared to take a risk. When these women were promoted they were promoted to much more junior managerial positions than their male colleagues, whether those men had come up the ladder from within the organisation or had been taken in from outside. Many more men than women were being promoted in the management hierarchy, with women's assumed lack of locational mobility being cited as one of the reasons. There are a great many assumptions that have prevented women from achieving everything that their inherent talents would normally allow them to do. I will return to that in a moment.

The affirmative action legislation that is before us today aims to ensure that equal opportunity practices are put into effect rather than simply talked about. Let me make it clear that this legislation is not social engineering or anything like it, as has been suggested by some. In fact, I would say that it is quite the reverse. The intention of the legislation is, I suggest, that for the first time in the history of this country merit, and only merit, will be the criterion used for employing and promoting people, both male and female. Passage of this Bill will go at least some way--

TALK.START.PARA: —Except in Telecom Australia and Australia Post.
—Except in statutory authorities, some of which have the worst employment and promotional practices in this country.
—Why are they?
—I presume because they are fairly largely technical and male employing areas. They are the two main hurdles. Passage--
—Why does the Government not do something about that?

—We will come to why the Government is not doing anything about statutory authorities. Not being a professional crystal ball gazer, I have a feeling that that is about to be fixed up one way or another. Passage of the Bill, as I have been trying to say for some moments now, will go at least some way towards ending previous sex-based work practices.

SPEECH.PARA: I was invited, as was Senator Peter Baume, to speak to a Coopers and Lybrand-W.D. Scott conference a couple of weeks ago which had as its title something like `Coming sex-based issues in the work force'. I suspect that I aggravated one or two people there by pointing out that this Bill was a desexing piece of legislation, that it was taking out the inbuilt sexism which has been so much a part of our assumptions, our legislative process and our past employment and promotion practices. I was referring to the sorts of practices which, over the past 80 years at least, have prevented women in this country from achieving their rightful place in the paid work force; practices in effect which have denied women all choice in making career decisions.

Anybody who does not believe that employment practices have been supported or imposed by sex-based legislation-indeed, I would say, sex-biased legislation-need only look at laws and decisions ranging from the Harvester decision back in the early years of this century to legislation which forced women to resign from the paid work force on marriage and to retire at 60 instead of 65, which imposed the most extraordinary weight lifting restrictions on women but not on men regardless, I might say, of the size of the person concerned, which offered transfer or promotion positions to men only and which failed to encourage women and girls to take on broad-based educational courses, retraining schemes, management courses and so on.

Given that sort of list, it is hardly surprising that what we are now faced with is undoing a lot of the damage that has been done to women through the legislative system in the past 80 to 100 years. There is no doubt that over that period the law in Australia and elsewhere, aided and abetted by entrenched public attitudes to men and women, let me hasten to add, has ensured that sex-based employment and promotion practices have been an integral part of the paid work system. That, of course, has not been helped by the fact that there have been so few women in the sorts of positions that I, Senator Zakharov, Senator Ryan, Senator Crowley or even Senator Bjelke-Petersen currently find ourselves in. As Senator Peter Baume pointed out, it has been only recently that women in any numbers have been represented in Federal politics or, indeed, in State politics. In fact, it was not until 1923 that women even had the right to be elected to the Victorian Parliament. In 1908 women in Victoria had the right to vote but they only had the right to do so for a male candidate and I find that almost the ultimate form of patronising legislation. It was not until 1923 that they had the right to bring themselves forward for election and thereby give the population the right to choose between a much broader range of candidates than had previously been the case.

I would remind people such as Senator Walters and Senator Knowles who claim that we should not have such things as sex discrimination legislation in this country that in fact legislation passed in all States and expressed in the Australian Constitution is precisely that-it is sex discrimination legislation pure and simple. You, Madam Acting Deputy President, Senator Ryan, Senator Bjelke-Petersen and I would not be in the Senate at the moment if it were not for the fact that that sort of legislation has been passed by all parliaments, sometimes for pragmatic reasons that had nothing whatsoever to do with the principle of giving women the vote. For example, in your own State of Western Australia, Madam Acting Deputy President, there was a much more cynical reason behind the move to give women the vote. The then Government of Western Australia faced a problem in the mining areas of Western Australia which it hoped to correct by giving very conservative women the right to vote. Nevertheless, had the parliaments not passed such legislation, we would not be here. Our predecessors would not have been here and our sisters and daughters, if they choose to follow our careers-and more for them if they do-would simply not have that choice at all. So I think it is quite extraordinary to hear people in this chamber argue that we should not have sex discrimination legislation when they themselves are only here because of such legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —But it is consistent with everything that has happened every time people have tried to empower women.

—Certainly. The sorts of comments that Senator Peter Baume made earlier about women who seek positions in the Parliament, ignoring their husbands, rejecting their children and so on, are still the sorts of things that are flung at me. Just to digress for a moment-if the honourable senator can be anecdotal, so can I-I recall that in 1977 when I was first appointed to this place to fill a casual vacancy I was something like 32 years of age and my children were aged 7 and 8. Senator Baden Teague was elected that year and his children were of pre-school age. I cannot think of any occasion on which I was being interviewed around that time when reporters did not ask me how the family was going to cope, nor do I imagine that it occurred to them to ask Senator Baden Teague the same question. The implication was very strong that somehow my children were going to suffer whereas his would not. For those people who are still tuned in to the parliamentary broadcast of this debate, might I say that I have not yet been sued for divorce and my children have not yet, as a consequence, become wards of the state.
—It is only a matter of time in each case.

—The honourable senator can speak for himself. His children were very young when he came into this place. In fact, while we are on a personal element, I recall the honourable senator saying to me that his daughter asked him once why everybody else's father was not always on television. I know that Senator Macklin's youngest son, when asked at one of the little school sessions in which the children talk about what daddy does, announced to all and sundry that his father went to work by plane. He was immediately told by the teacher that that could not possibly be true. When he insisted it was, she asked him: `Ah, is he a pilot?' Kevin said no. I presume he thought that his father might have been given the amount of time he spends in the air. So we all face these problems-not just women who have children and want to pursue a career.

SPEECH.PARA: In the past the law has imposed restrictions on working conditions for women ranging from the weights they can carry to the age at which they have to retire. The question of the amount of weight that may be lifted is, of course, a fascinating one since the restriction is usually set at 16 to 18 kilograms. For anybody who is interested, that is the weight of an average three year old. I have yet to see men in the street, who presumably are aware of the award conditions that prevent women from lifting weights of more than 16 kilograms, leap to the assistance of a women who is walking down the street, carrying a fractious two-year-old and a load of shopping and dragging an unwilling four-year-old.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or lifting them on to the bus.

—Yes, or lifting them on to the bus. Those restrictions are a nonsense. They are the sort of artificial impediments that, in the past, have been put in front of women to prevent them achieving the goals they would like to achieve. Nurses, of course, belong to another professional group that has been conveniently overlooked where things such as weight lifting requirements are concerned. Social attitudes to the roles of men and women within marriage have, very largely, been the reason for this sort of impediment being allowed to continue. That is the reason the community has used to justify that sort of discrimination and in justifying it, the alleged attitudes and assumptions were entrenched.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have just indicated, many of those beliefs have no base in fact, but that has not stopped people of both sexes from arguing that women should not do dirty work or the aforementioned heavy work. Again, nurses and housewives would be interested in that statement. I wonder what people told the women who worked in the munitions factories in World War I and World War II about their not being able to do dirty and heavy work. So all of those factors have operated to prevent women from achieving the goals that they would like to achieve. As a consequence of those legislative, assumed and socially enforced impediments and the sex-based work place practices and laws that have been around for many years, State and Federal legislation has had to be introduced in recent years to replace gender-based practices with merit-based principles and practices.

In many ways, this Bill is the contemporary equivalent of the sorts of things that Senator Peter Baume was talking about earlier-the nineteenth and twentieth century controversies relating to property rights for married women, restrictions on the use of child and sweated female labour, work safety requirements and regulations, paid holidays, equal pay for women, access to education for women and girls, women's right to work after marriage, access to superannuation schemes, the right to vote, the right to be elected to parliament, and so on. Each of the pieces of legislation covering those matters was resisted vehemently by some politicians, employer groups and professional groups, as well as some members of the general public. As Senator Peter Baume also said, learned and not so learned men asserted that allowing women to work, to own their own property after marriage, to earn and keep their wages, to enter contracts, to study and enter the professions, to vote, and so on, would lead to a range of socially catastrophic consequences, ranging from the breakdown of marriage, child neglect, atrophy of the uterus, inhibition of lactation, nervous breakdowns-which I do not doubt occurred but, I suspect, not in women-and depriving men of the jobs which were their natural born right.

For those who doubt the validity of the assertions that Senator Baume and I have made as to the nonsense that was talked about the likely social, personal and individual outcomes of this legislation, I suggest that they turn to the record of parliamentary debates, letters to newspapers, editorials and pamphlets distributed at the time because they show all too graphically how true are the statements that Senator Baume and I have made and how deeply entrenched were the prejudices. Sadly, some of those assertions are still being made in Australia in the 1980s. I refer anybody who is interested in pursuing this matter to the December 1983 debates on the Sex Discrimination Bill, in which we heard allegations of possible breakdowns of marriages if trucking companies were to send drivers of both sexes together on trips between Melbourne and Perth. We heard the more extraordinary example of what was likely to happen to the marriages of those Telecom employees of opposite sexes who were forced to work together underground with a pole between them. Anybody who thinks I am making that up or distorting the facts ought to have a look at the Committee stage debate on that legislation in December 1983. If people do not believe that in 1986 this is still the policy in some areas, I refer them to an article in the Canberra Times of 20 February of this year, in which Mr Ian Cameron, the honourable member for Maranoa, a member of the National Party from Queensland, is reported as saying on Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio:
. . . that as contemporary society was a consumer society, it made more sense to pay men more so that women would not be forced out to go to work.

``There are glossy magazines and radio and television all encouraging women to go out and take their place in the work force, but I believe governments should be spending money to encourage married women to stay at home'' . . .
``They could be making the kitchen a lot more attractive than what they're doing these days''.

I might add that not only did the honourable member run slap into the ire of people such as the Minister for Education, Senator Ryan, and me, but also I understand that his wife was not too happy either. While it may have been possible in a buoyant economy to defer to the somewhat fragile male egos that periodically pop up and allow arguments that women could not or would not do as well as men in many areas, even if one wants to leave aside the principle of the rightness of allowing choice and equal employment opportunity and if it is only economics that will get through to some people, we should realise that the fragility of the economy at the moment is such that business, industry and the public sector can no longer afford to ignore the talent and skills of half the population.

This sort of issue was raised with me earlier this year by a constituent. A metallurgist, who had a PhD, came into my office with some concern complaining that no one would employ her despite her overseas experience, her excellent references and her qualifications and despite the fact that her PhD involved original research in that discipline which had been put to practical use by industry in Britain. She could not get a job here, the reason being that she was a woman and the company she had approached had never employed a female metallurgist before and it did not want to start because the men might not like it. She was told that, anyway, a lot of travel was involved, and we all know that women are less mobile than men! Apparently, the fact that she was single and much more likely to be more mobile than many of the married male metallurgists counted for nought.

Whether some people want to acknowledge it or not, the fact remains that this kind of non-use of expertise, talent and experience means that businesses and industries are not maximising their opportunities to develop because they are ignoring the qualities, talents, capabilities and skills of half the work force. Providing employment, advancement, training and retraining, encouragement and extended opportunities to only one half of the population or the work force cuts employment opportunities by half. While some may prefer to keep the best jobs the exclusive preserve of men the country simply cannot afford it and women do not deserve it. They are entitled to be treated as people, not as some second rate group to be considered only after the needs of their betters are taken into account.

The Bill before us is at least a step in the right direction. However, it does have a considerable number of deficiencies which we want to address in amendments. The public reports required by the legislation should include reports on each of the eight steps of an organisation's affirmative action program, not just a general run down. The naming of employers who fail to submit reports as required by legislation should be mandatory. I imagine that the Government will probably name them in the Parliament. I suggest that that is likely to produce an elitist club that will probably rival the Melbourne Club comprising all the groups of employers who have thumbed their noses at the legislation and have been named in the Parliament. Employers who fail to meet their forward estimates without reasonable excuse ought to be named by the Director of Affirmative Action in the report he or she tables in the Parliament. The 28 companies which participated in the pilot program ought to be required to report at the same time as the higher education institutions; that is, at the first stage of implementation. Financial incentives could well be included, particularly with regard to tied grants for higher education institutions and, in particular, specially disadvantaged groups of women ought to be pinpointed in the legislation. There are something like 26 speakers on the second reading debate list and there is a day and a half left for debate. All I can say is this: We support this legislation in principle and in content but we would like to see it go further. If we cannot get the legislation through this session the alternative is to have it apply retrospectively to 1 August and we would certainly support-

TALK.START.PARA: —But you will not vote for that, will you, on principle? Let's gag it now.

—We have opposed punitive retrospectivity. If the honourable senator opposite thinks equal employment opportunity for women is punitive retrospectivity he will not shoot little barbs at me across the chamber about supporting legislation which would allow this Bill to apply retrospectively from 1 August.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak to the Affirmative Action (Equal Opportunity for Women) Bill today as Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate on behalf of National Party senators. I have no doubt that other senators will want to speak on the legislation if it is not pushed through as Government senators opposite were talking about earlier. However, the number of speakers in the present debate today is limited so I am just putting the National Party point of view.

SPEECH.PARA: The affirmative action, equal opportunity legislation, which is before us today, will cover all companies which employ more than 100 staff. The legislation requires that companies undertake a prescribed affirmative action program within a specified time-frame, reporting publicly both on compliance and confidentiality. The legislation requires employers to comply with certain prescribed steps, including the setting of objectives and forward estimates and prior consultation with trade unions. The legislation will establish a new statutory government agency within the portfolio of the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations to administer the legislation, assess the progress of programs, report annually to Parliament and conduct associated research. Initially, 25 people are to be employed to investigate 500 companies each employing over 1,000 people. This is estimated to cost $1.5m. I ask the Senate: How much will it cost to investigate the 5,000 companies in Australia which employ 100 people and over?

TALK.START.PARA: —Millions and millions of dollars.

—Indeed. I ask: Will it stop there? Maybe the Government will get down to firms employing 50 people and over; it is hard to know with this Government. Indeed, perhaps every business in Australia will have to do the same thing. I also draw the Senate's attention to the fact that clause 5 of this Bill invokes the use of an external treaty which will override State government legislation. This is something which every honourable senator worth his salt from every State should oppose--
—Or her salt.

—Or her salt. I suppose, seeing as this is an equal opportunity Bill I should say every honourable senator worth his or her salt. The Senate is supposed to be a House that protects State rights. It does not happen very often, though. I believe that the legislation is an unnecessary regulation of the private and tertiary education sector and it gives inordinate power to the trade unions.
—It will not affect the National Party. What are you worried about?

—This is a very important point. It amazes me that, when Australia needs more incentive for business, when the private sector needs assistance to go ahead and make it more efficient and provide jobs and job opportunities, the Government brings in legislation such as this that requires unnecessary regulation and more paperwork because that is what it will mean for business. Coming on top of the regulations and paperwork of the fringe benefits tax it is certainly enough to make all employers ask: `Is it worth it? Why bother?' This legislation will not create one more job or improve the efficiency of one more firm. Indeed, I feel that it is making a mockery of the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that business has to become more efficient. I feel that this type of enforced legislation will be counter-productive. Real social change cannot be enforced. It is best to proceed slowly via education, attitudinal change and independent acceptance. These changes are already occurring without legislation and without undue backlash.
—Where in Queensland?

—I can point to many people in Queensland who have excellent jobs. As a matter of fact, I cut an article out of the paper on Tuesday this week concerning Jan Taylor, who is the front person for the Queensland Consumer Affairs Bureau. I am quite sure that Senator Reynolds would want a consumer affairs bureau in Queensland. Jan Taylor, who is now the Assistant Commissioner of the Consumer Affairs Bureau, maintains:

SPEECH.PARA: `Affirmative action is only aimed at a small percentage of people. It doesn't address the nitty-gritty issues . . .
She said:
A lot of women will disagree with me-
of course, women senators opposite will do that-
but I think we can succeed without things like affirmative action. Women are in the minority in senior public-service positions--
Government senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators opposite can all make their own speeches. I just ask them to let me have a go. Jan Taylor continues:

SPEECH.PARA: Women are in the minority in senior public-service positions, but I don't think it helps to artificially push them up the ladder. From what I have seen of affirmative action in the States, that's what happens. And the result is a lot of resentment . . .

Changes are already occurring without legislation and without undue backlash as far as I am concerned. Legislation will inevitably encourage formal compliance in lieu of real commitment on the part of employers. To my way of thinking, it would be far more productive for people to accept equality of opportunity through education, encouragement and rewards rather than through enforced quotas and binding legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are not quotas.

—I am sure that the legislation will eventually come to that as it has in other places. This is a very important point for our women senators here today. In my opinion it is demeaning for a women to be given a job just because she is a woman rather than because of her ability and suitability for the job. The legislation says to me: `You are not good enough. You cannot make it on your own. You need artificial legislation to make you equal'.
—That is exactly how you got to be here. Your husband put you in against a sitting member.

—In the 1980s, more than ever before, doors are opening for women. If the honourable senator opposite would really like to know, I came to the Senate because the people of Queensland voted for me. That is how I came to the Senate. I would say that I am probably one of the best known women senators in this place. In the 1980s, more than ever before, doors are opening for women. In Australia, we have the first ever female Speaker of the House of Representatives, we have a woman Cabinet Minister in Queensland, two excellent women members in the Queensland Parliament and the National Party has a woman as its Federal President. That is more than honourable senators opposite can say about the Australian Labor Party. It has just got rid of Mr Wran, or he is going to resign, and it will put Mick Young in. It will not put in one of the women senators here who think, they are all doing a very excellent job, of course. I just say to honourable senators opposite that the National Party has a woman president. In Australia, we also have female judges, lawyers, business executives, scientists, surgeons, professors, teachers and politicians.
—And pilots.

—That is right. We have 15 women senators in the Senate. The woman pilot is doing a very good job for the Premier in Queensland; there is no doubt about that. We do not have 50 per cent of women senators but, after hearing some of the interjections from women senators today, I am very glad that we do not have any more of them. But certainly the number of women in the Senate and in the Parliament is increasing all the time. There are female truck drivers, bus drivers, jockeys, boilermakers, mechanics, labourers and airline pilots as has been mentioned. Everywhere we look, women are working hard and making an invaluable contribution to this country. In offices, in laboratories and factories, in social and political organisations, in local government, in service clubs, women are making their presence felt-and without an affirmative action and equal opportunity Bill, I might mention.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that if women have the ability they can get where they want to; that is obvious from what I have said. The whole subject of equal opportunity, sex discrimination and affirmative action is a very subjective one. Each of us is coloured by our own personal experiences in life. We must somehow strike a happy medium so that women are free to choose to pursue a career. But traditional family women who want to stay in the home and raise their families should also be encouraged to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nobody is stopping them.

—No. But, just as Senator Haines took us way back in time to what happened in the earlier days, I am just putting a point of view about which I feel very strongly. I support equal opportunity; I would be very silly if I did not as I am here as a senator. I have never found that I do not have equal opportunity in this place, although I must say that some honourable senators opposite are trying to stop me from having an equal opportunity today.

SPEECH.PARA: Affirmative action appears to me to enforce another form of discrimination with the quota system, forcing employers to employ a certain number of women regardless of talent or suitability. Allow me to say that not all women feel that they are discriminated against; but some do. Not all women want to achieve greatness in their careers.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will not worry you then.

—Some do not even want to have a career outside the home. My word, it is a good job that Senator Ray has a good wife at home looking after his family for him. There is certainly nothing wrong with that. I feel that the whole crux of the problem is one of how a woman can best reconcile her traditional and domestic role with her wider role outside the family. A growing number of women are choosing to pursue careers. Many of these are married women with families. Thirty-eight per cent of the total labour force in 1985 were women and 62.7 per cent of all female employees are in full time employment. Likewise, women comprise 79 per cent of the part time work force, with married women accounting for 58.2 per cent of all part time employees.

SPEECH.PARA: I accept that there are probably many women who work outside the home and do so out of sheer financial necessity these days. None of us needs to be reminded of just how difficult it is to manage these days with high inflation, excessive taxes and the very high cost of living caused in the main by the Labor Party that is in power at the moment. One wage really is not sufficient in many Australian households.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is three fibs.
—Your nose is growing.

—I have just touched a nerve over there. Because of the changing emphasis of society on the role of women, many women now feel forced both socially and economically into the paid work force. However, many are becoming disillusioned with the burden of trying to cope with a career, marriage and a family. The stress risks faced by these women are now recognised as a major health problem. It is really very hard to be the superwoman that the feminists think that all women should be. Those women who have chosen to care full time for their families have seen their role devalued by society as paid employment is promoted as the only method of achieving fulfilment.

SPEECH.PARA: I feel that the work performed by women at home needs to be recognised both socially and by some form of monetary compensation. This should increase the options available to those women who are now working out of economic necessity. It will give back to women in the home some sense of dignity and purpose. The Government should be looking at the provision of a homemaker allowance or at the splitting of family incomes. But, of course, nobody on the Government side will agree with that. It has always been the case in our society that women have traditionally taken on the responsibility for the young children and for the family-the role of the carer and the nurturer. The National Party believes that a recognition of the maternal and child rearing role that women have undertaken is very important not only to society but also because it has a very significant cultural, economic and social significance of its own. In this whole issue of legislating for affirmative action my biggest concern is for the family. We value the family in our own lives and for our children's future. Some of us fear that moves to legislate for affirmative action may occur at the expense of the traditional family and traditional family values.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I draw your attention to standing order 421 and ask you to draw the attention of the honourable senator to this standing order and to ask her to cease her continued irrelevance and tedious repetition.
—There is no point of order.
—I should think not. Thank you very much indeed, Madam Acting Deputy President. I am not quite sure how I am making tedious repetition.
—You are making good sense.

—I think so too. In my opinion the full time career of a mother and housewife is essential to the family unit and she should be supported by the Government. Time is the greatest changer of all things. I believe that, given a more enlightened education program, all people will accept that equal opportunity is a natural way of life and that women will be accepted into more and more demanding roles and environments because they are good, because they have the talent and because they are worthy of the job, rather than just because of legislation such as we are debating today.

SPEECH.PARA: True liberation means true freedom of choice, whether that choice is for paid or unpaid employment and whether it is employment in previously all male areas or in traditional female occupations. However, I do not believe that any government has the right to compel a private employer to employ certain kinds of people, as is the case in this legislation for affirmative action and equal opportunity that the Government has introduced. Our National Party has a free enterprise philosophy and I believe it is the right of a private employer to determine what constitutes maximum efficiency in his business. Perhaps the most important reason for opposition to affirmative action is the fact that affirmative action becomes reverse discrimination when persons who are alleged to have suffered a disadvantage are given special treatment and when merit and qualifications are bypassed in the process.

Affirmative action aims to eliminate inequality but, in addressing one problem, I believe it creates another in its place. Soon we will have men saying that they are discriminated against and that they want an affirmative action and equal opportunity Bill.

In the National Party we know that women are equal because they stand beside their men on the farms and in small businesses; they are part of the operation. They help to drive the tractors. They are the farm accountants. They help in small businesses by standing by their men; they do not need any legislation to tell them that they are equal partners. For these and other reasons that I have outlined, I and my National Party colleagues do not support affirmative action although we believe in equal opportunity for everyone, men and women. We do not see the need for this Bill and we do not support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to speak in this debate on the Affirmative Action (Equal Opportunity for Women) Bill 1986. I congratulate you, Madam Acting Deputy President, and Senator Peter Baume for your contributions to the debate. It is not often in this place that we have such broad agreement across the political spectrum on an issue as important as this. I certainly think that the contribution made by Senator Peter Baume through his service on the Representative Working Party on Affirmative Action Legislation is to be commended and I congratulate him on his contribution to the debate this afternoon. Senator Haines also made eminently good sense, as she always does when she speaks on this subject. However, I will refer to the other speaker in this debate a little later, because I would like first of all to take the opportunity to lead for the Government in this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: It is quite clear that this legislation has the support of the major political parties in this country; it has the support of the business sector; it has the support of the trade union movement; it has the support of higher education institutions. It certainly has the support of the women of Australia. I say to Senator Bjelke-Petersen that it has the support of the women of Queensland. I will be in a better position, when I continue my remarks later, to detail the extent of that support in Queensland. All major national women's organisations support the legislation we are debating today. At the National Agenda for Women Conference held in Canberra in April 1986, 500 women representing up to 100 organisations from throughout the country passed with acclamation the following resolution:
That the Federal Government be commended for maintaining its commitment to introduce affirmative action.

I take this opportunity to commend the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women, Senator Susan Ryan, the staff of the Office of the Status of Women, and the Working Party, which was representative of the Government, the Opposition, business, trade unions, women's organisations and higher education. I especially commend the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) because it was the Prime Minister who actually introduced this legislation in the House of Representatives.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—Some members of the Opposition, particularly Senator Boswell, may snigger at that, but I am sure that the women of Australia have taken note that the Prime Minister placed such high priority on this legislation that he himself introduced it in the House of Representatives.
—He should be giving priority to the state of the economy. We are going down the drain.
—The women of Queensland, in particular, will note Senator Boswell's comments because his Party does not even have a women's policy in that State.
—We treat them like men.
—You treat them like animals. I will deal with that later. The Prime Minister, in his speech introducing the legislation in the House of Representatives on 19 February this year, said:

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation is necessary to ensure that all large employers take seriously their obligations to their women employees. The changing role of women in our society is reflected, to a large extent, in the changing patterns in the work force. The Government is determined that women should be able to enter and compete in the labour market on an equal footing with men and that outdated prejudices or conventions should not prevent them from fully participating. Neither individual employers nor the nation can afford to waste the valuable contributions which women can, and do, make to our economy.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans) agreed to:
That, unless otherwise ordered, till 2 p.m. this day, matters of public interest may be discussed by senators, provided that no senator shall speak for more than 15 minutes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night the Prime Minister of Australia (Mr Hawke) gave an address to the nation. The address had been heralded as being of great significance to every person in this country. It has today been roundly condemned by every section of the community-by the trade unions, by businesses, by social service workers and, indeed, by all the media. It has been condemned roundly also in other countries of the world.

SPEECH.PARA: To understand what has happened one must look at the background and understand that for three years the Hawke Labor Government has said to the people of Australia: `Everything is all right. We have a sound economy; you are secure, your wages and conditions are secure'. This went on until a month ago and then suddenly, when the Prime Minister was overseas, the Treasurer, Mr Keating, reacted to adverse balance of trade figures and said that there was a critical situation which could lead Australia to be a banana republic or like a Third World country. Suddenly, a matter which the day before had been all rosy and meant prosperity for all Australians became a very serious matter indeed. The Government cannot have it both ways. Either it was right in the past and therefore is wrong in the present, or the situation is the other way round.

Mr Keating and his colleagues then set up a business and trade union summit to look at the matter and to tackle the great issues of the day. The Prime Minister was away. He reacted angrily to his Treasurer and came back. Mr Hawke, who had been impotent in these matters and who has always gone against the Treasurer and made deals behind the scenes with the Australian Council of Trade Unions, decided to cancel the summit and to give an address to the nation. So we had last night the projection of an address to the nation by the Prime Minister. His aim was to tell the people of Australia what was happening in Australia and the solutions to it. He did neither last night, and the tragedy is that we saw once again a Prime Minister who resorts to rhetoric and personal appeals, makes great promises and tries to talk things up on a grand scale but is in fact impotent within his own Party, within the Government of Australia when it comes both to projecting the truth and to facing up to the situation.

What are the facts? What did he say last night? He said last night that there had been a 3 per cent decline in the value of our export earnings and that therefore the living standards of all the people of Australia had to be reduced. This was fascinating, but for three years the story was that the living standards of the people of Australia would be preserved or rising. Suddenly, within days, the situation is such that the living standards have to be reduced. Why is that? It is because there is an adverse balance of trade, according to Mr Hawke, caused by a decline in primary industry. But, of course, the adverse balance of trade in terms of the earnings of primary industry has been going on for years. There is nothing new about it. The figures themselves were reflected and anticipated in the Budget months beforehand. There is nothing new, nothing new at all.

In any case, that was only a fraction of the truth. What was the truth? We are dealing with a symptom-the balance of trade-and not the cause. The crunch of the matter is that Australia has become totally uncompetitive with overseas countries. The unit costs of production in Australia are so high that we have costed ourselves out of world markets. The fact is that our manufacturing industry has declined year by year. Throughout the whole of the years of the Hawke Government manufacturing industry has shed employment. Unemployment in manufacturing has grown and our ability to stem the tide of imports has failed. Therefore, two things have happened. We have an adverse balance of trade because we are paying enormous amounts for imports, and we have no manufacturing industry to provide jobs for the 600,000 unemployed because our costs are too high.

The tragedy of the situation is that our costs are too high even though there has been a 30 per cent devaluation of the dollar-a judgment by the world about Australia, a judgment that Australia's economy had to be deflated 30 per cent. Even though that 30 per cent provided an extra tariff protection, manufacturing industry in Australia has been incapable, for a number of very important reasons, of competing with imports. The other side of the coin was not told, that being the fact that our unit costs of production are the central cause of this situation.

The Prime Minister went on to say that we will have to take a reduction in our living standards. I believe that it is the most outrageous statement I have heard from a government. It cannot decide suddenly, in one day, that what was rosy yesterday is to mean a reduction in living standards tomorrow. That is a quite outrageous proposition. If the Government knew that this decline was taking place, why were these actions not taken months or years earlier? Why were not the people of Australia told months earlier or years earlier?

The Prime Minister cannot have it both ways. He cannot say that this Government was right in its first three years whereas in fact they were three years of decay and degeneration, three years of failure to tell the truth to the people of Australia. We have been subjected to a pretence that here was a government making a consensus with the people and overcoming conflict when, in fact, there was the most major confrontation. A bargain was made behind the scenes with the trade union movement in confrontation with the rest of the community-with manufacturing industry, with the employees in shops, offices and factories; and with the pensioners and all others. Here was a situation of pretence. We were told that all would be all right because of the accord, yet the accord was based upon the indexation of wages through the consumer price index, a process which simply indexed inflation and kept the inflation rate in Australia throughout the whole of this period about three times higher than those of our trading partners.

This situation of pretence has gone on for three years, but the day of judgment has come. Even when the day of judgment came the Prime Minister and his Treasurer would not and could not tell the people the truth. The simple truth is that under this Government there has been a building up of costs through extra government charges, a failure on the part of government to see the competitive world around us, the imposition on industry of taxes such as the prospective fringe benefits and capital gains taxes and the crowding of industry so that competition could not survive. As a result, Australia has gone under in comparison with the rest of the world.

Fundamentally, the thing that to me is thoroughly ugly is the fact that the Government's solution is not a constructive one. It says: `All you people have to suffer because of what we have done; you have got to take a reduction in your living standards'. But that was never necessary. It would never have been necessary if there had been an honest approach to this situation over the months and the years.

How can Australia achieve a better competitive situation? How can we get costs down and quality up? It is not necessarily by the slashing of wages and working conditions, which now is inevitable. Let us not forget that is the solution the Government is now proposing. The absolute inevitability of that solution has been brought about because the Government has failed to say to the people of Australia: `If unit costs of production are as substantially high as they are, there are two ways in which to deal with them'. The first is the positive way-a constructive, co-operative teamwork between management and worker, an understanding that only by co-operation between the two will productivity get up and wages and living standards be preserved, an understanding that by getting productivity up and costs down the 600,000 people now out of jobs will be able to get jobs.

There has not been a squeak of a message for three years about the fundamental fact that the solution to Australia's present ailment is increased productivity through getting governments off people's backs and off the backs of industry and commerce; freeing up the situation to allow for better industrial arrangements between boss and worker; providing incentives so that workers can strive and gain more; and telling workers that the ugly, socialist idea of class conflict must go and that in its place, as is the case in all the countries we are competing with, must be a co-operative society.

It was left to the former General Secretary of the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia, Charlie Fitzgibbon, to say to the Economic Planning Advisory Council that we had to change from a confrontationist society to a co-operative society. It was left for him to say that it is no good hiding behind the fact that others outside Australia receive lower wages. He said: `Look here, the countries you are competing with now have higher wages than Australia'. That is not the answer. The answer is fundamental. It is fundamental that in those countries management and worker co-operate. They work as a team and productivity is high. In other words, the unit cost of production is lower.

The alternative is what the Government is doing. We can simply do nothing. As a result, living standards will fall, there will be more unemployment, wages will be cut and so on. Of course we must come out now saying emphatically that for the time being, for the years ahead at least, the superannuation scheme cannot be imposed on Australia's cost structure. We have to face up to the whole question of whether Australia can afford the productivity increases for the moment. The Government now says, as its only solution: `We have to discount wages'. This is a government which in opposition fought against the Fraser Government's wage freeze back in 1982-the wage freeze which, in fact, brought inflation down.

Here is a government groping. It has done a terrible thing. It should have said to the people of Australia: `We are going to ask bosses, workers-everybody-to take restraints, but before we do that we will do what is fair and equitable. We have promised to give tax cuts on 1 September, and we will give those tax cuts. That will establish the equity of the situation. Having established that equity, having given people relief of an average of $9 a week as promised, and as we have the money for it-there is no alibi about that-we will then ask for restraints on other matters, such as the deferral of national wage cases and so on'. But the Government has not said that. The Government which poses as supporting the ordinary working person has in fact slid the tax cuts away for months, and on what basis? It is saying: `Let the people pay in tax cuts for fixing our deficit, rather than our being efficient as a government'.

It was exposed last night that a Prime Minister cannot have as his only resource or depend only on some capacity to present some kind of charismatic rhetoric to the people of Australia. Ultimately they will look through that; they will look through the television screen and want to say: `Fine words, but tell us the truth. What are you doing? How did it happen? How could this accident happen when you told us it would not, that everything was beautiful? Why are you now saying that we must reduce our living standards? Why are you putting a gimmick into this situation?'.

The Government has always railed against any kind of idea that those who are unemployed ought to be put into some kind of constructive employment. The Government which opposed that proposition in season and out of season needed a gimmick, so it used one. Mr Hawke put it in his speech, but he did not know what it meant. Today all the learned people such as the leaders of churches and social security organisations are saying: `This is wrong. By all means give people constructive, meaningful work. By all means teach people to upgrade their education, but do not engage in a leaf-scraping, town hall-painting pretext because you will then be confessing total and ultimate failure. You will then be confessing that you cannot create any more jobs but in fact are losing jobs and that the best thing you can do is engage in some kind of pretence or leaf-scraping'.

That is the picture of last night. It is a tragedy. Leadership in this country will come not from that kind of message but from a message telling the truth to the people of Australia. The Government has costed itself out of world markets. If we want constructive jobs for those 600,000 unemployed, if we want to preserve living standards, let us get together. Let us get together and work as a team to get productivity up. If we can do that, if we can get costs down, we can not only prevent a further decline in living standards but also get jobs for the 600,000 people who are out of work.

Last night the Prime Minister touched upon things, and very quickly the ACTU said: `No more discounting of wages'. The man who said that he could get consensus was shown confrontation straight away. Why is it that, his speech having been made around the world, the world judged the speech to be no good? Why is it that the value of the dollar fell in England as against sterling and in an enormous way in Japan as against the yen? It is because the people of the world looked behind the pretence of words and said: `This is a failure of a Prime Minister with a failure of a policy. The implementation of these words rather than constructive action will cause in Australia a decline and very great danger, so we put a lower value on your Australian dollar'? Mr Hawke last night put far too low a value on the quality of the Australian people. They will see through what he has said and they will react, as they have done today, violently and vigorously against it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should have liked to consider the questions raised by Senator Sir John Carrick, but the matter that I am required to raise at this point cannot be raised at any other time before the Senate rises. I will explain why. First of all, I place on record my appreciation of Senator Vigor and Senator McKiernan yielding to me on this subject while the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans), who represents the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), is in the chamber. I am sure that the issues will be of interest to Senator Peter Baume also, as they relate to sex discrimination legislation. Actions in direct compliance with Commonwealth, State or Territory legislation which were in force when the Sex Discrimination Act commenced on 1 August are, by virtue of section 40 of that Act, exempt from the provisions of the Act even where what is done is inconsistent with provisions in Division 1 or Division 2 of the Act.
—Is that for a limited time?

—Yes. After 1 August 1986 the exemption provided by section 40 will in effect terminate insofar as the Government declines or refuses to exercise before 1 August 1986 the power given by section 40 to make regulations continuing the exemptions after that date. The Minister has said that a small number of discriminatory provisions in Commonwealth legislation will be preserved by regulations. At this stage it is surely appropriate, indeed necessary, that the Minister identify to the Senate which discriminatory provisions in Commonwealth legislation will be preserved by regulations, and which will not. We have only two days before the Senate rises. The task of identifying discriminatory provisions in the enormous mass of Commonwealth legislation is one which must be performed by government for its own purposes and which in practical terms can be performed only by government.

SPEECH.PARA: I am asking the Minister and the Government to supply to all senators a list showing, first of all, all discriminatory provisions in Commonwealth legislation which would cease to be operative on and from 1 August 1986 if regulations were not made under section 40 of the Sex Discrimination Act, and, secondly, all discriminatory provisions that the Government presently proposes to continue in force by regulations under section 40. I feel that the Minister and the Government should also supply to the Senate separate lists with respect to legislation in force in each State and Territory because in this, the States' House, the Government has an obligation to inform senators which State legislation is to be overridden by the Sex Discrimination Act, especially where, as here, the Government has the power by regulation to suspend the overriding operation of the Sex Discrimination Act. It is not at all clear which laws will be overridden by the Sex Discrimination Act if no regulations are made under section 40, or what will be the effect of overriding some of them.

Let us take, for example, section 66 of the Evidence Ordinance of the Australian Capital Territory, which provides that in a criminal proceeding the husband and wife of the person charged are competent witnesses but, except in a very narrow range of cases, not compellable witnesses. Will the Sex Discrimination Act have the effect of making a party to a marriage both competent and compellable as a witness in all criminal proceedings against the party's spouse?

TALK.START.PARA: —You are asking this of the Minister, are you not?

—Yes. I think this is a very vital point. If so, is that a desired and desirable result? Section 134 of the Real Property Ordinance of the Australian Capital Territory provides for the marriage of a female proprietor to be certified to the Registrar and for the register to be amended accordingly. There must be a host of other provisions in legislation of the Commonwealth and the States and Territories which will be affected by the Sex Discrimination Act when the sunset provisions in section 40 operate from 1 August 1986. That, as I said, is only one and a half sitting days away. Parliament will be rising, presumably, tomorrow afternoon.
—I have got the fingers crossed.

—I have only half a minute to go. I urge the Government to extend by general regulations the operation of paragraph (a) and (b) of sub-section 40 (1) of the Act. During the period of that extension the Government should publish lists of the legislation of the Commonwealth, the States and the Territories that would be overridden when the regulations expired, and it should indicate which pieces of legislation the Government proposes should continue to be protected from being overridden by the Sex Discrimination Act. The public could then make useful contributions to the ultimate decision-making process on which laws should be, and which need not be, protected from being overridden by the Sex Discrimination Act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to canvass a matter which has been brought into focus for me by the discussions associated with the self-government proposals for Canberra which have been put forward by the Government and to canvass some of the ideas associated with electoral systems and how fair particular electoral systems are. One of the things that we take for granted in a democracy is our ability to influence the political processes at election time. However, I believe that in the proposals for self-government in the Australian Capital Territory, put before the Parliament by the Hawke Government this year that particular right would have been denied to Canberrans. This is why the Senate has taken the strong stand that it has in saying that it would pass the self-government legislation only if a proper electoral system were provided for.

SPEECH.PARA: In practice, a person's fundamental right to influence the political process at election time depends very much on where the person or the elector concerned lives, because most of the seats are safe for one party or another. Indeed, this has been so in the circumstances that have prevailed until now. In the 1984 general election the efforts of 3,827,118 voters were completely futile. They managed to record a formal vote but they voted for a candidate who was defeated and their ballot papers were not examined at all for second or later preferences. These totally unsatisfied voters comprised over 44 per cent of those who recorded a formal vote.

I am certain that this lack of representation bedevils our political system. It means that large parts of the nation are ignored because there are no seats that can change hands. Sometimes the problem in those areas do not get any attention because a government does not believe it can ever get one of its own people elected there. At other times the neglect is because the local member uses the safety of that seat to indulge in other political games and ignore his or her constituency. In other cases the local member loses out to those in marginal seats when the pork barrel comes out, and hence the political process is distorted.

In these safe areas the political process usually revolves around getting and retaining the preselection. For instance, the electors of Bass Hill in New South Wales have not had a resident local member since 1971 and on current indications they are unlikely to have one for quite a while. Similarly, there is quite a deal of jockeying over who will get the Liberal plum-I refer to the Federal seat of Wentworth-once the present incumbent retires. I do not believe that the presence of such safe seats encourages real democracy. Ordinary voters feel that they are basically rubber-stamping the work of a panel of preselectors. The opportunity for public input at this level is severely limited.

This is not at all the situation in the Tasmanian election where the Hare-Clark system operates for the election of the House of Assembly. No seat is safe under that remarkably robust and fair system of proportional representation. There is very little need for boundaries to be redrawn and usually 90 per cent or more of the voters get satisfaction from their vote; that is, they get someone they voted for. The same electorates are used for the House of Assembly as for the House of Representatives. Each of those electorates returns seven members. This means, under the quota-preferential system of proportional representation that operates there, that any candidate who gets 12.5 per cent of the vote-just over one-eighth of the total formal votes cast-is guaranteed election. It also means that parties with a majority of the vote will obtain a majority of members in any seat, which is not the case in some other systems available.

At the last general election the Liberal Party won 19 seats, one for each of 7,300 voters, and the Australian Labor Party won 14 seats, one for each 6,400 voters. The Labor Party received under 35 per cent of the vote and would have been wiped out under a single member district system. However, the Labor Party retained fair representation under the Hare-Clark system and in fact in Tasmania is a viable opposition. It is this type of system that we were proposing for the residents of Canberra. They have, in fact, had a PR system in the past. We were hoping to improve it through the amendments that we planned to move to the Australian Capital Territory Council Bill to make it work. However, we are not being given a chance to move those amendments as the Bill is not being raised in the Senate. I continue with the electoral system. It is interesting that at the previous Tasmanian election in 1982 there were also 19 Liberals and 14 Labor members returned. The Liberals won one seat for every 6,400 supporters and Labor won one seat for every 6,600 voters. This is clearly as near to one vote, one value as one can get. I will come to some examples in the other system where this is completely out of kilter. Furthermore, the Tasmanian voters brought 17 members into the Parliament-two to replace retiring candidates and 15 in place of defeated candidates. That is what I mean when I say that there were no safe seats. The Hobart Mercury's editorial of 17 February was titled `Parliament got a house cleaning'. Part of this editorial read:

Casualties came from both Liberal and Labor ranks and included some surprises, but all in all, the electors of this State showed great perception in choosing from the many candidates people of proven skills and enthusiasm. People seen as ideologues, and others who have been given a chance and who had not performed up to expectation were cast-off by the electorate in an unprecedented shakeup, given more emphasis by the fact that it did not involve the defeat of a government or a major transfer in the balance of power.
I believe that that is exactly what the voters want in an electoral system. Later in the editorial we had these comments:

It is a tribute to the fine-tuning under the Hare-Clark multi-member electorate system that the voters can judge individuals harshly but still retain the same balance between the parties in the Parliament. Parties can guide the choice of electors but not absolutely as they can in single-member electorates, where often a voter is forced to back a candidate he does not like if he is to support an ideology which matches his convictions.

We note that in the last House of Representatives election many people deliberately spoilt their ballot papers because they could not find anybody worth voting for. That is an indictment of the system. What actually makes the Tasmanian system work apart from the quality of its voters? The crucial factor is that the parties cannot present a fixed slate of candidates. They do not specify an order in which names are to appear on the ballot paper. In fact, it was a private member's Bill sponsored by Neil Robson, which was passed in 1979 in Tasmania, which ensured that this would not happen. Every candidate endorsed by a party gets equal access to the best places in the party's column. This is achieved by rotating the order of names within the column and printing quite a few different batches of ballot papers. The party column remains in the same place but the order of names changes from ballot paper to ballot paper. This means that the party machine cannot control who gets elected and who does not. This is extremely important.

This procedure was used for the first time in February 1980 in the Denison by-election which was precipitated by court findings that candidates had overspent on their election campaigns. The interesting thing is that the seven candidates elected showed quite a deal of stability in their support, no matter in which position they appeared within their party column. Unsuccessful candidates relied a lot more on the top position for their vote. In other words, voters are quite able to pick and choose. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a table which shows the relative support for each candidate in each position within the party or group column.
