TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. This Denison by-election arose in most unusual circumstances. Ordinarily, Tasmanians do not return to the ballot boxes if a place in the House of Assembly becomes vacant. This is a way of saving money. It was among the proposals we were putting forward for the Australian Capital Territory. The ballot papers for the outgoing candidate are re-examined to see whom the voters who have lost their representative want to put in as a replacement. The process is orderly; it avoids the nonsense we saw surrounding the Lowe and Flinders by-elections in 1982 and the Scullin by-election earlier this year. Money is not wasted on a pointless exercise. For instance, the Labor Party did not even bother to run candidates for the recent Pittwater and Vaucluse by-elections in New South Wales.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that the Tasmanian approach could be improved if the ballot papers re-examined were all those without representation in the first place; in other words, those who failed to get a representative at the general election should not be automatically excluded as they are in the Tasmanian system. The principle should carry over to single member districts also, I believe, even if we cannot go the full way towards one vote, one value. It would certainly avoid the extravagance that goes with the current exercise. It would also force parties to offer more than one candidate. That would make branch stacking less important in terms of preselecting candidates, because the voters would decide who was going to be elected. We would find that the Government would go on with the job of running the country without worrying or being distracted by by-elections.

Earlier I mentioned that the one vote, one value figures for Tasmanian Hare-Clark elections were excellent. When we look at non-proportional representation systems we find that one vote, one value is a fraud. For instance, in New South Wales, which is taken as a model by some people, in 1984 the Liberal Party obtained one seat for each 44,000 voters while Labor needed 25,000 supporters for each seat and the Nationals, 22,000 voters. That was actually in a good year. In 1981 the Liberal Party obtained one seat for every 55,000 supporters. At the same time, less than 23,000 supporters each were needed by the Labor and National parties. However, the boot has been on the other foot at other times. For instance, in 1975 Labor received 42.8 per cent of the vote and won 36 House of Representative seats. The Liberals received 41.8 per cent of the vote and won 68 seats. There was a reduction in electoral enrolment tolerance to 10 per cent for the 1977 elections but the same misrepresentation occurred. Labor received 39.6 per cent of the vote and won 38 seats while the Liberals took 67 seats on 38.1 per cent of the vote. This is certainly not one vote, one value. The only way to achieve one vote, one value is to have a quota-preferential proportional representation system. That is what the Australian Democrats are proposing for Canberra. I believe that we should stand firm on this matter to make certain that the people of Canberra have an electoral system of which they can be proud and which allows them to change the people who govern them if they choose.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today must be the day for talking about electoral reform because that is the subject that I also wish to raise in this public interest debate this afternoon. The question of electoral reform in my home State of Western Australia has been the subject of great controversy in recent years, but I am thankful to say that it is one that looks like being resolved to the satisfaction of the majority of the citizens of Western Australia in the very near future.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not seeking in this address to skite or score political points because the matter is close to resolution. What I will be doing is accepting the will of the people of Western Australia who clearly expressed themselves in the ballot box in February of this year, to the effect that they wanted and needed some form of electoral reform. In doing so I will be acknowledging that the Liberal Party, the chief Opposition party in Western Australia, has now accepted that there is a need for reform. It released its policy on this matter only this week. It is a welcome statement. It is long overdue. There are still significant differences between what has been proposed by the Liberal Party and what has been proposed by the Western Australian Government. The National Party, which is now a significant force in the Western Australian Parliament, has also put forward different proposals.

I am not seeking to use this debate to analyse or compare the different submissions being put forward. That is more rightly done, and will be done, in the Parliament of Western Australia. I have no doubt that the argument will range far and wide in the coming weeks and months. Hopefully, a satisfactory degree of concensus and goodwill will prevail between all and we will get some semblance of electoral reform, some equal weighing of votes, for people in Western Australia in the very near future and certainly before the next election.

Each political party-I have mentioned three of them-has come forward with different suggestions. Each party has accepted that because of the size of the State and the uneven distribution of population centres there will be a weighting of votes in favour of rural or non-metropolitan areas. Honourable senators will appreciate that Western Australia covers approximately one-third of this continent and there are vast distances and very lightly populated centres across the whole of the State.

The ratios suggested for the weighting of votes are different, but not drastically so. The National Party is proposing a 2:1 ratio, the Liberals are suggesting a ratio of 1.8:1, and the Government's suggestion is 1.4:1.There is a difference of less than one vote between what has been proposed by all major parties. Even so, some people in Western Australia, certainly within my Party, will not be completely happy with what has been put forward and the fact that we seem to be moving away from the concept of one vote, one value.

It is worth noting that even if we end up with what is perhaps the worst of the proposals-the 2:1 ratio proposed by the Nationals-it is going to be an enormous movement from what we currently experience. In the House of Assembly elections the ratio is 7 1/2:1 and in the Legislative Council elections the ratio is in the region of 10 1/2:1-10 1/2 votes to the value of one-depending on the area of the State.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Tasmania having six senators, the same as New South Wales?

—I am addressing a State matter now. I think I will stay with the State matter, otherwise we might get into confusion with some of the things raised by Senator Vigor, who preceded me in this debate. By way of background, the Western Australian Parliament consists of two Houses-the Legislative Council and the Legislative Assembly. The State is divided into three areas. The lines that divide the three districts are drawn by the Parliament itself, not by independent electoral commissioners. There are political dangers in this and the parliamentarian with a vested interest in it could draw lines to suit himself. Indeed, accusations have been made that this has in fact happened. The three areas are the metropolitan area, which consists of 30 Assembly seats and seven Legislative Council provinces; the agricultural, mining and pastoral area, which contains 23 Assembly seats and eight Council provinces; and the north-west and Murchison area, which consists of four Assembly seats and one Council province. That makes up a total of 57 Assembly seats and members and 34 Assembly Council members, because each Council province elects two Council members.

SPEECH.PARA: Those figures lead to a great disproportion in the representation of the people of Western Australia. The metropolitan area as defined by the lines on the electoral map drawn by the Parliament itself consists of 68 per cent of the number of enrolments in the whole of the State. That 68 per cent has the opportunity of electing only 52.6 per cent of the Assembly seats. It is a majority, but it is nowhere near the representation deserved.

The situation is vastly different as regards the Council. The metropolitan area, with 68 per cent of the enrolments, elects only 41 per cent of the Council members. So there is a great chance that the rural area, with only 41 per cent representation, could control the House of Assembly if the representatives were elected on a party basis, which does not always happen because of our Party's good rural policies in Western Australia.

The average enrolment in the metropolitan area is 20,122 electors. In the rural area the average enrolment per seat is 10,585 electors. To get that into some perspective in order to do some comparisons, the State average enrolment is 15,581, so neither the metropolitan nor the rural average comes anywhere close to meeting the State average. That leads to a great disproportion in the number of electors per seat. The number of electors in the seat that contains the highest Assembly vote-that is, the seat of Murdoch-is 92.4 per cent higher than the State average. The number in the seat with the lowest enrolment, which is Murchison-Eyre, is 74.9 per cent below the State average. In the elections for the Commonwealth House of Representatives and for most State parliaments, the electoral enrolments may vary by only 10 per cent but we see that enrolments in Western Australia vary on the plus side by over 90 per cent and on the minus side by 75 per cent.

For the Council provinces the problem is graver. The average enrolment in the metropolitan area is 86,237 electors. In the rural area it comes right back to 28,443 electors, and the State average is 52,241. The seat with the highest number of voters-North-East Metropolitan province-has an average enrolment which is 87.9 per cent greater than the average State enrolment, a percentage that enables misrepresentation. On the reverse side, the seat with the lowest number of electors, Lower North, has an average which is 82.6 per cent below the State average. It would be possible for the four Legislative Council provinces with the lowest enrolments together to contain a lower number of electors than the single province with the highest enrolment. The four provinces with the lowest votes elect eight representatives. They can do that now with 87,792 as compared with North-East Metropolitan province with 98,186 enrolments.

Even within the boundaries of individual Council provinces there is great disproportion. Within the South-East Metropolitan province, which contains four Assembly seats, the seat with the highest number, being 29,979, contains 10,000 more voters than the seat with the lowest number, which is Canning with 19,489. In the province in which I have great interest, and not just because I live there, North Metropolitan province, the Assembly seat with the highest number of electors, Joondalup, which is very capably represented by my beautiful wife, Jackie Watkins, contains 29,067 voters. The lowest seat, Scarborough, contains only 17,825 voters. That is a difference of over 11,000 voters. I could give other examples that would establish the clear need that has now been accepted-I acknowledge that-for electoral reform in Western Australia.

Let us give just a thought on the dividing lines on the map done by the Parliament itself. It is provided in legislation that the lines dividing the four Assembly seats in the North-West Murchison-Eyre province are drawn by the Parliament. There is an enormous disproportion in the number of electors in each seat. Kimberley, which is by far and away the most distant seat from Perth-it is nearly as far from Perth to Kununurra as it is from Perth to Sydney or Perth to Canberra-contains 18,300 voters. It is larger than many metropolitan-based seats.

In conclusion, I pay a tribute to the Deputy Premier of Western Australia and current Minister for Parliamentary and Electoral Reform, Mal Bryce, for bringing about our achievement in that satisfaction is close even if it is not yet achieved.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Arthur Tonkin? Are you going to give him a guernsey?

—I am certainly going to give Arthur Tonkin a guernsey. Arthur Tonkin did work, but before I move on to him let me say a few more words about Mal. Mal will be remembered not only for being Minister for Parliamentary and Electoral Reform in a government that achieves a measure of parliamentary and electoral reform in Western Australia, but also as a former Prime Minister's favourite Mal. I am talking now of Gough Whitlam, who often uses that expression when he meets up with Mal. Of course the staff who work with Mal Bryce in his department at the moment also have to be included in that tribute. Arthur Tonkin, whom Senator Crichton-Browne mentioned a moment ago, is a former Minister for Parliamentary and Electoral Reform, and as I recall he was also a shadow Minister for that portfolio. Arthur pursued the quest for electoral reform with a vengeance, one might say; he certainly did not give up. I am certain his resignation from the Cabinet over differences of opinion-I am not fully informed on what those differences were-has been a loss to the Cabinet of the Western Australian Government. I will refrain from saying anything of Senator Crichton-Browne; he is getting his name in the paper too often at the moment because of things that are happening within the Liberal Party in Western Australia. I will not say anything about that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish in the short time available to me to speak on the effect on schools of the Federal Government's fringe benefits tax and to discuss the impact it will have on education, particularly in Western Australia. As a consequence of the Government imposing that fringe benefits tax on employers, it will tax institutions which under normal taxation arrangements would not be taxed. We have already seen, of course, that the Government was prepared to impose a tax on charity. Under the fringe benefits tax legislation, if there had not been an effective Opposition in this place, this Government, the Government which tries to claim some affinity with the poor and underprivileged in our society, would have imposed a fringe benefits tax on the Red Cross Society, the Smith Family and the churches which provide accommodation for the elderly. Happily this has been prevented but there still remains the fact that fringe benefit taxes will be imposed upon schools.

SPEECH.PARA: On 17 October the Treasurer, Mr Keating, clearly stated the Government's intention to impose a fringe benefits tax on schools when he admitted in a response to a question by the honourable member for Forrest, Mr Peter Drummond, that the tax would hit schools, both public and private. The main impact of the fringe benefits tax will be on schools which provide accommodation for members of staff. This may be provided for members of staff so that they can supervise children who board at school, or it may be provided in remote areas simply to attract teachers to isolated schools. The tax will also be levied on the provision of air fares for teachers who are posted to remote schools. In hitting these benefits the fringe benefits tax will hit Western Australia, particularly the private schools of Western Australia, more adversely than States such as New South Wales and Victoria. It will also hit a particular category of schools; that is, schools in remote areas. In so doing it will worsen the situation for a section of education which is already regarded as disadvantaged.

Western Australia is Australia's largest and least densely populated State. As the last speaker, Senator McKiernan, said, it occupies one third of Australia's land mass and has only 8.9 per cent of the population. It therefore comes as no surprise that it has a higher dependence on boarding accommodation for children than States such as New South Wales and Victoria. In 1984 11,853 children boarding at schools throughout Australia were in receipt of assistance under the isolated children's assistance scheme. Of these children 30 per cent, or some 3,600, were from Western Australia.

When schools provide accommodation for children who are forced to board they must of course also provide accommodation for one or more of the teachers to live at the schools to supervise. If they did not, of course, it is most likely that should an accident occur to the children who are boarding, the school would in some way be held liable, as a result of negligence, for failing to provide adequate supervision. When a teacher lives in at a school, that school, whether public or private, will under the legislation recently passed be liable to a fringe benefit tax. Based on the statutory formula in the Bill the tax could cost the schools $1,640 per member of staff per year if no rent is paid by the school teacher. While this tax will affect both public and private schools, its impact will be proportionately more on non-government schools than it will be on government schools. Using the figures of the isolated children's assistance scheme again, some 64 per cent of boarders in receipt of benefits were boarding at non-government schools. This is in contrast to the fact that only 25 per cent of children attend non-government schools.

A considerable number of schools will be hit by this tax. In Western Australia the Roman Catholic school system, for instance, runs 12 schools where boarding takes place, and 1,406 children board in those schools. The tax will also affect schools such as Santa Maria at Attadale, where about 100 children board and several members of staff live in to provide supervision. Such a school, to name only one, may face several thousand dollars in fringe benefits taxes.

The other way in which schools will be affected is if they provide accommodation to attract teachers to the area. One of the most ludicrous effects of this tax could be on the Aboriginal school at Turkey Creek. That school teaches about 50 children, mainly of Aboriginal descent. It charges no fees and it is so isolated that the Catholic education system has to provide a caravan to the teacher as accommodation. Incredible as it might seem, that caravan will be liable to the fringe benefits tax if the school is not charging the market rate for caravans at Turkey Creek. Such is the ludicrous position of the fringe benefits taxation arrangements recently passed. Flights home for the teachers at these schools will also be taxed in the same way as travel for employees of mining companies is liable. Schools may also be liable for the fringe benefit tax if they provide education for the children of teachers at the school at a rate lower than for members of the public.

The notion of taxing schools is quite unbelievable, to say the least. Historically schools have always been exempt from tax, in the same way that charities have been exempt. This is because governments in previous times have recognised that education benefits the whole community in addition to benefiting the individual. Not only has this Government overthrown this principle by introducing a fringe benefits tax in a way that will affect schools, but no consideration has been given to how the schools will actually pay the taxes.

The tax will have the greatest impact upon private schools. Despite what the Government would like the community to believe, most private schools are not extremely wealthy. The schools are not necessarily overflowing with funds, and the parents who send their children to these schools are not necessarily wealthy. In fact, 56 per cent of children who attend private schools have working mothers. In most cases children are sent to private schools because the parents have a genuine commitment to their children and are prepared to make a great sacrifice to enable their children to have the best education, to be exposed to the widest curricula and to be able to have religious instruction. For example, in the Catholic system the highest fees charged in Western Australia are slightly under $5,000, including board, and at Turkey Creek, which I have already mentioned, there are no fees charged at all.

It may surprise most people to learn that the general level of resources of non-government schools is lower than for government schools. In 1984 the Commonwealth Schools Commission indicated that to bring the level of resources in non-government schools up to the level in government schools would require additional educational spending of $400m. It is therefore highly unlikely that many schools will be able to pay the fringe benefits tax out of their own money. The alternative would be for the Commonwealth to increase the funding it provides for these schools, apart from the obviously ridiculous situation put forward of the Commonwealth simply taxing with one hand and paying it back with the other. That seems to me to be most unlikely.

Despite the evidence to the contrary, the Australian Labor Party regards non-government schools as some undesirable social phenomenon which it will tolerate only while the political pressure is great enough to force it to do so. The present Government does not believe that all Australian children have the right to some form of assistance for their education. The platform of the Labor Party requires it to make funds available, to quote its platform, `only to the non-government schools whose total public and private resources do not exceed the resources of comparable government schools'. From 1984 until 1986 total Commonwealth funding for non-government schools was increased by only 2.7 per cent.

It becomes obvious that the more inclined parents are to contribute to their children's education, the less likely they are to get help from the Government. Therefore I do not believe that the Government is likely to give further assistance to schools to help overcome the effects the fringe benefits tax will have upon them. I believe that ultimately the cost will have to be borne by the parents of the children attending the schools, despite the fact that many parents are currently spending an enormous proportion of their incomes on their children's education. This tax is therefore in my view both unfair and miserly. Despite opposition from the Liberal and National parties it was passed by an unholy alliance between the Government and the Australian Democrats. When the tax causes the damage to the education system which is predicted by the Opposition, these two groups will receive the condemnation which they deserve.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raised some time ago in the Senate the matter of waterfront land owned by the Army at Woolwich, on which the Army had planned to build houses. This of course is very expensive waterfront land. It has commanding views of the harbour and is worth multi-millions of dollars. The Army had sought, as I and the residents of the area understood it, to develop this land, which had been used as a horse paddock and a recreation area for the convenience of the people of that region, for Army housing. The Army has failed to explain properly the incredible reason for this. In any event, this action has been deferred, and I hope cancelled.

SPEECH.PARA: But the Army is now at it again with regard to this land. Its latest actions concerning this waterfront land, which as I said is in a very suburban area of Woolwich, are simply intolerable and demonstrate how inappropriate it is for this property to remain in such insensitive and arrogant ownership. The Army has subjected this quiet suburban area to an appalling onslaught of continuous noise and inconvenience for up to 24 hours a day, caused by heavy vehicles including mobile cranes, semi-trailers and trucks, during several weeks of an exercise involving the Tenth Terminal Regiment. The Army's motives for conducting this noisy and offensive exercise on a piece of waterfront land raise some serious questions, particularly in the context of the local residents having opposed so strongly the development of this land for Army housing. This latest exercise and the noise involved appears consistent with a desire by the Army to threaten residents by intimating that the alternative to developing the area for Army housing will be to use it in this sort of anti-social manner in which it has been using it in recent weeks.

The fact that the unit which undertook this exercise is not resident at Woolwich, in the neighbouring small craft section of the Army, but came from Middle Head for the specific purpose of the exercise, raises several questions. Are there any other more suitable areas for the Army to undertake such exercises in the Sydney area? If so, why did the Army decide to create such a public nuisance in a suburban area? If not, how would such exercises take place once the Army proceeded with its plan to build residential accommodation on this site? Is it the Army's intention to try out Woolwich as a possible site for relocating its Middle Head operations? Whatever the motives, the Army's arrogant disregard for the local residents of Woolwich is self-evident.

Beginning with the Anzac weekend, April 26 and 27, the streets leading to the horse paddock-which is the site in question, on the waterfront-from Woolwich Road were frequently filled with a large contingent of semi-trailers, trucks, transporters and mobile cranes of the maximum road size. From 11 p.m. on Sunday 11 May to Thursday 15 May, and again from 8 p.m. on Saturday 24 May the Army engaged in training exercises which were carried on at night and into the following day. The operation was carried out under floodlights and consisted of the use of heavy mechanical handling equipment to move dummy ammunition boxes from point to point on the site, onto a ship and then to their original positions. This operation created excessive noise and seriously disturbed all the surrounding residents, particularly during the night when they were attempting to sleep.

This latest exercise underlines the inappropriateness of the Army's presence on the horse paddock waterfront site and even calls into question its continuing occupancy of the old Woolwich dock. The Army's indifference to the manner in which its operations interfere with the surrounding residential area indicates a need to consider transferring the Army's activities at Woolwich-that is, its entire activities-to one of the Royal Australian Navy's other available outlets in the Sydney region. The current site could then be included in the existing harbour foreshore park. Of course this is very much in line with the views of the Wran Labor Government in New South Wales.

The reality is that there has been widespread and strong public opposition to the Army's continued use of the site. A petition with 2,000 signatures of local residents expressing their views on the matter has been presented by the local Federal member, who happens to be the Leader of the Opposition, the Hon. John Howard. We understand that some of these local residents who suffered most severely from the effects of the exercise are considering mounting a legal action to prevent the recurrence of such a nuisance in a residential area. A committee of local people that has been set up, called the Woolpac Committee or the Woolwich Peoples Action Committee is requesting of the Government an immediate undertaking that such exercises will never again occur on the Army site, on the horse paddock or at Woolwich. It has made a request, which is supported by the Hunters Hill Council, the National Trust, the Hunters Hill Trust, local Federal and State members of parliament and the New South Wales State Government, that serious consideration be given to relocating the whole Army site at Woolwich to a more suitable non-residential area. The arrogance that the Army has displayed in this matter surely merits its removal from the site.

I would like briefly to conclude on another matter altogether, relating to an extraordinary decision, or temporary decision, by the Industries Assistance Commission following an inquiry into luggage, handbags and similar containers. The IAC proposes a tariff of 15 per cent on goods which have had no protective duty placed on them since 1978, for no reason other than that it cannot distinguish between a wallet and an overnight bag. A company involved in this matter, Hunt Leather Pty Ltd, estimates the cost to the consumer to be $48m for the whole of the goods under reference and $23m for luggage, although this latter industry employs no more than 20 people in local manufacturing operations. Twenty people are involved and there is to be a $23m impact on the consumer.

There has been no attempt by the IAC to calculate the cost to the consumer and in any event the 15 per cent tariff is insufficient to have any effect on manufacturing employment, which has similar cost structures to clothing and foot- wear. The proposed tariff, compounded by a 24 per cent sales tax on imports, will have a damaging effect on sales to Australian travellers and overseas tourists, which are a significant part of the business of Hunt Leather Pty Ltd and many retailers in Australia. There is far more scope for employment in selling duty free travel goods to tourists than in manufacturing here.

I understand this matter has been raised with Senator Button. This draft proposal of the IAC to impose this 15 per cent duty on luggage is now getting very serious indeed because it appears that the IAC does intend to go ahead with this proposal. As I said, the number of people employed in manufacturing these items is miniscule. The concern that really emerges from this is that the IAC clearly proposed this impost on the consumer without any serious attempt to quantify the cost. I understand the estimates by the industry that the cost would be $23m have not been challenged effectively by the Commission. The Commission appears to have given no consideration to the increase in consumer prices and local protection, due to devaluation, that has already taken place. No consideration has been given either to the fact that an import duty of 4 per cent on all items is built into the sales tax legislation.

It seems to me that at a time when the Government is quite properly showing concern about inflation and costs in Australia, this kind of extraordinary tariff decision-as I said, 20 people are involved in manufacturing and there is something like a $23m impost on consumers-is simply absurd. The great majority of local and imported goods in this trade are bought directly from manufacturers by retailers. The sales tax on a locally made item is 20 per cent; on an imported item the sales tax is increased by a national wholesale margin of 20 to 24 per cent. If a 15 per cent duty is imposed luggage and many other items in this reference, which are not made here and are not likely to be, will have applied what amounts to a sales tax of 15 per cent plus 24 per cent. This compounds to 42.6 per cent on ordinary everyday items in use. The IAC commissioner at the public hearing seemed to think that the cost to the consumer was not particularly important, which perhaps explains why the commissioner did not cost it. He responded to the representations of Hunt Leather to the effect that `we have to look at the capital and the flow on from manufacturers to other people who might benefit'.
The capital employed in this industry is, though, negligible, and in regard to the flow on benefits I quote from page 29 of the previous IAC report in 1979:
As most materials used in the production of travel goods are imported, the recommendations made in this report, if implemented, would have only a slight effect on local supplying industries.
That report recommended the elimination of the duty which this report now seeks crazily to impose.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It now being 2 p.m. the debate is interrupted.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Senator Gietzelt, will be absent from the chamber for Question Time today and tomorrow. Any questions which would normally be directed to Senator Gietzelt in relation to his portfolio and those he represents in the chamber should be directed to the Minister for Community Services, Senator Grimes.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. I refer the Minister to the Prime Minister's statement yesterday, when he said:

QUESTION.PARA: We have, in the Budget process so far, identified savings of more than $1 billion.

Can the Minister explain whether the Prime Minister was talking about the reductions in existing programs or whether this figure relates to forward estimates of expenditure? Finally, does `identified' mean that either the Cabinet or a committee of Cabinet has agreed to specific cuts, or does it mean that possible areas of reduction have been put forward for discussion? When will the Government announce details of the spending cuts?

TALK.START.PARA: —The details probably will be announced in the Budget. Some of them may be announced before that; indeed some of them have been. One of the cuts decided on was debated in the Senate, I think, two days ago-the one regarding ending the pathology rip-off whereby specialist pathologists were charging specialist fees for pathology services performed entirely by machines and, therefore, there was absolutely no justification for specialists charging specialist prices for a service in which their specialist skills had absolutely no relevance. As I recall, that was severely criticised, if not opposed, by the Opposition. Of course, that is typical of the Opposition's double standards on this issue. They are forever demanding cuts in government expenditure and usually opposing specific cuts which this Government puts up. Moreover, the Leader of the Opposition is running around the country with his shopping list of political goodies filled with promises to increase expenditure by a total of $2 billion. The earlier part of Senator Chaney's question relates to matters which I regard as confidential to the Cabinet. I do not intend to answer it.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I find the end of the Minister's answer quite extraordinary. The Prime Minister announced as part of his formula for the recovery of the Australian economy $1 billion in expenditure cuts. Is the Minister saying that the Senate and the people of Australia cannot be told what is meant by that statement? Are we simply to be left completely in the dark as to whether that $1 billion represents cuts in actual expenditure or just some mythical figure that has been conjured up for the purpose of that wet statement of yesterday?

—The Expenditure Review Committee processes have not yet been completed. There will be significant decisions made about additional expenditure cuts. As I said before, one of them already is in legislation-and some others may be announced before the Budget-but I expect that the overwhelming majority of them will be announced in the Budget.

—Is the Minister for Finance aware that Queensland is the only State which will not allow scrutiny of its financial management by a joint party public accounts committee? As we can expect the Queensland Premier to distort, as usual, the facts related to Federal-State financial relations when he comes to the Premiers Conference tomorrow, will the Minister put clearly on the record the extent of the financial advantage which Queenslanders have enjoyed under the Hawke Government? Furthermore, will the Minister again attempt to get a guarantee from the Queensland Premier that his State at long last will introduce proper public accountability of government expenditure so that the Federal grants are not manipulated by the Premier to cover up his mismanagement as Treasurer of the Queensland economy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course, I know-I think nearly everybody knows-that the Queensland Parliament is the only parliament in Australia which does not have a public accounts committee. Even the Northern Territory has recently established a public accounts committee. I suggest that there are very good reasons why Queensland does not have such a committee. If there were a public accounts committee in Queensland the various rorts and rip-offs which the Premier's friends indulge in would be detected with more certainty and also more quickly than they are under the present arrangements. For exactly the same reason I do not expect that the Queensland Government will agree to set up a public accounts committee. As far as I know there is no way in which the Commonwealth Government could compel the Queensland Government to do so.

ANSWER.PARA: To the extent that Queensland has a dollar problem, or a revenue and expenditure problem, that has been caused by the runaway growth in Queensland State Government expenditure. The most recent Australian Bureau of Statistics figures on State Government expenditure show that over the six years from 1979-80 State government outlays in Australia as a whole increased at an average real rate of 4.2 per cent. In Queensland, the figure is above 6 per cent. That is by far the highest figure of all the States. It is around 50 per cent above the all-State average for expenditure increases. The fact remains-it cannot be contradicted-that State Government in Queensland is out of control and has been out of control for many, many years. That is contrary, of course, to the rhetoric of the Queensland State Premier. Moreover, the government financial estimates of overall deficits for 1985-86 for State Budget and non-Budget sectors combined, on a per capita basis, also published by the ABS, show that New South Wales had the lowest figure at $330, Victoria had $462, South Australia had $358, Western Australia had $529 and Queensland had $666. That is a figure very much higher than the all-States average. It is very much higher than those of any of the Labor government States. It is second only to the State of Tasmania, which had a per capita figure of $844. I suppose related to the runaway growth in Queensland Government expenditure is the fact that Queensland is accumulating debt at a higher rate than any other State as well.

Certainly, the Queensland Government has misused some Commonwealth funds provided to it. Previously I have given details in the Senate of natural disaster relief funding which for many years was provided from the Commonwealth Budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Waste Watch Committee looking at that?

—I do not think the Waste Watch Committee has shown any interest in this at all. It is an area to which it could well direct its attention. Funds from the Commonwealth Budget have been provided to the States. These funds are then on-lent, principally to farmers, at highly concessional rates of interest. For many years the Queensland Government has required farmers to repay those loans. The Queensland Government has then stashed that money away in a hollow log to use and misuse, for whatever purpose it chose. It is impossible to get an accurate figure on that, but the contents of that hollow log alone probably amount to some $30m. That is money that has been provided to Queensland at a 4 1/2 per cent interest rate for on-lending to farmers. That money has been on-lent to farmers for a very short period. The Queensland Government has then taken the money back from the farmers and used it for its own purposes while continuing to enjoy the highly concessional Commonwealth interest rate of 4 1/2 per cent, until such time as ultimately it is obliged to repay the loan. From memory, that is after a 20-year period.

ANSWER.PARA: Of course, there are other examples of waste in regard to Queensland Government expenditure. Qualitatively the most important of all was the political decision to locate a power station at Tarong instead of at Millmerran, where the State Electricity Commission of Queensland had recommended that it be located and where, I understand, the then responsible Minister, Mr Camm, also recommended that it be located. He was rolled on that decision. That imposed an additional cost on Queensland of $259m which is reflected in its State Government debt rather than in outlays. There is also the notorious case of the MacKenzie River dam in which a project which had never been submitted to the Commonwealth Government for funding-even though lists of water conservation projects which are submitted by the Queensland Government are in the nature of a wish list rather than a serious bid for funds-suddenly jumped to the front of the queue. It was announced that $5m would be spent building that dam. Fortuitously, immediately before that decision was made a licence had been granted to the Premier's son to install a 12-inch pump.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order. The very lengthy answer--
—And boring.

—The answer by the Minister shows very great signs of preparation and is really in the nature of a ministerial statement. I suggest that if the Minister wishes to give a great mass of detailed information of that nature he should give a statement. I do not know that this amounts to debating the question, because as one of the interjectors behind me said, it is too boring to be regarded as a debate. It clearly seems to be an abuse of Question Time. Mr President, I ask you to ask the Minister to finish his answer to enable other honourable senators to ask a question.

—Bearing in mind the question that was asked, the Minister clearly is in order in answering in the way he has. However, I point out that there are a number of questions which it is desired be asked today. I ask Ministers when answering questions to be as brief as possible.

—Thank you, Mr President. I shall certainly pay heed to your request. I have cited only two examples of politically determined and highly wasteful expenditure by the Queensland Government. Of course, the second case also reeks of political patronage, to say the least. The major problem of the Queensland Government, as I said in the beginning, is that its expenditure is out of control. It has been out of control for many years. Its expenditure is increasing at a rate that is 50 per cent higher than the rate of increase for State government expenditure in general and is higher than for any other State. In the same period, Queensland has accumulated for government and government authorities the highest per capita debt of any State. In the most recent figures that is also increasing at a rate that is faster than in any other State except Tasmania.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate and the Minister representing the Minister for Trade. I refer the Minister to a paper recently prepared by Mr Geoffrey Lill, the Marketing Manager of Utah Development Co., which indicates that an extra $1 billion could be earned from additional overseas coal sales if export controls were removed from that commodity. I also refer the Minister to the latest `Review of Business Regulations Paper No. 2', which indicates that despite this being a priority area little or no action has been taken on major export controls. In the light of this information from the Utah Development Co., why was no mention made of removing export controls in this area and in other mineral areas during the Prime Minister's address to the nation last night, which called for greater efforts by Australians to earn more overseas?
—The correct answer to that question is that export controls on coal and other resource products have been under examination for--
—Years.

—No, not for years-weeks, not months. They are under examination by the Department of Trade. A public announcement was made to that effect at the time. I do not know whether it was necessary for the Prime Minister to repeat that fact in his statement last night. I agree that those issues are very important. There are a number of conflicting views within the industry about them. Those matters cannot be dealt with simply unless one is in opposition and is charged up with macho feelings.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Education been drawn to an article in the Brisbane Daily Sun on 10 June headed `Brisbane Site for Christian Campus'? Is the Minister aware that the article claims that 35 students are already enrolled in the proposed private university which is due for completion in 1988? Will the proposed university be required to meet any Federal Government regulations or requirements? Will it attract Federal funding? Further, will any of the students attending this proposed university receive tertiary education assistance scheme payments or any other form of Commonwealth support?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My attention has been drawn to the article in the Brisbane Daily Sun headed `Brisbane Site for Christian Campus'. This institution, if it exists, has no status as far as the Federal Government is concerned. From what I have read in the article it has no status as far as the Queensland State Government is concerned either. Senator Colston's question addressed its status as far as the Federal Government is concerned. To the Federal Government, there is no such thing as a private university. If students are enrolled in this situation they are not enrolled at a university in terms of the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Act. Tertiary education assistance scheme payments are made to students undertaking approved courses; that is, courses that have been assessed and approved by the proper Commonwealth procedures. No courses from this alleged college have been accredited and therefore there will be no payment of TEAS to any students enrolling.

ANSWER.PARA: I am grateful to Senator Colston for asking this question because it is possible that young people or their families could be misled by organisations claiming to offer university education. University education is increasingly prized in our society. There is increasing competition for university places. Therefore, there is an environment in which unscrupulous people could mislead parents or students as to what is offered in some sort of private institution. This would be very much to the detriment of those students. I want to make it quite clear from the Federal Government's point of view no private university is or will be recognised. Therefore, courses offered by any private institution that simply chooses to call itself a university with or without State agreement will not attract any form of Federal support.

In conclusion, the Government has the best of all possible reasons for adopting this very firm position. That reason is that we are proud of the standards achieved by the Australian university system. University places are sought not only in fierce competition by Australian students but also by overseas students. In order to maintain those standards and improve them-which is an objective of our Government-we must be sure that all courses offered are offered at a standard which has been approved by Commonwealth approval procedures, which are constantly updated and under which courses are reviewed over time, changed if necessary and in general monitored so that standards are satisfactory. Any attempt to go outside the system and establish private institutions claiming to be universities or some other form of tertiary institution can only undermine that high standard and therefore act against the interests of Australian students.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw to the attention of honourable senators the presence in the presidential gallery of Sir Robin Vanderfelt, the Secretary-General of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association. Sir Robin will shortly be retiring after 37 years of service with the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association. I am sure that all honourable senators join me in warmly welcoming him to Canberra and thanking him for his contribution to parliamentary relations throughout the Commonwealth.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. First, does the Government believe that the Premier of Victoria, Mr Cain, has a right to determine whether or what sort of United States nuclear warships can come into Victorian ports? Secondly, what is the difference, if any, between Mr Cain's position and the position taken by New Zealand's Mr Lange? Thirdly, Mr Cain has said that his information on the United States Ship Rathburne and the United States Ship Cimmaron was from Federal Government sources. Where did the Government get its information from-the United States? If so, where does this leave the United States policy of neither confirming nor denying the presence of nuclear weapons? If the source was not the United States, where did it come from, given Janes Fighting Ships says that these two ships carry Asroc missiles which can be armed with nuclear weapons? Fourthly, does the Government agree that were the other Australian States to follow the lead of Mr Cain this would effectively place Australia in the same position as New Zealand on the nuclear warships issue?

—Order! I have already drawn attention to the length of ministerial answers. I now draw attention to the length of questions being asked. I ask honourable senators to respect the rights of other senators.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has actually been an item in the media claiming that the United States Ship Rathburne, which is a frigate, and the United States Ship Cimmaron, an oiler which left Melbourne a few days ago, were not carrying nuclear weapons, and that the Federal Government gave the Victorian Government an assurance to this effect. I want to make it clear that no such assurance was given. Neither ship was nuclear powered, but it is not the practice of United States authorities to depart from their established principle of neither confirming nor denying the presence of nuclear weapons. I am also informed that Mr Cain's office has confirmed that a briefing given to journalists addressed the question only of whether the vessels in question were nuclear powered. It did not address at all the question of their being nuclear armed. It is, of course, well known that our policy is not to seek to exclude nuclear weapons capable ships from our ports. Such decisions are for this Government to make, not the Victorian Government or any other State government. I believe that is a view which Mr Cain shares.
—It is within our constitutional prerogative.

—Of course it is within our constitutional prerogatives as an exercise of the defence power, both as an executive matter and, should we want to formalise that in legislation, as a Commonwealth legislative matter.

ANSWER.PARA: I am asked the difference between Mr Cain's position and that taken by the Prime Minister of New Zealand, Mr Lange. I suggest that the honourable senator direct that question to Mr Cain, if he feels so inclined to follow that up. As to whether or not other Australian States might follow the lead of Mr Cain and produce the effective situation of placing Australia in the same position as New Zealand, once again I suggest that that question be better directed to Mr Cain. It is his view that is allegedly in issue here, not that of the Commonwealth Government which has made its position absolutely clear.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Would the Federal Government impose its will over any State government denying access to nuclear armed or powered ships?

—Senator Sanders is a glutton for punishment. The short answer obviously is yes, we do accept the responsibility, take that responsibility, and if it became necessary to take action to enforce that assumption of responsibility, of course we would.

—What value does the Minister for Community Services place on volunteers working in community services? What encouragement can the Minister give to operations such as Telecare conducted through the Portland and District Community Health Centre in Victoria? Does the Minister see voluntary organisations helped by government growing in the area of community services?

—Volunteers are and will remain essential in the provision of community services in this country. They not only give local involvement to the provision and planning of those services, but also they assist fully paid and professional people in providing those services in an economic way so that the community and therefore the Government can afford to maintain those services. Senator Cooney mentioned Telecare which is a service provided, as he said, at Portland in Victoria whereby elderly people who are at risk are phoned each day at specified times by volunteers. This has the social effect of giving them someone to talk to at those times and it also gives the volunteers an idea of any help the people may need, and in times of emergency it means help can be got to them fairly quickly. This is a concept which is fairly common in other countries. It has been very successfully run out of the Community Health Centre in Portland. Under the home and community care services, the Minister for Community Services in Victoria, Mrs Caroline Hogg, and I have approved assistance to that organisation-as well as to many others to the extent of about $9m-to enable it to continue and develop. I, and, I believe, all the State Ministers, see the voluntary organisations helped by government as being a crucial part in the development of the home and community care program. In particular, the Victorian Government has been very active, once the home and community care agreement was funded, in combining with the Federal Government to ensure that good, innovative and sensible programs are developed. I am sure that Mrs Hogg and I will be able to develop home and community care in Victoria in the future to the extent that it will be a very good example to some of the other States and will enable us to get a rational program going in this area much quicker than we would have otherwise.

—I refer the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters to the rhetoric in the Prime Minister's address to the nation about streamlining the Public Service and to Mr Hawke's selective and deceptive misuse of statistics on the Carleton-Walsh Report in an attempt to prove the unprovable, that this Government has a better record of restraining Public Service growth than the Fraser Government. Will the Minister confirm that the figures quoted by the Prime Minister on the Carleton-Walsh Report refer only to direct Public Service increases and ignore increases in other Commonwealth agencies-that is the total Public Service increases? Will he confirm that the average rate of growth in the total Public Service employment for the Fraser years was well under 1 per cent, compared with about 3 per cent for the first two years of the Hawke Government, and that in three years under the Fraser Government there were decreases in both categories, something which the Hawke Government never has and never will accomplish?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not familiar with the figures which the Prime Minister quoted on the Carleton-Walsh Report last night, but if the Prime Minister quoted them I am absolutely certain that they would be accurate. Senator Walters raised the question of selection and deception which is an excellent description of the practices the Fraser Government followed in its period in office in order to conceal the true size of the Public Service. The Fraser Government, for a number of years, followed the practice of sacking the day labour force, particularly in the Department of Housing and Construction. In that way it achieved a cosmetic reduction in Public Service numbers. But the only effect of that is that construction and maintenance work previously done by people employed in the Department of Housing and Construction, and therefore under the Public Service Act, was then transferred to private contractors. That may or may not have been a defensible policy decision, but what was indefensible and remains indefensible is to present that as a reduction in Public Service numbers when, in fact, it is just a transfer of a function previously recorded within the Public Service to a function still paid for by the Commonwealth taxpayers and off the Commonwealth Budget, but recorded in the private sector.

ANSWER.PARA: At the same time as the Fraser Government was making that cosmetic adjustment-the area outside of the day labour force-the administrative section of the Public Service, particularly what was then the second Division and what is now the Special Executive Service-was exploding. It was growing at a run-away rate. So those who want to ridicule the corns on backsides syndrome or whatever it is supposed to be-people like Mr McLachlan-ought to know that that was running wild in the period the Fraser Government was in office. If Senator Walters wants to get the precise statistics on that I will try to get them for her by tomorrow. If not, I will post them to her during the recess and I will make them available to the Press as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to the fall in commercial interest rates in recent weeks, for instance, the reduction in bank bill interest rates, from 18 per cent in mid-February to 14 per cent yesterday. What impact will the four percentage point fall in this key interest rate have on the Australian economy? Is the reduction in this important commercial interest rate and the 1 1/2 per cent fall in interest rates on Commonwealth bonds in line with Government expectations?

—Key interest rates have been moving downwards since December 1985. Since that time, for example, the market yield on 10-year Treasury bonds has fallen by more than 2 percentage points. Yesterday it stood at 12.9 per cent. The market yield on two-year Treasury bonds, short term Government paper, has fallen by 2 3/4 percentage points over the same period. The 180-day bank rate has fallen by over 5 per cent, which is a spectacular fall over that period. I might add, for the record, that at no stage was the 180- or 90-day bank bill rate as high as it was in April of 1982 when Mr Howard was presiding over the economy. Since December 1985 the 90-day bank bill rate has also fallen by more than 5 percentage points. All of those four critical interest rates, both public and private sector rates, are now at levels below those prevailing in April and May of 1985. Long term bond rates are currently at or near the low levels achieved in 1984 before the significant devaluation of the Australian dollar commenced. The Government is now seeking to place greater stress on fiscal and wages policy in handling Australia's terms of trade problem. Interest rates should continue to fall, and that will provide an added inducement to business investment, that is, added to high profits, low labour costs and improved international competitiveness.

—Will the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security explain exactly how the Prime Minister's unemployment benefit community service scheme will work? Will it be entirely voluntary or is there a possibility, as seemed to be suggested by Mr Hawke in interviews last nights, of some element of compulsion? If it is to be voluntary, how does it differ from the pilot program announced by the Fraser Government in late 1982 but abandoned by the present Government after the election?

—The program will work as described by the Prime Minister in his statement last night and in associated documents. The trade unions, local government, State governments and other organisations will be consulted about making work available-work which would not normally be done under the existing system and work which will be of community benefit. These jobs will be offered to the young unemployed, and they will perform these part time jobs in exchange for the unemployment benefit. The co-operation of the union movement, local government et cetera will be necessary to ensure that other people are not displaced from these jobs, that the jobs are not used to provide community services and that the money comes off the unemployment benefit bill, which would normally be the case. The scheme will be gradually introduced. As for the voluntary/compulsory aspect of the scheme which the Opposition seems to be so interested in, we already have a work test for the unemployment benefit. If people are offered reasonable work-work at award wages et cetera-and they refuse to take that work they fail the work test and therefore are liable to lose the unemployment benefit. Inasmuch as that is compulsory, under the new scheme the same work test conditions will apply. I do not know of any suggestion that we will be making it compulsory other than that, and I remind honourable senators that there is a section in the Constitution about civil conscription. How does the scheme differ from the pilot scheme introduced by the previous Government in 1982? That is quite simple. First of all, it will be put into operation. Secondly, it will be put into operation with the co-operation of the State governments.
—You stopped it.
—We did not stop it; after all that time it hardly got off the ground. The third way in which it will differ is that--
—You haven't even got a scheme.

—Senator Chaney's comment is very interesting. Here we are, less than 24 hours after the Prime Minister's statement, and he says that we do not even have a scheme. The previous Government's scheme was introduced in 1982. We came into government in 1983 but it still did not have a scheme. It had not discussed it with local government, it had nothing off the ground. That was the sad tragedy of the previous Government. In the last two years of the Fraser Government 265,000 people were added to the unemployment lists in this country. That was the shame of the Fraser Government. It introduced a scheme to try to do something about it but when we got into office in 1983 it had not even got off the ground.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Health aware of warnings issued in the United States and in Britain about the dangers of giving aspirin-based medication to children and the decision to withdraw children's medicine containing aspirin from sale in the United Kingdom? In the light of evidence which indicates a link between aspirin and the potentially fatal illness known as Reye's syndrome, what action has been taken by Australian health authorities to control the marketing of these products and to inform parents of possible danger?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday the Department of Health issued a warning that children and teenagers with fevers should not be given aspirin as a medication. I must emphasise that this warning does not extend to children and teenagers who do not have a fever, and it does not include adults at all. It is important to emphasise this because aspirin will remain an important treatment for some conditions, particularly juvenile rheumatoid arthritis. This condition is usually treated under close medical supervision and certainly aspirin has a key role to play in its treatment. So I point out that people with children with that sort of condition who are being treated with aspirin should not be concerned because Reye's syndrome seems to be associated with the giving of aspirin to children who have fevers. There are very effective alternatives, such as paracetamol, for children who have fevers. Although the danger of Reye's syndrome developing is slight, as Senator Zakharov has said, the syndrome is very dangerous and frequently fatal, causing as it does liver failure and brain damage.

ANSWER.PARA: It is important to point out to parents and those who may be worried that Reye's syndrome is a very rare syndrome. But that does not mean we should not do something about it. The Australian Drug Evaluation Committee has had aspirin's possible role in increasing the risk of Reye's syndrome under continuing review for some time, and there has been continuing consultation with the Australian College of Paediatrics. The Department of Health believes that, unlike the situation in the United Kingdom, aspirin-containing products formulated specifically for children were generally replaced in this country with paracetamol products some years ago. This occurred for commercial reasons and for the reasons stated involving Reye's syndrome. As far as is known, paracetamol is quite safe and is not implicated in the development of Reye's syndrome. The Department is now checking with the aid of pharmaceutical importers and State health departments on the availability of aspirin-containing compounds specifically for children on the Australian market. So far they have discovered only two such products and they are holding discussions with manufacturers to arrange their withdrawal. Because of the reasons I have already given, the possibility of this type of product being on the market is very small. I hope that the warning given by the Department of Health and the general awareness which will arise in the community as a result of the publicity of the last couple of days will mean that the possibility of this very rare syndrome occurring much in Australia in the future will have been reduced considerably.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister representing the Treasurer confirm that the Reserve Bank of Australia is strongly supporting the Australian dollar in money market transactions? If so, what has been the cost to date of this prop for the dollar made necessary by the failure of last night's prime ministerial address to tackle Australia's fundamental economic problems? For how long and at what cost will the Government maintain its support of the dollar?

—I recall that during the 1983 election campaign it was asserted by the then Prime Minister, with the implicit if not explicit support of the then Treasurer, now the discredited former Treasurer, that if the Australian Labor Party won office there would be a run on the dollar. That sort of prophecy having been made by people who were seen to be in positions of authority, there was, of course, a run on the dollar. The really reprehensible thing about that is that Fraser and Howard were indulging in economic sabotage. They sought to score a political point which they thought would save them from the electoral oblivion which was staring them in the face, at the expense of the rest of the country. Leading members of the then Government were economic saboteurs at that stage. I note from Senator Puplick's question that they continue to be economic saboteurs. I am not going to answer questions about the Reserve Bank policy. It would be highly improper of me to do so, particularly on a matter as sensitive as the Reserve Bank's currency trading operations. For me to do so would be to provide information to currency speculators from which they could reap substantial windfall gains.
—Who do you think Senator Puplick represents?

—I was about to say exactly that. They might be the sorts of people Senator Puplick is trying to help. They are certainly not the sorts of people the Government and I are trying to help. If Senator Puplick is concerned about the Reserve Bank's overall operating position and profit, I suggest that he wait until the Budget Papers appear and look at what contribution the Reserve Bank makes to revenue from its profits in the 1985-86 financial year.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the Minister representing the Treasurer asserting that the Parliament is not entitled to be told the cost to public revenue of propping up the Australian economy in the face of the Prime Minister's clear failure to restore international confidence in the value of the dollar?

—I am asserting that the Parliament has absolutely no right to be told what is the currency trading policy being followed by the Reserve Bank at any particular time because to do so would be to provide windfall gains to currency speculators, who, I presume, are the very people Senator Puplick represents, at the expense of the nation as a whole and of taxpayers in particular.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General, follows in part that already asked by Senator Sanders and refers to media coverage of the situation at Port Melbourne on 9 June and, I understand, at Port Adelaide earlier in the week. My concern is about an incident that occurred when some Australian citizens, including anti-nuclear protesters and policemen, were struck by water from a high pressure fire hose operated by American crewmen of the USS Rathburne while the ship was in port. I ask: What is the legal position in relation to this incident and similar incidents? Does this incident constitute a precedent? If injury is caused to an Australian citizen or if property is damaged in such an incident, who is liable for the payment of compensation?

—I am advised by the Department of Defence, rather than the Attorney-General's Department, that the legal position and responsibilities of United States forces in Australia are set down in the 1963 Australia-United States Agreement on the Status of United States forces in Australia. Depending upon the circumstances, which would need to be assessed by due legal process, the agreement would allow for United States service personnel to be prosecuted in Australian courts. Naturally Australian citizens have recourse to due legal process. I do not want to comment or to speculate further on the particular incident to which Senator Coleman referred and the applicability of that legal process to those circumstances.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. How can the Government, as outlined in the Prime Minister's address to the nation, continue to justify a 3 per cent productivity claim which we as a nation cannot afford but which has already been distributed? Is it not a fact that the Government's commitment to the productivity claim arises from the fact that the Hawke Government is locked into governing this country by deals with the Australian Council of Trade Unions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —If we are accused of doing deals with the ACTU on this matter, we do not seem to be very successful at it. That is the obvious rider. The Opposition in this place continually misunderstands the fact that interventions by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in fixing wages in this country are interferences in the market-place and that a those interferences are, in a sense, built into the system and the Arbitration Commission is an independent organisation in making decisions about these matters. It may demonstrate that independence before long in a way which it has not done over many years. But it is an independent organisation. The Government's prices and incomes accord with the trade union is purely supplementary to that in that it seeks to reach agreement with the trade union movement about wages and other issues rather than impose its view on the market-place without discussion first having taken place.

ANSWER.PARA: As I have said here on a number of occasions, the Government's view is that this country very desperately needs wage moderation and, in a sense, that has been delivered over the last two years in terms of declining real unit labour costs in Australia. They are back to the levels of the late 1960s. The question of whether we have an appropriate wage scale and appropriate conditions of employment in this country has been further highlighted by the recent sharp decline in the terms of trade which has again given this issue considerable importance in politics and the public eye.

Insofar as the wage fixation system is concerned, the Government has put forward the view that there should be only one wage increase this calendar year-the 2.3 per cent wage increase-and that has been argued before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission by the Government. It would be the first wage increase since November 1985. That would produce wage outcomes which are consistent with the Government's general policy. A number of other matters relating to wages, including deferment of the productivity case, deferment of a subsequent scheduled wage case this year and also discounting when the next wage case occurs, were announced in the statement last night. It is a matter of balance and judgment by government and others as to what is the appropriate mix in a wage package. It is quite clear from what was said last night and what has been said by me and other Ministers in this place that the desire and concern to obtain wage restraint is of very great importance to this country and we are trying to achieve that. The method of doing it is often open to some degree of criticism.

Let me make it quite clear-I will say it in public; I have said it privately-that what we most fear in this country is an outbreak of wage increases in the trade exposed sector of the economy which would reduce the economic performance of this country to the levels it was at in 1981-82, when in one year there were 16 per cent wage increases, not 2.3 per cent. That sort of thing is the genesis of the current problems we have both with wage fixation and with the trade balance. That is what we are anxious to avoid. It is very easy to say when in opposition: `We will put a stop to all that'. To actually do it is beyond the performance of any current member of the Opposition. One only has to look at their performance over four or five very important years in the history of this country to understand that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. How can the Government continue to justify the 3 per cent productivity claim, in view of the Prime Minister's statement that we know we cannot afford it as a nation?

—I do not think one can say `in view of the Prime Minister's statement'. In the view of Senator Parer, perhaps, we cannot afford the 3 per cent productivity claim as a nation. That was the substance of my answer to his previous question. If he is asking me for a personal view, I would not wish for the productivity case to be brought on and dealt with in the near future. Of course I would not, and my position is clear enough on that; but these matters have to be dealt with in the context of overall strategies and considerations about the economy and the wage fixing environment generally. It is no good rushing into glib and smart solutions that will not produce the results that are required over time. None of the problems this country has at this moment in terms of economic management and in terms of the external account are going to be solved overnight by summoning up an export control and, according to Senator Durack, hopefully getting an extra $1 billion worth of coal exports next week and fixing up the trade deficit like that. All these things require attention. I will convey Senator Durack's suggestion to the Minister for Trade because I think that matter requires more urgent attention, but no magical wands are going to be waved overnight to deal with the trade deficit problem with which we are fundamentally confronted.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Education. Has she noticed the dishonest campaign by the Tasmanian Minister for Education, Mr Peter Rae, to shift the blame for State Government decisions on education outlays, in which campaign he has enlisted the support of education interest groups? How does this campaign gell with the attitude of Mr Rae's Party to the right of the States to decide their own priorities? Why should Federal Government programs be the only programs to suffer cutbacks? What is this Government's record of assistance to Tasmania in specific purpose education programs? Is there any basis for suggesting that Tasmania has been or will be unfairly dealt with by this Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the last part of Senator Coates's question is a clear no. There are no grounds for suggesting that Tasmania has been unfairly dealt with by the Commonwealth Government in the past, nor will it be. Tasmania, like every other State and Territory, gets its fair share both of the capital and recurrent program funds and of the special purpose programs. Indeed, the special purpose programs in the main are allocated on a per capita basis, so there are absolutely no grounds for suggesting that there has been any differential treatment of Tasmania. Schools in Tasmania, like schools throughout Australia, have benefited from the policies of the Hawke Government. For example, the total funding to Tasmania in grants to government and non-government schools in 1983 was $35,910,000 and it went up to $39,936,000 last year. No doubt there will be further increases. So there has been a substantial increase in funds available directly to Tasmanian schools from Commonwealth programs.

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to the campaign that Mr Rae is orchestrating, I think it is misguided. It suggests that the fate of Tasmanian schools is in the hands of the Commonwealth Government whereas, as Senator Coates's question rightly implies, the fundamental responsibility, the major responsibility, for schools funding is a State matter. The States attend to their schools' funding needs out of their general revenue grants from the Commonwealth. Perhaps what we should deduce from Mr Rae's campaign is that the Tasmanian Government is planning to give a lower priority to education and is hoping somehow or other to confuse the issue and suggest that it is as a result of Federal Government action. That is not a legitimate point of view and I doubt very much that the education lobby groups Mr Rae is trying to persuade of this will be hoodwinked for one second.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Prime Minister and I refer him to comments by Mr John Halfpenny of the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union who, referring to the announcement of a community work scheme for the unemployed, said on AM today that there was no way in the world all young people could be offered community work and that the Government knows this. He went on to say:

QUESTION.PARA: It is not a genuine proposition. The announcement really is a deceptive admission on the part of the Government that the Priority One and the traineeship schemes have failed.
How does the Minister envisage this new half-baked scheme fitting in with the failed Priority One: Young Australia program?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a number of parts to Senator Vanstone's question. I suppose the essential point she is trying to get at is whether the new proposition, as Mr Halfpenny was pleased to describe it, represents a failure of the Priority One: Young Australia program.
