Only a week ago I answered a question, from Senator Vanstone, as I recall it, about the Priority One program in which I frankly said that it had run into some difficulties but that the Government was working away at it, both with the business community and with the trade unions, to try to improve and lift the level of return and performance of the Priority One program.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not think the proposal announced by the Prime Minister last night really has very much to do with that. I think that Mr Halfpenny, as a constructive contributor, which he can be, would be best advised to direct his energies to ensuring that the trade union movement is fully supporting the Priority One program and the traineeship announced by the Government and that there are no obstacles to their success in that area, just as we have to address attention to ensuring that there are no obstacles to the success of those programs in the business community and, indeed, in the Public Service. I do not necessarily see the connection between the two, but if the point of the question is again to draw attention to delays in Priority One, I concede the point.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. The point of my question, apart from drawing attention to the failure of the Priority One scheme, was also to ask whether the Government did envisage this so-called half-baked scheme fitting in with the Priority One program; whether there were any administrative arrangements envisaged whereby the two will in some way be connected, or are they viewed as entirely separate programs?
—Not that I am aware. When the administrative arrangements are put in order an announcement will be made about them and I will make sure that Senator Vanstone gets an early copy of them.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government. In view of questions asked by members of the Opposition earlier, has the Minister noted the expressions of support from the Leader of the Opposition for the Government's `Buy Australian' campaign?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been drawn to my attention that the Prime Minister's address to the nation was hardly dry from the printing press before there were differences within the Opposition about the announcement which was made in respect of the so-called `Buy Australian' Program. For example, our new incumbent in office in the Senate, Senator Richard Alston, put out a Press release today calling it both fraudulent and unpatriotic and a publicity stunt designed to distract attention from the real issues. He continued:

ANSWER.PARA: `What Australia needs is a competitive environment in which Australian goods will win through on their merits, not a sheltered workshop . . .'

At the same time his Leader, Mr Howard, was on the Derryn Hinch show this morning saying that the Opposition supported the `Buy Australia' program, and Mr Howard has said that on three occasions to date. The Opposition has now had a bit of time and should sort out its views on some of these issues. In saying that, I totally agree with some of the detailed observations in Senator Alston's Press release:
What Australia needs is the competitive environment where Australian goods will win through on their merits.

Personally, I would not support a `Buy Australian' program which says `Buy Australian irrespective of quality, design' and a whole range of other factors that go to the merits of particular products. All is not lost. Senator Alston perhaps has introduced a new directional note into the Opposition's thinking on this matter, and that of course is welcome.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Notice of Intention to Withdraw Notices of Motion

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I give notice that, at the giving of notices on the next day of sitting, I shall withdraw Business of the Senate, notices of motion Nos 3 and 1 standing in my name for tomorrow and for 22 August 1986 for disallowance of the Plan of Management No. 5 South Bluefin Fishery Management Plan (Amendment).

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to make a very short statement.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been correspondence with the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin), firstly, concerning the relationship between the plan, certain fisheries notices and the Fisheries Act under which they were made; and, secondly, concerning review of discretionary decisions of officials. The Minister has explained the relationship between the plan, the notices and the Act. The Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances thanks the Minister for his explanation. The Minister agreed to make the discretionary decisions identified by the Committee subject to review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that I have received the following letter, dated 12 June, from Senator Messner:

INTERJECT.PARA: Pursuant to Standing Order 64, I give notice that today I propose to move-
`That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The need for more positive action by the Government to protect the living standards of Australians.'
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The need for more positive action by the Government to protect the living standards of Australians.

Some senators may recall the words of the Premier of New South Wales at the National Economic Summit Conference in 1983, when we heard him proclaim that the aims of this Government should be threefold-jobs, jobs, jobs. Now he has had his response from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), and what we got instead were-words, words, words. That has become increasingly clear today from Question Time, when Ministers tried to deliver rambling answers to very pertinent questions as to the way in which the new schemes outlined in the Prime Minister's statement last night would work. How was the new community work test to apply to youth-how, indeed, was it to work? There were no answers. Obviously the scheme has not been thought through at all. How was the Government to consider freeing up the position in regard to coal contracts, and I believe that the Utah Development Company was mentioned? No concern was shown about that issue.

What was the Government prepared to tell us about expenditure cuts? Nothing, other than that Ministers said that they had identified $1 billion worth of expenditure, but they could not tell us whether it was coming off the Budget or the Forward Estimates, or whether programs were identified for the chop. There were no particulars whatsoever. Clearly, the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) was embarrassed over that question, and that demonstrates the rubberiness of this statement made by the Prime Minister last night.

Is it any wonder that Mr Wran is getting out? He knows better than most-he is, after all, President of the Australian Labor Party-that the Prime Minister cannot deliver, and all that he can deliver are words. That is all we got last night-a Hawkespeak version of the Keating banana republic theme. It was smooth, surely, and as a television production it was tops, but as a charter for action it was the absolute pits. To the Government's credit, last night's statement admitted one thing-namely, that there is a crisis in the economy. It is interesting to note that the Chinese word character for `crisis' is in two parts: One part is `danger', and the other is `opportunity'. Hawke showed us the dangers, but none of the opportunities.

Let us examine why that is so. There is no doubt that the overriding concern of Australians is for jobs-jobs for breadwinners, jobs for their children, jobs in order to gain self-improvement for those already in work, and opportunities for small businessmen and farmers to expand. While it is at least mildly surprising, but welcome, that the Government finally has woken up to the fact that international competitiveness is linked inextricably with our domestic cost structure, it is nothing less than astonishing that it has taken this Government three years to find it out. During that time no doubt the Government has basked in the lavish self-praise of all those who swallow their own propaganda-that is, that the Government has increased the number of jobs while economic growth has gone ahead. Government members have been led into their own trap by believing that propaganda. They kidded Australians that Utopia was just around the corner as a result of their policies which it now seems they believe, even though some rationalists, such as Senator Button and Senator Walsh, apparently have been preaching the truth within the ALP's inner councils. It is interesting that neither of those Ministers, who both have responsibility for economic management and represent those portfolios in the Senate, is prepared to take part in this debate today to defend the actions of his Prime Minister.

What were the policies they espoused to produce those kinds of growth rates from a very low base which made their rather ordinary statistics look somewhat prodigious? In short, the policies were to build up government spending, risk a false boom which would lead to a balance of payments crisis, which is now plainly evident, and push up interest rates to attract foreign money to cover our shortfall of imports over exports, which increases our foreign indebtedness. What is the result of all that? The result is very little change in the unemployment rate, some small reduction in inflation and a huge overseas debt build-up from some $35 billion in 1982 to $80 billion this year. Now these policies are being seen to be disastrous. Now we have a crisis, and we have to deal with it.

To reduce the crisis to its bare bones, this debate is all about jobs. Without increasing the availability and the numbers of jobs in the community, living standards for all will fall. There will be competition for existing jobs, but prosperity in any economy is about expanding job opportunities, not decreasing them. The concern of the Prime Minister last night seemed to be more with debates and arguments about how the cake was to be cut up among those with jobs already, rather than with looking to ways to expand those opportunities in the future.

The Prime Minister had his language right. He told us where there were problems in the economy. He recognised the problem of overseas competition, of the great growth happening to our north in many of the Asian economies which are producing goods far faster and more technologically advanced than our own. He failed to note the effect, however, on business in this country, particularly on small business and farmers, of the fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax. It is astounding that the Prime Minister should be making statements of such moment and portent when some few days ago he sponsored the passage through this chamber of two new tax measures, along with others, to impose heavy tax liabilities and future cost restrictions on business. Clearly those measures will destroy jobs, not improve them. The essence of the problem that the Government needs to face is bound up with union control over existing jobs, whereas the solution obviously is to free up the control and create new and sustainable jobs which have real prospects for the future. There is a need to recognise that the cost problem, which is very evident in this country today, is the result of union control of existing jobs. In his statement last night the Prime Minister failed entirely to grasp that fundamental point.

Let us have a look at the question of costs in the community. On many occasions we have heard in answers to questions here and in the House of Representatives both the Prime Minister and Senator Button say that there has been a reduction in the unit costs of labour since this Government came to power in 1983. It has been one of Senator Walsh's favourite lines during Question Time. He insists on claiming that the Government is getting control over that particular issue. Yet in the papers that were handed out last night by the Prime Minister there is a very revealing graph of our competitiveness, comparing the first quarter of 1985 with the first quarter of 1986. We find that in that time our competitiveness improved by 23.7 per cent. However, when one takes account of the fact that those figures are already adjusted for the changes in our exchange rate and one deducts from that the trade weighted index change-and that index fell by 25.2 per cent-one finds that the change in relation to unit costs, which the Government says it has under control and is doing great things with to improve Australian competitiveness, results entirely from the change in the value of the Australian dollar. As everybody knows, the value of the dollar has fallen substantially-by about 25 per cent-since this time last year. In other words, the improvement is entirely due to the exchange rate change and not the Government's control over labour costs in this country.

Each fall in the exchange rate will bring lower standards of living. If the Government's policy is to reduce costs by allowing the exchange rate to continue to fall, which it obviously is, that means there will be more and more pressure on Australian living standards. The result, as admitted by the Prime Minister last night, will be that those living standards will continue to fall. In reality the lesson to be learned from that very interesting graph provided by the Prime Minister-which he apparently overlooked-is simply this: Apparently we are prepared to pay ourselves while allowing the devaluation of our currency to maintain our present competitive state but we are not prepared to allow methods to come into play by which we could improve our competitiveness. The crux of our problem in dealing with labour costs is political. The Government is running slap bang into the trade union movement, the very constituency with which it must deal if it is to deal effectively with the problem. At that test the Government is obviously failing. It gave away nothing in the statement last night, nothing that had not already been agreed to in the accord mark 2 with the Australian Council of Trade Unions last September. I admit that there has been some attempt to open up the question of wage discounting, but again there is absolutely no commitment in specific terms of what that will entail and how it will be achieved. The question of a further wage case in 1986 was part of the original deal back in September. The question of the superannuation deal being spread over two years was stated quite clearly in the accord mark 2 and spelt out equally clearly in the superannuation guidelines that were announced by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) last December. There is nothing new at all in those proposals.

If the Government is interested in jobs and in improving the circumstances of those who are out of work, it must deal with those very rigidities which it ignores by virtue of last night's statement. Yet those are the very issues which the Liberal and National parties have addressed in their industrial relations policy. We offer flexibility rather than rigidity; we offer the opportunities for business to negotiate with employees for the advantage of both through the proper management of new wage, salary and conditions arrangements. All those things mean that the process of changes which this Government seeks to implement is too rigid, too slow and too tied into what the trade union movement is prepared to forgo-if anything. It is an indictment of the very system under which we operate and therefore the only solution lies in a change in attitude. This is the only way in which we can address the central issues that are before us. It is the central tragedy of the Prime Minister's statement that by his own admission the economy has changed-changed since the Government entered into the accord in September last year. By his own admission yesterday, the Prime Minister is not prepared to take any action other than that that has already been agreed to by virtue of that accord last year.

If the Government believes that the only solution to containing the costs in this community in order to generate jobs is by improving our competitiveness, I must ask it what has happened to the 100,000 jobs that the Prime Minister promised us last year as a result of the devaluation of he dollar. Honourable senators will recall that the Prime Minister got on his soapbox last year when the dollar crashed after the famous MX missile crisis. He told us that this would all be a good thing in the long run and that we would end up with 100,000 extra jobs. Have those jobs arrived? Can the Prime Minister identify them? Why did he not refer to them in his statement last night? In fact, he offered exactly the opposite point and said that our living standards were falling. This means that the number of jobs in the community is dwindling and that living standards are down by some 3 per cent.

At the beginning of my remarks I noted how this Government's policies of encouraging high borrowings overseas had led to high interest rates-in fact, the highest real interest rates in 50 years. The Government risked the very balance of payments problem that it now has by its policy of borrowing to pump money into the economy to produce growth and, by its standards, generate jobs. Now it is not only stuck with a high and increasing trade deficit but it also has a high Budget deficit of its own. Both these deficits are unlikely to produce lower interest rates in the short term. Nothing could be more destructive of the incentives for business to invest in new jobs than these continuing high interest rates in Australia. If we view this scenario against Australia's inflation rate, which is stuck at about twice the level of that of our trading partners, coupled with an inflexible system of wage determination and an obdurate ACTU, we now have a very difficult position to be managed by any government. This Government particularly is incapable of managing it. This effectively denies the Government any control over the absolutely vital pivot of economic policy-its wages policy. This is the core of the problem which this Government failed to address in the Prime Minister's statement last night. It has failed to do anything more than had already been agreed to between the Government and the ACTU last September. It has failed to deal with wage discounting in any detail whatsoever. It failed to deal with the so-called productivity case and the superannuation deal. It surrendered to the ACTU at the vital moment of crisis when Australia demanded action from its Government. Australians' jobs are at stake and the jobs for unemployed Australians and for future Australians are in the balance. There is more than a need to protect Australia's living standards. Australia demands positive action from this failing Government to cut the cackle and get on with the job-a job which it obviously does not have the heart nor, apparently, the nerve to undertake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Messner has moved a hypocritical urgency motion on behalf of the Opposition. He did not talk much about living standards which are the central point of his urgency motion. The Opposition is concerned to protect the living standards of only some Australians-those whose living standards are already high. It does not care about those in poverty or even those in employment who are in receipt of low and moderate incomes. The Opposition's attitude has been shown over the years by its record in government and by its pronouncements in opposition. In fact, it fights against any attempt to protect and, even more so, any attempt to improve, the living standards of the less well off in our society. Members of the Opposition have been chanting for a long time the slogan about Australians living beyond their means. Also, they have demanded that living standards drop. They cannot have it both ways about protecting living standards.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Messner stated untruth after untruth and misrepresentation after misrepresentation, both about the economy and about the Government's policies. In fact, there has been positive action by this Government to protect living standards. The Government has been attempting to take positive action over the past three and a quarter years since the 1983 election; and that is what it has achieved. This Government has a record which ought to be the envy of those opposite. It puts them to shame when we compare it with the seven damaging dismal years of the Fraser Government during which Senator Messner was a Minister-undistinguished, perhaps, but he has to share the blame for those years. Of course, his leader, Mr Howard, was the Treasurer for much of that period and during that time he showed little concern for the living standards of Australians. This Government's task has been made more difficult because of those seven years and the earlier 23 years of conservative rule during the 1950s and 1960s.

The Opposition has the impertinence to suggest that more positive action should be taken and taken only by the Government. Of course the Government, especially a Labor government, should take the lead. However, those opposite do not acknowledge the need, as expressed by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) last night, for all sections of the community to share the challenge facing us. The Opposition is always clamouring for living standards to be reduced for Australians generally. It opposes the centralised wage fixation system which protects living standards. The drier and uglier amongst members of the Opposition would have the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission abolished. They want to see industrial chaos. They oppose the accord which aims to protect living standards, not only income and working conditions but also the other aspects of the social wage which are so crucial to all overall living standards-welfare, health, education, housing and so on. On the whole the accord has been effective in doing so. At the same time the Government is ensuring an unprecedented period of industrial stability, improvement in productivity and growth in the economy.

The Opposition clamours for more and more cuts in Government expenditure, especially in those areas which are part of the living standards of this country. Yet, it has the cheek to come in here and pretend that it is in favour of protecting living standards. For example, the Opposition would chop Medicare completely just as it dismantled Medibank until it was a complete mockery of the original scheme. The Opposition does not acknowledge that health is an important aspect of Australians' living standards. To the Opposition, universal health insurance coverage is anathema. If it has its way, the better-off would be protected. The higher income earners would pay less for private health insurance while the low and moderate income earners would have to pay more and receive less effective coverage. This Government does not agree that only the wealthy have the right to be healthy.

The Government has been, and is continuing to be, very rigorous in its budgetary saving exercises. Every year so far we have achieved expenditure reductions of the order of $1 billion-$1,000m. This is more than the Opposition when in government was ever able to achieve. Those reductions in outlays included some which caused pain to those of us who wanted particular programs to continue or to receive a higher level of support. Last night the Prime Minister referred to a further $1,000m of identified savings. No doubt these will include some painful and unwelcome cuts. But the Government is attempting to achieve a deficit level which is said to be in accordance with the demands of the economy while at the same time protecting living standards as much as possible. What is absolutely clear is that the Opposition's choices about where the cuts should be made would be quite different from the Government's and would lead to worse effects on the living standards of ordinary Australians. No matter how much the Government responds to the call for expenditure restraint, no matter how responsible we are about it, the Opposition and all of its powerful friends in business and industry call for even more and more to be chopped from the Budget. They are never satisfied.

At the same time the Opposition is being completely hypocritical because it keeps proposing more and more of its own favourite expenditure programs which really would blow out the Budget. It wants those parts of the tax reform package with which it disagrees, because of its ideological prejudice and its desire to protect the well-off in this society, not to be implemented. However, it wants other aspects, such as the forthcoming tax reductions, to proceed. The Opposition does not want the capital gains tax, mild and totally prospective as it is, to proceed. It opposes the fringe benefits tax, fair and reasonable and as watered down as it is. It wants the rip-off of entertainment deductions to be restored. It does not want negative gearing dealt with as the Government is dealing with it. It wants to protect its mates involved in the tax avoidance industry. It has committed itself to repealing the tax reforms of which this Government can be proud. It wants to return to the dark days of an unfair tax system.

The Government is taking positive action to protect the living standards of Australians. As I have just suggested, it is making the tax system fairer. It is spreading the load in a more reasonable way so that the burden does not fall primarily on pay as you earn taxpayers-those who do not have the opportunity to rort the system. Of course, we will be introducing really substantial tax cuts some time between September and December this year.

Let me just list some of the achievements of this Government in various areas of policy that affect living standards in Australia. In the area of social security, available funds have been concentrated where the needs are greatest. In respect of unemployment, the increase in the adult single rate of unemployment benefit has reduced the gap between it and the pension level from $12.85 to now only $6.45. Family assistance has been provided to those who need it most. The pension rate per child has increased by 60 per cent. Help for those people renting has been increased substantially. Those who are in the greatest need-those whose living standards are most in need of protecting-have been looked after. In respect of community services, we have doubled the number of child care places available and an extra 20,000 places will be offered by 1988. The Government has instituted programs in the area of community services. It has taken action in regard to disability services. I refer to the home and community care program and the supported accommodation assistance program. The Office for the Aged was established as a result of the reorganisation which resulted in the Department of Community Services.

Achievements have also been made in Aboriginal health. Only three years ago 27 Aboriginal medical services were funded. Now there are 49 and over $15m has been committed. In the area of employment something like 10,500 Aboriginal people have been placed in jobs under the community employment program and many of these have now found permanent jobs. Aboriginal education has been promoted. There are specific programs to ensure an adequate supply of Aboriginal teachers. Those are just some examples of this Government working to protect living standards of Australians in all sorts of ways.

In education, despite the difficult economic circumstances, we have managed to provide extra places in tertiary education-3,900 in 1984, 5,500 in 1985, and around 5,000 in 1986. Full time enrolments in higher education are up by around 8 per cent. There is a participation and equity program. The Government has worked hard to increase participation and equity at all levels of education. That program is aimed at the most disadvantaged groups. In 1984 funding for schools was increased by 5.6 per cent. A four-year funding program has been legislated for 1985 to 1988 to give schools some security in funding arrangements. I turn to housing. This year the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement has provided $654m of direct Federal funding to the States. Funding has been granted for much needed research into housing and homelessness. This will allow the Government to define its policies and determine areas of real need. Of course, assistance is provided through the first home owners scheme, which, again, has helped so many thousands of Australians to buy their own homes.

Even matters such as the status of women involve questions of living standards of Australians. The sex discrimination legislation is an important achievement which ensures that those Australians who have been discriminated against in the past will be looked after. Women's information centres have been opened in Brisbane and Hobart-in the two States where there is special need, because of the State governments that are involved-to provide the much needed service and information to those women who have been ignored by those State governments. Assistance in the immigration and ethnic affairs area has been provided through grants to cultural groups, again to look after their needs. So we have had economic growth and increased employment, including the introduction of schemes such as the community employment program to ensure that as many Australians as possible can be assisted in getting away from the problem of unemployment and getting into permanent jobs.

Later in the debate Senator Cook will deal with some of the other economic aspects of the statement the Prime Minister made last night, especially the wage aspects, and so on. I want to highlight just one important aspect in the Prime Minister's address to the nation-that is his call for business to play its part not only by investing, working to increase exports and, with individual consumers, buying Australian goods where possible, but also by being more reasonable about price increases. There is always the temptation to charge what the market will bear, regardless of cost increase, the worth of the goods concerned or the ability of the consumer to pay. A recent Australian Consumer Association survey showed that supermarket prices have risen well above the consumer price index. So I think it is important for business to heed the Government's call for reasonableness in price increases.

There is also the need for non-wage remuneration-executives' salaries, directors' fees and professional incomes-to be restrained. If that does not happen, how can anyone expect ordinary wage and salary earners to accept the restraint they have already shown and are being asked to continue to show? Let the Opposition support these aspects of the Government's call for action. We will not get that support, of course. The Opposition is basically not in favour of equity. If it were fair dinkum it would endorse the Government's program involving, as I have said, some hard decisions to maximise employment prospects, to make it more likely that we can not only protect living standards in Australia but also enhance them for all and not just for some. That is what I want to see. The Opposition's prescription is to reduce living standards even more. So I reject the so-called urgency motion as being not only unnecessary but also hypocritical.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is one policy issue on which we are all agreed, and this is the urgent need for jobs, jobs and more jobs. The question is how to get them. There is no doubt that if the 580,000 unemployed people in Australia were to be found employment the Government would be better off to the tune of $4.5 billion, and most of its budgetary problems would be over. There is also not doubt that as Australia's terms of trade have dropped, our living standards have inevitably dropped. That raises the question, even if only temporarily, of how this fall in our living standards is to be shared across the community generally and what are we to do to increase our living standards in the future.

SPEECH.PARA: The policy prescription of the Opposition amounts to a recognition of the need to drop our living standards. Its prescription is to cut wages and government expenditure, which is another way of saying: `Let us reduce the standard of living of the workers of this country and of others dependent on governments'. Unfortunately the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), in giving his prescription said very similar things with less force. There were very few hard policy options in the Prime Minister's statement to the nation. There was certainly no change of direction for the economy.

Let us look briefly at what the Prime Minister said. The only concrete pledge was that there would be further wage discounting. The likely outcome of the present wage case, a 2.3 per cent pay rise, is to be the only pay rise for workers during 1986. There is some considerable doubt as to how this will be achieved, although it is significant that Simon Crean has said over the last few weeks that the Australian Council of Trade Unions would perhaps be willing to delay the next wage decision. That really looks like the only concrete policy option that the Government has come up with. The Government said that prices are not to be controlled; that it will ask business to be careful about increasing them. The Budget is to be cut by $1 billion. What that will mean at the end of the day is really anybody's guess. The tax cuts and the productivity case will go ahead. Australians are to be encouraged to buy Australian goods, to invest, to run faster, to sing louder and to sail yachts. I am afraid that it is all pretty airy-fairy stuff.

Regrettably, we are seeing the end result of the Government's commitment to total deregulation. It has not been able to respond sensibly to a balance of payments crisis other than to say that the solution is to cut wages and limit expenditure to please financial markets. The Government has delegated responsibility for the economy to international currency speculators who have no interest whatsoever in Australia other than making profits out of currency speculation. The Government has adopted the monetarist rhetoric. It has to do this or run the risk of the currency going down the drain. It has come up with no real alternative policy option. It has not addressed the other side of the equation; it has ignored the investment side. If we are to get ourselves out of the problem we are in, we must develop export industries-both service and manufacturing industries-and we must be able to channel low cost finance to productive areas.

Over the last few months we have seen $7.7 billion channelled into the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd takeover. That amount of money, in current dollar terms, was the subject of the Khemlani scandal during the days of the Whitlam Government. It does not seem to cause so much concern these days, for reasons which are amazing to me. But the channelling of this $7.7 billion into unproductive investment is really a symptom of a much wider malaise. We are encouraging the misdirection of investment through our unwillingness to control our economic destiny. Both the Australian Labor Party and the Liberal Party of Australia are saying: `Let the market forces reign supreme no matter what the consequences'. In simple terms, we are like a family living beyond its means, buying all kinds of expensive goods on time payment without the income to meet its commitments. That is a recipe for disaster for a family and it is a recipe for disaster for our economy.

There is only one solution. We must work our way out of bankruptcy. Unfortunately, we have not been given a new direction as to how to do that. The Australian Democrats have addressed this problem. We have a very clear policy direction. We say that it is essential for the Government to intervene creatively in the economy so that we can establish a strong private sector and an export-oriented manufacturing and service industry in this country. It can be done. It has been done by countries such as Japan. In 1945, it started from a heap of rubble and today it has an industrial machine that is the envy of the whole world. Japan now makes more motor cars than the United States of America, it produces 53 per cent of the steel used in the United States and it makes 90 per cent of the motor bikes. I could go on ad nauseam, but I will not.

TALK.START.PARA: —We started with a heap of rubble, too, after this lot had been in government.

—I just wish that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce would be a little more specific in his policy statements as to what we should do about it. In the time that I have available I will very quickly outline nine policy points that represent the Democrats' solution to our current economic problem. The first is creative government assistance to develop export-oriented industries, both servicing and manufacturing industries. Existing industries must be assessed as to their viability and their export potential. Areas which have a capacity to compete successfully internationally must be identified and assisted. The old red herring that one cannot pick winners has to be disregarded. We do have winners and if we do not pick them nobody else will do it for us. The second policy option that the Democrats advocate is government and industry co-operation. Government and industry must co-operate to establish long term indicative plans so that key industry sectors can be identified and given concrete directions for the future. The criterion for assessing the long term directions must be the potential to develop them as export oriented industries. We must do this based on the model that the Japanese again have set with their Ministry of International Trade and Industry.

SPEECH.PARA: The third policy direction is the protection of our foreign currency reserves. By scrapping exchange controls the Government has given up any power it ever had to control the flow of money into and out of this country. Our savings have to be mobilised and they must be mobilised to fund national priorities. They cannot be left to slosh around the world's money markets, as is happening at the moment. The fourth policy direction is the encouragement of productive investment. At present, although our profit levels and our share of profits in industry are rising, investment in industrial plant and equipment is stagnant. Investment is being misdirected into share market speculation and current business activity is obsessed with takeovers simply because they are seen as the quickest way to make money. If there is no encouragement or direction to do other than that, we will see money being squandered on stock market ventures for the control of companies so that they can then be split up, sold to overseas bidders and so on, as we have recently seen with the Repco company. Here a New Zealander got control of a very important Australian company and, within a matter of months, that company has been broken up and the initial purchase price already recovered by that entrepreneur. While those sorts of profits can be made on the Australian stock exchange, who will put money into productive resources?

The fifth area of policy as we see it is that we must do something about the on-cost burden on industry. We are not competitive because Australian industry carries an on-cost burden out of all proportion to its competitors around the world. I speak of things such as payroll tax and workers compensation. The full imputation of dividends, of course, will help us to some degree and we can congratulate the Government on that initiative at least. I turn to the sixth policy area-that is, to introduce a `Buy Australian' Act. We note that the Government will encourage the buying of Australian products, if they are competitive, of course. Nobody wants to see rubbishy Australian products bought by governments or by the general public. But the fact of the matter is that last year $22 billion was spent by governments, State and Federal, on equipment and goods generally. If just 5 per cent of the $22 billion could be directed to be spent on Australian equipment and goods by governments it would save $1.2 billion in foreign exchange.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry, what is the $22 billion for?

—The $22 billion is the total government expenditure, State and Federal, last year. It is an enormous sum. I am suggesting that a big percentage of that was spent on overseas purchases. If 5 per cent were directed to Australian purchases, it would have made a big difference-a $1.2 billion difference in fact. There is no reason why the Australian Government could not bring down a `Buy Australian' Act, just as the United States has a `Buy America' Act, which simply requires governments, where possible, to buy goods made in that country.

SPEECH.PARA: The seventh policy area is that some direction to investment should be given. Fifty per cent of the money spent on stock exchanges in Australia comes from superannuation. If guidelines were brought down, there is no doubt that we would have an enormous potential to encourage productive capacity in Australia through that area. The eighth policy initiative that we would recommend is that further attention be given to personal income tax to break down the very steep marginal tax rates that apply in the average income area. This would go a long way towards encouraging personal incentive.

The ninth and final point I make is that the best way for our industries to become internally efficient is to encourage worker participation. That is the secret of Japan's success. It is a matter that receives a certain amount of support from both sides of this Parliament but, unfortunately, very little action. My Employee Participation Bill 1985 still awaits debate in this place. It is very straightforward; it embraces principles that have been proven in many countries, notably in Japan. It encourages employee share ownership, giving employees a stake in their enterprise so that we can establish an environment of co-operation. It sets down a system of small group activities so that we can look to employees for their contribution to ways of improving the efficiency of the companies. It suggests profit sharing. I am pleased to see that the Opposition is encouraging that in its policy documents as well. My Bill suggests that we should have consultative councils in business so that internal problems can be discussed before they become major matters requiring the intervention of the trade union movement.

I have outlined nine policy areas. As I have said, their hallmark is creative intervention by the Government in the way the economy is managed. It is pitiful that the Government has renounced any responsibility to intervene in the economy and is simply making this plaintive cry to international money markets: `Whatever you do, do not sell down the Australian dollar'. We should have control over our own destiny. We should have control over our own money markets. We should not lie back abjectly and let the international speculators do what they will with Australia. We do have the resources and the power to do something about it. Many countries do it and there is no reason why Australia should not.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLARD
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the following motion of urgency which was put to the Senate by my colleague Senator Messner:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The need for more positive action by the Government to protect the living standards of Australians.

It will come as no surprise to those people who are interested in this debate that this has been brought about by the speech to the nation last night by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), a speech which has fallen flat everywhere and which very few people chose to listen to in any case. When he was speaking today on Ray Martin's show Mr Hawke had quite a lot to say but I will quote one little section. He said:

It's going to be a tough Budget and its going to be a tough Premiers Conference because the simple fact is that we can't as a community just keep spending on the basis that we'll borrow abroad to finance the sort of levels of consumption that we want to have so we've got to make the decisions as governments, federal and state, that give effect to that.

It is almost as though-we have heard this expression quite frequently lately-Mr Hawke also has been on the road to Damascus. He is just saying what everyone else has been trying to tell him for the last six to 18 months. Quite interestingly, when Senator Coates was supposed to be addressing himself to this subject, he did not address the subject. He talked about everything but the subject. I do not blame him. After the performance of his Prime Minister last night-I will be very interested to hear what Senator Cook has to say-it would be very embarrassing to have to go into bat on a subject such as this. However, I give Senator Coates full marks for trying, and undoubtedly we will do the same for Senator Cook.

This was the Prime Minister's big chance. We all know that he has tried to act as the great communicator. This was his big chance and he blew it. Significantly, the people of Australia accept the fact that we are in trouble. I believe a recent poll suggested that something like 64 per cent of people believe that the country is in deep and serious trouble. Here was a time for the Prime Minister of this nation to exercise leadership, and he blew it. Significantly, I noticed this morning when I was watching one of the early television programs-before most Government senators get out of bed-that, of those people who were interviewed on their way to work, many had not seen the Prime Minister's address. Two years ago it would have been hard to imagine, when the Prime Minister was going to address the nation on a matter of dire consequences, and with all the hype and the publicity before it, that people would not be watching with bated breath. But last night most people chose not even to watch the address. Those who did pretty well all gave it the thumbs down.

Mr Hawke started by mentioning the fact that when he came to government in 1983 we were in the most serious economic crisis for 50 years. What he did not say was that we are a great exporting nation and that we were then also in the middle of one of the worst droughts this nation had had for some considerable time. He did not say that the international economic situation was not good at that time either. Those are the parts that he overlooked. Senator Chaney quite rightly pointed out yesterday that the Prime Minister was going on air last night and that, after three years of his rule, the drought has broken but we are in the worst economic situation we have been in for 53 years. So the Prime Minister took to the infamous box to tell the people all about it. As we have indicated, he blew it.

Quite significantly, the economic crisis with which we are confronted now is peculiar to Australia. There is no international recession as such, as there was in 1983, and no drought. The economic crisis is peculiar to Australia. Indeed, the economies of most of our trading partners-those against whom we compete internationally-are quite strong. I give credit to Mr Hawke for having spelt out some of the problems. We are receiving less for our exports; we all know that. In one of the Prime Minister's answers to Ray Martin, he said:
I think that the people of Australia will come to understand what's been done to us by the rest of the world.

That is fair enough. The Opposition has no quarrel with that as far as it goes; but our terms of trade are only part of the story. I shall quote Senator Chaney once again. Some time ago in a different debate he made the point that as a nation we are consuming more than we are producing; we are buying more than we are selling. That is the crux of the matter. It is not just our terms of trade. This is being reflected in our current account deficit. For the financial year 1985-86 it looks as though the current account deficit will go pretty close to $13.7 billion. Our overseas debt is currently approaching $80 billion. Significantly, that figure has doubled in the three years that the Hawke Labor Government has been in power. That is a large amount of money. In fact, it is so much money that it is almost mind-boggling and people find that it goes over their heads.

Let us bring the situation down to a level on which we can all understand it a bit better. When a family sits down to draw up its yearly budget, it can project pretty well what the breadwinner-the husband, the wife or both-will earn. They put down that figure and look at their costs and they are then able to balance them out. They know what they have coming in, how much they can afford by way of rent or house repayments, whether they can afford to change the car, whether they can afford to send the children to a particular school or buy them new clothes. That is the sort of thing that every household does every year. What happens if the family says: `Hang the expense, let's live it up. Let's put in a swimming pool. Let's air-condition the living room. Let's get a new hi-fi stereo set'. The family borrows to do that. At the end of the year there is still the same amount of money coming in and so the family finds itself in pretty dire trouble. They may be evicted from the house and the house sold. The car may have to be repossessed and so on. In other words, the family is technically bankrupt. The same thing can happen, and indeed is happening, to this once great country of ours. Whereas a country does not quite go bankrupt as easily as does a family, quite a few economic analysts are suggesting that it will not be too long before the International Monetary Fund comes in like the big banker and starts sitting down with the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and saying: `Well, Mr Treasurer, your country is now indeed a banana republic and this is how you will construct your fiscal policy'.

Obviously, for us to survive, the first thing we have to do is to sell more. It is no use our growling about our terms of trade. We recognise that that is something over which we have no control. Having recognised that, we have to see what we can do about it. The problem is that we have become less competitive, particularly over the last three years, and at the same time we have gone deeper into debt. Nobody has tried to balance the budget as an ordinary family would have to do. Mr Keating, and to a lesser extent Mr Hawke, have quite often cited figures showing that we have had so much economic growth or so much recovery. Indeed, those figures are right on the surface. However, I say to honourable senators that what we have had has been a debt led recovery. We are like the family that went beyond its budget because it wanted to live it up, to live beyond its means, and borrowed to do so. That is the situation in which Australia finds itself. We have had a debt led recovery and we are now paying the price. We have to become competitive. We have to increase productivity. We have to reduce our costs; in other words, we have to encourage the farmers, miners and manufacturers to be able to produce more and sell more, because they are the engine room of this society. They are the people, the only people, the only sector of the community, who will get us out of trouble.

The one concrete thing that Mr Hawke said last night was that there would only be one wage increase this year. Significantly, that will be an added cost and an added burden on our competitiveness. That was the one structural, firm thing that Mr Hawke said. The rest was hyperbole and rhetoric. He did not come to grips with our structural problems. He must realise, as all members of this Government must realise, that neither the Australian Council of Trade Unions nor the Government raises our standards of living; they just redistribute what other people produce. It is those in the engine room of the society who have to be encouraged. They are the ones who should be helped and not hindered by things such as the fringe benefits tax. We must recognise that we have on-costs which other nations do not have, such as the 17.5 per cent leave loading, four weeks annual leave and long service leave. Our competitors do not have those on-costs. I am not saying we should do away with them. We can keep all of those things, but we must work that much harder than the nations which do not have those costs if we want to survive and if we want to maintain our standard of living. As is the case with the family budget, what one cannot afford one cannot have.

Much has been said in regard to jobs. My colleague Senator Messner mentioned the job situation. I will refresh the memories of honourable senators opposite with regard to the level of unemployment during 1974 and 1975. There seems to be something about a Labor government. It is big spending, big taxing and all the rest of it. In those two years it tripled our rate of unemployment. It also increased our inflation rate to heights which we never thought we would see in this country. Now the present Labor Government is talking about the fact that it has provided 600,000 to 700,000 jobs since it has been in office. Of course, it does not say in what sectors those jobs have been created. The taxpayers of this nation are funding about 150,000 of those jobs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Eighty per cent in the private sector. Get your facts right.

—The taxpayers are funding those jobs which are certainly not in the productive sector. The Minister can say that some of those jobs have been created in the private sector, but they are government assisted jobs or schemes. This country cannot survive on that sort of basis.
—Rubbish!

—Senator Button, in all honesty, knows that that is so, because he alludes to it quite often. The Prime Minister has identified $1 billion in savings in the Budget. Every government at this time of the year prunes forward bids. What did this Government do in 1983? It belted us continuously over the head in regard to the projected deficit of $9.6 billion, before the forward bids had been pruned. The Government cannot have it both ways. It cannot say to the country `We are pruning our forward bids' and still belt us over the head with that spurious and artificial figure, as it did then. William Gladstone once said: `The first essential for a Prime Minister is to be a good butcher'. That is what this Prime Minister must do in regard to his own profligacy and government spending. Significantly, the government sector now makes up a little in excess of 40 per cent of our gross domestic product. No nation can continuously afford that sort of a figure. So this Prime Minister must be a good butcher, but he must start work in his own butcher's shop.

SPEECH.PARA: This nation must come to grips with the problems we are facing. They are structural problems, and this Government must treat them as structural problems. We must increase our productivity and get rid of our archaic work practices that are holding us back. We must get our costs down and we must reduce expenditure in the government sector as a percentage of GDP. We must get rid of government imposts on the private sector. Unless this Government is prepared to address those matters in a meaningful way, Mr Hawke had better book television time for a repeat performance, because he will need to talk to the nation again in about six to 12 months time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a cliche to say that I rise more in sorrow than in anger. Unfortunately, it is true that I rise sorrowfully to deal with the puerile superficiality that the Opposition has put forward in this debate. I guess it is a reflection of the depths to which the Liberal Party has plummeted that this is the best it can do after a major economic statement has been issued. Senator Siddons made a gallant effort to rescue this debate with some degree of respectability, but he, too, was torn on the grounds of no responsibility for hard decisions and having a two bob each way package. At least he made an effort. Senator Messner put in a dreary and shallow performance, and Senator Collard a pedestrian one. I now look forward with some dread to the theatrical histrionics of the schoolboy debating champion, Senator Peter Baume, when he replies to the debate.

SPEECH.PARA: This could have been an important debate. It has not been an important debate because the Opposition has failed to address any issues seriously. If it were to be thoughtful and not engage in a sloganeering exercise in cheap political rhetoric, it would have concentrated on establishing what is the case in regard to the Australian economy, analysed what are the problems, canvassed what could be the solutions and, informed by a sense of reality and not fantasy, suggested what would be constructive outcomes for the Government to seek in the economy. None of those things has been tried. It has been an exercise in political gimmickry, and we are all the worse off for that.

What is true about the Australian economy is that intrinsically on a domestic basis it is a strong economy. What is true is that the J-curve is working-not in the superficial, comprehensive way in which political analysts and Opposition spokesmen sometimes allege, but in a sectorial way our trade balance is picking up and the J-curve is showing signs of turning around. What is also true is that, despite all of those things, world terms of trade have moved against us. We cannot pretend that that does not exist; it does. It is a reality with which we must deal and it is a reality to which the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) addressed his message to the nation last night. Senator Messner in his remarks pretended that that does not exist. At least John Howard, the failed former Treasurer, was honest enough to say, in commentary this week, that Australia is living beyond its means. That is what the Prime Minister said last night. He addressed a comprehensive program for dealing with the structural adjustment of this economy to the world trading scene, so that we can grow again, be more competitive and provide an increasing living standard in the medium to longer term for our citizenry.

All of those matters were ignored by Senator Messner and some other speakers in this debate, as if sacrifices do not have to be made. Indeed, the emphasis of their contribution is that if there are sacrifices to be made, they must all be made on one side. The emphasis of what the Prime Minister said last night, and what we assert is the only way this country can proceed to deal with the very difficult terms of trade problem we have, is that if there are to be sacrifices there must be an equality of sacrifice across the board. It is not an argument of protecting privilege. It is not an argument of singing, as did Senator Messner, a hymn of hate against trade unions. It is not an exercise in pompous rhetoric or shallow superficiality.

What is perhaps one of the most outstanding statistics, in all of the statistics that have been canvassed in this debate, is that the deficit in our terms of trade in 1982 comprised 6 per cent of gross domestic product. It is slightly less than that now. In 1982 it was not noticed as being a major flaw in our economic performance, because we had then an inflation rate in excess of 11 per cent. We had over 600,000 Australians unemployed. There was constant disputation and division. There was negative growth in that year. In that plethora of adverse statistics, that performance was not noticed. The fact is that we have turned the economy around in terms of inflation. We have brought the level of inflation down. We have turned the economy around in terms of unemployment by reducing the level of unemployment. There are higher participation rates than at any time during the Fraser period. In view of the fact that there is far less disputation now than there has been over the last several decades, in view of the fact that we have achieved positive growth, and in view of the other positive indicators in terms of the unit cost of labour and so on, that present figure of just under 6 per cent of GDP stands out. That is why this Government is addressing it.

As I have said in previous debates in this chamber when the economy has been centre stage, the Liberal Party's rhetoric on economic solutions cannot be given any credence because if one resorts to the record one sees that what it achieved when in power was negative economic growth, spiralling inflation, burgeoning unemployment, higher labour unit costs, rampant division and industrial conflict, wages explosion and a switch of investment away from the manufacturing sector into the mining areas, thus building into the economy the structural problems with which we are now dealing. That is the record of honourable senators opposite, who lecture and hector this Government today-a Government that has presided over a resurgence of the economy. The Opposition uses that record to try to pretend that it has some credibility in this matter.

We have seen an overcoming of the recession. We have seen a lowering of inflation and unemployment and all those things that I have spoken about. Under this Government it is possible to achieve a discount of wages because of the prices and incomes accord which it has with the Australian Council of Trade Unions. It is possible to achieve a redistribution, in terms of gross domestic product, from wages to profits-undertaken due to the accord-because of moderate wage outcomes. This has lifted profits to record levels. We now expect that those profits will be invested in the manufacturing sector. That has been achieved because of the accord. It has been possible to set up a co-operative framework to tackle problems such as those in the steel and motor vehicle industries. It is now possible to tackle the problems in the heavy engineering area with the package brought out in that area. It is possible now to protect jobs, to make those sectors competitive and to get investment back into those sectors so that we can take our place as a competitive nation. As well it was necessary to float the exchange rate to let the dollar, which was overvalued under the Liberals, find its proper level. All of those things have been achieved because of the accord. All of those things were the starting point for the Prime Minister's address to the nation last night.

It is not that we have done anything wrong. We have done everything right. Because we have done everything right we have been able to tackle these problems. As I have said, the domestic economy is sound but, as a nation, we are caught in an international trade war. Minerals and agricultural products form 90 per cent of our exports. On the agricultural front, because of the common agricultural policy of the European Economic Community, we are caught with an oversupply of agricultural products on the world stage. That world-wide oversupply has pushed the United States into passing its Farm Bill, which will further complicate the matter. If we add the competitiveness of East Asia in this area too, we find that many of our traditional markets are being flooded by agricultural goods that are more competitive than ours. That is having an adverse effect on a major trading sector for this country.

We find an oversupply of minerals around the world. Just recently the Japanese were able to negotiate a lower price for Australian iron ore. That has nothing to do with anything that is the fault of this country. We are a more efficient and more reliable producer of iron ore now than at any other time in our history. However, Brazil, India and other countries are contributing to the oversupply of iron ore. Because the client country, in this case Japan, wants to lower the price it is able to break the price ring and negotiate. Japan has offered a higher volume and market share to India in exchange for iron ore at a lower price. This then forces the other suppliers of iron ore to follow suit. They are some of the real reasons that we are in difficulties in regard to our terms of trade.

To face those problems we have to shift investment into our manufacturing sector. It is true that all world economies that are performing well now do so because they have a burgeoning and buoyant manufacturing sector. It is true also that under the Fraser Government, when the false horizon of the mineral boom was being pursued, investment switched from our manufacturing sector, in search of a quick buck in dividend returns, to minerals. We are now paying the price for that loss of investment because we have not re-established our capital stock. We have not modified our production processes to be competitive. That is what this Government is addressing. We do not do it with cheap populist stunts. We answer the challenge. We do not have the snake oil remedies that the Liberals are talking about. The almost sole purpose of the Prime Minister's address last night was to stimulate investment in this economy in order to make jobs. I must say that I have been disgusted by the greed and self-interest of some employers who, not recognising what the union contribution to the stimulation of this economy has been, simply ask for more and more. Rather than describing myself what in fact the union contribution has been I turn to an article written by a senior economics commentator in this country, Ross Gittins, in the Sydney Morning Herald of 2 June. He said:

The signs that the Government may ask the ACTU to accept further wage discounting will neither surprise nor satisfy the bosses. To them, wages are always too high and it's always the right time for a pay cut.

But to ordinary wage-earners and their union representatives, it's very hard to swallow. From their point of view, they already have shown a considerable degree of restraint and it's a bit rich to ask for more. They've already forgone any catch-up for the wage freeze, accepted the Medicare fiddle, agreed to a wage discount for the depreciation, cut back their productivity claim, allowed it to be delayed until July 1 and phased in over two years, and have been waiting since April for the latest indexation adjustment.

As for the two compensating tax cuts, they only offset the effect of fiscal drag. So I'm quite prepared to accept that wage-earners have demonstrated an impressive degree of restraint, particularly when you consider the pay rises they could have got away with had they tried. They've stuck to the Accord agreement; wages drift has been modest, and the level of strikes is way down.

Ross Gittins went on to talk about the reduction in real labour unit costs as well. That is the commitment that has been made to rectifying this economy by those on the labour and union side. In addition, they are being asked to take a further wage discount by accepting the delay in the current national wage case which would amount to a one per cent discount on the wage outcome. They are being asked to accept a further one per cent discount at the next national wage case, on 1 January next year. On top of that they are being asked to accept a further discount in real terms of an unspecified amount. They are also being asked to accept the deferral of tax cuts from 1 September to some time before 1 December.

I think that no matter what one thinks about those outcomes the Government is seeking from the union side they are indeed, as expressed by the independent commentator Ross Gittins, a considerable sacrifice. What is needed now-if honourable senators opposite who are members of the Liberal Party had any guts they would stand up and say so-is price restraint. This year we are looking at wage increases of 4.3 per cent but price increases of over 8 per cent. It is about time that we heard a call from the Liberals for a restraint on prices. It is about time we heard a call for States to hold taxes and charges too. It is about time we heard a call for executive and upper class salaries, which have been galloping ahead of those of ordinary wage and salary earners, to be held back to those levels as well. It is about time we heard something about professional incomes being kept in line with those of ordinary wage and salary earners. We hear nothing at all about that. Honourable senators opposite do not want equality of sacrifice. They do not want to meet the challenge that this country faces. They simply want to continue on in their ideologically blinkered way demanding more and more sacrifices so they can wax under some of the profits generated and not reinvested in this country.

The challenge that the Prime Minister's address last night put squarely is that business should now invest. The climate has now been set. There is now no restraint on investment. None of the possible barriers to investment that could have been put up have been introduced. It is now an open go for investment. If this package fails it will not be because of this Government, nor will it be because of what the ACTU contributes. The reason will be as stated by Ross Gittins in an article on 30 April:
Its to be hoped that Australia's businessmen will stop whingeing and making excuses, and will lift their game in the way the unions have.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the following matter of urgency which was moved by my colleague Senator Messner:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for more positive action by the Government to protect the living standards of Australians.

Labor senators cannot have it both ways. If Senator Cook and Senator Coates are right why did the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) find it necessary to make an address to the nation last night emphasising the gravity of our economic situation. If the Prime Minister was right how could these Labor senators fail to acknowledge here the gravity of the situation and the extent of the crisis? Senator Cook has told us that there has been a resurgence in the economy-a resurgence indeed. We are in trouble in Australia. That is why Mr Hawke addressed the nation last night. That is why the Treasurer, Mr Keating, a few weeks ago said that we were becoming, in his words, a banana republic. That is why Professor Fred Gruen said that our foreign debt is making our economy similar to that of a South American country such as Argentina. That is why Maximilian Walsh says that the economy is showing all the signs that preceded the two worst depressions ever for Australia-1890 and 1930.

In summary, we have a balance of trade crisis. Our Treasurer says that we are becoming a banana republic and respected commentators say we are like a South American country and are facing a very bad recession. This is a disaster for all Australians. It threatens us with fewer jobs. This will particularly affect young Australians. It threatens us with higher prices and with having to cope with a dollar that is now worth less than US60c-and worth less since last night. It threatens us with a lower standard of living. A recession of the kind that has been talked about means unemployment for young Australians because no jobs will be created. It means unemployment for adult Australians because jobs will be lost and will disappear. It means that wages will be cut-and the Prime Minister called for that. It means that there will be less overtime and more hardship and bankruptcies. It means repossessions, business failures and a failure to invest. It means blighted hopes as opportunity disappears.

Why have we heard nothing about that from Labor senators when the Prime Minister at least found it necessary to tell the nation that we were facing grave times? That is why he took the step of addressing the nation last night. Apparently the Prime Minister cares more than do those Labor senators. Australians are struggling. We know that we are worse off now than we were three years ago. We know that the Labor Government has meant more tax, more hardship and more registered unemployed-the voters of 10 electorates make up the number of unemployed after 3 1/4 years of Labor government. It means that 23 per cent of young Australians are out of work and families are unable to live on their incomes. It means more crime, more drugs, more violence and more evidence of societal failure. That is what Australian families are facing and what they are talking about.

At least our Treasurer had the honesty to talk about our becoming a banana republic. He meant it. He said it because he thinks that it is true. He knows that it is true. The Treasurer's colleagues do not mention it and as far as I am concerned they do not understand what he was saying.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you going to tell us what to do about it?

—Give me a moment, Senator Siddons. The Federal Government responded last night. What did we get? What was the response from the Prime Minister when he addressed the nation? He delivered an economic statement about the crisis. He admitted the crisis but he failed to meet it. What was the community's response to the Prime Minister's speech? Was the speech accepted as being good and effective or an adequate response to the crisis? It was not. The Sydney Morning Herald talked about it as being `a tinsel and trust package' and anti-climactic, and said that it failed to back rhetoric with specific commitments. It talked about the dollar falling in response to the speech. That was the judgment of the international community. The Sydney Morning Herald said that the speech contained too few specific decisions and had all the untimely superficiality of being thrown together since the weekend-which of course it had. The Australian said that the Prime Minister has failed to address the rigid structures that hold us back and has failed to offer the inspiration Australia needs. That is what that newspaper said today about the speech last night of the Prime Minister. The Age newspaper said that the bad news is that Mr Hawke's speech failed to fulfil the pre-address expectations. It also said that the speech failed dismally and that it is simply too late for pep talks and good intentions. Perhaps all those newspapers are wrong and Senator Cook is right. The Australian Financial Review said that instead of the fireworks expected, last night our Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, gave us a damp squib. So it goes on. The Government's speech got a thumbs down, and our currency dropped on international markets.

SPEECH.PARA: What needs to be done? The following are the standards against which Mr Hawke's speech must be judged. Did it provide economic leadership? Did it set directions? Did it take hard decisions? Did it take action? It did none of those things. Our troubles will not go away just because of slick talk. Is Mr Hawke just all talk? He failed dismally to meet the standards last night that were necessary to resolve the crisis. That was the judgment of the Press and of leading commentators. That was the judgment of the international market on our economy and that is the judgment of Australians.

The statement was vague on tax cut timing, on the amount of wage discounting, on the delay in the productivity superannuation deal, on the size of Budget spending cuts and on the size of next year's Budget deficit. These are the things about which people want to know so that they will know whether they can put any credence in what the Government is saying. Mr Hawke gave no direction, leadership, decisions or policies around which the community could rally. We have a crisis but no hard answers. A crisis without answers and with indecision will send us down the gurgler if we are not there now. We are facing more unemployment, lower wages, higher prices and a lower standard of living for families and all Australians.

But this did not need to happen this way. There are ways of pulling us out of Mr Keating's economic hole. Unlike the Australian Labor Party, the coalition has spelt out clear and specific policies. My colleague Senator Messner has already referred to some of them. We need the community to unite behind the policies. We can come out of this crisis without lowering our living standards unduly. We can improve our trade and manufacturing, our investment and productivity. Above all, we need to lower the price of production of our goods. We have dismally failed to do so under this Government in three years. Changing that alone, apart from anything else we want to do, will lead to more jobs, lower prices and eventually to higher wages.

We want an immediate recall of the Parliament for a June mini-Budget to cut government spending, because nothing was said last night about doing that. We want the productivity claim before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to be abandoned now. We want the national wage case currently being heard to be postponed for up to 12 months. We want the anti-business and anti-investment elements of the tax package abandoned now. We want foreign investment controls relaxed. This package of measures will help us come out of the recession which faces us. These specific policies give the country a clear direction. We have done what the Government is not prepared to do and have indicated what we want to see happen. In the longer term we need to introduce tax policies that provide effective incentives for risk taking and effort. We want to introduce a new industrial relations framework to promote work place productivity and greater competitiveness. We want the gradual removal of distortions and excessive regulation in industry. We want more choice, higher standards and greater relevance in education with the pursuit of excellence. We want less government and more competition in our transport and communication.

The Prime Minister last night talked about working for the dole. I remind honourable senators that this proposal is very similar to one introduced by the Fraser Government in the wage pause program. At that time, we foreshadowed that we would use money from the unemployment benefit and some saved from the wage pause to provide work for the long term unemployed. We saw then what Labor is now belatedly realising. Our proposals were attacked by the Labor Party, and on its election in 1983 the Labor Government abandoned our proposals to provide work for those on the unemployment benefit. But the Labor Party is coming back to it now because it is right and it is needed. The Government's own youth poll showed that young Australians do not want something for nothing; they want to work. We tried to give them work. The Labor Party abandoned that proposal when it came to office, and I suppose we should be grateful that it is coming back to it now. The proposal announced by Mr Hawke last night of working on community services for the dole has always been fought against by Mr Howe and by some of the left wing. They do not realise that the unemployment stigma can be beaten only by community work and by empowering people and giving people greater skills.
