One month ago we received bad trade figures. We received evidence that we were going broke as a nation under the Labor Party. We were told by the Treasurer that we were facing banana republic circumstances. We know that this could have been avoided had we spent less, produced more and indulged ourselves less. We have not heard from the Government how those issues can be addressed. It has reneged on its promises to the Australian people and it has avoided the hard options and decisions which are necessary.

Labor tries to blame its crisis on the previous administration. Labor has been in office now for almost 40 months-for 3 1/4 years. If Labor senators wish to assert in this chamber that a Labor Government cannot control the economy, cannot address problems, cannot turn things round, cannot be responsible after 3 1/4 years in government, and that 3 1/4 years is not enough time to be taking responsibility for what it has done and for resolving problems, it is time for a new government, and it is time to get rid of the Labor Government.

I want to spend one moment telling the Senate how sad some Australian parents are. A letter appeared in this morning's Australian which seems to sum up many of the problems inherent in the youth employment-unemployment debate, at a time when 23 per cent of our youth are unemployed. Mr Richard Fordham of Western Australia complained that it is hard to keep his apprentice son motivated when the son sees the good life of his many friends on the dole. The son rises each morning at 5.30 a.m. His mother cooks his breakfast and he leaves home at 6.15 a.m. to be at his place of employment by 7 a.m. Mr Fordham wrote that his son puts in a long, hard day. He averages 45 hours a week. His work is dusty, dirty and physically exhausting. He does all the cleaning and he draws at the end of a week $160 clear. In contrast, his friends on the dole get $88.20 and are allowed to earn an extra $30 a week. Most of those boys are excellent sportsmen. Six of them live in an old rented house. They have a combined income of $529.20 a week and can earn up to another $180. Usually they do not bother. The father's problem is how to keep his son motivated while people are taking the dole, doing nothing in return, and gaining nothing in the sense of responsibility.

I come back to what I said a moment ago. If the Labor Party wants us to believe that after 3 1/4 years it is not in the position to be responsible for what it has done and to be responsible for the position in which Australia finds itself, I offer to it the same advice that Oliver Cromwell offered to the Rump Parliament at the end of April 1653:
You have sat too long here for any good you have been doing. Depart, I say, and let us have done with you. In the name of God, go!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Black Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I recall reading this afternoon on the Australian Associated Press monitor a statement from the Queensland Premier to the effect that the Australian Labor Party at its next National Conference intended to abolish the Senate. I do not think that anybody has explained to him that there is a little more to it than that. At least, if that were to happen it would spare us the sorts of contributions which we have had here this afternoon, and it would, at least in one respect, be welcomed.

SPEECH.PARA: I am bemused at the idea that the Opposition will protect living standards by cutting wages. It would seem that irrespective of how the rhetoric is dressed up, the bottom line always is that wages will be cut. I am completely at a loss, as a former union official, to understand how one could protect living standards by cutting wages.

I think that it is appropriate at this time that I deal with the credibility of the Labor Government as an economic manager and compare that to the sort of record that the Opposition had when it was in government. In keeping with the general predictability of this debate, I will continue to repeat the truth to the Opposition in the hope that it will begin to understand it.

I will look at the major indicators of the economy: Inflation, unemployment and growth, and compare the position which was left to us by our predecessors with the sorts of achievements which we have been able to bring about. First, for the year ending March 1983, when we came into government, the inflation rate was running at 11.5 per cent. For the year ending March 1986, inflation was running at 9.2 per cent. For the last full financial year, 1984-85, the consumer price index was growing at a rate of 5.8 per cent. The prediction for the 1986-87 year, depending on the credibility of sources, ranged around that 5 per cent figure.

Secondly, on the subject of unemployment, during the last 12 months of the Fraser Government with the current Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) as the Treasurer, 243,000 jobs were lost to the Australian economy. That is almost a quarter of a million jobs lost. There is no real protection of living standards there. We had an unemployment rate of some 10 per cent. The unemployment rate, by this morning's figures for May, was 7.8 per cent. Since the election of the Hawke Labor Government, 674,000 jobs have been created. That represents a very real improvement in the living standards of those people.

Thirdly, in the 1982-83 financial year, dominated by the conservative policies of economic management by the Opposition, economic growth was minus 0.8 per cent. During the 1984-85 financial year, under the policies of the Labor Government, economic growth was 4.6 per cent. In the 12 months ending March 1986, the figure was 4.5 per cent. I indicate those figures to the Opposition and to those people listening in order to point out that the record of the Opposition is appalling in those areas, that the record of the Government is something to be proud of, and also to indicate that whilst we appreciate that we are facing massive problems brought on by events overseas, we nevertheless have the Australian economy in a reasonably sound position to meet those adverse circumstances.

I would now like to touch on some of the other measures which the Labor Government has brought about since it came into office. The major task we had before us when we were elected was to create jobs. As one of the earlier speakers said, our priority was jobs, jobs and jobs. As any experienced economic manager would know in dealing with the Australian economy, any increase in demand for labour across the economy can be syphoned off by disproportionate wage increases gained by workers who are lucky enough to be in a powerful bargaining position at that time. This can result in both wage inflation and unemployment, as the conservative government learnt to its sorrow. It is also inevitably accompanied by a high level of industrial disputes. What the Labor Government has achieved under the accord and under a centralised wage fixing system is a means by which the increased demand in the economy is used to mop up the large pool of unemployed which was left to us as a legacy of the Fraser-Howard years. This has been achieved with record low levels of industrial disputation. I will give a couple of figures to highlight my case.

During the seven years of the Fraser Government, the figure for average annual working days lost was 3.2 million. Under the Labor Government this figure has been halved and it is now at its lowest level for almost 20 years. This represents not only a pretty enormous improvement in the living standards of three-quarters of a million Australians who now have jobs and their families, but also a considerable improvement in the living standards of those people who have not had to fight through the strike mechanism in the work place to protect those living standards. It has also served to protect Australian workers in weaker bargaining positions who traditionally have had to rely on the mechanisms of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to protect their living standards.

The Opposition has no alternative at all to these policies. Its own industrial relations policies would create chaos and dislocation in every individual work place in this country. With no upper limit on wages, there would be a massive wages push by powerful workers and a severe dislocation as other workers sought to protect their living standards. Wage push inflation and unemployment again would be the inevitable result of these sorts of policies. Under the accord the Government has also sought to protect low income earners through a system of family income supplements under which low income earners, earning less than $273 a week, receive direct transfer payments from the Government of $16 per child per week. This is yet another means by which the Labor Government has protected the living standards of low income Australians and provided an indirect subsidy to the rural sector and to other areas of the economy which have been experiencing consistently low levels of profitability.

It is worth while emphasising that point because a lot of the rural lobbyists from the National Farmers Federation and a number of other conservative organisations who have been urging welfare cuts on the Government ought to realise that those welfare payments in a number of areas will subsidise their own level of profits. I have heard complaints from employers in the country that they cannot get labour these days for $4 an hour but that at the same time those potential workers are living off the dole. I simply point out to them that the only way they can get any workers at all for that sort of money in a deregulated labour market is because those kids are living off the dole. We are giving through the dole payment a direct subsidy to those people. I do not laud that procedure by any means. The Federal Government has done a good deal through its youth traineeship program, although we acknowledge that it is still in its infancy, to increase mobility in the work force and to introduce some degree of flexibility with traineeships.

While on the subject of improved living standards and transfer payments, I point out as far as pension payments are concerned that in March 1983, when the Fraser Government fell, the single pension payment was $77.25. In March 1986, three years later, it was $97.90. That represents a real increase of 5 per cent. As I have said, the Government has been aware of a number of problems within the economy-long term problems, nothing to do with our current balance of trade problems-which it has sought to counteract with the primary objective being the protection of living standards. The superannuation agreement currently being negotiated will do a great deal when it eventually comes to fruition to protect the position of the working poor, particularly women, people working in the private sector and part time workers. There is no way that we could continue to manage the economy of this country in the longer term without doing something to reduce the burden on the economy of increased pension payments. Some sort of superannuation agreement was needed, but, of course, it was opposed by the Opposition.

The Government has provided considerable assistance to rural producers, who we acknowledge have been facing severe problems. I remind the Opposition of the $200m rural aid package. I remind the Opposition also of the $100m sugar aid package which was delayed for about nine months due to the opposition of the Queensland Premier. The State Government wanted to claim all of the political kudos that resulted from the provision of this money. That $300m is now flowing through to the rural working poor and to their employers, and is providing a genuine measure of assistance in protecting living standards in Australia.

I also touch briefly on the proposal to introduce an identity card, which would go some way towards protecting those workers who are paying the tax they are obliged to pay through the pay as you earn system and would also prevent a degree of welfare fraud, which unfortunately exists in our society. I mention, too, the fringe benefits tax, which again is designed to protect the living standards of PAYE workers. It is designed to prevent the sorts of rorts which have proliferated over the last couple of years. That was also opposed by the Opposition.

The main point of the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) last night was the deterioration in the terms of trade and the steps that the Government intends to take to try to counteract that. I note that many of the Opposition speakers appear to have read the newspaper editorials and summaries, but it certainly appears that not many of them have read the 22-page statement attached to the address made by the Prime Minister. I commend it to them. If they had read the statement and the attachments they would have acknowledged that they are a genuine attempt to come to grips with the problem this country is facing.

Since the December quarter of 1984 our terms of trade have fallen by almost 14 per cent, with more than two-thirds of that fall coming since the June quarter last year. There are few signs of any sort of early reversal. Despite the large depreciation of the Australian dollar, which in normal circumstances would raise returns to our exporters, prices for our exports in domestic currency terms have risen little, if at all. I think the Government has made a genuine attempt to address that sort of problem, and it has listed a series of measures which will go a long way towards counteracting it. I would like to go through those and discuss them briefly.

The first proposal from the Prime Minister was that the 2.3 per cent increase sought in the current national wage case should be the only national wage increase in 1986. Outside the ambit of the accord the Opposition would have no mechanism to bring about this degree of liaison with the union movement and with wage earners generally. The Government intends to argue for further discounting in the following cases. The Government intends to seek to delay implementation of the productivity superannuation case so that it is implemented over a period of some 2 years. That is again a very real measure to ensure that in the longer term the gain is introduced and yet in the short term costs to employers are kept to a minimum. The Government is also determined to stop the growth in the wages drift by restraining non-wage pay cheques in the form of executive salaries, directors' fees and professional incomes. The Opposition has no alternative to that sort of policy, because those things would be completely deregulated under its wages system.

The Government also intends to upgrade the Prices Surveillance Authority to ensure that we have a greater capacity to restrain the growth of prices to maintain our degree of international competitiveness. The Government will also make greater efforts to hold down the level of public sector growth, which has already been considerably restrained during the last three years.

I wish to touch on a number of other measures which I have no doubt the Opposition would consider to be fluff and nonsense. They deal essentially with motivation, with people's intentions, and they are very nebulous concepts. But as anybody who has studied economics would know, those sorts of nebulous concepts provide the foundation for economics. The rest of it is a mathematical superstructure which in itself is quite okay, but if the underlying assumptions about behaviour do not hold up, none of it does. The Government intends to launch a `Buy Australian' campaign, to commence within the next few months. It also intends to promote purchasing policies which favour Australian producers, and it is setting up a committee to report on that within six months.

The Government intends also to initiate a number of other moves to encourage exports and to try to improve the balance of payments. I will list those briefly in the time remaining. They include export management education, a new small exporters scheme, a high technology exporters scheme, reduction of insurance charges on exporters and transport and handling costs, and a reduction in the pricing of agricultural inputs. I commend to members of the Opposition all of those points in the 22-page attachment, which I urge them to read. Their contributions might have been a little better had they already done so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-By any test of what has been put forward in this place today, the Government has failed to support the case made by the Opposition during this debate. The fact is that members of the Government have not successfully put forward answers to the questions that have been raised. Chiefly, and put quite simply, the Government has failed to tell us what it proposes to do to fix the economy. The statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) last night was just 22 pages of waffle. Senator Black should have known better than to try to justify the statement. No specifics are mentioned, and even when we tried to pin down the Government at Question Time in the Senate today as to what the statement really meant, for instance, by expenditure cuts, Government Ministers were not prepared to tell us in what general areas they were going to cut expenditure. They could not tell us, for instance, whether it would come off the expenditures already voted for departments and those which have been entered into already during this financial year, whether they were cuts from forward estimates proposed by departments and considered by the Expenditure Review Committee, or whether they would be some other kinds of cuts. So how on earth can anybody, after proper consideration of the Prime Minister's statement, say that the Government has made any attempt to justify in specific terms what it intends to do?

SPEECH.PARA: I pick up Senator Black's last point in connection with the terms of trade. He pointed out to us that somehow this is all beyond the control of the Hawke Government, that a 14 per cent decrease in our terms of trade has produced the results it has, and that has come about because we have had such heavy investment in our resources industries rather than in manufactured products. That is the line of the Government. Yet as my colleagues have pointed out during this debate, the Government has been in power for three years and has had responsibility for the economic policies of Australia over the period. When did the Government suddenly find out about the terms of trade? Apparently it is only in the last few days, since we found out that we are a banana republic, according to Mr Keating. The terms of trade have been around for a long time. If the Government has failed to recognise that from time to time there are changes in the terms of trade for our export industries it has failed in its duty in economic management because it has failed to address and control in a proper way the problems that are occurring in our economy. If the Government woke up to the fact that we were too heavily dependent on our export industries, why did it not start in 1983 to develop policies that would have produced alternative industrial structures? Why did not the Prime Minister spell out in his statement last night what he intends to do about alternative industrial structures? The Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd, from all the derogatory comments on the Prime Minister's speech last night, said about the statement:
. . . short on specifics and long on generalisations. It's hard to know what we've learned from the speech that we didn't know before.

That is precisely the conclusion the Opposition has reached and it is the reason why it raised this matter of urgency today. Quite clearly, all the points that were raised during the Prime Minister's statement have been put forward in the course of the last 12 months in debate with the trade union movement, by agreement with the trade union movement. The question of putting off the superannuation case for two years was agreed to last September. It was also agreed in the last 12 months that there would be only one national wage case this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where are all your supporters?

—Before I worry about that, I am sure that the Government's support would have to be examined. The point about this issue is quite clear. Apparently the Government's determination is governed by one overriding factor and that is its difficulty in coming to terms with the trade union movement, which of course is its constituent organisation. That is what the Government has failed to address in the statement. It is the point that cannot be addressed appropriately by the Prime Minister because the Government knows that the trade union movement is not prepared to forgo the very things that will cure Australia's economic problems.

SPEECH.PARA: I should again like to put on the record the Opposition's position so that the Government might contemplate the points that are brought forward and consider them in future policy development. We consider them to be the major issues before Australia in the restoration of our economic health. There are several steps. Our short term approach involves the immediate recall of the Federal Parliament to debate a mini-Budget in order to cut government expenditure. In that way we might find out the specifics of the Government's program. We seek the immediate abandonment of the specious productivity claim that is before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. We seek the postponement of the national wage case for up to 12 months. We seek the abandonment of the anti-business and anti-investment parts of the taxation package, some of which has already been passed. Of course, we seek the relaxation of foreign investment controls.

To attack the long term problems of the economy we believe that we should be doing the following: Firstly, we should be introducing taxation policies that provide effective incentives for risk taking and effort. Secondly, we should have a new industrial relations framework promoting work place productivity and greater competitiveness and co-operation between employers and employees. That policy has already been announced and is in the public arena. Thirdly, we should seek the gradual removal of distortions and excessive regulations in industry. Fourthly, there should be more choice, higher standards and greater relevance in education generally in relation to the industrial framework within which we operate. Lastly, we should have less government involvement and more competition in the areas of transport and communications which are so vital to the establishment of a more competitive economy.

By all the tests the Government failed to put forward a reasonable package in its statement last night. The Prime Minister failed to tell us in detail what he intends to do, and we know the reason why he cannot do that. The reason is that he simply does not have a program he can sell to the trade union movement. Until the Government is prepared to deal with that problem in particular the living standards of Australians will suffer as a result. Until we deal with that problem effectively we will not get more job opportunities for young people or for those who have been out of work for a long period, and apparently their number is growing. Those are the issues that need to be addressed and they are the ones this Government is failing to address.

This matter of urgency is of complete and utter relevance at the present time because it brings to the attention of the Senate the issues the Government failed to address in the statement last night and which now, through debate, have been brought forward as weaknesses in the Government's position. The Liberal-National Party Opposition has already put down its alternative position on how it would address these problems. That is something we believe ought to be carried by the Senate now so that even at this late stage the Government may turn its mind to those problems and take into account the issues that have been raised by us.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian Science and Technology Council Report

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

Today we are moving rapidly towards a cashless society as demonstrated by the community's increasing reliance on the operation of cheque accounts, credit cards and, in the last five years, electronic banking facilities. We have quickly become fluent in the use of the acronyms of the new system of financial transactions, acronyms such as ATMs for automatic teller machines, PINs for personal identification numbers, and EFTPOS for electronic funds transfer at point of sale. In the era of EFTs, money is becoming an electrical impulse travelling within a communications network. EFTPOS represents a transformation of the payments system. It reduces the need for consumers to carry cash or cheques and it extends the number of outlets from which people can operate their accounts, with very little or low transaction costs for the banks and the non-banking financial institutions. To demonstrate the benefits of the move away from the paper based and labour intensive paper transactions, in its submission to the Martin Review of the Australian Financial System the Westpac Banking Corporation estimated that the transaction cost for every cheque processed was 60c, compared with a cost of only 30c for every EFT transaction.

Electronic funds transfers have been described by the Law Reform Commission as `a legal no-man's land, with legal regulation and protection lumbering along in the wake of technological development'. Consumer protection and the safeguarding of financial privacy are major problems arising from this new technology. At present the onus to disprove a financial statement lies with the customer. The Australian Consumers Association is concerned that the burden of the loss incurred from fraudulent automatic teller machine withdrawals rests with the customer and that many customers have had their accounts incorrectly debited because of ATM malfunctions. Under most of the contracts the banks have devised, customers are now totally liable for transaction failures, even if they are a result of negligent behaviour on the part of the banker, and also for fraud and carelessness. The customer is made responsible for reviewing his or her bank statements and bringing discrepancies to the attention of the bank.

I believe that the laws must be revised, particularly the old statutes governing cheques, which are still largely drawn in terms of paper procedures, because these are now increasingly being replaced by electronic messages. I believe reform is needed in placing the onus on financial institutions to justify financial statements rather than, as at present, normally imposing on the customer the onus to disprove a statement. I believe there is a need to safeguard the financial privacy and security of the electronic system and to limit access to the data in it. I also believe there is a need to control the use to which financial institutions can put electronic, financial and personal data-for example, limiting its sale or supply to associated travel companies, insurance companies, credit cards companies and direct marketing bodies. I believe there is a need to define the extent to which law enforcement authorities can, without court orders, have access to instantaneous records of financial dealings by which movements of citizens can be traced. Legal regulation and protection are certainly lagging behind technological development.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON EDUCATION AND THE ARTS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts, I present the sixth report arising from the Committee's examination of annual reports, dated May 1986.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

On behalf of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts, I table a sixth report arising from the Committee's examination of annual reports, pursuant to the provisions of sessional order 7. During the past year, the Committee has tabled five other reports on its examination of the annual reports of Government departments and authorities. Two of these reports dealt with technical issues; namely, timeliness of reporting and the appropriate contents of annual reports. Two reports dealt with children's television. In the remaining report, the Committee dealt with the annual report of the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority and with the assessment in secondary colleges in the Australian Capital Territory.

The report I table today deals with the annual report of the Australian National Gallery for 1983-84. The Committee decided in September 1985 to examine this report in detail. At that time, the Public Accounts Committee intended to hold a public hearing with the Gallery in connection with adverse comments made about some aspects of the Gallery's administration in the Auditor-General's report of April 1985. With the agreement of the Public Accounts Committee, the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts decided to investigate the issues raised by the Auditor-General. Given its wider interests, it also pursued issues relating to other aspects of the Gallery's operations.

The Committee took evidence from officers of the Gallery and from an Assistant Auditor- General at public hearings held in Canberra on 17 October and 4 November 1985. The annual report of the Australian National Gallery for 1983-84 adhered closely to the Commonwealth Government's reporting guidelines for statutory authorities. The Committee commends the Gallery for its comprehensive coverage of its activities during 1983-84. The Gallery's annual report was one of the few reports investigated by the Committee which identified its major operational problems. The Committee considers that it is strange that relatively few statutory authorities and departments addressed operational problems in their 1983-84 annual reports.

The Committee's survey of the Gallery's operations indicated that the Gallery, in general, is well managed and is fulfilling the role set out in the National Gallery Act. The functions of the Gallery are described in the Act as follows: Firstly, to develop and maintain a national collection of works of art; and, secondly, to exhibit, or make available for exhibition by others, works of art from the national collection in the national interest. Under the Act, the Gallery is also obliged to `use every endeavour to make the most advantageous use of the national collection in the national interest'.

As I indicated earlier, the Auditor-General has commented adversely on some aspects of the Gallery's administration. It should be remembered, however, that the National Gallery has been functioning as an art gallery for only a short time. Its first full year of operation was 1983-84. The Committee considers that some of the Auditor-General's criticisms, although warranted, have resulted from what might be described as `teething problems' at the Gallery. There have also been some isolated mistakes which occurred in circumstances which are unlikely to recur. Most of these problems appear to have been solved, either during 1983-84 or in the period since 1 July 1984. Some problems, however, seem to be more deep-seated. The Committee, therefore, has made four recommendations on difficulties identified by the Auditor-General. These are that the National Gallery should: Firstly, develop and implement, as a matter of urgency, a systematic, progressive stocktaking strategy for its collections of works of art; secondly, make a special effort to complete the cataloguing of its library and to institute a system of stocktaking its library holdings; thirdly, ensure that local purchasing procedures meet all the financial management obligations required of statutory authorities as soon as possible; and, fourthly, implement a system of checks on the condition of stored works of art.

The Committee has found that the Gallery has generally functioned efficiently in terms of developing a national collection and displaying the collection in Canberra. It has also made available works of art from the collection for exhibitions in other centres and has organised some travelling exhibitions.

While commending these activities, the Committee considers that it would be desirable if the Gallery were to make works of art more readily available to all Australians, including those in localities remote from Canberra. At present, the Gallery is attempting to find private sponsorship for travelling exhibitions. The Gallery's Director, Mr Mollison, suggested that now that the National Gallery `has brought its collection to order' it may have staff it can use to work on touring exhibitions. The Committee welcomes the Gallery's initiatives in this area. It considers, however, that touring exhibitions should now be given a higher priority by the Gallery and should be a continuing activity. It has recommended, therefore:

(5) If private sponsorships are insufficient to fund touring exhibitions, the Gallery should allocate funds for such exhibitions to ensure that as many Australians as possible in areas remote from Canberra are able to view works from the national collection.
I conclude by thanking the Director and other senior staff of the Gallery for their co-operation. I commend the report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Deputy Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts that undertook this inquiry into the Australian National Gallery, I have pleasure in supporting the remarks of the Chairman of the Committee, Senator Colston. In the few moments of debate that are available to me, I will seek to highlight one particular matter. Honourable senators will recall that 3 1/2 years ago on a very splendid occasion the Queen opened the National Gallery. Some 11 years ago the Parliament passed the National Gallery Act. For some 10 years the Council of the Gallery has been conducting its work, and for nine years the administration and management of the collection have been in the hands of the Director of the Gallery, James Mollison. It was therefore timely, given that the preparatory decade has been completed and that the Gallery has been open to the public for 3 1/2 years, that the annual report of the Gallery be investigated by the Senate Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: In this first public review of the National Gallery, we found it in order and were pleased to see there a responsiveness to the Auditor-General's inquiries, and indeed to questions and other matters raised in Estimates committees over recent years. The matters that had caused some concern that were in our minds when we undertook the inquiry, we are happy to see, are now in hand in the administration of the Gallery. In this context I was anxious that our inquiry not be misinterpreted as seeking to make the Gallery more unnecessarily bureaucratic, or pedantic or inflexible. It is, after all, an artistic endeavour to locate works of art and to display them to the Australian public, and that must always be paramount in the management of the Gallery. But we see that it has the matter of accountability in perspective.

I want to emphasise the Committee's recommendation that the Gallery place even greater priority on some exhibits from the Gallery touring to other parts of Australia so that the art exhibited here permanently in Canberra can be more accessible to all Australians. The terms of our fifth recommendation are:

If private sponsorships are insufficient to fund touring exhibitions, the Gallery should allocate funds for such exhibitions to ensure that as many Australians as possible in areas remote from Canberra are able to view works from the national collection.

While we welcome and anticipate real results in the Gallery's looking to private enterprise to put up the money to enable regional touring, if that is inadequate let the agenda still be determined by the Council of the Gallery to set aside funds and to make proper submissions in the Budget process to enable the magnificence of the Gallery to be displayed to all Australians. Then we will see that the National Gallery truly has a national impact.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the 249th report from the Joint Committee of Public Accounts entitled `Proposed Computer Acquisition for Repatriation General Hospitals by the Department of Veterans' Affairs'.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: — by leave-This report contains the findings of the Public Accounts Committee's inquiry into the proposed computer acquisition for repatriation general hospitals by the Department of Veterans' Affairs. This proposal was the first received by the Committee under its standing reference to examine and report on major computer acquisition proposals before they proceed to Cabinet for approval of funds. The Committee accepted this standing reference in May 1985 in response to the Government's concern that major computer acquisition proposals are often of such complexity and raise such important related issues that they cannot be dealt with adequately under the severe pressures imposed by the Budget timetable. It is intended that the Committee's scrutiny of automatic data processing acquisition proposals will occur outside the annual Budget process and will precede any Cabinet approval for the commencement of tendering and acquisition action.

SPEECH.PARA: Some of the major matters which the Committee was requested to examine in its review of these proposals included their justification and cost effectiveness, employment and industrial relations issues, technical and other risks and provisions for Australian industry participation. The Department of Veterans' Affairs proposed computer acquisition for repatriation general hospitals was approved by Cabinet and funds of $2.6m were included in the 1985-86 Budget, subject to advice from the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh). The Minister for Finance subsequently advised the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) on 1 August 1985 that no expenditure should occur until a satisfactory report on the proposal had been received from the Public Accounts Committee.

The Committee is concerned that this proposal was not referred to it directly as a result of a Cabinet decision as envisaged under the arrangements agreed between the Committee and the Minister for Finance. It also notes that the intention of the reference was, as the then Minister for Finance, Mr Dawkins, stated in his speech, to ensure proposals are reviewed outside the Budget cycle, and well in advance of any decision to commit funds. This clearly has not been the case for this proposal where funds had already been approved for the current 1985-86 Budget subject to a satisfactory report from this Committee. The Committee is unequivocally of the view that all proposals should be referred to the Committee by Cabinet itself and well in advance of any request for or approval of funds.

The proposal from the Department of Veterans' Affairs is to upgrade the computing capacity and facilities available in repatriation general hospitals to provide an integrated hospital information system to improve patient care and treatment, including admissions, scheduling of patient services and discharges. The Department proposes to acquire an IBM computer for Concord Repatriation General Hospital and IBM compatible computers for the four other mainland capital hospitals at an equipment cost of $10m over the four years 1985-86 to 1988-89. The Department proposes to acquire the IBM computer for Concord without going out to public tender, but to request tenders for the computers for the other hospitals.

The Committee's major conclusions about this proposal are, first, that the Department of Veterans' Affairs has not to date conducted the development of an integrated information system for the repatriation hospitals in a manner consistent with existing planning guidelines and sound project management practices; secondly, that the computing systems at repatriation general hospitals generally lag well behind those available in other public hospitals; and thirdly, that some form of integrated hospital information system is the most effective way to satisfy repatriation general hospital information requirements and that the patient care system proposed offers the only available means of achieving this in an IBM compatible environment.

The Committee recommends that the Department of Veterans' Affairs proceed with its negotiations with the Department of Finance and the Department of Local Government and Administrative Services with a view to purchasing computers for the repatriation general hospitals and that the Department of Veterans' Affairs supply the Committee, accompanied by comments from the Department of Finance, with information on computer capacity requirements before placing an order for a computer at Repatriation General Hospital Concord, and that the Department of Veterans' Affairs respond to the other Committee recommendations through the Minister for Finance minute mechanism prior to proceeding beyond the purchase of the Concord computer. Should the Department of Local Government and Administrative Services accept the arguments put to it by the Department of Veterans' Affairs for a certificate of exemption for an IBM computer for Repatriation General Hospital, Concord, the Committee recommends that a supply and development contract be concurrently negotiated with IBM which ties further development and support for the patient care system software to the initial IBM computer acquisition.

The Committee also makes several general recommendations for future computer projects. Some related recommendations are also contained in the Committee's Report on the Australian Audit Office Computer Acquisition which was tabled yesterday. From its experience with the Department of Veterans' Affairs proposal the Committee recommends that departments include in their ADP strategic plans a clear statement where the proposed acquisition of computer software is subsequently likely to involve or influence computer hardware expenditures; and that this information be explicitly drawn to the attention of the Department of Finance, the Department of Local Government and Administrative Services and this Committee. I commend the report to honourable senators.

DEBATE.TITLE: AFFIRMATIVE ACTION (EQUAL OPPORTUNITY FOR WOMEN) BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —When this debate was adjourned before lunch I was speaking in favour of the broad cross section of support for the Affirmative Action (Equal Opportunity for Women) Bill 1986. I welcomed the remarks that had been made in this place by Senator Peter Baume and Senator Haines. I welcomed this broad agreement from the Opposition, notwithstanding some of the comments from the National Party's Senator Bjelke-Petersen, which I will come to later. However, I must admit I am a little intrigued as to why, if there is such wholehearted support for the Bill from the Opposition, there are 27 speakers. It concerns me because at the rate Government business is proceeding I am not sure how all those 27 speakers will have the opportunity to put forward their views today and tomorrow. As Senator Peter Baume assures us that there is broad agreement for the Bill-and we welcome that agreement; it is a very commonsense approach-why can we not ensure that this important piece of legislation is passed in the next 24 hours?

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Education, Senator Ryan, and other speakers in this place have often detailed the statistics which indicate the urgent need for affirmative action legislation as outlined in the Bill. Senator Baume and Senator Haines also commented on the extensive statistics that are available to show the need for this legislation. They tended to comment particularly on the still low representation of women in both the Federal and State public services. Although this is low it has certainly improved at the Commonwealth level and it is improving at State level with the notable exceptions of my home State of Queensland and Tasmania. I well remember noticing very early in my career in the Senate that not one woman member of the Public Service was at a high enough level to be called to give evidence at hearings of the Estimates committees. I certainly took note of that when I was on my first Estimates committee, Estimates Committee E. It was with great delight that 12 months later I noticed that there were women represented at the Estimates committee hearings and I also noted with some amusement the reactions of the predominantly male public servants when a woman was called to advise a Minister. The Minister certainly was not embarrassed but a number of senior male public servants looked quite askance that a woman had been asked to come forward to advise the Minister-a male Minister-about a particular issue before the Committee.

I have special concern for the very low representation of women-still only 28 per cent-employed by Commonwealth statutory authorities. Many organisations which are performing functions that are still regarded as traditionally male oriented still have a low representation of women. Many of those statutory authorities would continue those practices of not giving women the same recognition and opportunity if this legislation were not to proceed. I am afraid that many of those statutory authorities-and of course I am far too polite to name them in this debate-would be backward in improving the situation without a good hearty shove from the Federal Government in the form of this legislation. That hearty prod is certainly long overdue.

TALK.START.PARA: —But the statutory authorities have been excluded by the legislation.

—They will be dealt with separately. They will be encouraged by this legislation and I hope that they will take note of the excellent record that will develop throughout the Public Service and in academic institutions.

SPEECH.PARA: Similarly academic institutions present a fairly depressing picture. Women are over represented at the junior levels-tutors, research assistants and so on-and under represented at senior levels. Some recent statistics show that women comprise 42 per cent of tutors in academic institutions; 20 per cent of lecturers; 11 per cent of senior lecturers; 4 per cent of associate professors; and only 2 per cent of professors. A similar pattern obviously exists with colleges of advanced education. I do not believe that anyone in this place can seriously suggest that affirmative action is not required.

Because of some of the statements that were made by Senator Bjelke-Petersen I would like to run through the actual processes involved in the affirmative action program. There are eight basic steps and these include: The issuing by management of a policy statement notifying employees of the commencement of an affirmative action program; conferring responsibility for the program on a person with sufficient authority and status within the management to enable its proper development and implementation; consulting with trade unions which have members in the work place; consulting with employees, particularly women; collecting and recording statistical and other relevant information on the program; and-I consider this one particularly important-reviewing policies and practices of the employer to identify any discriminatory policy or practice or any patterns of lack of opportunity relating to women. I would particularly identify interviewing practices. I wonder how many of my women colleagues have had similar experiences to mine in regard to interviews. I have never been to an interview where a woman was on the interviewing panel. I have been asked questions that are totally irrelevant to my ability to perform the job for which I had applied. I have been asked questions about my child care arrangements, for example, which no interviewing panel would dare to ask a male coming forward for the same job. As my background is in the teaching profession, honourable senators can gather the area I am criticising. That applies to the State governments, universities and colleges of advanced education.

I turn to the situation in which the National Party of Australia finds itself in regard to the affirmative action legislation. I do not know whether its members are as confused as I am about their position. I believe that there was a good deal of hypocrisy in the speech Senator Bjelke-Petersen made this morning. She said-I wrote it down-and honourable senators can check the Hansard: `I believe in equal opportunity'. I congratulate her if she believes in equal opportunity. It shows that this place and this Government have started to educate her. I wish that she could pass on some of that broad education to her husband so that Queensland can start to be brought into line with the other States in regard to women's policy. However, it seems that while Senator Bjelke-Petersen is prepared to say `I believe in equal opportunity', she ruins the whole effect by saying': `But I am not prepared to do anything to ensure that everybody will in fact have access to equal opportunity'. So, really, her statement that she believes in equal opportunity is negated by the fact that she is not prepared to do anything to support any legislation that will ensure that that principle that she actually stated she believes in is enshrined in legislation and practice.

Of course, I am confused when I go back to the performance of the National Party in regard to this sex discrimination legislation because one of the very excellent speeches from Opposition members in the House of Representatives came from Tom McVeigh. He spoke eminent sense on the need for sex discrimination legislation. Yet, when it came to the debate here in this place, we found that the National Party performed as if the passing of that legislation would mean the end of the world as we know it. As honourable senators will no doubt have noticed, there have not been any disadvantages to women or men since the sex discrimination legislation was passed and the dire predictions of the Queensland National Party have not come true. I think we will find precisely the same situation in regard to the affirmative action legislation. Headlines early in March indicated that the Nationals were looking for a legitimate excuse to split the coalition and that they were prepared to use the affirmative action legislation for that purpose. Of course, by mid March they had been brought into line by their more sensible and senior colleagues in the Liberal Party of Australia. A newspaper article of 17 March stated:
National Party opponents of the Federal Government's affirmative action legislation are preparing to scale down their trenchant stand in a move to head of a crisis within the Coalition.

So, obviously, no matter what we may hear in this place, and no matter what we may hear from National Party members as they travel around the country, we know that they have in fact scaled down their opposition. I do not quite know how they are going to vote on the legislation. I wonder whether they know how they are going to vote? I guess we do not have to hold our breath for that, the way the debate is going at this stage.

Senator Bjelke-Petersen made a number of other points which I think bear comment. She was especially concerned about the cost of implementing the affirmative action legislation. Does the honourable senator not believe that 51 per cent of the population is entitled to some cost in regard to equal opportunity, especially, as she has already indicated, that basically she believes in equal opportunity? Given that the Queensland Government has been shown by Australian Bureau of Statistics figures to be the highest spending State government with the second highest deficit, I am not sure that Senator Bjelke-Petersen is in a particularly good position to be critical about costs.

Secondly, Senator Bjelke-Petersen spoke about the fear of the external powers being used in regard to affirmative action legislation. This is an old favourite tactic in Queensland. As soon as the Federal Government takes any initiative, we can be absolutely sure that members of the National Party will jump up and down on their soap boxes and say that the Federal Government is going to interfere and intervene in regard to Queensland. What they do not seem to know is that they are essentially a minority government, that 61 per cent of Queenslanders did not vote for the National Party and that 61 per cent of Queenslanders frequently urge Senators Colston, Jones, Black, Georges and me to urge the Federal Government to take special action with regard to Queensland. This is because the 61 per cent are fed up with being dominated by the 39 per cent.

It is obvious that legislation in recognition of women's policy is so overdue in Queensland that at some point in time it may well be necessary to consider just what can be done to overcome the nineteenth century attitudes of the Queensland National Party. Senator Bjelke-Petersen also referred to social change. As she believes in equal opportunity, apparently she has decided to believe in social change. Again, her husband does not agree with social change. He likes things just the way they were 100 years ago. Senator Bjelke-Petersen is convinced that equal opportunities will develop if we just sit back and wait for social change to take place. She cited Jan Taylor, the head of Consumer Affairs Bureau, as a shining example in Queensland of the view that affirmative action is not necessary. I congratulate Jan Taylor on the excellent work that she does in consumer affairs. However, the Consumer Affairs Bureau is a minute section-it is not even an independent department-of the entire Queensland bureaucracy. The fact that there is one woman in that position, that there is one woman in the cockpit of the Premier's plane, that the wife of the Queensland Premier is a member of the Senate and that there is one woman Minister-just four individual women who are in positions of authority-really does not do anything very much for the women of Queensland in respect of whom there is no policy, no information and no sex discrimination or affirmative action legislation. So, the fact that the honourable senator can pick out a couple of names here and there and say `Look at them, they are examples of why we do not need affirmative action', is not, I am afraid, acceptable to the women of Queensland.

Senator Bjelke-Petersen talked about women being artificially pushed up the ladder. I think her basic assumption is that the majority of Queensland women belong at the bottom of the ladder. I suggest that she go out and tell the women of Queensland that she considers that they belong at the bottom of the ladder. Nobody is suggesting that affirmative action will result in women being pushed in any direction, artificially or not. This legislation simply seeks to give women the opportunity to be considered on an equal basis with men, performing at the same level. Again, Senator Bjelke-Petersen was guilty of telling a few mistruths in regard to quotas.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator cannot accuse Senator Bjelke-Petersen of telling mistruths.
—I thought I was expressing that nicely. I do not like to use the word `lies'; so I used the word `mistruths'.
—Order! That remark should be withdrawn.

—I withdraw my statement that Senator Bjelke-Petersen was telling mistruths. Rather, she was distorting the facts. I will put the facts about the quota situation clearly on the record. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), in his second reading speech on this legislation, said:

SPEECH.PARA: I want to stress that the Government's affirmative action legislation does not propose positive discrimination or reverse discrimination. We are totally opposed to the use of quotas, and this legislation, by stating that all actions are to be based on merit, makes this clear. Those opponents of equal opportunity for women who tried to discredit our legislative approach by claiming that we are proposing quotas are wrong.
I say to Senator Bjelke-Petersen that she is wrong. The Prime Minister continued:

The Bill clearly demonstrates that. It is also clear from the definitions of objectives and forward estimates contained in the legislation, that these are to be determined by the employer and not imposed by the Director of Affirmative Action.

I wish to continue with a few comments about the Queensland National Party women's branch, whose members, I am afraid, would be in agreement with Senator Bjelke-Petersen, who said that she believed in equal opportunity, because in 1980 the National Party women's branch moved at its annual conference on Magnetic Island that sex discrimination legislation be introduced. At that conference, the Premier agreed to look at the role of women in the Public Service. Apart from the appointment of the Premier's pilot and the appointment of Jan Taylor to the Bureau of Consumer Affairs, we still have no public policy document from the Queensland National Party about women in the Public Service. We have no policy on programs for women throughout Queensland. We have no equal employment opportunity legislation, no women's advisory committee, no Public Service reforms; in fact, the Queensland Public Service is top heavy with old men. It is rather comparable with the minority Government in Queensland.

I turn to the teaching profession. I have some personal experience in this regard. The teaching profession is well represented by very able women, but they are to be found in the lower echelons of the Queensland Department of Education. I have personally been told `Why do you want to go for a promotion? You are only a married woman. You have no need to go for a promotion' and that was not all that many years ago. Having been a tutor at a teachers college, I am aware of male students being placed in schools even though their results were way below those of female students who were not placed for a further six or nine months.

Frankly, Queensland women are fed up. Queensland women want some change. I shall quote some resolutions that were passed by the Queensland Division of the Australian Federation of Business and Professional Women at its annual conference in Brisbane in April of this year. It resolved:
. . . that the Queensland Division of A.F.B.P.W. urge the Queensland State Government to appoint more women to senior positions within the State Public Service.
It commented:

The lack of women in senior positions within the Public Service-and we acknowledge that the appointment of Beryl Young to lead the Government air wing does not fall within the gambit of the Public Service-shows that women have not attained senior positions because-
(a) their sex;
(b) their ability has not been examined;
(c) that they have not been given the same opportunity to train for and advice to these positions the same as men.
At the same conference this resolution was passed:

. . . that the . . . Queensland Government . . . set up a department for women's services within the Department of Social Welfare or the Department of the Premier, to administer, co-ordinate and formulate policies in relation to those matters that specifically affect women.

I think there is absolutely no doubt that Senator Bjelke-Petersen and other Queensland National Party senators are totally out of touch with what Queensland women are saying. Queensland women's organisations throughout the State-I have spoken at numerous meetings over my three years as a senator, and particularly in the last six months-are saying over and over again: `Why should we lag behind every other State except Tasmania in regard to women's policy? We want to have the same sorts of programs and policies. We want the same opportunities. We want affirmative action in Queensland. We are tired of the National Party Government treating us in a way that does not recognise our abilities'. On a final note, I recall that this morning Senator Boswell made references to Queensland women being treated very well. Of 60 government instrumentalities, only six relate to women.
Debate (on motion by Senator Gareth Evans) adjourned.

Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, may I suggest that the Senate have a cognate debate covering this Bill and the Supply Bill (No. 2) 1986-87.
—Is it the wish of the Senate to have a cognate debate covering these two measures? There being no objection, it is so ordered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Supply Bill (No. 1) 1986-87 and the Supply Bill (No. 2) 1986-87, the subject of this debate, relate directly to the Government and to the governing of this country. It is therefore to the Government and the governing of this great country that I address my remarks. Last evening the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) delivered a speech to the nation which was supposed to be directed to the governing of this nation. He made the speech for several reasons. First, his Treasurer (Mr Keating) put our money markets and the Australian dollar on the skids with his intemperate, even if accurate, remarks a month ago that Australia risked becoming one of the poor nations of the world rather than the wealthy, prosperous and vibrant nation that we have every potential of becoming.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, the Prime Minister saw himself and his leadership of the Australian Labor Party as being at risk because Mr Keating appeared to be calling all the shots. Thirdly, Mr Hawke, having the peculiar psychological make-up for which he has long been famous, believed that if he and no one else were to appear on television before the people of Australia all would be well with the nation. The Prime Minister, with his minders-the Manchu Court, as Paul Keating has described them-having taken the unilateral decision again to publicly humiliate the Treasurer by pushing him aside, saying, in effect, `Paul, this is too big for you, let me handle it', had to ensure that his speech contained several essential ingredients. It had to meet the enormous expectations that he, Mr Hawke, had deliberately created in the electorate. It had to analyse the deep-seated problems facing Australia-problems which should have been the basic reason for the speech in the first place.

Having analysed the problems, the Prime Minister had to provide answers. The speech had to be specific. It had to show the people of Australia that the Government was on top of things, that the Government was leading the nation, that it was, in fact, governing. The speech was, therefore, of critical importance for the Australian economy, the Australian people and the Hawke Government. It was of special importance because only now, in mid-1986, more than three years after its election to government, the Hawke Government has been forced to take hard decisions and to exercise economic management skills. Until now it has been held afloat on the wave of extreme good fortune that accompanied its election in March 1983-good fortune which included the inheritance of the stimulatory Fraser Government Budget of 1982, the inheritance of the Fraser Government's 12-month wage freeze at the end of 1982, the inheritance of the world economic upturn, which commenced just at the time of the Hawke Government's election, and the inheritance of the breaking of one of the worst droughts in Australia's history in March 1983.

Not to put too fine a point on it, and to borrow a little political licence from the immortal words of Bill Hayden as he lay mortally wounded politically from the knives of Bob Hawke during Mr Hawke's leadership coup of February 1983: `Even a drover's dog could have managed the Australian economy during the past three years'. But no longer. Now, in June 1986, the Prime Minister and his Government are being put to the test to perform, to take responsible economic decisions, to exercise leadership, to really tackle the problems facing Australia. It is against that background that the Prime Minister's performance yesterday and the performance of his Government must be judged. What is that judgment? It is the judgment of virtually all sections of the Australian community-the business sector, the union movement, the financial markets, which today have seen the dollar fall sharply and interest rates rise again, the welfare agencies, the young unemployed, the media, Mr and Mrs Average Australian. The judgment of all those sections of the community is that Mr Hawke and, therefore, his Government, have failed miserably the first real test of economic responsibility and leadership. Mr Hawke has failed on every count. He raised expectations to unprecedented heights and then callously, want- only and destructively dashed those expectations and hopes. He failed to provide an adequate analysis of the real problems facing Australia. He failed to address the root problems and, inevitably, he therefore failed totally to prescribe any real solutions.

Last night's performance by the Prime Minister was of the greatest significance to Australia and to Australians. It seemingly deliberately insulted the intelligence of average Australians. It demonstrated beyond any doubt that this Prime Minister has feet of clay. Bob Hawke, the self-proclaimed Messiah, has walked the waters too often. He has become water-logged. It demonstrated a total, pathetic lack of leadership by the Prime Minister and his Government and it will, without any doubt, hasten the demise of this wretched Government and this plastic Prime Minister-this Prime Minister of whom the Melbourne Sun's cartoonist this morning so devastatingly and so accurately said: `At least he was funny in the Gillies' report'. I also like the Tanberg cartoon in today's Age which shows the Prime Minister saying `Any one of us is capable of designing a keel like Ben; sailing like John; singing like Joan', to which someone off-stage in the cartoon then adds: `And running the country better than Bob'. I add to that statement that few of us would be capable of running the country worse than Bob. Today the Prime Minister of Australia is the object of ridicule throughout the nation and overseas for his pathetic performance yesterday. I suppose that I, as a member of the Opposition, should be pleased about that, but I am not.

TALK.START.PARA: —And you are.

—I am not because I believe, unlike the members of the Government, that all Australians, whichever way they vote, want, need and deserve a Prime Minister they can respect and look to for leadership. Australians no longer have such a Prime Minister.
—Why do you talk him down all the time?

—I do not have to talk him down; he did it himself last night. That is a matter not only for considerable sadness but also, and perhaps more importantly, for great concern. What we have today in Australia is a leader less leader in charge of a rudderless rump that masquerades as the government of Australia. Let us now have a look at some of the facts the Prime Minister should have talked about and was expected to talk about last night. Let us have a look at some of the facts behind the present serious economic situation we find ourselves in. The facts which make the situation so serious are numerous. Inflation, which is high and rising, is already up to three times as high as the average of our major trading partners-
—What was it when you were in?

—For a considerable period of the time we were in office the inflation rate in Australia was below the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development average and at no time was it as high as it is now above the OECD average. Indeed, our comparative inflation performance over the last 12 months is the worst it has been in our post-war history at least. That is my first point. Let us consider the balance of payments deficit. We have a balance of payments deficit of $14,000m this year alone. That is not far short of $1,000 for every man, woman, and child in Australia.
—Where did that come from?

—It came from the policies of this wretched Government. It is a debt owing to foreigners, amounting to about $80,000m; a debt which has trebled since the Hawke Government came into office. The Government component of this foreign debt has increased by no less than 500 per cent-an increase in the foreign debt component of 500 per cent in three years alone. As well there is a total Federal Government debt at the national level in excess of $100,000m, which is about $7,000 for every man, woman and child in this country. This debt has increased by more than 70 per cent since the Hawke Government came to office. We have an interest bill on this debt which exceeds what the Federal Government spends on the defence of this nation, on education, on industry and even on health. We have a dollar which has declined in value, compared with other currencies, by 30 per cent in the last 18 months alone, thereby putting up the cost of our imports while reducing the prices we get for our exports, and thereby automatically lowering our standard of living.

SPEECH.PARA: It is this latter point-the so-called terms of trade effect-on which the Prime Minister placed so much emphasis in his statement yesterday. I agree with the Prime Minister that this is a fundamental problem, but the Prime Minister was wilfully misleading. He was almost criminally negligent in his presentation of the argument. The deterioration in our terms of trade and in the value of our dollar is a symptom of our problems; it is not in itself a cause. The Prime Minister conveniently omitted to point this out. Why did he fail to point it out? There can be only two answers to that question: Either the Prime Minister is an economic illiterate or he is unwilling or unable to face reality. I suspect that the truth may lie somewhere in between those answers. I repeat: The magnitude of our very serious external economic situation is a symptom, not a cause, of our deep-seated economic difficulties.

What are the causes of our difficulties? They, too, are numerous. Let me just mention the main ones: Government spending, which has increased at a rate far in excess of the capacity of the economy or of ratepayers to fund it; an increase in the tax take to the highest level in our history; an increase in Government borrowing to the highest level in our history; the introduction of new types of taxes which are totally anti-business in their application--

TALK.START.PARA: —Actually, anti-crooks-tax evaders and avoiders, whom you call businessmen.

—I continue: The failure to provide incentive to large and small business people, farmers and financiers, manufacturers and miners to invest, to create, to produce, to provide jobs and to generate wealth and income-a concept that members of the Government, and particularly the honourable senator who spends his time interjecting, seem to find incredible; the maintenance of an archaic and inflexible wage fixing system which pays scant regard to the capacity of the economy to pay, or to the circumstances of individual firms or of particular industries.

SPEECH.PARA: Unless we as a nation directly attack these root causes of our problems we will never solve the problems; instead we will play around with the symptoms. We will bandage the wounds but fail to treat the infection. That is the indictment of the Prime Minister's performance yesterday. To be fair, he did address himself to the wages issue, but in a totally unsatisfactory, wishy-washy, indeterminate way. Indeed, by expressing his Government's continued support for the Australian Council of Trade Unions superannuation claim, Mr Hawke demonstrated beyond any doubt that he has no real conception of the cost pressures facing Australian industry in all sectors of enterprise. Other than his totally inadequate approach to the wages issue, the Prime Minister deliberately and deceptively ignored the other causes of our problems-causes that are the direct result of the Government's policies and which I have already mentioned.

Mr Hawke omitted to mention that the massive deterioration in our terms of trade over the past three years-a factor of which he rightly made great play-has been a direct result of his Government's economic policies. As the Australian newspaper put it today, the Prime Minister failed to address the rigid structures that hold us back and he has failed to offer the inspiration that Australia needs. He also failed to tell us why the Government has so late in the piece come to a recognition of our difficulties. It is only a matter of weeks since the Government was trumpeting to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and to the nation at large how well the economy was doing. Why the sudden change of heart? Why the damaging delay in recognising some of the facts? The Government gives the impression that it has only just discovered the deterioration in our terms of trade, despite the fact that that deterioration has been with us for years.

It is no wonder that the Prime Minister's performance has received an unmerciful caning from all sections of the community. It is no wonder that the statement has been variously described as vague, rhetorical, a disaster, bitterly disappointing, a failure to address the root causes, insulting, a failure to bite the bullet and as bearing all the hallmarks of a policy on the run and of much cosmetic fluff.

What should the Prime Minister have said? At the very least, he should have announced firm and specific decisions to reduce Government spending and to control the money supply. He should have announced the abandonment of the capital gains tax, the fringe benefits tax and the other raft of socialist taxes that so destroy incentive and damage the confidence of the private sector, particularly small business. He should have announced an unequivocal and specific approach to the elimination of the Budget deficit. He should have withdrawn the Government's support for the ACTU superannuation claim at this time and he should have opposed further wage increases for the next year. Those are the tough decisions that the nation was looking for yesterday. Mr Hawke said: `I will not shirk from the hard decisions that are necessary'. Well, he did shirk. He did not announce one single hard decision; nor did he give any indication that he would take any hard decisions in the future.

Last night Australia saw the Prime Minister for what he really is-a man who is not able to take the lead and the decisions required; a man unwilling to face up to his responsibility as a leader; a man and a Government that have no clear vision of where they want Australia to go or of the type of country they want Australia to be; a man whose economic policies and the policies of his Government-the accord, high interest rates, an explosion in business regulations, punitive anti-business taxes, record levels of Government spending, taxing and borrowing-have served only to undermine confidence and create a climate of instability.

Yesterday the Prime Minister put a terminal nail in the coffin of his Government by failing to provide hope, encouragement and incentive for those upon whom rests the task of dragging Australia out of the economic hole that this Government has previously dug for it; I refer to those Australians willing to take a risk, to have a go at contributing to the nation's wealth and to do an honest day's work for an honest day's pay. Do those descriptions not apply to virtually all Australians? The Prime Minister has put a terminal nail in the coffin of his Government and of his leadership of both the country and the Labor Party. What we in the Opposition and what the men and women of Australia must ensure is that Mr Hawke has not also placed in a coffin the future of Australia and the future of our children and our grandchildren. We can only ensure that by getting rid of this leaderless and rudderless Government at the earliest possible opportunity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening we are debating Supply Bill (No. 1) and Supply Bill (No. 2) for 1986-87. These Bills seek an interim appropriation for the services of the Commonwealth Government for the period from 1 July next until 30 November 1986. Supply Bill (No. 1) seeks appropriations totalling some $7.9 billion for the ordinary annual services of the Commonwealth Government. Supply Bill (No. 2) seeks interim appropriations totalling some $2.1 billion for expenditure on capital works and services, payments to or for the States and the Northern Territory and also certain other services for the period from 1 July until the end of November. So it can be said that the Bills provide finance for the Government from the beginning of the next financial year until the time at which the 1986 Budget is brought down.

SPEECH.PARA: In addressing myself to these Bills, I wish to begin by nailing some of the distortions of and the carelessness with which Senator Short has used facts in his speech in this debate just a moment ago. For example, Senator Short made some really outrageous claims about foreign debt owed by Australia. He distorted the picture completely on the structure of foreign debt. I remind honourable senators that Senator Short, before he came into this place, was an officer of the Commonwealth Department of the Treasury. As a former officer of the Treasury, he would be very familiar indeed with Budget Statement No. 1, one of the papers that accompanies the Federal Budget every year. I will quote from page 65 of that document. It is not written by the Government of Australia; it is written by the Commonwealth Department of the Treasury. It is the economic data which is provided to supplement the Australian Budget every year. I turn to the table on page 65 which deals with Australia's external debt. At the end of June last year-the latest period for which we have official information on the overseas debt-Australia's total gross debt owed overseas was $68.4 billion. Senator Short, throughout his address to the Senate this afternoon, tried to create the fiction that that debt was government debt.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I did not.
—He did. He tried to create the fiction that that debt was government debt and the result of government policies.
—I said that the biggest increase in it since you came into government has been in the government proportion, and that is correct. The government proportion has gone up by 500 per cent.

—Senator Short is wrong again. He has just dug a deeper hole for himself. He is now saying that the biggest increase in that debt was the result of an increase in the government debt. The figures from the Treasury-Senator Short is a former officer of the Treasury, I believe-show quite clearly that the biggest percentage increase in overseas debt owed by Australia was in the private sector, not the government sector.
