I will cite the figures. Pick a number, pick a year. At the end of June 1980, private debt owed overseas by Australian companies was $6,700m. At the end of June 1985 the figure was not $6,700m, but $42,300m. That is not government debt; that is private debt. They are the sorts of increases that have occurred. So of the total amount of overseas debt of $68.4 billion owed by Australians and Australian organisations at the end of June last year, $42,300m was owed by the private sector, by the corporate sector of our economy-not by the Government and certainly not by the Commonwealth Government. I would like to point out also that the Commonwealth Government-we are members of that Government-is a net lender overseas; it is not a net debtor overseas. The figures show very clearly that at the end of June last year, we had official reserve assets of $13,500m and the Commonwealth Government's debt owed overseas was $12,700m. So in those terms, despite the rhetoric, despite the nonsense, despite the fictions created by the Opposition, the facts presented by the Australian Treasury clearly show that the Commonwealth Government is not a net debtor overseas; it is a net lender overseas. Let us nail that lie once and for all.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to talk about economic growth in our country under the Hawke Labor Government. The fact is that since the Hawke Government was elected to office in 1983 Australia has achieved higher economic growth in real terms-that is, growth ahead of inflation-than any other developed country in the world. It has achieved higher growth than any other member country of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, which is based in Paris. The national accounts data show clearly that the Australian economy has grown in successive financial years at over 5 per cent annually in real terms, which is very strong, high growth by international standards, on any criteria.

Before we came to office in 1983 we promised to create half a million jobs in our first three years in office. The Opposition-it was then in government, of course-ridiculed that promise. At every opportunity and on every occasion it tried to convince the Australian people that by no stretch of the imagination, under no circumstances, could Labor create half a million jobs in three years. Of course, the record contradicts that statement. The record demonstrates very clearly how successful we have been in creating new employment opportunities for Australians. The fact is that since the National Economic Summit Conference in April 1983, just over three years ago, not 100,000 jobs have been created in Australia, not the 500,000 extra jobs that we promised, but over 600,000 new positions have been created in this country, which is over 100,000 above the figure we pledged to the Australian people. Despite the carping of the Opposition, despite the Liberal Party speakers' notes which are retailed in this place time after time, the fact is that the jobs created in Australia have not been band-aid jobs; the overwhelming majority have been created in the private sector and the overwhelming majority have been full time jobs.

During the current financial year the Government estimated that it would create 180,000 extra jobs for Australians. That was part of the Budget forecast in August last year. But the figures released today show just how out of date that forecast was. Today, figures were released by the Australian Statistician showing new employment levels in our country. The fact is that we did not create 180,000 extra jobs in the financial year. In the 11 months to the end of May we have created 260,000 jobs. So with a month to spare we have created 80,000 more jobs-not 18,000, but 80,000-than were promised in the Budget Speech last year. So that is the record. The figures released today by the Australian Statistician show the continued fall in the unemployment rate in Australia. It is certainly not falling as fast as I would like to see it, and I am sure it is not falling as fast as other members of the Government would like to see it, but a further fall in unemployment was measured in the figures released today. The fact is that the highest rate of unemployment in Australia, as a result of the Howard induced recession in 1982, was 10.4 percent. There was double digit unemployment. The figures released today show that the unemployment rate has been reduced to 7.8 per cent. So in just 2 1/2 years the unemployment rate has been reduced by one-quarter.

One of the most unfortunate things about the recovery which has occurred in Australia to the present time has been the very tardy, belated economic recovery in Queensland. I regret to say that Australia's third most populous State has been holding down the economic performance of the nation. Unfortunately, the tail has been wagging the dog in this case. Queensland, unfortunately, has acted as a brake on economic recovery in Australia. I was very concerned today to see that Queensland has now opened up a very significant unemployment gap compared with the figure for the State with the next closest figure. The unemployment rate in Queensland is now 9.8 per cent, which is well ahead of Tasmania which has the next highest level. So Queensland has by far the highest unemployment rate in Australia. The most incredible thing that was evidenced in the figures released today by the Australian Statistician was that there are now more people seeking full time work in Queensland-they are unemployed, but seeking full time work-than there are in Victoria. That is a very historic position, because Victoria has a labour force-that is, an economically active population which wants to work-which is 65 percent larger than that of Queensland. So one State has a vastly larger labour force than the other, but the other State, as of today, has more people wanting full time work.

In September 1983 the Premier of Queensland, Mr Bjelke-Petersen-now Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen-delivered a policy speech in which he said that he would implement policies for growth and jobs. That is what he told the electors of Queensland in September 1983. When he delivered that policy speech, the Australian Statistician at the time indicated that 14.8 per cent of Australian's jobless resided in Queensland. Today's figures show the relentless slide which has occurred in the Queensland economy. Today, according to the figures published by the Australian Statistician, it is not 14.8 per cent of the unemployed people of Australia who live in Queensland, it is not 15.8 per cent or 16.8 per cent, but 19.9 per cent of all unemployed people in Australia live in Queensland. There we have it: Queensland, the third State of Australia, on a population basis, is the second State of Australia, in terms of numbers of persons seeking full time work.

As a result of the policies of the Hawke Government there has been a reduction of inflation in Australia. The rate of increase of prices has been brought down. Despite the fictions which Senator Short tried to perpetrate a moment ago, when he claimed that inflation was not a problem under the Liberals, in fact the record shows very clearly that when the Liberals lost office-despite all their rhetoric about fighting inflation first and getting rid of double digit inflation-inflation was 11 1/2 per cent. It is now not 11 1/2 per cent but 9.2 per cent.

I believe that there are further prospects of falls in the rate of inflation in the community, for example, with the delay in the national wage case. A national wage increase was not awarded in April, as would normally have been the case. So far the trade union movement has agreed to discount wage rises to take account of the effect of the devaluation of the Australian dollar on price levels. It has agreed to discount wages by some 2 percentage points. The union movement is not seeking a 4.3 per cent wage rise; it is seeking a 2.3 per cent wage rise. We have had the Government decision in regard to petrol prices. There has been a reduction in the price of fuel of 5.3 cents a litre. Information made public by the Australian Statistician last week showed that the manufacturing cost index for Australia fell in the month of March. This is the first fall in 16 years. That is very welcome news indeed. Therefore, there is indeed a good chance that the current 9.2 per cent rate of inflation in the country in fact will be reduced to a lower level.

Obviously, the country has a problem with the balance of payments. One of the reasons that we have balance of payments difficulties in regard to overseas trade at the moment is that we have had very rapid economic growth in Australia. It is very well known in the economic field that rapid economic growth can create balance of payments problems as bottlenecks occur and as there is a need for equipment to be purchased from overseas. We have had very rapid growth in Australia and, therefore, have had some difficulties with the balance of payments. The Government has taken a number of actions to stem the flow of imports. The Australian dollar has been floated with a subsequent devaluation of the dollar. There has been a tightening of monetary policy. Interest rates have been lifted to try to attract overseas capital to Australia in order to improve the balance of payments. The March balance of payments figures for the current account show that there is some improvement occurring on the import front. Certainly, in terms of the volume of imports the devaluation of the dollar is working. The physical quantities of imports into Australia are showing some slackening as a result of the devaluation of the Australian dollar.

I think that it is very important to put on record the fact that Australia's balance of payments problem has not arrived in the last week or in the last month. It has evolved over decades. This problem has developed over tens and tens of years in this country. I think that if one really wants to sheet home the blame for the current balance of payments predicament in this country one really has to go back to the Menzies years in Australia. I do not remember very much of the Menzies years. I was not old enough to recall all of the things that were perpetrated on the Australian people during that era. However, I do know that the Menzies Government had very much of a laissez-faire attitude to economic policy. It was very much a hands-off policy. That Government had an open-door policy on foreign investment. It tended to postpone the very hard decisions that needed to be made in Australia about economic policy.

In fact, they were the days when State Premiers regularly were seen at airports catching planes for overseas destinations in a desperate scramble to try to bring industries to their States. Of course, what happened was that overseas firms tended to play those Premiers off against each other and reap the gains. For example, we had the then Premier of Victoria, Sir Henry Bolte, rushing overseas to try to attract industry. We had Sir Thomas Playford of South Australia fighting against the Victorian Government to try to outbid it for industry for South Australia. I think that we are now paying the price for those years and for that Menzies era when those Liberal Premiers went overseas and attracted heavily tariff dependent industries to Australia. These were industries that produced goods for a very small domestic market. They were import- replacement oriented rather than export oriented as was the case with industries of comparable countries such as Sweden and Switzerland.

If the Government's strategy is to work each group in the community must take its share of the weight. I believe that the Australian Council of Trade Unions has more than kept its half of the bargain up to the present. The union movement has adhered to a commitment to seek no further wage claims other than those to take account of the consumer price rises and productivity gains. I think that it is very important to note that since the prices and incomes accord with the trade union movement was signed in early 1983 there has been a very dramatic fall in work days lost as a result of industrial disputes in Australia. It is very important to note that in the 12 months to the end of December 1984 the total number of days lost in Australia through industrial disputes was well below the average for all of our major trading partners. If we take the average of all days lost for all the countries with which we normally trade we see that days lost as a result of disputes in Australia were well below average.

It is striking-pardon the pun there-to note that the number of days lost as a result of industrial disputes in Australia in 1984 was less than a quarter of days lost in Mrs Thatcher's United Kingdom. Days lost as a result of disputes in Australia represented less than a quarter of those days lost under the conservative model worshipped and admired by the conservatives in this place. The fact that days lost as a result of industrial disputes in the United Kingdom were four times as high as Australia really shows what happens when a government puts into practice the policies of industrial confrontation rather than policies of industrial conciliation.

The statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) last night recognises that Australia is facing new economic challenges. The declining terms of trade require a different set of policy responses. They require policy responses designed to increase Australia's export competitiveness and to reduce our reliance on imports. If Australia is to face the challenge both unions and business must join with government in a common purpose. Let us put the Prime Minister's statement in a proper context. Australia is not facing an economic crisis. It is not entering a recession. The current job figures today show that over 600,000 new employment positions have been created in Australia in a three-year period. We have not created half a million jobs as we promised; we have created over 600,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many have the taxpayers paid for?

—The great majority of those, as I said earlier when Senator Collard was not in the chamber, are not band-aid jobs, they are not make-work jobs, but jobs in the private sector of Australia. Some 65 per cent of all the jobs being created in Australia at the moment are in the private, not the public, sector of the economy.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian economy is not now in the sort of mess that the Government inherited from Mr Howard in 1983. The Australian economy is not on its knees. Record job creation is occuring in the country. The Government is making a series of policy adjustments which will ensure the long term future and viability of Australia's economy. This Government has the guts to make the hard decisions. It rejects the weak-kneed indecision of previous Liberal governments. It rejects the soft options. It rejects the short term expediency that characterised the Fraser years. The success of this Government's strategy in just three years is clearly evidenced by the hundreds of thousands of people who have found new jobs, the shortening of the dole queues and the re-emergence of hope and opportunity in the Australian community.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.
(Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the opportunity of this debate on Supply Bill (No. 1) and Supply Bill (No. 2) to discuss an overview of Australia's foreign policy. Australia is not adequately defended. This fact has become terrifyingly clear. Our foreign and defence policies and the assumptions underlying them have little connection with political or logistic realities. These policies guarantee Australia neither security nor national independence. Instead, they have become a source of continuing division in Australia as have similar policies within other member nations of the Western alliance.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to discuss ANZUS briefly. The Australian Democrats say that ANZUS not only is of no use to Australia for our defence but it is a positive danger in its present form. It would cease to be a danger only if all nuclear involvement could be eliminated from the alliance. There is no indication that this is possible. Successive Australian governments in the hallowed name of ANZUS have made a number of places in Australia prime nuclear targets. In fact, the entire continent may be in danger. A superficial argument could be advanced, although the Democrats could not embrace its crazy logic, that even though Australia has been exposed to the risk of nuclear attack, the risk is worth while because of the guarantee of Australia's defence. The stark facts are that there are no guarantees either explicit or implicit. There are only two relevant articles in ANZUS, Articles III and IV. I ask leave of the Senate to have incorporated in Hansard the text of those two articles of ANZUS.
Leave granted.
The documents read as follows-
Article III:
The Parties will consult together whenever in the opinion of any of them the territorial integrity, political independence or security of any of the Parties is threatened in the Pacific.
Article IV:

Each Party recognizes that an armed attack in the Pacific area on any of the Parties would be dangerous to its own peace and safety and declares that it would be dangerous to its own peace and safety and declares that it would act to meet the common danger in accordance with its constitutional processes.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The lack of any definite obligation by the USA in view of what we as a nation have mortgaged in the name of ANZUS is quite breathtaking. Let us take the hypothetical case in Indonesia attacking Australia. No-one would seriously say that the United States would send troops, planes and ships to attack Indonesia if it attacked Australia. The decision for the United States to become involved would depend on one thing only-on relevant factors but not on a simple piece of paper.

SPEECH.PARA: Even a casual reading of Article III discloses the disturbing fact that the only responsibility of the President of the United States, and of the United States itself, under the terms of ANZUS if Australia is attacked is to `consult'. There is absolutely no obligation under Article III for the United States to do anything more than consult. However, if the President of the United States did, by some extraordinary act of beneficence towards Australia, decide to send armed forces to attack our attackers, he would by the explicit terms of Article IV, need to have the decision, his decision, ratified by Congress. Having had its fingers burned in Vietnam, the United States Congress would be exceedingly reluctant to commit forces to another South East Asian war. ANZUS, therefore, gives Australia no automatic protection. Indeed, it could be argued that it gives us no protection at all.

On the other hand, the extent of the concessions which the United States has gained from successive Australian governments, both Liberal and Labor, in return for nothing is outrageous. In the name of, or to protect, ANZUS, Australia has done the following for the United States: It has given the United States 24 pieces of Australian soil for bases, some of which make us a nuclear target; it has been a party to complicity and duplicity in President Reagan's Star Wars mania, with such things as the electro-magnetic railgun and the upgrading of Nurrungar; it has permitted the entry of nuclear-powered and nuclear warships into our ports and cities, which makes our most densely populated areas targets for nuclear bombs. I am impressed, Madam Acting Deputy President, by your question today about the fact that Australia regarded with a stifling yawn the fact that members of the United States Navy-foreigners-hosed down decent, idealistic young Australians, simply because they protested against the visit to one of our ports of a ship which carried nuclear bombs.

TALK.START.PARA: —They actually punched one of them.

—As my friend reminds me, one of these Australian idealists was punched and savaged by one of these Americans. Yet we do nothing. We regard that with an air of singular reticence. The list continues with Government's silence in the face of the massive and destabilising buildup of Tomahawk cruise missiles and the right to fly B52 bombers, possibly loaded with nuclear bombs, through Australia. I have now completed 25 years of service in this country and I find it incomprehensible that 95 per cent of Australians do not give a damn that we are now allowing B52 bombers from the United States to fly over Australia in low flying exercises possibly carrying nuclear bombs-we do not care. Much of the 2.9 per cent of our gross national product which is devoted to defence equipment is not to defend Australia in the region but to fit in with United States global foreign and defence needs and objectives-not Australian needs and objectives. I refer also to Australia's complicity in the development of first strike nuclear weapons-for example, the MX and the Trident II through Geosat and Navstar.

SPEECH.PARA: In any event an unforgettable fact of history is that no nation has ever honoured any treaty it has had with any other nation if it did not suit it to do so at the time. I do not quarrel with that. The Australian Democrats do not quarrel with that. But we do question the way in which we have mortgaged our future, our children's future, under the terminology of one treaty, namely ANZUS, which means nothing. Nations send forces to protect other nations for only one reason, that is, if it is in their own self-interest so to do. Therefore, the Democrats say that it can be concluded that Australia has meekly submitted to the demands of the US in what can only be described as a craven, simplistic and childishly trusting manner, thus ensuring our children are the nuclear targets of the Soviet Union. I ask the few senators in the chamber at the moment and those people who are listening to contemplate that fact. What we have done is to make our children nuclear targets of the Soviet Union in order to accommodate the United States on the pretence that we will be protected by the United States but we have absolutely nothing in writing to guarantee that kind of protection. In other words, we have sold our birthright, we have mortgaged the future of our children, for nothing. Yet in return we have received no automatic guarantee whatsoever of protection. The position is even worse than that because, by our simplistic subservience, over the past three decades we have denied ourselves the opportunity of creating a defence structure which could have gone a long way towards making a free, independent Australia with a defence policy based on armed neutrality.

Australia is now in as great a danger as Western Europe, where nuclear bombs are stationed. To our knowledge there are no nuclear bombs in Australia, and yet we are in as much danger as Western Europe, which is 14,000 kilometres or more away. The Russians know that in order to knock out the United States the facilities in Australia have to be hit first. The United States has now placed a virtual prohibition on Australia seeking to establish a firmer and closer relationship even with New Zealand. It most certainly is in our interests to establish a closer relationship with New Zealand. We live next to New Zealand and we have so much in common with New Zealand, but the United States has virtually put an embargo on Australia forming a close relationship with our cousins across the Tasman.

What are the possible threats to Australia? People have the good old Aussie way of putting hard questions into the back of their minds and saying: `She'll be right, mate'. When I say to Australians `Do you know that you have made yourselves a nuclear target?', they say `Oh yes, but we need the protection of the Yanks' or some other expression. I just wonder how that proposition could be defended by those people in Australia who have children, who go to church and say `I am a good Christian' but at the same time have allowed their children to become prime nuclear targets of the Soviet Union without thinking the matter through.

They say that they need someone to protect them. Let us examine who are our enemies. what are the scenarios that could lead us into a dangerous situation? What are the possible threats? Scenario one, a nuclear war, is certainly a possible threat, but could ANZUS and the United States help us if there were a nuclear war? Let me break down that question into two possibilities-a global nuclear war and a limited nuclear war. Firstly, if a global nuclear exchange occurred ANZUS is irrelevant and powerless. To rely on the protection of the so-called United States nuclear umbrella is mindless and its proponents have been dishonest. The United States cannot protect itself from nuclear attack in a global context, let alone Australia.

In a limited nuclear conflict, I remind honourable senators that Mr Reagan, Secretary of Defense, Weinberger, and various Pentagon officials have advocated a winnable limited nuclear war and have pursued policies towards it. Australia would not have to be directly involved in a limited nuclear conflict for us to be annihilated. We could be annihilated even though we were not involved. The nuclear winter research indicates that if only 500 of the 50,000 nuclear bombs in stock at the moment exploded anywhere in the world it would have the effect of destroying all animal, plant and human life on earth. I will just recount the chilling statistics. There are now 50,000 nuclear bombs in stock in the world. If only 500 of those bombs were exploded, and that is a small proportion of the 50,000, there would be a nuclear winter where nothing, not even the parasites, would survive.

TALK.START.PARA: —That, in part, is still a theory. It has not been demonstrated in absolute terms.

—I would have thought that no sensible nuclear scientist or physicist would disagree with the figure of 500. If Senator Crichton-Browne wants to make it 600 or 700, I will accommodate him. The fact is that the insanity of a limited nuclear war has now been proven by people on both sides of the political spectrum. Below 500 bombs, ordinarily Australia would not be affected. However, because of the United States bases on our soil, Australia would be a target, even in a limited nuclear war. More recently, the nuclear winter has been used as an argument for Australia to throw its weight behind ANZUS. To pretend that ANZUS would be a protective shield if a limited nuclear war were to occur is absurd. However, without our United States nuclear involvement there would be no reason for the Soviet Union to make Australia a nuclear target.

SPEECH.PARA: Scenario two that the so-called defence experts put forward is an Asian invasion; that is a possible danger for Australia. That scenario can be broken down into three sub-scenarios. The first is that Australia could be over-run by an Asian nation for its mineral wealth. It is believed that the major motive for Japan's aggression against Australia in the 1930s and early 1940s was to acquire strategic raw materials. Today there is no question of denying Japan or any other country access to our raw materials. We now pay countries to take our raw materials away, as with woodchips. Australia has an overriding need to sell more than the world is willing to buy, and since buying is cheaper than invading our raw materials do not constitute a temptation for invasion.

The second sub-scenario of an Asian invasion is an over-populated Asia-Asian hordes flooding south to an under-populated Australia. This domino theory is the issue upon which Harold Holt, in 1966, won probably the biggest electoral majority since Federation. Most people who put forward this example of an over-populated Asia and the yellow hordes of Asia coming down point to Indonesia which has a population of over 160 million. While parts of Java are overpopulated, other parts of Indonesia are underpopulated. I speak with a little expertise because I have been to Indonesia 17 times during my parliamentary career. I can say that the Indonesian Government has found it extraordinarily difficult to get people, even of their free will, to leave the overpopulated areas for resettlement in the underpopulated areas.

The third sub-scenario of an Asian invasion is a beleaguered Asian dictator. I take this threat seriously. It is possible that a dictator could try to unite his people by turning their minds from domestic problems to foreign ventures, rather in the way Confrontasi was used by Sukarno. But whether a dictator would be able to rally the people, the arms and the equipment would be quite another story. It is most unlikely that such a country could mount an invasion, but if such a country were to attempt an invasion we should be able to defend ourselves. It is in respect of this threat of invasion that Australia should be directing its defence policy. This is the point I make in my speech tonight. We should be devoting our defence resources-we should be spending more to this end to make Australia capable of defending itself against a beleaguered Asian dictator or what are the real threats. So far as this threat is concerned, ANZUS is of no help whatsoever to us. Australia could certainly not count on the United States to bail us out. In any event, the United States might see her interests lying with Indonesia or the Philippines. I would not blame the United States one bit if it said `Indonesia has attacked Rockhampton or Cairns or Darwin', but then went through the exercise of saying: `Is it in our interests to intervene, to send troops, to send a navy, and planes to attack the Indonesians to stop this invasion of Australia?' I would have thought that Indonesia, with 160 million people, straddling the equator with great strategic importance to the United States, would be equally important, if not more important, to the United States than would Australia.

Scenario three is the invasion, conquest and occupation of Australia. For us to feel fearful of the future we must contemplate what nation, if any is capable of invasion, conquest and occupation of Australia? Clearly the only two powers on earth that are possibly capable of that are the super-powers. The realities of modern warfare are such that there are only two nations that would be capable of this, and they are the United States of America and Russia. One cannot in one's wildest imagination conceive of the possibility of the United States ever doing so. If the Soviets were to mount this sort of attack on Australia, could the United States stand idly by? The United States would become involved, not because of its love of Australia, or its mateship with Australia, or because of ANZUS, but simply because it would be contrary to United States interests to allow her rival to acquire such a strategic area.

Assuming that the Soviet could persuade itself to go thousands of kilometres, mount an invasion force to occupy three million square miles in Australia, does anybody here believe that the United States could stand idly by, with or without ANZUS, and let that happen? It is incomprehensible to contemplate that. The United States would become involved in that situation, not because of ANZUS but simply because it would be a direct threat to the United States of America.

As for the Soviet Union possibly invading Australia, I ask honourable senators to contemplate some facts. Russia has a huge surface and sub-surface navy, but lacks the essential air cover. Working on a three-year deterioration of Australian-Russian relations, Australia in that period could build up to three divisions with weapons, equipment and logistic support with a total strength of 150,000 personnel. To conquer this force, the Soviets would have to plan on putting ashore some 450,000 personnel-that is at a ratio of 3:1, three times our forces.

Can people listening to this debate contemplate an invading force coming thousands of kilometres from the Soviet Union? How many ships would that country require to carry 450,000 personnel? It is absurd to contemplate that the Soviets would even think about it. And for what? To invade Australia, to occupy us. To be superior to the Australian naval force of 14 destroyers and probably eight submarines, the Soviet union would need approximately four aircraft carriers with 30 aircraft each and the necessary merchant ships carrying troops, guns, vehicles and whatever is necessary to carry the troops. About 180 ships would be required. Can gung ho senators in the Liberal Party who say that the Soviets one day could invade Australia imagine an armada of 180 ships coming through where?-the Indian Ocean? What a prime target for the American Air Force or Navy they would be. For anyone wishing to pursue this invasion scenario, it is well to remember that Britain had to commit 23 destroyers and frigates as well as six submarines and many supporting ships to the Falkland Islands in order to land only 10,000 troops out of a task force of 28,000. In addition, 70 merchant ships were required. We are not talking about a Russian task force of only 28,000 troops to invade Australia, we are talking about a task force of 450,000 troops. Therefore a Russian invasion of Australia can be dismissed as being totally absurd.

What about our current defences? While we can say there are no foreseeable threats to our security, if we as a nation are not prepared to have a strong defence posture our very weakness or unpreparedness may create a real threat. Therefore the Australian Democrats say that we should spend more on Australian defence, notwithstanding our economic problems. We should be self-reliant in defence. The defence postures of countries such as Sweden and Switzerland are commendable. Both are highly respected members of the world community with track records of skill and judiciousness in the conduct of their military, diplomatic and economic affairs that Australia might well envy and indeed copy. One of the reasons why these countries are highly respected is that they have always made it clear that they will fight to defend themselves if they are attacked and have taken elaborate steps to make that defensive or deterrent capacity a viable reality. How much credibility would we have in world forums with our defence forces now if we said: `If Indonesia attacks us we will get stuck into them and beat them'. All our defence expenditure has been directed towards assisting the United States of America in its global pre-emptive strike strategy. The European neighbours of Sweden and Switzerland, both large and small, know the readiness with which these two nations are prepared to defend their liberty. These nations are respected because they do not fawn over anyone but neither do they go looking for trouble. Australia is capable of developing a similar self-reliant defence posture.

What is the Australian Democrats' plan? It is the objective of our party for Australia to achieve self-reliance in defence. The Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, has said publicly that he believes Australia could be self-reliant in defence for only 3 per cent of gross national product. It is not necessary now to look at a future `shopping list' for a positive defence; that is really a question of a means to an end. If the will to be self-reliant is there the choices as to the best equipment for the job can be made. Extra or additional equipment may be required, increased numbers of existing craft might be necessary and minesweepers and mine hunters should also be considered, given Australia's vulnerability to mine warfare. For goodness sake, if we are to build more mine sweepers or ships or whatever and if we have to buy them under licence from the United States or France, let them be made in Australia. This is done by both Israel and Sweden. We believe it is important that, as far as possible, equipment should be made in Australia under licence. More than half our defence dollars are spent in buying equipment overseas. The total value of Australian produced defence output in 1980-81 was a pathetic $270m.

Under no circumstances would the Democrats find conscription for overseas service acceptable. Any overseas commitment should have to be passed through both Houses of Parliament. We find it quite quaint that both the Australian Labor Party and the Liberal Party of Australia should resist this. Surely the democratically elected representatives of the people should not be denied a say in the decision as to whether young Australian men should be conscripted and sent overseas. We say that that must be a decision of both Houses of Parliament and we have introduced a private member's Bill to this effect which will find no support with either the Liberal Party or the Labor Party.

Anyone who would like Australia to snuggle up to the Russians or the Chinese or some section of the Third World should look elsewhere than to the Australian Democrats for encouragement. We will not have a bar of that. We would be totally opposed to any such move. Australia's security and independence are too important, too central to our future and our development as a proud, independent country in this geographical region to be left to the custody of others. It is far too important to ever be the area for party political point scoring, intolerance or misrepresentation. The foundation of our foreign and military policy is not a game to be played by party politics or media manoeuvrings. Some other countries, including Sweden and Switzerland, take their security and integrity far more seriously than we do. They know what they want and what they need. They are not prepared to let outsiders tell them what is best for them, be it Uncle Sam or Big Brother Boris. It is time for Australia to adopt policies and concentrate this country's resources, human and natural, in creating a strong independent Australia; to take responsibility for our own military defence, for our own regional security; to be a respected member of the international community; and to be a leader in disarmament. That is where our future interests lie and, perchance, our survival depends.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard a very significant speech from Senator Chipp not only for its content but also because it may well be his last contribution to the Australian Parliament after 25 years. I must say that Senator Chipp, in his former role, helped me considerably to become a member of this Parliament in 1975 and I will always be grateful to him for that. I simply regret that, in what I take to be his last major speech to the Parliament, there was very little with which I found I could agree.

SPEECH.PARA: In dealing with the Supply Bills, I would like to make the point that it is bad enough when a government imposes incorrect and, in fact, counter productive economic policies on a nation because it does not know that there is a serious problem but that government is in fact culpable when it fails to provide proper economic leadership at a time when it belatedly admits that it does know what is wrong with our nation. While it can be said that the speech that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) made last night was significant in that it involved a major admission that we were in a crisis, that all sorts of things had to be done, that in fact we had to accept reduced standards of living and increased standards of effort, that the Government will make the decisions necessary to meet this challenge and that it will not shirk from these hard decisions, the fact is that these decisions have not been made. That the Government has admitted that there is a crisis but is in fact not taking appropriate measures is, I think, a matter of major concern to us all.

In reality, the Prime Minister did very little last night to advance the debate beyond the points already well and truly made by the Treasurer, Mr Keating, in his banana republic statement on talkback radio. As we all know in this place, unfortunately this Government has a tendency to govern by talkback radio or television rather than by treating chambers like this one and the House of Representatives in the proper way. Not only were the people of Australia well aware of the crisis that we faced after hearing Mr Keating last month but they were well aware of it when back in March the Sydney Morning Herald leaked a Cabinet submission which indicated, according to Mr Keating, that the Australian economy was at the point of crisis and that $1.4 billion had to be cut off the Forward Estimates of expenditure by the Government if that crisis were to be avoided. It is disturbing to note that three months later, not $1.4 billion has been cut, but so far the Government has been able to find only $1 billion. It is still hunting around, with something like three weeks to go before the start of the next financial year, for the remaining $400m of expenditure cuts that are required simply to meet the target that we heard about in March. The reality is that since then-I have had the Parliamentary Library do some work for me on this matter-the Government has undertaken something like half a billion dollars-$500m-worth of additional measures which will increase its deficit, other things being equal, by half a billion dollars. That means not simply that the Government will have to cut $1.4 billion off its spending to end up with this $5 billion deficit that it talks about but rather that it will have to cut something like $2 billion off its spending. In other words, the Government has achieved less than half of its target of a $5 billion deficit.

On top of that, however, other disasters have taken place, such as the collapse of the oil market, which means that something like $1 billion of revenue which it would otherwise have received from the export of Australian oil-which is simply not taking place now-will not be available to it. The collapse of the car market has meant that the enormous revenue that comes from car sales, particularly from the importation of motor vehicles, on which there is a 57 per cent duty, will not be available. There are various estimates of what that will cost the Government, but it is generally estimated at around $300m.

This Government has talked about restraint; this Prime Minister has talked about prices; and this Treasurer has talked about the absolute need to have a deficit no bigger than $5 billion. The Government started off with a forward deficit estimate of something like $6.4 billion. It has been chopped down, on the Prime Minister's admission, by only $1 billion-that leaves it at $5.4 billion-and it has had an extra $1.3 billion added to the deficit as a result of subsequent disasters. We are now looking at the risk of running a deficit next year of between $6.5 billion and $7 billion, at a time when this Government is saying that there is a vital need not to have a deficit any larger than this year's deficit of around $5 billion. The cut of $1 billion that the Prime Minister announced last night was inadequate even to meet the target that the Treasurer set last March, let alone the target that has now developed because of the sudden disasters that the Prime Minister says have come upon us. The reality is that last night the Prime Minister failed this country. He established what the crisis was, but he has done nothing practical to resolve it.

The simple reality is that when Mr Keating, quite properly, freed up the financial system-I congratulate him for it-that very action imposed a discipline on the Government that the Opposition welcomed at that time. It said in these very terms: `It is now up to the Government to make certain that it meets this discipline, because no longer will it be able to hide behind the protection given to it by controls over the financial markets'. We can see now that this Government had no stomach for that discipline. We are all now paying the price for that governmental indiscipline. That, of course, is related to the massive increases in government spending that have taken place in the three Budgets under the Hawke Government.

There would not have been a deficit of $5 billion in the Budget for the current financial year had it not been for the increased spending that has taken place in totally new programs initiated by this Government since it has been in office. The only reason for the existence of deficits and of the crisis we face now in fiscal terms is the extra spending this Government has undertaken. The Budget Papers reveal that for everyone to see. Of course, the Government had a clear warning that this would happen. The Opposition has been given warnings about what would happen. The Budget Papers of last year warned of the serious deterioration that would take place in the terms of trade this year. The Governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia warned us, as did the Secretary to the Treasury last November, of the consequences of the Government's continuing with its policy of high interest rates as the only way to control this economy. High interest rates were all the Government could think of to protect us from a balance of payments crisis and to control inflation. Of course, that policy did none of those things. We have a balance of payments crisis. We have the worst relative inflation rate we have had in 25 years compared with that of the major countries with which we trade.

So we have the situation that the Government's policies have failed. It was warned that they would fail, not simply by the Opposition but also by its own people, by the Secretary to the Treasury and by the Governor of the Reserve Bank. The Government had a determined need, for political purposes, to ignore that advice. The reason it rushed ahead with these new Government spending programs-which, I repeat, are the only reason for the current deficit which is causing all these problems-was that it had to reduce unemployment, for political purposes. In other words, the price of buying the jobs that have reduced unemployment and provided the Government with its target has been the destruction of our currency, the enormous increase in our interest rates, and the crisis with which we are now faced. We have to put up with all those things because the Government decided, for a window-dressing purpose, for a political exercise, that no matter what the cost in terms of long term jobs it would rush ahead to meet a dramatic job creation target. The disaster is that those jobs will not last because of the way the Government has gone about gaining them.

Look at what has happened in the last 12 months. In the last 12 months under this Government unemployment has gone down by only 10,000. That is just appalling. All we ever hear the Government talk about is how it has created so many jobs since it came to office. The point is that unemployment has fallen by only 10,000. In the last month-the figures came out today-the number of people at work fell by 39,000 on a seasonally adjusted basis. So all this effort, all this cost, all this disturbance, all this disaster to the Australian economy, has been in order for the Government to get a political advantage, that is, to get the unemployment level down temporarily. That cost has been enormous but, even more significantly, the Government has failed because, as can be seen, the unemployment situation is getting worse.

Let us look at the significance of the latest unemployment figures. The Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd's series of job advertisements has revealed a 2.9 per cent decline in May, indicative of reduced demand for labour in coming months. The Government has laid the groundwork for a deterioration in employment and an increase in unemployment. Mr Willis and Mr Keating have both indicated that their best scenario is for no further falls in unemployment this year. We know what optimists they are, so we can imagine what the real prospect is. The Prime Minister's economic statement yesterday acknowledged:
. . . employment typically lags demand and output, and it would not be surprising to see some slow-down in employment growth in the months ahead . . .

Yet if we do not have adequate employment growth we will get rising unemployment because, of course, of the increase in the population. The Treasurer's chief economic adviser, Dr Barry Hughes, said on 4 June:

. . . the trend in unemployment will be broadly level, monthly volatility in the labour force figures aside. How quickly renewed falls in unemployment can occur is at this time a matter for conjecture.
We can see that the Labour Party is preparing us all for a continuing, inexorable, inevitable rise in unemployment as the tactic simply has failed.

With unemployment now stuck at about 8 per cent, the accord is clearly failing in its stated objective. Total unemployment is still higher than for all but five of the 86 months of the Fraser Government. Government members cannot blame the Fraser Government for that. They have been in government for three years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish.

—If Senator Robertson considers that rubbish, I would be grateful if he would produce the evidence. I am dealing with facts here. In only five months out of the Fraser Government's 86 months in office the unemployment level exceeded the unemployment level under this Government. Youth unemployment is a major concern; it is 22.4 per cent. That is three and a half times the adult rate. I remind Senator Robertson that that was the worst level achieved by the Fraser Government, but when the Hawke Government came to power it was something like three times that level. Clearly, youth has not shared equally in the recovery.

SPEECH.PARA: I might tell Senator Robertson that, at 22.4 per cent, youth unemployment is a percentage point higher now than it was when the Prime Minister launched his Priority One: Young Australia campaign last August. That has been the effect of the Priority One campaign. It might have given the Prime Minister a great promotional boost but it did nothing for youth unemployment, which has risen one per cent-from 21.3 per cent to 22.4 per cent-in that period. So obviously Priority One, youth traineeships and community work proposals do not tackle the central problem of excessive relative wages for youth and an inflexible wages and industrial relation system. As I have said, after all this effort in the last 12 months, unemployment is down by only 10,000. The number of people who left the work force last month was 50,300. They are the people who have given up looking for a job.

I would like briefly to deal with Mr Hawke's solution to looking after the unemployed. The only thing we heard about it was that younger recipients of the unemployment benefit should be given the opportunity to undertake some community work in return for that benefit. This seems to have brought the greatest reponse to his speech today. While I commend the idea that people should be given the opportunity to work part time a couple of days a week-I would hope at union award rates-for their unemployment benefit, it is remarkable that this is now being floated after the Labor Government rejected outright, opposed and then cancelled, a proposal announced on 8 December 1982 by the Fraser Government. I might say that I am proud to have been involved in encouraging that Government to undertake this scheme-a scheme which did exactly this. The Australian Labor Party not only has sat on this scheme for almost four years but also has actively blocked it. Let me indicate the reality by quoting from a speech recorded in the Hansard of 8 December 1982:

The Commonwealth would provide grants through the States for local bodies to undertake specific additional projects using part time labour recruited from the longer term unemployed. These grants would cover employment at casual award rates for a period necessary to earn an equivalent of benefit plus $35 a week.
A person could earn up to $35 a week by working at union award rates two days a week. The speech continues:

Each project could run for up to 12 months and employ up to 50 people. As a guide the Commonwealth would be willing to provide funds equal to the benefit rates involved plus an amount of $2m to cover the $35 a week supplement. This would enable trial projects involving about 1000 people.

All I ask Mr Hawke, he having announced this as some brilliant, bright new scheme to provide part time work for the unemployed, is: What has eventually made him admit his error? What has made him eventually admit to the young people of Australia that it was wrong, foolish and disastrous to cancel the scheme that was announced by the Fraser Government on 8 December 1982 and which would have provided exactly this?

TALK.START.PARA: —It was like most of the schemes you put up; it would not work.

—Senator Robertson says that it would not work. What is different about Mr Hawke's scheme which means that it will work? That is the important issue. The interesting thing is that Mr Hawke has no idea whether his scheme will work. His speech last night was a con. He has no scheme. He simply outlined a proposal. He has no concept of how it will work. If there is a concept of how it will work, why is it not set out in the detailed supporting documents? He simply says: `It is an outline and we will work towards it'. If any Government member pretends that it is more than a broad outline that the Government is working towards and seeking to introduce, he is talking absolute nonsense.

SPEECH.PARA: The accord is the central reason for the disaster that we now face because of the inflexibility that is imposed upon our economy. To say that the only reason that wages are being held down and there has been restraint in Australia is because of the accord is self-evident bunkum. In the rest of the world there has been wage restraint; in the rest of the world wage rises have been lower than ours; in the rest of the world inflation has been savagely reduced in order to enhance the economies and the job prospects of people. But in Australia the accord has resulted in the contrary situation. Let me read from the extraordinary, wasteful, expensive and disgraceful booklet that the Government has produced at our expense to promote itself and the accord. It is entitled `Accord-The First 2 Years'. It has been paid for by the taxpayers of Australia. Under the heading `The Achievements of Accord' the booklet reads:

In following this course, in contrast to many other countries, the Australian Government is determined not to revert to the orthodox response to devaluation of using contractionary economic policies to reduce inflation. It also rejects calls for the dismantling or destruction of our wage indexation system. Wage indexation systems overseas have been recently interrupted or suspended, with no one system escaping unscathed through the 1980s.

This booklet admits that Australia is the only country in step. It lists the other countries-Denmark, Belgium, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, France and so on-in which wage indexation has been either destroyed or diminished. It continues:
The record of statutory minimum wages is also one of set-backs and reductions . . .
It mentions Belgium, the Netherlands, Britain and the United States. I pick up what it says about the United States in particular:
In the United States, 15 per cent of unionists accepted pay cuts in 1983--
as if this is something disgraceful; in fact, it saved jobs--
and another 22 per cent accepted a wage freeze. Some 8 per cent of early 1984 Agreements allowed for new employees being taken on at lower rates of pay than existing employees.
In comparison with this overseas record, the gains achieved by Australian wage and salary earners under the Accord's wages policy are impressive.

This booklet seeks to demonstrate that Australia is the only country in step. Is that why Australia is the only one now facing this economic disaster, while the rest of the world has its economic house in order, while in the rest of the world inflation is down, while the rest of the world is looking forward to increasing economic activity, and we are looking to a fall in gross domestic product, rising unemployment and rising inflation? Is that happening because we are out of step because of this accord?

I put it to the Senate that this statement of achievement of the accord is an explanation of disaster for Australia. If we can see one simple reason why the Government's approach to the problems we face has been so totally inappropriate and how it has generated the problems we now face, it is that this Government was well aware that the terms of trade would be disastrous. It was warned at the time of the last Budget. It was warned by everyone that that would happen and that has happened. It was warned by the Opposition, by its advisers and in its Budget Papers; yet it persisted in being the one nation out of step, by way of the accord. As a result, we now face this crisis. The one fortunate thing is that at last Mr Hawke has stopped telling us fibs about how we are on track and how the economy is going well. At last he has stopped singing that song. But we have yet to hear him face up to the reality of what we should do. Until he does that, the rest of the world has every reason to be concerned about the future of our currency. We have every reason to hope that this Government, which has got Australia into this mess, will soon be replaced.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the opportunity, in spite of the attempt by Senator Grimes to interject, in speaking in the debate on Supply Bill (No. 1) 1986-87 and Supply Bill (No. 2) 1986-87 to touch for a moment on the broader macro-economic problems facing this country. It has now become clear that the failure of Australia's current account deficit to improve in response to the 30 per cent depreciation of the dollar is not an illness in itself but, more particularly, it is a symptom. For the past 12 months the Opposition and industry associates have been crying out to the Government and pointing out the dangers of promoting an unstainable rate of economic growth and asking for restraint in public sector spending. We have been pointing out the dangers of prolonged tight monetary policy which has inhibited the growth of new investment. However, the Government simply would not listen.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, the Hawke Government has conceded the fact that its choice of an economic mixture has failed. Mr Hawke now, albeit after much prompting, is attempting to change the Government's policy direction. He has said so superficially but we have yet to see the truth of the matter. Of course, if the Prime Minister really is on the road to Damascus-if he is Saul with the scales falling from his eyes-there is hope for us. Frankly I fear that the Government lacks sufficient foresight or, perhaps, is too entrapped or anxious at the thought of the forthcoming Federal election to commit itself to the necessary long term policy changes which are required to get this country back on its feet.

A short term turn-around in the balance of payments position in response to the depreciation of the dollar could occur only if world markets responded with increases in demand for our mining and agricultural commodities. The mining and agricultural exports together account for something like 80 per cent of our export earnings. Traditionally Australia's high standard of living has been supported by strong world demand for raw mineral and metal exports and for our rural exports. However, changing world trends in consumption and production of these commodities has, of course, altered world supply and demand patterns. A rise in the world supply of both agricultural products and raw materials has depressed demand and therefore depressed world prices. There has been an increase in supply over demand not only for agricultural products but also for natural raw resource products produced by Australia. More particularly, in recent times the percentage of raw metals and minerals consumed in the manufacturing sector has dropped significantly. It ought to be understood that Australia as a price taker on the world market consequently has suffered a real reduction in export income, despite the depreciation of the dollar, as its exports have so heavily concentrated in these areas.

The rural economy is faced with a glut in world demand and low world prices, particularly, in recent times, in respect of wheat. In the last five years the rate of growth in world trade of wheat has declined very significantly, and for some very good reasons. Largely this has been due to the improved capacity of wheat production in the major nations which, as a consequence, have now become considerably more self-sufficient. Our traditional importers of wheat are now either approaching self-sufficiency or are net exporters. India, which produced 12 million tonnes of wheat in 1965-66 increased production to 44.2 million tonnes by 1985-86. In fact, it was a net exporter of wheat in 1984-85. Its production is forecast to rise by 46 million tonnes in 1986-87. It is now the fifth largest producer of wheat in the world. China's production of wheat also has risen from 26 million tonnes in 1966 to 80 million tonnes in 1985. That is forecast to increase to 88 million tonnes by 1986-87. It is suggested that by the year 2000 China will be a net exporter of food. Last August when I was in Egypt there was a delegation from the Chinese seeking to sell wheat. I was disappointed that the Australian Wheat Board did not have a single permanent representative in Egypt which at that time was our major buyer of wheat. While China in many respects is still a net importer it now purchases relatively small quantities of wheat. It has a capacity in the short term to export.

Similarly, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics is the world's largest producer of wheat but is also the largest purchaser. Last year sales from us doubled. Last year the USSR bought more wheat from us than any other country. As is China's, it is a volatile and not certain market. In talking about China, the USSR, and Egypt we are talking about by far our major consumers. We cannot guarantee them as sources of export income in the future. The future outlook for wheat producers, therefore, is not one of immediate revival and prosperity, nor is it for the dairy, wine, beef, sugar cane or rice industries, just to name a few. As a result of the European Economic Community's protectionist policies and the USA's recent farm policy our traditional markets are being very much impinged upon. That was demonstrated by recent sales of rice to Papua New Guinea and by the sale to North Yemen of US wheat.

The mining industry has suffered very much a similar fate. Increased world supply and reduced demand for raw materials have forced prices down. Rising capacity has not been matched by sustained demand for raw materials as expressed during the investment boom of the early 1980s. Further, the fall in oil prices is an aggravating factor in reducing demand for Australia's steaming coal. Because of a very major iron ore project coming on stream in Brazil our iron ore market is also threatened. It has to be understood that in recent times the level of exports amongst the less developed nations has improved very much. In the last 10 years mineral and metal exports have increased between 20 and 35 per cent in developing countries. As long as they have such levels of debt they will not be interested in making profits but in attracting foreign exchange currency. The mining industry has thus been faced with a substantial reduction in profit levels. Profit has also been squeezed by costs.

Wages and total labour costs have risen significantly as a proportion of total industry costs. A coal miner now earns $750 a week. A worker in the iron ore industry earns $730 a week. In comparison, the average Australian male as a full time employee earns $413 a week. It is interesting to note that the rise in wages within the mining industry caused by the resources boom in the late 1970s and early 1980s has not been matched by a decline in labour costs during this period of reduced raw material demand. Labour costs for the mining sector for the year ending 1984-85 amounted to some $3 billion as estimated by the Australian Mining Industry Council. This represents 25 per cent of total industry costs. Therefore, under the present circumstances, a 3 per cent productivity increase and a 2 per cent award rise in my view would be most inappropriate, to say the least. Adding 5 per cent to the total cost of labour, a productivity claim and a wage award would squeeze profits even further.

While the long term prognosis has not been considered by some people to be bleak a crucial factor in determining the industry's outcome is the current control of domestic costs which is within the grasp of this Government if it chooses to have the courage and fortitude to do something about it. It is obvious, however, that the competitive pressures induced by an increase in world production and capacity have meant that Australia can no longer rely on the rural and mining sectors to produce the necessary increase in exports which will in turn solve our balance of payments problems. The time has come, in my view, for a major re-think. The nature of world trade has changed and we simply have not kept up with the pace.

Between 1949-50 and 1953-54 Australia's exports averaged 21.7 per cent of gross domestic product. Australia was one of the largest exporting nations in the world. By 1982, Australia's exports had declined to 13.9 per cent of GDP, while Canada's share, for instance, had increased to 23.8 per cent, France's to 17.8 per cent, Germany's to 26.7 per cent and Sweden's to 27.1 per cent. The United States of America's share had almost doubled from year 1958 to 7 per cent. Additionally, Australia's share of exports has not grown as fast as world trade. In 1938, for instance, Australia supplied about 2.2 per cent of the world trade. This declined to 1.18 percent in 1980.

The commodity composition of Australia's trade has also changed. In the early 1950s wool alone made up almost half of Australia's exports. As I said earlier, mining and rural commodities now account for about 80 per cent of our exports with manufacturing accounting for something like 20 per cent. It is the composition, of our commodity imports which is arguably responsible for the reduction in our share of world trade. Between 1970 and 1981 world manufacturers' trade volume increased by an average of about 7 per cent per annum, but Australia's increased by only 2.2 per cent. Eighty per cent of that world increase comprised elaborately transformed manufactures which include high technology goods. However, Australia's own export share of elaborately transformed manufactures was only 12.2 per cent. In contrast, imports of manufactured goods rose from 68.9 per cent of total imports in the early 1950s to 75 per cent in the early 1980s. Australia's share of technology intensive goods was 36 per cent of total imports in 1980.

Australia's share in manufacturing has clearly suffered a substantial decline since the early 1970s and it has failed to maintain its trade proportion in line with world trade, as I have pointed out in the statistics I have given so far. One of the crucial problems affecting the manufacturing industry is the declining or static and generally inadequate levels of profitability. By and large, company profits have not recovered the historical levels which were necessary to encourage adequate investments, particularly in real terms. Despite some recovery from the recession levels during the two years to September 1985, profit levels in most industries have not been sufficient to sustain an adequate rate of private investment. In the December quarter of 1985, the gross operating surplus of trading enterprise companies fell by 6.1 per cent, while wages and other labour costs rose by 4.4 per cent in current prices and seasonally adjusted terms.

Reduced opportunities for business investment by declining profits have been exacerbated by rising labour costs as a proportion of total industry costs. On-costs in particular have risen as a proportion of direct payments to labour and Australian industry. It was estimated by the Australian Confederation of Industry to contribute to roughly 40 per cent of the total cost of labour for the year 1983-84. Adding a 3 per cent productivity claim and a 2 per cent award wage rise would bring on-costs to about half of the industry's total labour costs. High interest rates and high levels of taxation have also been major factors in reducing the level of productivity and profitability, thereby causing inadequate levels of business investment. That is one of the intrinsic problems which face the manufacturing sector at present.

However, that is not the whole story. The manufacturing industry was established through protectionist policies which were designed to increase Australia's self-sufficiency. Such traditional infant policies, so to speak, have been maintained in a fiercely competitive international environment. Tariffs, quotas, content requirements, bounties and export subsidies have prevented the industry from undertaking the necessary structural readjustments which are required, in my view, to maintain international competitiveness. Protection has been a major cause of misallocation of resources and inefficiency in these industries.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does Watson agree with that?

—Senator Watson and I do not agree on everything, particularly, I suspect, in respect of protection of the manufacturing sector. I do not believe for a moment that all right is on my side, but I think there is a nice balance between what the two of us say. The burden to consumers and consuming industries as a result of all forms of assistance to the manufacturing industry is estimated to be $11.3 billion for the year 1982-83. Clearly, the protectionist policies of the past are outmoded in the current climate of changing international trade. In the past Australia has not been programmed to specialise or to excel in particular areas of expertise. We have not been encouraged to continue the production process. We have left designs and innovations where they were some time ago.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, before I touch on education-I point out that for very many years there has been no real tangible or intrinsic relationship between education and job opportunities-I want to refer to one changing factor in respect of the manufacturing sector. The amount of industrial raw materials needed for one unit of industrial production is now no more than two-fifths of what it was in 1900 and the decline is accelerating. The Japanese experience is particularly striking. In 1984, for every unit of industrial production Japan consumed only 60 per cent of the raw materials consumed for the same volume of industrial production in 1973, just 11 years earlier. Industrial production is steadily switching away from heavily material-intensive products and processes. One of the reasons for this is the new high-technology industries.

The raw materials in a semi-conductor microchip account for one to 3 per cent of total production costs. In an automobile their share is 40 per cent and in pots and pans it is 60 per cent. Even in older industries the same scaling down of raw material needs goes on. For example, 50 to 100 pounds of fibreglass cable transmit as many telephone messages as does one ton of copper wire. This steady drop in the raw material intensity of manufacturing processes and manufacturing products extends to energy as well, and especially to petroleum. To produce 100 pounds of fibreglass cable requires no more than 5 per cent of the energy needed to produce one ton of copper wire. Similarly, plastics, which are increasingly replacing steel in automobile bodies, represent a raw material cost, including energy, of less than half that of steel. Thus it is quite unlikely that raw material prices will ever rise substantially compared with the prices of manufactured goods or high-knowledge services such as information, education or health care, except in the event of a major prolonged war. Senator Puplick has quite properly argued long and hard for that. Australia needs a clear change of direction in terms of its export capacity and the areas on which we ought to be concentrating. That is something we have ignored so far. If we do not recognise that our major export-minerals and metals-is diminishing in its percentage contribution to the manufacturing sector, our balance of payments will continue to deteriorate dramatically and our capacity for exports will also decline dramatically. If we do not understand that we ought to be moving into the high technology areas, we are really going to get left behind in terms of our balance of payments and our capacity to understand what exports the world wants.

That leads me to the question of education. In my view, our education system does absolutely nothing to encourage students either to stay on in further education or to study science oriented subjects. In 1982, the percentage of 16-year-olds enrolled in full time or part time study in Australia was 77.3 per cent. Those enrolled in the United States of America, Japan and the Netherlands represented 93 per cent, 94 per cent and 97 per cent respectively. In Australia in 1984 45 per cent of school students stayed on until year 12. Of the 26 subjects available for tertiary entrance examinations in Western Australia, exactly 50 per cent cover the fields of languages and history. Only 20 per cent are related to science. This gives us some indication of where our priorities are in our education system and its intrinsic and necessary relationship with the jobs that are available, and the growth and the dynamic capacity that this country ought to have.

The greatest challenge facing Australian industry is to improve its ability to compete in the international market when a greater proportion of that market is being taken up by the high technology trade. The future strength of Australian industry thus depends on its ability to produce more inventors, more researchers and more technological innovators to meet these immediate demands. It is essential that the Australian economy be assisted with short term policy measures, but long term foresight is necessary also to prevent its general demise. Our education system must encourage a greater uptake of subjects relevant to the economy's future needs. Employers in manufacturing must become more aggressive in their marketing and production plans. Greater investment should be encouraged in those industries and commodities which cater to world trends in demand, and resources must be allocated to their most efficient use in production.

Our outlook need not be bleak, but it will require recognition by the Government that the economic environment must be improved to increase and promote business confidence. Industry can be assisted in this respect by a reduction in the costs caused by high taxes, high interest rates, high labour costs and government regulation. If the Government continues with its failure to adopt a long term view of Australia's economic future, it will continue to fail in restoring any prospect that this country has to enjoy the kind of prosperity we have experienced in the past.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity of debating Supply Bill (No. 1) 1986-87 and Supply Bill (No. 2) 1986-87 to refer to appropriations under divisions 315 and 316 for the Department of Foreign Affairs and to introduce a subject that might be of a controversial nature-the question of the application of sanctions to a country. I refer particularly to South Africa. I do this in a constructive spirit because I believe that the Western World-the democratic communities of the world-is not entirely cognisant of the differences that exist between conditions in the African continent and conditions in a country such as Australia. It is very easy for the international community to criticise activities in South Africa and to relate those activities to the conditions that exist in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I recall my first visit to that continent in 1969, when I visited the northern African States. I observed the effects of the handing over of rule by the colonial powers and the Africanisation of departments, hospitals and so on which were formerly under English administration. There was a considerable period in which the African people who took over the responsibilities at that time needed the guidance of expatriates in order to maintain administrative efficiency.

I well recall meeting a very young aggressive Minister from Kenya called Tom Mboya, who was a Luo-a potential threat, if one can so put it, to the supremacy of Kenyatta, who was a Kikuyu, the predominant tribe of that country. I formed the impression that Tom Mboya, the Minister for Development and Education, was a very astute, intelligent young man who, in my view, would be the ideal person to take over the presidency of that country from Kenyatta, who had ruled very effectively following his days as a terrorist Mau-Mau leader. I was very distressed when I learned nine or ten months later that he had been shot by a Kikuyu tribesman. That alerted me to the immense difficulties of the African continent with its tribal traditions.

Seven years after that experience, I first visited South Africa and was not pleased with what I saw. I noticed that there was decided discrimination between the whites and blacks in particular and the other ethnic groups that constitute the most complex society in the African continent. South Africa consists of no fewer than 10 or 11 black tribal groups, the Indian tribal group, the coloured tribal group and two white tribal groups. Those white tribal groups combined represent five million people, 60 per cent of whom are Afrikaner and roughly 40 per cent English.

The South African Government faces a complex problem at present in coming to some arrangement to accommodate diverse ethnic groups, among whom are 100,000 Jews, as well as Asians from China and Japan. The Western world does not appreciate the complexity of South Africa. I am an opponent of apartheid, as we all are.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—My friend Senator Puplick is also an opponent, but I take the view that the way in which the international community is treating the South African Government at present is reprehensible. Many moderate blacks and the majority of the two white tribes in South Africa believe that the attitude expressed internationally is retarding the progress of reform. The authorities have admitted the mistakes of the past and have said they believe that apartheid was wrong. When I first went to South Africa the policy of apartheid envisaged the establishment of homeland states, wherein the tribal groups among the black people would be able to be provided with independence and autonomy in their particular group. I believe the Western world is culpable for not recognising that that Government has been big enough to say: `We were wrong and we are attempting to correct the mistakes of the past'.
