Honourable senators must remember that the policy of apartheid has persisted for 50 years and the majority of people in South Africa-most of the white people, the majority of moderate black people and the Indians and other ethnic groups to which I have referred-have recognised the sincere purpose of the President of South Africa, Mr P. W. Botha, and his Ministers in the program that they have instituted. Many of those particular matters have been addressed, the more difficult ones are being addressed at present and will be addressed in the future.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem in South Africa is the extreme left wing which, unhappily, is represented by the African National Congress. The ANC comprises a majority of the Xhosa tribe which is not recognised by the Zulus and certain other people as being entirely representative of the black community. Unhappily the Congress is influenced-and I am not a red witch hunter, but one must recognise the facts of the case-by its executive and members of that executive are predominantly members of the South African Communist Party. These people owe their allegiance to the Soviet Union which supports them financially and provides them with weapons. However, I do not want to give the impression that I brand the whole of the ANC with that particular brush because there are some people who are more moderate. On my most recent visit to South Africa I found that Oliver Tambo claims to be and has the reputation for being a nationalist. I understand also the feelings about Nelson Mandela, who is incarcerated in gaol, and who was convicted 25 years ago on a charge of treason, because of his accumulation of weapons which threatened the peace and security of South Africa. I will not go back over the past 25 years, but I do believe that there could be very good reasons why Nelson Mandela should be released-on the condition that he rejects violence in respect of the accommodation of the black people of South Africa.

TALK.START.PARA: —Even if he did it would be meaningless because he is no longer in control of the ANC.

—I believe that Nelson Mandela is a myth, but in the eyes and minds of the younger people in South Africa he is a person of influence. As far as I am concerned, there could be merit in releasing him and in consulting with Mr Tambo who, I hope and believe, is a moderate and a nationalist. But that is not the end of the problem in South Africa because the majority of the black people do not recognise the ANC as the legitimate spokes organisation for the black community in that country. In particular, the Zulu people have a traditional history of antagonism to the Xhosa tribe. That in itself is a problem. The Zulu nation is under the leadership of a man whom I regard as a black statesman. In my view he has made constructive comments about the situation in that country. He has advocated the release of Nelson Mandela. I believe that he is a leader of great credibility among the black people of South Africa who represent 75 per cent of the population.
—That is Gatsha Buthelezi.

—He does not like to be called Mangosuthu Gatsha Buthelezi. He has a different name. I refer to the Chief Minister of KwaZulu. When I visited that country recently I was impressed by the way in which the predominantly ethnic population happens to be running its own affairs in a very aggressive and independent way. The Chief Minister is prepared to stand up to the white administration and say `I will consult with you under certain conditions' which I believe involves the release of Nelson Mandela. I think that is worthy of recognition. I return to what I said earlier. I think the people of Australia are sympathetic to the people of South Africa. Australians recognise-this is something that is often denied-that sport in South Africa is multiracial. There is no question about that. I believe that the average Australian recognises that historically in the past South Africans have always stood up with us against the aggression of other countries.
—Oh, they are fascists.

—The honourable senator may say that, but I am pointing out that we ought to be reasonable and compliment the South African people. I am an apologist for the Australian Government. The Australian Government has let the people of Australia down economically. It has let the workers down economically. The Government is unwilling to recognise its mistakes. If the Australian Government got up and said `We have made mistakes economically. We have done the wrong thing by the workers of Australia', I would not have to be an apologist for it. I believe that governments say that apartheid in South Africa is wrong but South Africa is saying: `We are doing our very best to correct that situation. We are frustrated by the people in the black community who are now known and becoming infamous as Comrades'. These young people are killing black people who dare to co-operate with the white government in the interests of the total black community. South Africa is trying to accommodate the wishes of the black people. Once the mayor of a black town-there is local government there-dared to suggest that he was going to co-operate with the white government, so called--
—Collaborators.

—They call them collaborators. Those people are then marked down for necklace treatment by these Comrades who are young black people who delight in necklacing fellow moderate black people. The Comrades terrorise and inject fear into these people because they are afraid that they will evolve a peaceful resolution to accommodate the wishes of the black people of that unfortunate country. I believe that we can do far better; I have said that before in this chamber. I am as great an opponent of apartheid as any other member of the Senate, but I believe that international governments should treat members of other governments as people. If I were to say to Senator Sheil that I disagreed totally with the way he was running a medical practice, that what he was doing to his patients was wrong, that he should be doing something else, and if I condemned him for his treatment, he would be likely to tell me what to do. If I were to say to Senator Sheil that I admired the treatment he was giving to his patients in one respect and asked whether he thought that perhaps by doing something different in another area he and his patients could profit, that sort of carrot rather than the stick approach would be much more helpful, as it would be to the black people in South Africa.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to the heading `Millions could die, Fraser group warns'. I say to honourable senators that the person who is held in high regard in South Africa--

TALK.START.PARA: —Is Malcolm Fraser.

—It is not Malcolm Fraser; it happens to be General Obasanjo, who was the general in Nigeria who put down the Biafran riots. General Obansanjo summarily executed without trial his officers who were incompetent at that time. It so happened that he expelled 200,000 refugees from Nigeria at that time. He was one of the more moderate generals in Nigeria. He ultimately became President and introduced a civil administration in that country. He is respected more than Malcolm Fraser, who does not know anything about tribalism in that continent. He went to South Africa for two days and branded the Government of South Africa as being nazi, simply because it has a problem. It has a problem-this is what I want to get around to-with the members of the extreme black left who want to necklace the moderates who are prepared to co-operate. Unhappily, there are also the members of the extreme right amongst the Afrikaners, whom I deplore equally because they want to introduce violence. They are in the minority. One cannot brand the whole Afrikaner race, because the majority absolutely reject that attitude. It is those nazi-like people who have the laager mentality who want to isolate the white community from the black people, and that is wrong. So I am suggesting to honourable senators--
—What category would you fall into?

—Of course, Senator Jones would not know anything about this. I have a great regard for Senator Sibraa, but I did not believe my ears the other day when I heard Red Harrison on AM-I am not sure what the `Red' stands for; I presume he has red hair or something like that-call upon Senator Sibraa, a senior member of the Labor Party and Chairman of the so-called influential Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, to make a comment. What did Senator Sibraa say? I like Senator Sibraa. I would have thought that he would have some knowledge of the tribal problems in Africa, but he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Well, I think we've got to look at downgrading our diplomatic representation in South Africa. We ought to look at closing the South African Tourist Commission in Australia--

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!
—The Minister for Finance says `Hear, hear!'
—No, he said that.

—Well, I am sure that the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) would not agree because it happens to be very important to Australia that we attract international finance. We want to correct our balance of payments. Senator Sibraa went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: We ought to look at closing the South African Tourist Commission in Australia and perhaps stop South African Airlines operating into Australia.

Of course, what we ought to be doing is allowing South African Airways to have two flights a week. Qantas Airways Ltd ought to have two flights a week to South Africa because that would increase our tourist income. I would have thought that would be important to the Government of Australia. I have heard on good authority that Qantas is anxious to do that. What happens now is that Qantas flies into Harare and then South African Airways has to transport Australians down to Johannesburg and we have to pay for that. What an absolutely stupid idea that is. I repeat what I said about Senator Sibraa. I like the fellow; I believe he is a moderate and reasonable fellow, but this was the climax of what he said:
Perhaps give more assistance to the ANC to allow them to run their office and train people within this country.
Can honourable senators tell me who is training the African National Congress people? It is the Libyans, the East Germans, the Czechoslovaks and the Russians.

TALK.START.PARA: —Against foreign incursions.

—The honourable senator can say that, of course. But what is this Government all about? We are supposed to be combatting international terrorism. We are supposed to be trying to help the black people of South Africa. Will that be of help to them? I remind you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that there are two million foreign black people working in South Africa who send back to their countries 60 per cent of their wages every time they are paid. That is a significant contribution to the economies of 10 or 12 African states. The South Africans have also entered into an agreement with four or five other countries with respect to sharing of Customs excises. South Africa allows the exports and imports of those other countries into and out of the ports in South Africa and allows the railways they have built to be used for that purpose. That represents a significant economic contribution to those other countries in Africa.

SPEECH.PARA: Any economic sanctions that are applied inhibit the capacity of South Africa to continue that sort of economic assistance to those other states. We have to recognise the significant contribution that has been made by the South African Government to those other people. If we are worried about black people, we should include the number of black people who happen to be in the northern part of Africa but who are being assisted by South Africa. South Africa also provides something of the order of $3 billion worth of aid to other countries less fortunate than itself. It provides food, fresh fruit and other exports to those countries. I am glad to see that Fraser's Eminent Persons Group has fallen short of calling for economic sanctions against that country because it realises the damage that would be done not only to South African blacksbut--

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought they recommended that.

—No, I am glad to say that they did not. I am, of course, concerned about the problems in South Africa. Nevertheless, I think we ought to be giving South Africa a few carrots, a few commendations, for its recognition that it has been wrong in the past and for the fact that it prepared to redress those matters, to correct them in the future. I was talking to Kent Durr, who is an Assistant Minister in the National Party, who was in Australia in 1966 and doorknocked for Andrew Peacock. He said: `I am a progressive Minister in this Government and we are anxious to accommodate the black people on the question of decision making and on the question of political determination in this country'.
—Who paid your fare to South Africa?
—I believe, quite frankly, that the Western world would do well to encourage this Government rather than talk like Senator Jones, who would not know anything about it.
—No wonder you are an apologist for the South African Government; it paid your fare over there.

—Yes, of course it did. I do not mind admitting that. I do not mind admitting that people on the other side of this House have been paid to go to China and Yugoslavia. I do not mind accepting a fellowship to inform myself of the facts in that country. Senator Jones could not care less about the welfare of the black people in that country. I condemn Senator Jones for that and suggest that he is negligent and reprehensible for making the suggestion he makes. I could nominate people who have gone overseas to the Eastern bloc countries-apologists for the communist countries of the world, who have accepted the same sort of invitation that I have. I will do it again, because in three visits I have noticed incredible progress. I could talk for a long time on this subject, because I think the people of Australia do not realise just what is happening. I will talk again about this matter, because I believe that the rest of the world is not helping the black population of South Africa-incidentally, the whole of Africa-in the way in which it is approaching this important subject.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It may come as somewhat of a surprise to those few Australians who still happen to be listening to the airwaves coming from Parliament House that we are, in fact, debating Supply Bill (No. 1) 1986-87 and Supply Bill (No. 2) 1986-87. We are debating whether the Government should be allowed the money necessary to carry on. I will endeavour to confine my remarks to matters of money and finance, even though this may be less exciting than the affairs of South Africa. These Bills will be supported by the Australian Democrats as they are money Bills and we have a commitment to support such Bills. However, I believe that these Bills should give food for thought to all in this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: The amounts shown in these Bills reflect a larger than inflation increase on the amounts shown in the equivalent Bills of last year. I know, of course, that there are reasons why there should be increases at a rate above the inflation rate on the amounts shown for last year. We have had to increase payments to rural industries to help farmers through the present tough period caused by the world glut in agricultural products. We have had to offer special support to the sugar industry to cushion the devastating price falls experienced by producers, particularly in Queensland. Significant expenses have been incurred as a result of payments for major pieces of defence hardware. Nonetheless, these Bills show that there has been a significant real increase in Government expenditure in a number of areas, despite the Government's commitment to the trilogy.

The whole question of Government expenditure needs to be reviewed. We hear plenty of talk about the pros and cons of Government expenditure. Indeed, it is a favourite hobby-horse for the coalition parties. Government expenditure, we are told by the coalition, is the root of all evil. Government expenditure, we are told, is unproductive. Government expenditure, we are told, is the cause of inflation. Throughout the 1970s we were hammered with what I consider to be the preposterous position that inflation was caused by big government expenditure and that the squeezing of government expenditure, the squeezing of the government deficit, would squeeze inflation out of the system. Those who pushed that view ignored probably the most significant political and economic happening of the last 20 years. The fact is that the price of oil rose from $3 a barrel in 1973 to $30 a barrel in 1980. Oil, the major input of the world economy, experienced a tenfold price leap. Its cost rose by no less than 1,000 per cent. But this, we are told, was not connected in any way with inflation. That, at least, is what the monetarists of this country would have us believe.

Of course, the increase in the oil price triggered inflation. It triggered a recession and an enormous change in the priorities and attitudes of all world economies-the West, the East, as well as the Third World. Looking back, it is, I believe, a testament to the durability of the Western economies in particular that there was not in the 1970s a depression as bad as that which took place in the 1930s. All of this, of course, went unnoticed by the Right and, indeed, by the Opposition parties, although I must admit that their record in reducing expenditure was in marked contrast to their rhetoric.

Again, this country, unfortunately, is facing a balance of payments crisis. We are still being bombarded with the tired old `government spending' rhetoric. Let us look at what the small government people are really saying. Quite simply, they are saying this: `Let those dependent on the government for their income or the provision of services carry the can for whatever economic problems we happen to be facing at the moment'. In the 1970s they were saying: `Let social security recipients and those who use public services-public transport, public hospitals and so on-bear the brunt of the increase in the oil price'. Interestingly, implicit in the rhetoric is the undertaking that government services to the wealthy in terms of aid to private health and education systems and the existence of tax inequalities should not be touched, although this is never stated explicitly. They did not want society as a whole to bear the burden of the oil price shocks. They thought the disadvantaged and the workers should carry the can. I am afraid it is the same story now. To get over the balance of payments problem, we are told that the Government must cut its expenditure. Once again, those least able to accept reductions in living standards are singled out to carry the burden.

Of course, this addresses right wing prejudice rather than the real problem, which is the balance of payments situation. The only way out of the balance of payments predicament is through the adoption of meaningful industry policies, agreements with unions through employee participation, and other similar measures to end irrational, restrictive work practices, and the closing of rorts which disadvantage those who are in a position to engage in jiggery-pokery investments on the stock exchange.

There is another point that the conservatives cannot come to grips with. Their knee-jerk, reaction to any crisis is to cut back government expenditure, in other words to disadvantage those who already are disadvantaged. They are unable to cure the problem. In fact, their reaction just exacerbates the problem. Whether we like it or not today government expenditure is necessary to provide social and economic infrastructures to keep up demand in the economy. To cut back government expenditure in real terms at this stage would take out all the impetus that is in the economy at the moment. To cut back government expenditure at a time of economic difficulty would be a sure recipe to bring on a recession. The grotesque example that should bring this home, even to the Opposition, is that of Thatcher's Britain. I wonder whether the unemployed in Liverpool and Glasgow would get a warm feeling in their hearts if they were to hear their Prime Minister say that she had managed to squeeze inflation out of the system. Somehow, I doubt it. Her obsession with cutting expenditure in fact has strangled that nation. Therefore, the important point is that we, like it or not, need government expenditure. I suggest that in the 1980s this should be an undisputed fact.

However, the important question-it is a very important question to the Australian Democrats-is what type of government expenditure we need. Unfortunately the Democrats seem to be the only people in this country to ponder this question. In the 1930s government expenditure meant giving jobs to people to build roads. Of course, those days are gone forever. The advent of machines has meant that road building employs very few people. In the 1980s President Reagan used government expenditure to boost the economy. He did this very effectively. However, he chose to do it by boosting the arms industry in response to his idea of the cold war. This, too, the Democrats find grotesque because it threatens life on this planet and diverts resources from socially and economically useful ends; the arms industry in the United States booms while the infrastructure in many American cities crumbles.

What worries me and the Democrats about these Bills that we are debating at the moment is that inevitably they are a pointer to the target of Australian Government expenditure. If we choose to spend money on unproductive self-expanding bureaucracies we will head for disaster. Both Federal and State governments have expanded their bureaucracies-this is undeniable-at a greatly alarming rate over the last 20 years. Much of this bureaucracy is unnecessary. Many of the jobs bureaucracy creates provide little satisfaction in the work they develop. They are little more than a wage for those people who occupy a position in the bureaucracy. Also the role of many of the departments that have been set up seems to be to hinder both citizens and business. In many cases the term `public service' has become one of black humour.

The Democrats would like to see a policy of reducing bureaucracy through the freeing up of regulations and the utilisation of computer technology. We would like to see it rearrange its resources so that it can be a public service rather than a public hindrance. We must channel government money straight into the community without the bureaucratic conduit. We should fund councils, work programs and community groups to provide social, economic and cultural services. We should fund those in industry who have new ideas and who want to be innovative. Let us increase welfare payments and the allowable income that can be earned by those prepared to take part in part time work and thus increase their living standards. Let us fund farmers to find new crops for which there is world demand and to plant trees on their properties. Let us put money into rural communities to help them survive. This sort of creative government intervention would benefit us socially, environmentally and economically. What I find disturbing about government expenditure is not its size, but its direction. By using our imaginations we could create a better nation. If we do not accept this challenge we will face a depression that will make the 1930s look like a tea-party.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night the speech of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) cost the nation $745m. This cost does not represent the cost of presentation of the address which the taxpayer will pay for. It is just the additional cost on our overseas debt caused by the immediate fall in the dollar following the speech. The Prime Minister's speech, according to so many editorials, was so long on rhetoric and short on specifics, so short in detail and sincerity that in the first 10 minutes the Australian dollar fell by half a cent overseas. As the night wore on its value fell by an additional half a cent. That value was worse when compared with the price of sterling. In Japan the Australian dollar tumbled. Our present debt of $74.589 billion immediately went up another three quarters of a billion dollars because every time the Australian dollar falls by a cent we lose another three quarters of a billion dollars. Headlines in the newspapers have also said this. The Sun said: `It's discord'. It also said: `Unions upset, dollar dives'. Another comment which I think is most appropriate was in the Age. Terry McCrann said:

SPEECH.PARA: Disastrous. That is the only appropriate word to describe what Bob Hawke did last night. And everyone in Australia-except perhaps John Howard-is going to pay the price.

After raising expectations that the Government would demonstrate conclusively that it was prepared to take the tough decisions necessary to address the worst economic crisis this country has seen since the 1930s Depression Mr Hawke produced a wishy-washy-albeit impressively delivered-damp squib.

That is the sort of comment being made. From overseas markets to local financial markets, from the Australian Council of Trade Unions to the business community, from Australian Labor Party members-there are many-to Liberal Party members, there has been extreme disappointment, criticism and disgust.

The Prime Minister told us that he was at last telling the people the truth about the Australian economy. The Opposition has been telling the people the truth for 18 months to two years. The Government Ministers-indeed, the Prime Minister himself-have been saying that it was just our political rhetoric. Now, belatedly, we have been joined by Mr Hawke and the Treasurer (Mr Keating). The Treasurer told us that his plans just had not worked. He told us that Australia was now in a hole, that things were a disaster, that we were nothing short of a banana republic, that we cannot go on living in the way we are, and that we have to pull our belts in. In the past he said to us: `There are no worries. She'll be right mate. The J-curve is just around the corner'. He said that we could all take our share of the 3 per cent productivity claim, even those in industries such as the rural industry where there was no productivity at all, as the J-curve would fix all that. The Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission was told by the best Treasurer in the whole wide world: `You fix it. The unions want it. The J-curve is coming, so she'll be right.' All this time the Opposition was telling the people that things had to change, that things were not all right, that the Government was not telling them the truth, but ours was a lone voice. The Treasurer kept telling them that the J-curve was coming.

The world's best Treasurer lulled the man in the street into a false sense of security-and then the crunch came. When the last balance of payment figures came out, Australians found out that what the Opposition had been saying all along was true. Mr Keating, the world's best Treasurer, was not heard from for 24 hours-he went to water. The media tried to interview Mr Keating but there was no response from him. After 24 hours the world's best Treasurer said that he had turned Australia into a banana republic. That did not do too much for the Australian dollar. He then said: `But it is not my fault; the overseas markets are the problem, so we will have a summit'. He wanted to have one to share the blame. But the Boss, who was visiting China, said: `No, we won't have a summit'. He spoke a few kindly words to the Treasurer and the summit was off, and instead there was to be an advisory committee meeting. When he came home, the advisory committee meeting was off and we were to have a speech from the Prime Minister himself. What has he said? He was asked last night on the Carlton-Walsh Report to say what were the hard decisions he had made. These were the ones he chose. First, he said that it was not easy for a Prime Minister to tell his nation that it has to have a reduction in its standard of living. That was a hard decision to make. Secondly, he said: `It is not easy when we have an accord with the trade union movement to say unequivocally something that you know it is not going to like but I did that'. Thirdly, he said: `It is not easy to tell both the community and the States that we will have to force some hard decisions upon them in the Budget and in the Premiers Conference'. He patted himself on the back, saying that he made those three hard decisions.
The Prime Minister also talked about the Public Service. In his speech to the nation he said:
. . . under successive Governments, including my own, the federal public service has continued, inexorably, to grow in numbers.
While a good public service is essential to the well-being of our society, an increasingly efficient public service does not mean an increasingly large public service.

Let me give some figures supplied to me by the Parliamentary Library's statistics section-a truly independent source. I will give the true figures showing the increases over the years of Commonwealth government employees. When we came to government in December 1985, following Gough Whitlam, the number of Commonwealth government employees, the public servants of Australia, totalled 400,500. When we left government the number totalled 407,500, an increase of 7,000. In 1978, when we took over the public servants of the railways of South Australia and Tasmania, we had to add 9,500 public servants to the Commonwealth payroll. We did not make that decision, Gough had made it, but we had to take over the additional 9,500 public servants. If we take off the Northern Territory self-government figure of 5,300, of that additional 7,000 people put on the government payroll during the Fraser years we find that there was an increase of only 4,200 Commonwealth public servants. The Fraser Government had 407,500 public servants on its payroll, but what happened when the Hawke Government came to power? At December last year there were 432,900 public servants, an increase of 25,400.

The Prime Minister has fiddled the figures. He has distorted the public service figures for his own purpose. It is for reasons such as that that this side of the Senate, as well as the people of Australia, no longer trust him. An editorial in yesterday's Herald stated:

The first thing to say is we have been living with too many myths. Myth Number One. Bob Hawke was wrong to cultivate the fiction that a swing in the business cycle (the recovery of 1984) and drought-breaking rain somehow flowed from summits, consensus, a swooning Press and silver-topped charisma. It's pointless to now blame Bob Hawke and his men for `going bad' on us. The truth is they were never that good. Competence and luck should not be confused with supernatural powers, which brings us to Myth Number Two.
We never owned a world champion Treasurer . . .
The truth is wages are regulated less by market forces than by a bureaucracy that produces blanket rises (as though all industries can pay equally) and mocks words such as productivity.
The editorial went on to point out to the Australian people that Bob Hawke was just a dead loss. It continued:
So what we now have is a confiscatory Government, and the ridiculous part is it all seems to have happened by accident.

The editorial was referring, of course, to the fringe benefits tax, the capital gains tax, and all the other taxes the Government has introduced just lately. The Government has become a government that confiscates public moneys. We have a fringe benefits tax that rips off $600m from business and a capital gains tax that, in a few years time, will be doing likewise. What have we as a result of that? The Prime Minister has offered to give back some businesses, just to one section, a limited subsidy on interest rates. The Government put interest rates up so high that it has now offered one section of the community a limited subsidy on those interest rates, and that section of the business industry is that section which invests in heavy manufacturing projects where, believe it or not, management and unions are co-operating. Good heavens, is it any wonder the people are at last recognising that it is no use blaming Bob and his Ministers for going bad on us; the truth is, they were never that good.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it is important to get Supply Bill (No. 1) 1986-87 and Supply Bill (No. 2) 1986-87 through the Senate, but I want to make a few short points because some criticism has been made of the speech last night by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). The Prime Minister said that what is required is that there be a reduction in the increases in people's wages below that which they would normally get if those wages were adjusted according to increases in the consumer price index. He said that there would be a 2.3 per cent increase as a result of the national wage case that is presently before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and that after that there would be nothing. I would have thought that that was a fairly severe burden to place on the ordinary citizens of this country. At times we all become ordinary citizens; we become very ordinary citizens when we go into a shop to buy groceries, when we try to send our children to school or perhaps to send them on a school excursion, when we go to buy some decent clothes or perhaps try to go away on a holiday. We are now being told that we cannot do that because any increased prices will stay increased but the wages we receive to pay for those things are going to stay the same. We are told that we have to reduce our standard of living. People quite plainly understand that.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Chaney, who studies these theories, is known here as a man of some compassion, but when he studies this theory he forgets the very people he should be serving-the wage earners, the people who try to keep themselves and their families alive and with some sort of decent standard of living. In his speech the Prime Minister called for a reduction in wages. He said that there will be only one national wage increase in 1986 to keep up with increased prices. Prices keep going up. Senator Chaney said that the Government is not taking any real action. The fact that a person's salary has lost its buying power, the fact that a person might have to withdraw his children from certain schools, the fact that a person might not be able to go on some minor outing-to the pictures or some show, to meet some friends and have a few beers-is not good enough as far as Senator Chaney is concerned; there have to be further reductions. Senator Chaney has said that there is no real action on wages, that nothing is being done by the Government about the wage burden which is part of the problem of Australian industry. What Senator Chaney is really saying is that in this equation of employer and employee, industry and the people who work in it, there is only one factor to take into account and that is the people who he says create the jobs-as if it is a privilege to have the job that one is given. Is that the way to get over the economic, social and cultural burdens that are falling on this country? Is it not only proper that all elements-employers, employees and those who are unfortunate enough to be disadvantaged-should share the burden equally? Why does the Opposition criticise a Prime Minister who calls for wage cuts? Why does it say that those wage cuts should be even greater, even more draconian and even more onerous than those cuts which the Prime Minister has called for?

The Opposition supports a situation where the greatest burden of external debt is contracted by private enterprise. Let us hope that that debt is being used to produce jobs. That is what has been happening under this Government and let us hope that it continues. But the Opposition, instead of looking to see how the burden can be more equitably distributed overall, says that there is one solution, and one only, to the problems of this nation, and that is the reduction of wages. The Opposition also envisages the cutting down of social services that this Government and hopefully other governments may provide. Why does the Opposition want to throw the burden on the person who is least able to bear it-the person who will not be able to send his or her children to the school he or she wants or to buy decent food and clothing? The Opposition would rather load up the wealth of this country into one sector and one sector only. Why is it that the burden should be so unjustly cast upon those who are least able to bear it? I do not wish to say anything beyond that. I shall now resume my seat in the hope that I shall hear the answer to that question.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating Supply Bill (No. 1) and Supply Bill (No. 2). I shall be pleased at the end of my address to give Senator Cooney a few practical proposals he might like to take back to the man who pretends he is the Prime Minister of Australia. Let us look at the disastrous state of the Australian economy-an economy which the Treasurer (Mr Keating) described as a banana republic. It is a terminal problem which the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) referred to in his pathetic address to the nation as a `challenge'. Let us examine some of the statistical factors-for example, the dollar. Our dollar has collapsed in just 12 months under this phoney little ex-President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, reminiscent of his sortie into Bourke's stores and ACTU-Solo.
—He was into travel, too, wasn't he?

—Yes, I think he was into travel. Let us look at some of the comparative currencies. In Japan in just 12 months our dollar has dropped from 204 yen to 114.25 yen, a drop of 44 per cent. In the United Kingdom the dollar has dropped from 64p to 54p, the lowest level against the pound sterling in 10 years. Our dollar has dropped against the West German Deutsche mark from 2.40 to 1.52, a drop of 36 per cent, and against the Swiss franc from 2.00 to 1.25, a drop of 37 per cent. That is how far, even after the initial devaluation, that our standard of living has slipped in just 12 short months.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the balance of payments. Australia is headed for a $14 billion current account deficit for 1985-86-well over the $10.7 billion in the Treasurer's Budget predictions. I turn to our foreign debt. The extraordinary and frightening overseas debt was not even mentioned in the Prime Minister's address to the nation. In March 1983 the gross foreign debt stood at $33 billion. Confidential Treasury forecasts indicate that by June 1987 the gross external debt could stand at $100 billion. Since the Hawke Government came to power, the debt will have increased by around 300 per cent, which is $17,500 for every taxpayer and $6,300 for every man, woman and child in Australia. Every newborn baby has an IOU around its neck inscribed: `I owe $6,500'. Let us look at interest rates. We have the highest real interest rates in 50 years. Comparative bond rates in February 1986 were: Australia 13.7 per cent, Japan 5.2 per cent, United States 9.1 per cent and West Germany 6.2 per cent.

Another statistic which we should consider is that of inflation rates. Australia's inflation rate is increasing while those of our major trading partners are decreasing. The latest Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development estimates show that Australia's inflation rate is 9.2 per cent. Among the seven major industrial economies, the United States has an inflation rate of 1.6 per cent. In the 12 months to April, Japan had an inflation rate of 0.9 per cent, France 2.6 per cent, Britain 3 per cent and West Germany 0.2 per cent. These and any other statistics that we may care to use show what the Government and its political controllers, the Australian Council of Trade Unions, have done to our once great country in just three years. Once again we saw the people of Australia conned by charismatic little figures and once again we will see the people of Australia throw them out.

Australia's position is very grave indeed. Everyone knows that the cause of the problem is the experimenting in this country yet again with socialist ideology and more importantly, the disaster of a totally inflexible wages policy embodied in the accord. The accord may have reduced the level of industrial disputation. But at what price! The political control exercised by the unelected ACTU has brought Australia to its knees in just over three years. These are the facts that the Prime Minister did not bring to the attention of the Australian people in his address to the nation. He did not tell the people that as President of the ACTU in a short period of prosperity he presided over and instigated industrial disputations to force wages and conditions which have inevitably brought this country into an economic mess. Why did he not have the intestinal fortitude to state plainly what people know? Why did he not say that under the accord consumer price index-adjusted wages guarantee that our inflation rate will continue to outstrip those of the rest of the world? Why did he not say that the number of holidays we give ourselves is totally out of kilter with the rest of the world? Why did he not say that our sick leave, holiday loadings, penalty rates and long service leave conditions are major contributors to our lack of competitiveness in both export and import replacement businesses? Why did he not say honestly and bluntly that these were the factors which have created our unacceptable unemployment rate?

The Prime Minister's address to the nation was nothing more than patronising rhetoric which will gain the applause only of his Manchu court. With all the hype surrounding the address to the nation, Australia expected and deserved something better. Australia expected leadership. We heard an address which, if given by any other leader in any other country in the world, we would have ridiculed. It is embarrassing to Australia and Australians. The Prime Minister has made himself-and therefore unfortunately us-the laughing stock of the whole world. What are the Prime Minister's solutions? First, he asks all Australians to work harder. What a joke! This Government, with its negative gearing, capital gains tax and fringe benefits tax on the productive sector of the economy, has taken away every single incentive for initiative and investment. The excuse has been to extract more tax from a few tall poppies who have evaded tax. The effect has been to destroy all incentive. Yet the Prime Minister says: `Work harder'. The phoney accord mark 2 productivity superannuation deal will be phased in over two years. This was always the stated aim of the Government. Our country is in the mess it is in today because of the political control exercised over it by the ACTU.
Debate interrupted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being after 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not satisfied with the control exercised by the ACTU, the Government, through union controlled superannuation, is hell bent in handing over financial control so that the militant unions associated with the ACTU can take control of key industries. The Prime Minister has also suggested that the activities of the Prices Surveillance Authority should be increased. This is a totally expected motherhood approach. The shelves of our supermarkets are full of competitive goods and comparative goods that are over priced and will not be bought. We do not need more public servants to prove that in a competitive situation the law of supply and demand does work.

SPEECH.PARA: The unemployed will be paid the dole for work they might carry out on community projects. However, this work will be voluntary. The Prime Minister will, no doubt, be surprised at the lack of response that this so called incentive will engender. In a folksy sort of way, he refers to our stars in various fields. No one would disagree with the excellence of these people. We have always had outstanding people but never in our history has this country been dragged into such a crisis by a government. We thought the Whitlam Government was bad. It pales into insignificance compared with the damage done by the Hawke Government. The rigidity of the centralised wage fixing system was not addressed. The Prime Minister and the Government did not have the courage to subject the labour market to the discipline of deregulation. The only solution to our problems is the expansion of existing, and the developing of new, growth sectors. This simply cannot happen while the rigid wage fixing system stays in place. Hanging on to conditions which were bludgeoned on employers in affluent times is akin to promoting the horse and buggy when the motor car was introduced. While this Government is in power, because it is the political arm of the ACTU, the real problems will not and cannot be addressed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I take a point of order on two matters. One is the official point of order, and that is the matter about reading speeches in the Senate. The second is an unofficial point of order about agreements in respect of the length of speeches. I think, really, when an honourable senator speaks for 120 per cent beyond what was agreed, and he reads his speech as well, it is very difficult for those of us on this side of the Senate to tolerate what is happening.

—Order! I assume Senator Parer is reading from copious notes. In regard to the second point of order, the Chair cannot be cognisant of the agreements that might have been entered into between various parties. Therefore, there is no point of order. However, I draw Senator Parer's attention to the remarks made by the Minister.

—Thank you, Mr President. The notes that I have in front of me-they are all over the place-are indeed copious. The Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, is at last perceived to be a man of straw. All Australians were looking for a clear commitment on wages and fiscal policy. As all commentators have said, the speech failed on both counts and is nothing more than very poor window dressing. Senator Cooney requested that we give some indication as to what the solution would be. I am happy to give that gratuitous advice. Solutions to the problems would be, firstly, to abandon the phoney 3 per cent productivity increase and, secondly, to introduce a 12-month wage freeze. This Government, in its first 12 months, cruised along on the effects of the Fraser Government's wage freeze.

—Mr President, I take a point of order. I am sorry that it is very difficult to get the message through to Senator Parer, but I point out that honourable senators on this side of the chamber kept to the agreement, and Senator Parer has ignored even the relatively subtle remarks you made. If he could actually exclude a few paragraphs, cut out a few commas and do what we are supposed to do in this place and actually make speeches without reading notes, perhaps this debate could be finished at a reasonable hour.
—I draw Senator Parer's attention to standing order 406 and ask that he make sure that his notes are not as copious as they might appear to be.

—Thank you, Mr President. I was concluding. I think the time I have taken is a lot shorter than that taken by most other speakers. People are looking for solutions, because the Prime Minister certainly did not give any in his address to the nation. I had got to the stage of talking about introducing a 12-month wage freeze. This Government cruised along on the Fraser Government's wage freeze for its first 12 months. We should simplify the tax system and remove the fringe benefits and capital gains taxes so that we can give more initiative and incentive to the people who create the wealth. We should ban penalty rates for any work of less than 38 hours. The Prime Minister, in his address, has probably signalled the end of his Government. Politically, the effect of his address has been akin to a duck declaring open season on ducks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is considering Supply Bill (No. 1) 1986-87 and Supply Bill (No. 2) 1986-87, which give the Government money for the next five months. Because of the peculiar way in which a government runs its affairs, its Budget-the public servants' Budget, I suppose-is not introduced until August and is not normally passed until the end of October. Therefore, we give the government a five-month advance. This brings up the whole direction of a government's spending policy and its economic policy. The address last night by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is central to that. The Prime Minister's speech last night was a double disaster-an immediate one for the country and one for him too. He was trying to sound like Winston Churchill, who said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . We shall fight on the beaches, we shall fight on the landing grounds . . . we shall never surrender.

Unfortunately, he came over like Neville Chamberlain, coming back from Munich, having done a sordid deal, waving a piece of paper called `Peace for our time'. The Prime Minister is still waving an equally disastrous piece of paper called the prices and incomes accord, and he is also claiming that it will bring us peace for our time and economic prosperity. It was said by Tacitus that the barbarians created a wilderness and called it peace. This Government has created an industrial desert and called it an accord. In economic terms we are heading into the desert, under this disastrous Prime Minister.

Prime Minister Hawke is absolutely incapable of leadership. If he had been in Winston Churchill's position, his rallying cry would have been: `I will set up a committee, aah, to investigate the problem in respect of whether we shall fight on the beaches or the landing grounds, and I will study its report when it comes in six months time. With respect to, aah, surrender, that will be an option, but it will be voluntary, and only if clear community attitudes prevail will we make it compulsory'. This man is incapable of giving the leadership that we desperately need. The problem is that he does not recognise the problem, which would be the first step in solving it. He does not seem to realise that the reason we recovered from the 1982 recession was nothing to do with him; it was because of the wage freeze which the Fraser Government had the guts to impose, the breaking of the worst drought in our history and the upsurge in the world economy. It had nothing to do with the Prime Minister at all; it was mere coincidence.

What does Mr Hawke say now? We have a real problem, with our wages costs pricing us out of markets. What he says is: `There will be no freeze now. You will have your 2.3 per cent increase'. For a country trading with the rest of the world at a cost of $1,000m a month to grant itself a wage freeze sounds absolute lunacy. He says: `You may have your 2.3 per cent increase now but you will not get another one for six months'-the people did not expect another one for six months anyway-`and you will also have your so-called productivity increase'. Any rational country faced with our problems would surely have used the productivity increase to make itself more competitive on world markets. Do we make ourselves more competitive? Oh, no, we whack it up among the employees. The three disastrous years of the Hawke Government have been years in which the swarming locusts have eaten.

Mr Hawke talks glibly about 700,000 new jobs having been created. Where have they been created? They have certainly not been created in new export industries. The downward trend in the value of our traditional exports has been apparent for several years. It is not a new thing-the Opposition has been warning about it for several years-but, instead of encouraging new export industries and import replacing industries, for three years this Government has been promoting a milk bar economy and wasting $40 billion in overseas loans and credits in doing so. Imagine what a country such as Singapore or South Korea would have done with the $40,000m this country has encouraged to be frittered away. Three years of Hawke Labor Government have trebled the overseas debt, built up in the previous 80 years, without doing anything to improve our export earnings.

What we need in our current economic crisis is leadership to tackle our problems. We need another wage freeze, such as the one the Fraser Government introduced. Singapore, whose economic situation is much less serious than ours, has a two-year wage freeze. This Government is incapable of even contemplating that. We also need to tackle all the industrial rorts that make the on-costs business has to pay over and above wages the highest in the world. We have a 17 1/2 per cent holiday pay loading. That is all right if a country is rich, but this country is not rich any more. An on-cost of 17 1/2 per cent is absurd. Workers compensation has increased by 20 per cent this year in New South Wales. In addition there are penalty rates. Sick leave is another rort. So the list goes on. We need to go back to a 40-hour week. Most of the people in the countries with which we compete on world markets work longer than 40 hours a week. We must become competitive. We must get our inflation rate down. At the moment it is more than double the rate of our major trading partners, and the situation is getting worse. We need to improve the efficiency of our ports to reduce the costs of our vital exports. It is absurd that, using identical equipment, someone in Rotterdam can unload in a single day twice as many containers as someone working in an Australian port. It is a total rort and it is damaging--

TALK.START.PARA: —What about coastal shipping?

—I would hate to get on to the subject of coastal shipping. I am talking about exports now. The whole structure is very damaging, and none of this has been tackled by this do-nothing Government. Perhaps most important of all, we must lower our interest rates to encourage productive investment. The world does not owe us a good living. If we do not work for it, we will not have one.

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) have been talking absolute nonsense about the internal economy going well. They say that it is only the external economy that is going badly. That is like a family whose breadwinner has lost his job and then gets another job which pays substantially less, yet the family goes on living as before, relying on borrowed money to do it and saying cheerfully: `Our internal economy is going well'. Perhaps it does go well until the bills start coming in. The bills for this Government are coming in now.

Historically, the term of a Labor Government, before it reduces the country to economic chaos, is about three years. We have had Scullin, Whitlam and now Hawke. What we need is a leader who can inspire us to earn our place in the world, who is not simply a lowest common denominator manipulator. The time has now passed when we can afford any longer the disorderly rabble which is the Government-I was going to say led by Mr Hawke, but he is incapable of leadership. He has all the leadership potential of an attractively decorated but soggy blancmange. It is time that we were rid of the whole lot of them, because that is the prerequisite for economic recovery and the place in the world which our potential offers us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —What Australians saw and heard last night from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) I believe was nothing short of a disgrace and a gross understatement of the crisis that Australia is now facing. The Prime Minister simply called this crisis a challenge. Some three years later the Prime Minister is still trying to blame the previous Government for his own misdemeanours and the state of the nation today. Last night he even said repeatedly that he had inherited the inflation rate. All I can say to that is: What rot. The simple fact of the matter is that Australia's inflation rate has been rising for more than a year and it has risen in each of the past five quarters. Since the last election it has risen from 5.1 per cent to the current 9.2 per cent. Who is responsible for that-the previous Government or this Hawke socialist Government? It is absolutely this Government's responsibility and no one else's.

SPEECH.PARA: Why is it that Australia's inflation rate is increasing while that of our major trading partners is decreasing? The latest Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development inflation estimates quite clearly show the dramatic differences, and I would just like to run through those differences. As I have already stated, Australia has a massive figure of 9.2 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —We can't live with inflation like that.

—Exactly; this country cannot afford such inflation, especially when we look at countries such as Japan with an inflation rate of 1.1 per cent, the United States of America with 2.3 per cent, West Germany with 0.1 per cent, France with 3 per cent, Italy with 7.7 per cent, the United Kingdom with 4.2 per cent, Canada with 4.1 per cent, the OECD average of 3.1 per cent and our major trading partners with an average of 2.9 per cent. I repeat: Australia's figure happens to be 9.2 per cent.
—And rising.

—And rising rapidly. It is almost triple that of the OECD average, more than triple that of our major trading partners, four times that of the United States of America and more than eight times that of our major trading partner, Japan-what a disgrace. Yet we get this Prime Minister boldly coming on television last night and saying that we are facing a little bit of a challenge. The fact of the matter is that Australia's relative inflation rate is three times the OECD average, and that simply is not good enough. That is the highest rate, the worst rate that we have seen in 25 years. It is disgraceful. This disastrous achievement has been attained in only three short years. Does it not make one really wonder exactly what will happen if this Government runs its full term and it is in office for another 18 months? The Prime Minister simply said that we must all buy more Australian products. I do not think too many Australians would disagree with the fact, but I wish it were as simple as that. Australia is just not competitive and it can never be competitive while our inflation rate is soaring at the rate that it is, while there is pressure on the Australian dollar such as we have, and also while our interest rates are where they are. Is it any wonder that Australia is not competitive?

SPEECH.PARA: When one marries our inflation rate-quite frankly, I think the Government is trying to achieve an inflation rate which is like a football score-with the growth in average weekly earnings, the combination simply puts us further out of the competitive ball park. Like inflation, average weekly earnings have risen strongly over the past year-3.2 per cent over the year to May 1985 and 7.3 per cent over the year to February 1986. The most recent data available on earnings growth show the figure for Australia as 7.3 per cent; Japan, 4 per cent; the United States of America, 2.7 per cent; West Germany, 4.1 per cent; Canada, 4.4 per cent; and France, 6 per cent. I repeat: Australia's figure is 7.3 per cent. Like inflation, labour costs in Australia are increasing faster than those of our major trading partners. We are seeing at the moment the thin edge of the wedge. It is only child's play by comparison with what is further down this economic track of disaster. Under the accord labour costs are set to rise by at least 13 per cent in the next year. So much for the Prime Minister's sincerity in saying that he and his Government want restraint. They champion this wonderful accord.

All the other anti-business and anti-investment taxation Bills that this Government has rammed through the House of Representatives and the Senate in this session can only deter employment and investment by business, thereby reducing the chances of lowering unemployment. The Prime Minister, I suppose, last night was at least partly honest when he said that the Federal Public Service had continued, inexorably, to grow in numbers under his Government. What has he done to stop that growth? Absolutely nothing. He mouthed those lovely words, similar to those that he uttered even before he became Prime Minister, that he would streamline and rationalise some existing functions and agencies. What does that mean?

TALK.START.PARA: —Rhetoric; just rhetoric.

—Exactly. It is rhetoric, rhetoric, rhetoric. What will he do and how will he do it? Heaven knows. Anybody's guess is as good as mine. On his own admission he has done exactly the opposite; he has increased the size of the Public Service. The Prime Minister's statement that he wants Australians to show a readiness to work with great application and dedication would be wonderful, I suppose, if it were not quite so crude. He and the world's greatest Treasurer have managed very successfully to remove any motivation, any incentive that business could possibly have, that employers could possibly have, through the taxation system alone. That is a real pity for this country.

SPEECH.PARA: This disaster that the Prime Minister calls simply `a challenge' must not be overlooked or downgraded in any way. Australia is in real and unadulterated strife, no matter how much the Prime Minister wants to play it down. Despite his rhetoric, this socialist Government is by any measure a big spending and enormous taxing Government. Tax revenue in real terms has increased at an annual rate of 5.4 per cent in the three years of Hawke socialism, compared with 3.3 per cent during the seven years of the Fraser Government. Tax receipts as a percentage of gross domestic product are budgeted to increase by 25 per cent in 1985-86-the highest increase in post-war history. Government expenditure in real terms increased by 4.8 per cent per year under Hawke, compared with only 2.1 per cent per year under Fraser. Government expenditure as a percentage of GDP is budgeted to increase to 29.4 per cent in 1985-86-also the highest figure in post-war history.

If the Government were serious and determined to reduce government expenditure, why would it not bring down a mini-Budget in June, which would then allow any reductions or decreases to take place as at 1 July, in preference to 1 November, as will be the case when the Budget is brought down in August? Some drastic steps must be taken, and taken immediately, to stop the slide. I will go through a little shopping list of what that slide includes. Economic growth has slowed. Private business investment has ground down. Investment in housing has declined. Dwelling commencements or new starts have declined. New motor vehicle registrations have declined. The Australian dollar has not just declined; quite frankly, it has dropped right out of sight. The terms of trade have declined. Interest rates have soared. Levels of taxation have soared. Unemployment has risen in four of the past five months. The current unemployment rate is higher than for all but five of the 86 full months of the Fraser Government. Youth unemployment, that is the 15- to 19-year-olds, has risen steadily to 23 per cent, which is higher than it was when the infamous Priority One: Young Australia campaign started last year. The average duration of unemployment has risen. Inflation has risen. Trade balance of payments are in total disarray. Last month's seasonally adjusted merchandise trade deficit was the worst ever recorded.

Australia's foreign debt has risen dramatically. Commonwealth public sector employment has risen by 5.9 per cent over 2 1/2 years. Imports have risen while exports have declined. There has been negative real growth in retail sales. Both receipts and outlays will run well above Budget estimates, in the order of $1 billion plus. How's that for a shopping list? This is a summary of the real story. This is the story that the Prime Minister should have told Australia last night. Instead, he said that we were simply facing a minor hiccup-not even indigestion-called a challenge. It was pathetic and nothing short of a disgrace. I hope that Australians realise that we need firm and positive action taken by the Government to ensure that Australia does not go further downhill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In closing the debate on the Supply Bill (No. 1) 1986-87 and the Supply Bill (No. 2) 1986-87 I must say that I gather that Senator Knowles was not very impressed by the speech last night by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). I do not understand that. Traditionally the Supply Bills involve a series of debates in which honourable senators can say what they like about anything they like. Therefore, it is absolutely impossible for a Minister to stand up and reply to everything that has been said. All I can say is that this debate has been a very good demonstration of the old statement-I cannot remember who said it because I have not had time to duck out to the library to look it up-that statistics in this place are frequently used like a drunk uses a lamp post, more for support than illumination. We have had plenty of that in the last several hours of the debate tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: All I can say is that when I became a Minister three years ago this country had record inflation. We had had 250,000 people added to the unemployment list within two years. In the three years I have been in government we have had 650,000 people added to the employment list. Inflation is much better than it was in those days. I am not concerned about what the community thinks about this because the polls consistently have shown that we have maintained our position in the electorate. That may upset honourable senators opposite and may cause them considerable concern; but, so be it. They can stand up and speak on the Supply Bills. They can wax long and hard--

TALK.START.PARA: —And lyrical.

—They can wax lyrical on the things that interest them. However, it is of no interest to the electorate. The electorate is interested only in what happens to the people who are working and the people who are being paid. That being so, I will say no more. Senator Archer has been holding up signs with `three minutes' and `five minutes', and all this sort of thing, written on them. However, we have heard honourable senators speaking for 20 minutes longer than they were supposed to speak tonight. I am a very kind person and a pacifist and I do not want to provoke anyone. Therefore, I will say that I thank honourable senators for their contribution to the debate. I will thank honourable senators for the fact that they are not opposing the legislation. I commend the Bills to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without requests or debate.

That the Bill be now read a second time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
