DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Creation Science Foundation Ltd-Advertisements: West Australian-Tasmanian Economy

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Grimes) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 11 March I asked the Minister representing the Minister for Trade (Senator Button) a question concerning the Creation Science Foundation Ltd. I asked the Minister whether this tax-exempt organisation had written off over $92,000 because of the failure of the company's investment agents and whether this organisation was in receipt of an export market development grant from the Government. I also asked whether the Treasurer (Mr Keating) would be reviewing the tax-exempt status of this body.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins) has provided me with an answer which essentially skirted around the issue by stating inter alia that the Government could not alter the criteria of the Export Market Development Grants Act and that if the firms of organisations fulfilled the criteria then a grant could not be denied on `moral grounds'. The Minister said that this did not necessarily mean that the Government endorsed the views of any or all claimants under the scheme.

As a result of my temerity in raising this question, the Creation Science Foundation wrote to various honourable members and honourable senators, accusing me of being a `stooge' for the Australian Sceptics-a body for which I do have the highest regard-making threats to write to all of their alleged 12,000 readers to expose me as having misrepresented the truth.

In order to put the record straight I wish to make certain further remarks this evening. The Creation Science Foundation Ltd was incorporated in 1980 in Queensland. According to the articles of association of the Foundation the members believe that:

The Bible is the written Word of God. It is inspired and inerrant throughout and the supreme authority in all matters of faith and conduct. Its assertions are historically and scientifically true in all the original autographs.
They also believe that:

The account of origins presented in Genesis is a simple but factual presentation of actual events and therefore provides a reliable framework for scientific research into the question of the origin and history of life.

This statement is perhaps the raison d'etre for the Foundation's existence as an organisation, and I have no criticisms to make of its beliefs. Essentially the Foundation asserts that the theory of evolution is invalid although it clearly does not understand the theory, and in particular the work of Maya, Eldredge, Gould and others on the theory of punctuated evolution, which explains the difficulties of so-called gaps in the fossil records of evolution. It holds that the truth surrounding the question of the beginning of life lies in the Old Testament. This truth, it believes, is scientifically demonstrated and most of its efforts are spent attempting to `prove' that the universe was created by God some 6,000 years ago, presumably using the calculations of Bishop Usher and others.

The Queensland Government has accepted that creationist theory should be taught alongside evolutionary theory in the science syllabus in that State's secondary schools. There has been considerable debate about the wisdom of teaching such material when one must concede that creationism is not a scientific theory at all, but rather a theory which relies on one's faith in the truth of the Bible which, I suppose, would make it quite acceptable for the syllabus for religious studies. I am not concerned here tonight with the rights or wrongs of the creationist argument, but rather with the extraordinary activities of the Creation Science organisation, which has received taxpayers' money in the form of a $24,693 export grant and the tax exempt status under section 23e of the Income Tax Act Assessment Act which it enjoys.

There are seven directors of the Creation Science Foundation. In fact, there are only seven members in the entire company. I assume its claims to being a broadly based organisation are founded on facts hitherto unknown to the general public. The directors of the Foundation as of April 1985 were Mr David Denner, a teacher; Mr Robert Gustafson, a solicitor; Mr Kenneth Ham, a missionary and full time employee of the company; Mr John Mackay, a teacher and full time employee; Dr Alfred Osgood, a medical practitioner; Professor Tyndale Rendle-Short, a medical practitioner and chairman of the company; and Mr John Thallon, accountant and company secretary and treasurer.

In the annual accounts of the Creation Science Foundation for the year ended 31 March 1984 the Foundation wrote off some $47,939 occasioned by the failure, in August of that year, of Goldcom International Pty Ltd. Goldcom failed with a deficit of over $1m. Goldcom had invested a considerable amount of money in the now failed International Commodity Traders Associated of Australia, which closed its doors in July 1984. It is interesting to note that the Creation Science Foundation wrote off half of its investment in Goldcom International in its accounts before 31 March 1984, whereas Goldcom did not fail until August 1984. The date of the presentation of the annual accounts by the directors was 10 October 1984. Could it be that the directors decided post-31 March to write off the amount partly in that financial year and partly in the next financial year to reduce the impact in any one year? It seems that this is the case. Had the directors decided to write off the entire amount in the 1985 financial year the loss would have represented a very substantial proportion of the Foundation's net worth and, if it had not been for the export development grant of $24,693 in that year, may have represented all the equity in the company.

The firm of accountants which prepared the Foundation's accounts for 1985 was C. L. Lunt and Associates of Perth, the principal of which, Colin Lunt, and his wife, are also the Western Australian representatives of the Creation Science Foundation. In 1984 the Creation Science Foundation reported an income of $293,457 and so the loss of $47,939 represented some 16 per cent of total revenue in that year. Donations made up $152,398 of the total income. The net surplus for that year after the write down was $160. In the next year's annual report-1985-the Foundation wrote off the sum of $44,424 due to the failure of its investment agents, Goldcom International. The total amount written off over the two years was $92,363. The surplus for 1985 was $1,359.
The Creation Science Foundation is very sensitive to criticism of its handling of its investment funds. In the February 1986 edition of Prayer News, its fortnightly newsletter, it claims:
The media has taken this thing out of context and distorted it in an attempt to discredit us.
It then claims falsely:
The money only included magazine subscriptions and did not include donations as reported by the media.

If it were only magazine subscription money, which it was not, it would be bad enough as the accounts show that the surplus on the magazine after production costs was only $8,897 in 1984. According to its own annual accounts, the total income from magazine subscriptions in the year ended 31 March 1984 was $47,000. The amount written off in that year's accounts was $47,939. When one adds the $44,424 written off in the next year one can safely assume not only that magazine subscription money went down the gurgler with Goldcom International but also that at least some of the donations found their way into that shonky investment company.

Some of the supporters of the Creation Science Foundation may be very interested to know what the seven directors of the organisation have been doing with the donations made by generous members of the public. A leading Australian evangelical journalist, Reverend John A. Coleman, who edits the magazine New Life, commented on the $92,000 loss by saying that such losses `will doubtless happen again'. It would appear that the directors of the Foundation have little expertise with investment of their company's funds and, whilst not legally responsible to their supporters, should morally be providing a full explanation as to why the money was so invested and why no steps were taken to check the credentials of Goldcom International before investing such large sums of money.

I was interested to note in the director's report attached to the 1984 accounts that the Foundation had engaged Tralil Pty Ltd as a management consultant for the year 1 September 1984 to 30 June 1985. One of the directors of the Foundation, Mr John Andrew Thallon, declared at an executive committee meeting on 27 September 1984 that he was a director of Tralil Pty Ltd. The reason I mention this is because Tralil Pty Ltd also invested money with Goldcom International. In fact, Tralil lost $83,689.90 according to the list of unsecured creditors of Goldcom International attached as an annexure to the report of the affairs of the company dated 24 August 1984. It would appear on the face of it that the management and investment advice that the Foundation is receiving is hardly of a high professional standard.

I would like now to turn to the question of the $23,696 export market development grant which was made to the Foundation in 1985. According to the President of the Creation Science Association Incorporated of South Australia, Dr C. Wieland:
Two of their people-
that is Creation Science Foundation people-
went to the United States to promote the sales of that book.

The book is B. Setterfield's The Velocity of Light and the Age of the Universe. It would seem that the Government is handing out money willy nilly so that authors of pseudo-scientific tracts can go on junkets to the United States in order to sell their published works. It is bad enough that this organisation is able to receive taxpayer funds, but it has also acquired tax-exempt status under section 23 (e) of the Income Tax Assessment Act. I find it quite incredible that the Government can justify giving grants to organisations that have a penchant for investments in fly-by-night commodity trading enterprises and who send their members off to the United States to sell their books. Is it common practice for the Export Market Development Board to make grants to authors for the sole purpose of promoting their books overseas?

I believe that the Treasurer ought to ask the Australian Taxation Office to investigate the tax exemption status of this company and I believe that the Minister for Trade ought to investigate the terms upon which export market development grants are made. There must, I believe, be no repetition of this scandalous waste of public money, especially at this time of restraint and when maximum effort must be put into encouraging our genuinely productive export industries. No doubt this Foundation will attempt to make further threats against me for exposing them for what they are. I have neither worry nor fear of this because the truth about the Creation Science Foundation speaks eloquently enough for itself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to spend only a few brief moments tonight talking about three matters-the fringe benefits tax, advertising and inflation. The advertising I am talking about is a series of full page advertisements that appeared in the West Australian over the last two weeks. The fringe benefits tax was the subject of those advertisements, and the inflation is related to the figures in the polls, the results of which were in the advertisements. The first full page advertisement was headed `Mr Hawke There's Nothing Left to Take!!' and appeared on Tuesday, 27 May 1986 and was repeated on Thursday, 29 May. It called for, among other things, the readership of the West Australian newspaper to telephone the Western Australian Labor senators at their offices complaining about the tax and asking for it to be stopped. My office in Perth received 15 calls resulting from those two full page advertisements over two days. Two of those 15 calls were actually in favour of the Government's action on the fringe benefits tax.

SPEECH.PARA: On Thursday, 29 May, the day on which the second Liberal Party advertisement appeared, another full page advertisement, headed `Say ``no'' to Paul Keating's Fringe Benefits Tax', was inserted by the Western Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry and the Small Business Association of Western Australia. Again, they were calling on people to make telephone calls, except that on this occasion the calls were to be made to the Chamber of Commerce and Industry in Perth. The next day, Friday, 30 May, it was reported in an article on page 11 of the West Australian that a spokesman for the Chamber of Commerce and Industry had indicated that the Chamber had received 600 phone calls in response to that advertisement. I remind the Senate that, in response to two full page advertisements, 15 phone calls were received, two in opposition to what had been requested. Yet we are supposed to believe that 600 responses were received from one full page advertisement.

Today, 12 June, another full page advertisement appeared. This one, headed `Labor's formula for Australia's disaster', again inserted by the Western Australian Liberal party, calls on people to telephone the Western Australian Labor Senators, at the phone numbers provided to register opposition to the fringe benefits tax. Late this afternoon I had my office in Perth check with the other Western Australian senators to see what the response to the advertisement was. Those statistics make very interesting reading. Senator McIntosh's office received six calls, four supporting the Liberal advertisement and two supporting the Government line. Senator Cook's office received four calls in support of the Liberal advertisement and one in opposition to it. Senator Coleman's office received five calls in favour of the advertisement and one against it. Senator Giles's office received five calls supporting the advertisement and my own office received three in support of the advertisement and one supporting the Government line. I have not added up the calls to get a total, and I am not going to because we are running out of time.

It would appear to me that two things need to be questioned here. Either the report given by the spokesperson for the Chamber of Commerce and Industry in Western Australia which indicated that the Chamber received 600 phone calls in response to its one advertisement was a gross inflation of the facts or the electorate in Perth, which was so sensible in February of this year, was completely turned off the photograph of the Liberal leader which appeared in all three advertisements.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Already this evening Senator Grimes has referred to the uses people make of statistics. I would like to take that matter a little further. For the last two days in the Senate at Question Time the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) has made allegations about so-called Tasmanian feather bedding and claimed that Tasmania has been treated too generously in the past. Senator Walsh either revealed his ignorance of the practices of the Commonwealth Grants Commission or, alternatively, deliberately misled the Senate when he claimed that the Grants Commission had recommended that Tasmania should have its payments reduced by $60m in one hit. The true situation is that the Commonwealth Grants Commission does not recommend the amount of money that should be received by any State. It merely recommends the proportion of the funds made available by the Government that should be distributed to each State. In Tasmania's case, in 1984-85 the proportion recommended was 38.5 per cent per capita more than the six-State average. In 1985-86, as I stated in my question yesterday, it was 37.6 per cent. It was up to the Government to decide on the distribution of funds in the pool. It was the Government, therefore, which decided that Tasmania's funding should be cut by $60m. The Government cannot hide behind the skirts of the Commonwealth Grants Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Walsh gleefully claimed that Tasmania received nearly 50 per cent more than did the other States. He surely cannot be as ignorant as his answer would suggest. That 50 per cent included the amount which the Government gave back to Tasmania to allow an adjustment period for our small and vulnerable economy. It also included sums for special revenue assistance to enable Tasmanian hospitals to adjust to a new hospital agreement. As Senator Walsh must be aware-if he is not aware he should resign as Minister for Finance-other States, for example South Australia, also received more than the formula when their special revenue assistance grants were added to the financial assistance grants formula.

We in the Senate are only too well aware of the selective use of figures to which this Minister for Finance is prone. Apparently, however, it still comes as a shock to some of his Australian Labor Party colleagues. ALP National Executive member Alan Evans is quoted in both today's Mercury and Examiner as saying that Senator Walsh had used only those figures which suited his argument. Mr Evans said that Senator Walsh should get his facts straight before condemning public sector spending in Tasmania. The Senate will recall that on Wednesday, in response to a dorothy dixer from Senator Sibraa, the Minister for Finance claimed that 28.3 per cent of the Tasmanian work force--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I take a point of order. I would not raise this point of order in any other circumstances, but we are now on the adjournment debate and we have a rule in the Senate that honourable senators should not read their speeches. Senator Newman is quite clearly reading her speech. I do not care what happens under normal circumstances, I do not argue about it, but this is the adjournment debate. Surely Senator Newman, who is a lawyer and an articulate person, can make a speech without standing up and drearily reading her speech in the way she is doing tonight.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw Senator Newman's attention to standing order 406, which clearly states:

INTERJECT.PARA: I ask Senator Newman to stick to her copious notes and heed the point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course, as a new senator, I am not so up to date with the Standing Orders as the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes), but I trust that he will not mind if I take longer by not speaking from my notes at all.
—I do not care how long you take. It does not worry me at all.
—Good. I did get the impression that the Minister did not like the body of my speech.
—I have no worries about that.
—Order! The honourable senator will address the chair.
—I am sorry, Mr President.
—I just want you to lift your eyes occasionally, that is all.

—The Minister obviously wants to look into my eyes. I would like to make a date with him afterwards if that is what he is on to. At the moment I am much more concerned about a serious matter concerning the affairs of Tasmania. If Senator Grimes would like to shout me down again, he might remember from last time that I can do a much better job of shouting him down than he can of shouting me down. So I think he is wasting his effort. The people of Tasmania are only too well aware of how little effort he has been making for Tasmania in this matter. I draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that it has been an ALP National Executive member Mr Alan Evans who has been getting stuck into the Minister for Finance. In response to a question from Senator Sibraa the other day, the Minister for Finance claimed that 28.3 per cent of the Tasmanian work force was employed by the State Government, compared with 20 per cent in New South Wales. Senator Walsh is inclined to use figures carelessly, as we are all well aware. I draw the Senate's attention to the fact that that 28.3 per cent included not just the State public servants but the Commonwealth public servants and local government employees in Tasmania. So much for the Minister for Finance.
—He is misleading the Senate.
—Misleading the Senate, indeed. He should resign. Mr Evans considers that his comments were almost unforgivable. Mr Evans said:

SPEECH.PARA: He's quite simply misquoted the facts. I think it could be a softening up process before the Premiers' Conference.
Mr Evans drew attention to the fact that Tasmania is an exporting State and that it subsidises New South Wales manufacturing industries by approximately $6,000 per person.

TALK.START.PARA: —And Victoria.

—And Victoria, of course. I thank Senator Watson. He consciously did not mention that, said Mr Evans, and I remind the Senate that Mr Evans is a member of the Australian Labor Party National Executive.
—What did Mr Batt say?

—Yes; what did Mr Batt say? Those critics in Tasmania cannot be stopped. They are friends of Senator Walsh. The former national ALP leader, Mr Batt, now the leader of the State Opposition, in case Senator Grimes was not aware of the fact-he has not been home for a while so he may not realise what is happening in Tasmania-went into bat for the State, even if Senator Grimes cannot. One might say he is trying to become a member of the Premier's eleven. Today he was also reported in the Mercury and the Examiner as saying that Senator Walsh's comments are particularly unhelpful. In fact, Mr Batt sent a telex to the Minister for Finance telling him to act in a more responsible manner.
—He did not table that today.

—No, he did not. He was told to act in a more responsible manner in the future and to have regard for the legitimate concerns of the smaller States. Mr Batt went on to describe Senator Walsh's comments on the level of funding to Tasmania as irresponsible and ill informed. I draw the attention of the Senate to these facts because it is not very often that Mr Batt and I see eye to eye. But in this matter we are in possession of the real facts and the Minister for Finance has no excuse as he should be in possession of the facts.
—He did not have the decency to turn up tonight, even though you asked him to.
—I thank Senator Walters for pointing out that Senator Walsh cannot even be bothered to listen to the problems facing Tasmania.
—This is like a song and dance act.

—I am glad Senator Aulich is listening. He might learn something too. I draw attention to the fact that the Premier, Mr Gray, commissioned a special report on the Tasmanian economy by Mr John Donovan from Coopers and Lybrand. Mr President, I was goaded into this, if you recall, by the Minister.
—I have not said anything.
—Senator Grimes is listening carefully then. I trust that he has also read the Donovan report on the Tasmanian economy.
—I did.

—I hope Senator Grimes sees the seriousness of the situation to which his government has subjected our State. The Premier of Tasmania has drawn this report to the attention of business leaders and trade union leaders in our State. He has also drawn it to the attention of the Federal Government. It is these matters which are being taken into account by the Commonwealth Grants Commission in assessing our needs. In order to help Senator Walsh understand better the workings of the Commonwealth Grants Commission, I refer to the 1981 report of the Commonwealth Grants Commission in which the role of the Commission is clearly set out so even Senator Walsh can understand it. I ask leave to incorporate this rather than take any further time of the Senate.
—Is leave granted?

—No, leave is not granted. The honourable senator did not do what most senators in this place do, and this is pay the common courtesy of asking us to have a look at it. I know that she is a new senator but she has had an opportunity to do that in the past and she has not done so.
—Leave is not granted.
—I claim to have been misrepresented.
—Order! The honourable senator sought leave to incorporate a document in Hansard.
—If she is asking to incorporate a paragraph, that is fair enough, but she asked to incorporate a document. If it is only a paragraph, I accept that.
—Mr President, I am happy to read it into the Hansard if the Minister would prefer that.
—Order! Senator Newman, what do you seek leave to incorporate into Hansard?
—I seek leave, as I previously asked the Minister courteously, to incorporate a marked passage on a page of the report of the Commonwealth Grants Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The paragraph read as follows-

8.44 The Commission wishes to add that the question whether its assessments are to be adopted, and if so the manner and timing of the implementation of assessments, appear to it to be essentially political matters for decision by the Commonwealth after consultation with the States. The same may be said of a number of associated questions which were adverted to during the course of the inquiry but were not seriously addressed because they were the Commission's terms of reference. These included proposals such as: increasing the total tax sharing entitlements of the States so as to ensure that no State would receive less in money terms than under the previous relativities; providing a guarantee similar to that given in 1976 that no State would receive less in ensuing years than in the year prior to the new factors being adopted; giving interim relief to States which would be disadvantaged by the new factors or allowing them some prescribed means to seek supplementary grants for special financial assistance; phasing in the operation of the new factors over a period of time in anticipation of further reviews; or providing for a continuing examination of the matters which influenced the new factors.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr President. I am not wishing to take the time of the Senate unnecessarily tonight but in view of the interruptions by the Minister and by some of his colleagues I do not intend to be pushed into making my speech shorter than I had originally intended as this is a matter of great concern to my State. Senator Walsh had misrepresented the purpose of the Tasmanian Premier, who has not been asking Canberra for more. He has been asking Canberra to honour agreements-to be phased in as adjustments and agreements as to a 2 per cent real increase in Commonwealth funds for each State. The States' budgeting plans have been made on the basis of these agreements.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Walsh used figures in the Senate in answer to Senator Sibraa which were misleading and irrelevant to the question of equity among the States. He said that Tasmania receives $2,034 per head and that this was $660 more per head than the six-State average. He neglected to mention that the Northern Territory receives $6,456 per head. Those figures conceal the important fact that Tasmania's needs have been assessed with those of all the other States and found to require an additional 37.6 per cent per capita of Commonwealth assistance compared with the average of all six States. We in Tasmania are tired of being the butt of savagery from this Government. Ten years ago--

TALK.START.PARA: —Brace yourself.
—Senator Crowley should listen very carefully.
—We are all ears.

—Good; I am glad to have the audience. Ten years ago Sir Bede Callaghan was commissioned by the Federal Government to inquire into special problems of Tasmania relating to its economy, industry and employment and to make recommendations.

—I raise a point of order, Mr President. My point of order is that the senator is reading her speech. She just turned over the page which was visible from this side of the chamber-I saw the honourable senator turn over the page as she read down it. It is clear from the way she is presenting her speech and the way in which she is reading it from the desk top that it is a read document and therefore is against Standing Orders. I suggest that the honourable senator speak to the subject but not read her speech.

—I rise on the point of order. Mr President, as well you know, it is late at night and we are getting a little thingy on both sides. I am one of those who in general principle agrees with Senator Grimes that the sooner we get back to speeches that are not completely read the better. However, in this instance we have an Opposition senator who is quoting people who have said things in her home State. She is quoting a lot of figures about her home State. It is obvious that she would have to have those quotes and figures written down on a piece of paper for her to do justice and so that she would not misquote what other people have said or misquote figures.

—I would like to speak on the point of order. I can understand Senator Cook's problem, but the good Senator Newman is incapable of making her speech unless she reads it in the way she has. She is making remarks about people in this chamber, and she has to be careful about it because she has received those remarks from information she has received in the past from her spouse. I think we do have to put up with this, if we are to have to put up with this person--
—On a point of order--
—Sit down. I am speaking to my point of order, you stupid twit.

—Order! Senator Grimes, I am in charge of the proceedings and I would ask you not to speak to honourable senators like that. Senator Grimes is taking a point of order and I would ask Senator Walters to resume her seat.

—Therefore, I say that it is very late at night, let the good senator do what she will. She will make her reputation on what she does in this place. Why should we argue about it? Why should we be concerned whether she reads it or not? Therefore, I ask you, senator, to ignore the matter.
—I wish to speak on the point of order--
—Sit down, you drunk.
—Order! I would ask the honourable senator to withdraw that remark.
—I withdraw.
—I seek leave to make a personal explanation on Senator Grimes's last comment.
—No.
—Leave is not granted.
—I claim to have been misrepresented.

—Order! I suggest that the honourable senator might seek leave to speak after Senator Newman has concluded her remarks. The honourable senator cannot claim to have been misrepresented when she has not spoken in the debate at this stage.
—Even on interjections?
—That is so.

—I wish to speak on the point of order. Obviously Senator Newman's comments have cut the Labor Party to the quick. Labor members seem to be taking a mean, retaliatory measure in view of the fact that Senator Newman is a new senator. I would stress the point that she has relied on copious notes, she has quoted extensively from the Grants Commission report, and she has quoted a number of statistics. In those circumstances it is necessary to quote accurately, otherwise these people would come back and claim that Senator Newman had misrepresented their position. I believe that she has represented their position quite accurately. There is no point of order. Senator Newman has had copious notes. I believe that she is doing a first class job and that she has severely embarrassed members of the Australian Labor Party.

—Senator Grimes has already taken the same point of order. I drew Senator Newman's attention to standing order 406 at that time and I asked her to ensure that she referred only to copious notes. I draw the honourable senator's attention to my earlier ruling.

—I am referring to my copious notes, but even they have to be turned. I draw attention also to the fact that the Callaghan inquiry was initiated 10 years ago by the Fraser Government. That inquiry introduced tremendous changes for Tasmania, based on an orderly review of its problems. During that review facts were obtained and there was co-operation between the State Labor and Federal Liberal governments-something which seems to be very difficult to arrive at these days when the positions are reversed. The program introduced under the Callaghan report was introduced under the supervision of senior officials of both the State and Federal governments and a Federal Minister was appointed to oversee the implementation of the Callaghan report. Eight years down the track those recommendations were gradually being finished.

SPEECH.PARA: We are now at a stage where the Tasmanian economy is once again very vulnerable, due to a Labor government for the second time, and we need an updating of the Callaghan inquiry. I call on the Federal Government to stop acting in this manner which is prejudicial to Tasmania, to get together with the State Government and introduce a review of the Callaghan inquiry so that decisions can be made for the Tasmanian economy which are based, not on prejudice and bias as we have seen from Ministers in this House, but on proper, impartial observations of the social as well as the financial situation in Tasmania. Tasmanians have already suffered a cut of $20m last year and we recognise the fact that Australians everywhere will have to make sacrifices in the nation's good. But we do not consider that Tasmanians should pay a double penalty to get this Government out of its strife. We have already pulled our belts in a notch; we do not want to pull them in too much more. Although we are a hard working and a proud people, we expect to get a fair go and we have not had it from this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —The arrogance of the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes), his disgusting behaviour, and his denigration of both Senator Newman and her husband are a disgrace to this Senate. His behaviour in the Senate has always been a disgrace. He commented that I was drunk. Mr President, you asked him to withdraw that remark. I take grave exception to that comment.
—Hic!

—Judging by the Minister's comment now, I can only take it for granted that he has been attending a last night party. I have not been consuming alcohol at all, and anyone who knows me back home or up here would vouch for that. There is no doubt that the Minister will sink to any depths at all in this place in attacking anyone on this side of the Senate. He has lost control of himself completely. He cannot take the stress that his Government has suddenly come under. It is he who cannot stand the heat in the kitchen, to use a great saying of his. The Minister should try to pull himself together because he is a disgrace to his Party as well as to the Senate. He is a disgrace to the--
—Mr President, I take a point of order.
—To the country.
—Order!
—He is a disgrace as a Minister of the Crown.
—Order!
—Let it ride.

—I know that the Minister says: `Let it ride'. However, I must say that I take exception to the many number of times that the honourable senator has called the Minister `disgraceful'. I think that is most unacceptable in this chamber.
—I am not concerned about it.
—I am, Mr President.
—Order! I ask the honourable senator to withdraw the remark that the Minister is a disgrace to the Senate.
—Mr President, I do not feel like withdrawing that comment that the Minister is a disgrace to the Senate because I believe he is a disgrace to the Senate.
—Order! I would ask the honourable senator to withdraw her remark that the Minister is a disgrace to the Senate.
—I am afraid I cannot do that, Mr President.
—Order! I name--
—Mr President--
—Order! Senator Grimes will resume his seat. I have asked Senator Walters to withdraw a remark. Senator Walters on two occasions has refused to withdraw. I name Senator Walters.
—Mr President, can I speak-

—Order! There shall be no debate on the matter. I have asked Senator Walters to withdraw a remark. She has declined to do so on two occasions. Therefore, I have no alternative but to name Senator Walters, which I have done. In accordance with standing order 440, I call upon Senator Walters to make any explanation or apology she may think fit.

—Mr President, I am afraid I cannot withdraw at all that I believe that the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) is a disgrace to the Senate. I honestly believe that his remarks tonight and his remarks on previous occasions in this place do make him a disgrace to this Senate. I believe that people who have listened on previous occasions-I am not referring to tonight-would support the fact that he is a disgrace. He is a Minister of the Crown and, as such, he is expected to gather unto himself respect from the people of Australia. He does not do that. He succeeds only in disgracing the Senate. Mr President, under those circumstances, I am afraid that I cannot withdraw from something I so firmly believe in.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek leave to make a brief statement on the matter raised by Senator Walters.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the 12 years I have been a member of this chamber I have never ever asked anyone to withdraw any statement made about me, and that includes statements made by Senator Walters. I believe that this place is the centre of democracy in this country in which people sometimes make statements in the heat of the moment that they may regret later. I have apologised for making statements in this place but I have never asked anyone to withdraw something that has been said about me-never ever.

SPEECH.PARA: I am sorry about the situation that has arisen tonight. Had I had the opportunity I would have asked that Senator Walters not be asked to withdraw her statement because, over the years in this place, in the heat of the moment, she and I have made statements about each other which I think have probably offended most honourable senators on both sides of the chamber. Therefore, tonight, when she made an outrageous statement, I tried to ensure that she would not be asked to withdraw. I have never asked anyone to withdraw what has been said about me. However, Senator Walters has now been named twice. She has refused to withdraw something she said. It is the first time in the many clashes between Senator Walters and me that either of us has refused to withdraw. If she will not withdraw, I suppose she wants to bear the consequences of that refusal, and she realises that she will get her headline in the Mercury tomorrow. I suppose that is what she is about.

I think this is a place of vigorous debate, where people make unfortunate remarks about each other. I have had remarks made about me which I have never asked to be withdrawn. Mr President, if Senator Walters refuses to withdraw the remarks that you asked her to withdraw she may bear the consequences, but she is only bearing the consequences so that she can get her headlines in the Mercury and in the Examiner. Good luck to her; fair enough.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I have heard what the Minister for Community Services has said, and I have already instituted a course of action in accordance with standing order 440. In view of what the Minister has said, I again invite Senator Walters to consider my request that she withdraw.

—Mr President, you make it very difficult for me because I have a tremendous respect for you. I have none for the Minister opposite-the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes). I do not believe that I have used language unbecoming to the Senate. I believe I have only said that the Minister is a disgrace to the Senate. It is something that has been said before on many occasions in the Senate. I have always withdrawn-

—Order! That matter is a matter for the Chair. I regard that which Senator Walters has said as being a personal reflection on a member of the Senate, and that is not in accordance with standing order 418. Senator Walters, again I ask you to withdraw.
—Mr President, I am sorry but I cannot.
—Order! I call on the Minister to move the appropriate motion in accordance with the standing order.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, Senator Walters has created an impossible situation. In terms of upholding the dignity of this place and the dignity and honour of the Chair, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That Senator Walters be suspended from the sitting of the Senate.
Question put.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I apologise to you for the embarrassment that I have caused you. At the time that I refused to withdraw, I had no idea that we would have the numbers. I had no idea that Government members would have gone home. I apologise to you for the embarrassment that I have caused you.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 11.54 p.m.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following papers were tabled:
Health Insurance Act-Statement of particulars of a Ministerial Determination authorised under section 106aa, dated 21 May 1986.
Public Service Act-Determinations 1986 Nos 37, 39, 41.
The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 5 December 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Attorney-General's Department been asked to provide information or advice to the authorities on Norfolk Island, the Department of Territories, the Australian Federal Police or Australian intelligence organisations in relation to the stay of the yacht Ouvea at Norfolk Island after its return from New Zealand; if so, when did this occur, who sought the advice or information, and what was the subject matter of the request or requests.
(2) What was the advice or information provided, and on what factual material was it based, in general terms.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The authorities on Norfolk Island and the Department of Territories were given advice by the Attorney-General's Department on 15 and 16 July as to the basis on which extradition could be granted of fugitives in Norfolk Island to New Zealand. That advice was that a request for the extradition of a fugitive to New Zealand would be dealt with pursuant to Part III of the Extradition (Commonwealth Countries) Act 1966. Part III of that Act permits a warrant of arrest issued in New Zealand to be executed in Australia or one of Australia's external territories such as Norfolk Island if that warrant is endorsed for execution by a Magistrate in Australia or one of Australia's external territories. On 16 July 1985 three persons from the yacht Ouvea were detained on Norfolk Island for questioning pursuant to section 9 of the Police Offences Ordinance on suspicion of having committed an offence of having explosives in possession. Police investigations revealed that there were no explosives on board and the persons were then released. Close liaison was maintained at all relevant times with the New Zealand authorities.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 11 February 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister for Health received a copy of a submission to the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations from the National Council of Health Organisations in relation to Nursing Manpower Planning; if so are any officers from the Minister's Department part of an Inter-Departmental Committee formed to report on the submission.
(2) What other action is being taken in relation to the submission.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. My Department is not represented on the interdepartmental committee.
(2) My Department has contributed to a co-ordinated response being made on behalf of the Government by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations.

Action is already proceeding on a number of the issues raised in the submission through the Commonwealth/State Nursing Labourforce Sub Committee and the National Nursing Consultative Committee, the latter of which includes representation from the National Council of Health Organisations.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, upon notice, on 12 February 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many statutory authorities currently exist under the auspices of the Minister's Department.
(2) What are the names of these authorities.
(3) What appeal mechanisms, if any, exist for the general public to lodge a complaint against these authorities.

(4) If it is proved that any member of staff of any of these authorities is guilty of incompetence, what action, if any, could be taken by a member of the public to sue the authority for compensation; if it is not possible to sue the authority, why is that the case.

(5) How many cases concerning these authorities are currently before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, and what is the delay at present between the listing of a case and its hearing before the Tribunal.
(6) If any statutory authority under the Minister's Department cannot be sued, will the Minister consider amending the relevant legislation to make this possible.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) Australia Council, Australian Film and Television School, Australian Film Commission, Australian Heritage Commission, Australian National Gallery, Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service, Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, National Library of Australia, National Museum of Australia, Supervising Scientist for the Alligator Rivers Region.

(3) The Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act and the Ombudsman Act 1976 apply to all statutory bodies for which the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment is responsible. All are subject to Federal and State Courts jurisdiction and the Freedom of Information Act 1982. In addition the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority and the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service are subject to review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

(4) The Attorney-General's Department has advised that unless an authority is statutorily protected, it is liable for the torts of its servants committed in the course of their duty. Where employees, acting in the course of their duty are incompetent and, as a consequence, loss is suffered by a member of the public, it will commonly be found that the act or omission which was seen as incompetent was also tortious. For example, incompetent driving would probably be tortious. In the absence of a denial of liability the negligent giving of erroneous advice is tortious where the advice is given by a person having a duty of care to one who suffers foreseeable damage as a result of reasonably relying on the advice. Many other forms of incompetence would also be tortious, but each case would need to be considered on its own facts.

In addition, the following statutory authorities are bodies corporate with perpetual succession and a common seal and ``may sue or be sued'' in their corporate names, pursuant to the provision indicated below:
Australia Council-Section 8 Australia Council Act 1975
Australian Film and Television School-Section 4 Australian Film and Television School Act 1973
Australian Film Commission-Section 4 Australian Film Commission Act 1975
Australian National Gallery-Section 4 National Gallery Act 1975
Director, Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service-Section 15 National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975
Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority- Section 9 Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act 1975
Australian Heritage Commission-Section 11 Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975
National Library of Australia-Section 5 National Library Act 1960
National Museum of Australia-Section 4 National Museum of Australia Act 1980
None of the authorities listed in answer to part (1) of this question is statutorily protected against general liability in tort.
(5) 4. The Administrative Appeals Tribunal has advised that there is a delay of approximately 6 weeks between the listing of a case and its hearing.
(6) Not applicable.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 13 February 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Will the Attorney-General investigate commitments made on radio 2CN between 8.45 a.m. and 9 a.m. on 12 February 1986, to determine whether Mr W. Mandle's comments or comments of telephone callers to the program at that time, were in contempt of court, especially those comments which related to Mr Justice Murphy and advise on the outcome of the investigation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: I have taken advice from the Director of Public Prosecutions who has advised that in so far as the comments relate to Commonwealth prosecutions there has not been a contempt of court. The Director does not express an opinion of the comments relating to the other persons referred to in the broadcast as they are not matters of Commonwealth concern.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 19 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: What steps have been taken by the Government to initiate prosecutions arising from the conclusions or recommendations contained in the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts report number 236 entitled `Medical Fraud and overservicing'-Pathology.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Following receipt of the Public Accounts Committee report, I directed my Department to review the current pathology arrangements with a view to advising me on options for revised arrangements which would address the identified problems. As a result of that review, the Government has announced that changes are to be made to the current pathology arrangements, and legislation to give effect to the changes was introduced into Parliament on 8 May 1986. The legislation is designed to rationalise the present administrative arrangements concerning pathology and to introduce new initiatives to curb abuses of the present system.

In the circumstances no prosecutions have been initiated based on the adoption of the conclusions or recommendations of the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts Report No. 236 on pathology. However, the Health Insurance Commission has referred three investigations to the Australian Federal Police for further investigations with a view to prosecution. The matters which have been referred to the Australian Federal Police were the subject of investigation by the Commission before the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts issued its report in August 1985.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Jurors: Disclosure of Information About Deliberations

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 5 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has any consideration been given by the Australian Government to implement the recommendation of the New South Wales Law Reform Commission that new laws should be introduced to make it an offence for jurors to receive payment for disclosing information about their deliberations, in the judicial areas under its authority.
(2) How widespread has been the suspected selling by jurors of their deliberations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The question whether it should be made an offence for a juror to receive payment for disclosing information about jury deliberations is only part of the broader issue as to whether there should be a prohibition on jurors' disclosures generally. The New South Wales Law Reform Commission in its Discussion Paper on `The Jury in a Criminal Trial' has tentatively proposed that there should be some restriction on disclosure by jurors of jury deliberations and that publication of such disclosures should be an offence with certain limited exceptions. The Commission has alternatively suggested that it may be necessary only to prohibit paying or offering to pay a juror for his or her ``story''.

The Australian Law Reform Commission in its Discussion Paper on `Contempt and the Media' has provisionally proposed that it be an offence for any person to solicit, harass or seek to induce a juror to disclose details or jury room deliberations of for any juror to solicit publication of jury deliberations for the principal purpose of financial gain. Both the New South Wales Law Reform Commission and the Australian Law Reform Commission have invited public comment on issues arising out of their respective Discussion Papers before making any final recommendations. The Government will be giving careful consideration to the final recommendations of these Commissions when they become available.
(2) Neither my Department nor myself has any specific knowledge or information in respect of jurors selling details of jury room deliberations.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Isolated Communities: Funding of Child Care Centres

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Community Services, upon notice, on 29 April 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Can the Minister for Community Services report on arrangements that the Department of Community Services is making to accommodate the funding problems of child care centres in isolated communities, where income levels and cost of living combine to make the new fee system difficult to implement on the same basis as in more populated regions.
(2) Will the Minister protect the needs of parents and children in remote areas.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am aware of the problems faced by communities in isolated areas. In order to better understand these problems my department is compiling information on the costs associated with operating child care centres in various locations. I have given an assurance that the difficulties of services in remote areas will be taken into account.

(2) Yes. I gave an assurance in a press statement issued in December last year that the difficulties of services in remote areas would be taken into account and that the needs of parents and children in these areas would be protected.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morris Sen J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 7 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What role does the Government believe methadone treatment programs have to play in the Drug Offensive.
(2) What action is the Government taking to increase funds for such programs.
(3) What action is the Government taking to encourage the expansion of such programs by State authorities.

(4) What action can be taken to ensure reliable supplies of methadone so that the expansion of methadone treatment programs can be encouraged, in view of recent severe shortages of methadone in Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The role of methadone programs in the National Campaign Against Drug Abuse is fully explained in the ``Guidelines for the use of methadone in the treatment of opiate dependence'' issued following the Special Premiers' Conference on Drugs on 2 April 1985. A copy of the guidelines has been provided to the honourable senator and a number of copies have been placed in the Parliamentary Library.
(2) In 1985-86 an amount of $1,809,592 was approved, by the States/Territories and the Commonwealth governments, under the NCADA 50:50 cost-shared programs, for methadone programs.

This amount has been increased by 48% to $2,676,814 in the 1986-87 proposed State/Territory and Commonwealth 50:50 cost-shared programs approved by the Ministerial Council on Drug Strategy held in Sydney on 2 May 1986.

(3) Under the NCADA cost-shared program, primary responsibility for determining funding priorities rests with the States and Territories, although proposed programs require approval by the Commonwealth. It can be seen by the increase in funding by 48% from 1985-86 to 1986-87 that the States and Territories have responded to the community's demands for increased methadone programs.
(4) There are no shortages of methadone to supply patients on the various methadone programs.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 14 February 1986 (Hansard, page 384), Senator Walters asked me as the Minister representing the Attorney-General the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Can the Minister representing the Attorney-General name the active members of the Human Rights Commission? Are there any inactive members and, if so, why?
The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Human Rights Commission currently consists of the Chairman, Dame Roma Mitchell, D.B.E., who is a part-time member, the Deputy Chairman, Mr Peter Bailey, O.B.E., who is a full-time member, and 5 other members who are part-time members. These other members are Professor Manuel Aroney, O.B.E., Mr Marcus Einfeld, Q.C., Mrs Norma Ford, Mrs Eva Geia and Ms Elizabeth Hastings. Professor Peter Boyce, who was also a part-time member at the time of Senator Walters' question, has since resigned his appointment.
All of the present members of the Commission participate in the work of the Commission. There are no ``inactive'' members of the Commission.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 30 April 1986 (Hansard, page 2082), Senator Elstob asked me a question, without notice, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry in the Senate. Senator Elstob's queries were based on an article in the Australian on 23 April 1986 and he asked:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware that Italy's top millers were reported to have been critical of the level of contamination in the Australian wool clip, and to have called for a dramatic improvement in the classing standards for the clip?
(2) Does the Minister accept these allegations of excessive contamination?
(3) Does the Minister believe they will adversely affect the export performance of the industry?
(4) What action will the Minister consider taking in this regard?
(5) Is the Minister satisfied with the classing standards administered by the Australian Wool Board?
The Minister for Primary Industry has supplied me with the following additional information:
(1) Yes, I am aware of the article which appeared in the Australian on 23 April 1986.

(2) Quantification of the level of contamination in the Australian wool clip is extremely difficult. The objective of the Australian Wool Corporation (AWC) is to see it minimised and if possible completely eliminated.

On the one hand, clip preparation and avoidance of contamination by the large majority of growers is good. But the frequent and widespread publicity by the AWC, brokers, press, etc seems to have little effect in reducing the relatively small incidence of problems.

On the other hand, complaints from mills are few in number, but persistent. Most are well balanced and well justified, but one or two mills may use the technique, as was suggested in the initial response to this question, as a bargaining stance.

There is no question that a small quantity of contaminant, such as polypropylene twine, passing undetected through machinery processing wool, can give rise to costs of thousands of dollars. This can be in the form of mending costs to the final fabric, or losses if the material has to be sold as a downgraded product. At times contaminants in wool can cause quite costly damage to processing machinery.

(3) Again this remains a matter of opinion. To the extent that contamination causes mills problems and gives rise to additional costs, the image and value of the product must suffer. Ultimately, such costs are borne by the grower in one form or another.
(4) There is a continuing program of action to seek to ensure that contamination will not adversely affect the export performance of the wool industry.

The ``Keep the Clip Clean'' Campaign was initiated by the AWC 18 months ago and since then over 300,000 pamphlets, posters and car stickers have been distributed to growers and classers. In addition, a video film ``Keep the Clip Clean'' has been widely shown and shed rubbish bins highlighting the problem have been distributed.

The AWC operates a trace-back system on complaints from mills and this information is presently being gathered from the overseas offices for analysis. Complaints are investigated by AWC staff wherever possible and, if confirmed, the errant grower and classer concerned are notified and warned of the potential danger to the industry and advice given to prevent a recurrence.

(5) From July, 1986, the classing standards will be those agreed by the whole industry, as embodied in the new Code of Practice for preparation of Australian wool. The Code sets the framework for better industry self-regulation than has been possible in the past. The AWC has arranged for a printing of 250,000 copies of the Code for distribution throughout the wool industry during June.
